Subject: KRR: somewhat related rave joke... kind of long,, enjoy
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hello there happy girls and boys, it's me, your brother Earthlyn again...

Well I am sitting at work right now, and all of a sudden I realized something,
there have not been rave related jokes in awhile. Well I've got something that could
somehow relate to us, and something which is kind of funny....


Ok, here is the situation: YOu've had the best weekend, you've gone to the
best party, you've met tons of people, the stuff that you got this weekend just 
ruled, and even was better than the first time you did it... But here is monday
again, and you go back to work. You walk into the building feeling very spiritual and happy, only to realize that people around you are dull, and boring....

Well here are some tips on how to keep the wackiness at your workspace and prolong the fine that you had during the weekend...

Enjoy

=)

Alik aka Earthlyn

LUV and PLURity to all of you...


    
 Put a chair facing a printer, sit there all day and tell people you're
waiting for your document.
     
 Arrive at a meeting late, say you're sorry, but you didn't have time for
lunch, and you're going to be nibbling during the meeting. During the 
meeting eat 5 entire raw potatoes.
     
 Insist that your e-mail address be
"zena_goddess_of_fire@companyname.com"
     
 Every time someone asks you to do something, ask them to sign a waiver.
    
 Every time someone asks you to do something, ask them if they want fries
with that.
     
Send email to yourself engaging yourself in an intelligent debate about
the direction of one of your company's products. Forward the mail to a 
co-worker and ask her to settle the disagreement.
     
Page yourself over the intercom. (Don't disguise your voice.)
     
Name all your pens and insist that meetings can't begin until they're all
     
present.
     
Come to work in your pajamas.
     
 Put a picture of your mother on your business card.
     
 Find out where your boss shops and buy exactly the same outfits. Always
wear them one day after your boss does. (This is especially effective if 
your boss is a different gender than you are.)
     
Make up nicknames for all your coworkers and refer to them only by these
names. "That's a good point Sparky."
    
 "No I'm sorry I'm going to have to disagree with you there, Chachi."
    
 Suggest that beer be put in the soda machine.
     
 Include a piece of your children's artwork as a cover page for all
reports
that you write. (If you don't have children, draw stick figures 
yourself.)
     
 Schedule meetings for 4:14 pm.
    
 Encourage your colleagues to join you in a little synchronized chair 
 dancing.
     
 Agree to organize the company Christmas party. Hold it at McDonald's
Playland. Charge everyone $15 each.
    
 Send email to the rest of the company telling them what you're doing.
For
example "If anyone needs me I'll be in the bathroom."
     
 No matter what anyone asks you, reply "Okay."
     
 Put your garbage can on your desk. Label it "IN."
    
 Plant a hedge around your cubicle.
     
 Grow mold in your coffee cup.
     
 Build models of the Seven Wonders of the World using empty soda cans.
     
 Put on your headphones on whenever the boss comes into the office. Talk
in
a loud voice. Remove your headphones when he or she leaves.
     
 When in conversation, no matter where you are in the office, mutter, "I
think my phone is ringing" and leave. Go get a coffee.
     
Determine how many cups of coffee is "too many."
     
 Develop an unnatural fear of staplers.
     
 Compose all your e-mail in rhyming couplets.
     
Install a set of buttons and lights in the arm of your chair. Talk into
your daytimer.
     
 "Hi-lite" your shoes. Tell people that you haven't lost your shoes since
you did this.
     
 Organize a carpool. Go to pick everyone up in a taxi.
     
 Email nude gifs (graphic image files) of yourself to your coworkers.
Tell
them you got them off the Internet.
     
 Hang mistletoe over your desk.
    
 Include a personal note on every email you send. "On a personal note,
I'm
feeling a bit tired and grumpy
today."
"On a personal note, I'm pleased to announce that I got my highest score 
ever on Tetris last night."
     
 Bring in dishes that you tried to cook but didn't turn out quite right
as
special treats for your co-workers.
     
 While sitting at your desk, soak your fingers in "Palmolive".
     
 Put up mosquito netting around your cubicle.
     
Decorate your office with pictures of Cindy Brady and Danny Partridge.
Try to pass them off as your children.
     
For a relaxing break, get away from it all with a mask and snorkel in the
fish tank. If no one notices, take out your snorkel and see how many you 
can catch in your mouth.
     
Send e-mail messages saying free pizza, free donuts etc... in the
lunchroom, when people complain that there was none... Just lean back, 
pat your stomach, and say, "Oh you've got to be faster than that."
     
 See how long it takes until the last person stops believing you. Then
start planting pizzas.
     
Put decaf in the coffeemaker for 3 weeks. Once everyone has gotten over
their caffeine addictions, switch to espresso.
     
When you go to a party at somebody's house, don't automatically assume
that the drinks are free. Ask, and ask often.

                Lunch Time Concert Series

          ...upon a Garden Chill
Illbient-Ambient-Downtempo Sound Artists and Collectives   
Thursdays, June 5, 12, 19, 26, 1997
12:30-1:30pm

Sound is manipulated to create beats and grooves in an unobtrusive aural 
environment-resulting in what has become popularly known as "chill out rooms" 
and "underground raves." Co-curated by William Linn of Blasthaus, a San 
Francisco-based gallery and performance space dedicated to the emerging genre 
of electronic and digital arts.

June 5:         New Dog Music/Dogon

June 12:        Mood Clinic, featuring Arjan and Danja Girl           

June 19:        SuperGroup/Charlie 

June 26:        Dark Horse

...Jungle DJ's in the Bay...

1 Stareyes:  Funkstep madness, wicked inna dance...

2 Flux:  Mad different flavas everytime out...Sets build till you just have to bust out...

3 Abstract:  Fuck the dark shit...Watch out!!!!  Massive RINSE OUT selections make me move...

4 Jason Mouse:  Trancers, watch the ride...Trippy sets that hit you where it counts...The future of the SF Jungle sound  (Main Room @ the Gathering anyone?)

5 UFO:  Pure junglists local hero...

6 Noel:  Veteran dj who saw the light...

7 Rinse:  Proper Hardstep Selector

8 Thad:  Too SCARY!!!!

9 Mudfoot:  Still tryin' to forget Alec Empire @ Paradise...

10  G.I.M.P. - Super Sounds Crew...Newstep, Funkstep....Jungle boogie!!!!!!!!!!!!


Keepin' It Real,

Crimedog McSpliff =)-~

There is another fantastic Jungle DJ who is pretty much on the down low...
and is better well known back east....  JOHNSIN.... I don't mean to keep
bringing this guy up, but I just wanted to.... because he's really
talented... there are a lot of talented DJs who just haven't put the
effort to get caught up in the MACHINE... :-)

For every 1 Dj that makes it there are 10 that are better and just don't
know the right people.. just like musicians...

Here are my favorite DJs... (5)

1. Dutch (I really like trance)
2. DJ DAN (Needs to explanation)
3. Cesar (Pronounced: say-zar... not SEE-ZER... I learned this little tid
bit from his Girlfriend who was at Mirasol supporting her extremely
talented DJ main squeeze... :-) I love his techno! So smooth and sharp. )
4. Apollo (Communique Minneapolis)
5. *too many to name*

Not that it's too related.. but my favorite non electronic music artists
are:

1) Sade 2) George Michael and 3) Simply Red and almost all 80s british
pop!... (Wham!)


see you in the 9th dimension,

Byroni

This bothers me, because there are a lot of good jungle djays in the bay..
But due to lame scene politics of the scene many are never heard here and
have to play in far away places to get any respect.. For instance.. Please
read the following message that was posted on MW-RAVES about my set at
Further when I had to fill in for Ed Rush, Trace, and Nico because they
missed their flight.

---->
im -still- ranting and raving about this mans set...
i try and explain it to ppl who didnt hear it...
but my words just dont seem to express it correctly...
i pity each and every one of you who missed it...  ;)
it changed me.
only on a few vary rare occasions have i felt like this.
especially from a dj set.
richie (stairway) and dieselboy (looking glass) are it.
but then johnsin (furthur) falls next in line.
johnsin?  whos johnsin?  that guy from massive?
yeah...
i trancended...  like the musik is sposed to make you do.
and then, i came back...  when he was all done...
a changed man...
the musik.  the people gathering and filling the tent.
the lighters.  the insane group screams.  and group hugs.
oh...  the group hugs!  yes!
hundreds of ppl in the main tent for johnsins dark stuff,
hundreds of ppl i dont know at all, dancing near +
with them, and feeling the bass make our hearts skip,
waiting for the breakdowns and the explosions,
and literally losing our shit when they hit,
freaking out, jumping up and down, running around crazy,
and on many occasions i found myself in the midst of super big group hugs
just as the bass would drop or the shit would get intense...  there was
-unity- and -love- and -resepct- on the floor that night.  all to a sound
track of dark step and tech step jungle...  it aint evil...  its
driving...  a force that makes you move...  not only physically...  but
mentally and emotionally, as well...

thanks johnsin!

all yall --- get on the 'bandwagon'

*hugs.n.breakbeats*
JAWSH!
east.side.crack...
--->

My set is being compared to Richie Fucking Hawtin and Dieselboy, and the
sad fact is, I can hardly get a gig in the Bay area because of the BASS
Crew monopoly and over all politics in the scene.. (as with Thad, the Bass
Crew doesn't like me.. but I hear about it endlessly since my GF is one of
the founders I never stop hearing about it.. GOd kill me and end the
suffering now..

I have much respect for Rinse.. He is a new kid that can mix better then
everyone on this great top ten you have posted.  But I am sad to say you
are hyping a lot of people that just dent the scene and are very oblivious
of it in many ways.  Phantom 45 of Chicago is America's number one DJ of
Drum n Bass.  Hands Down.. No arguement..I quote stareyes when we spun a
club together in Milwaukee last week, "Shit, Brian is better then most UK
DJ's" Yet most of these kids you listed besides Vivian Stareyes (who is
down wit the scene globaly and not just locally) had never heard of
Phantom.. And are really not that interested in bringing him out.. I wonder
why.. It might shed some light on who's really who in the jungle scene.

Look farther then your bay area.. and perhaps look a little deeper with
what you are offered.  A healthy scene is one that has a lot of new people
spinning within it.. NOt the same people for the last 3 years..

Johnsin
Massive Magazine.
SFJUNGLE.COM

=====         -----------------------------          ...................>

remember the underground is massive...

Johnsin sez:
>read the following message that was posted on MW-RAVES about my set at
>Further when I had to fill in for Ed Rush, Trace, and Nico because they
>missed their flight.
<snip>

Ok. I had to comment on this, 'cause I was there. My head was in blissful
union with a bass cabinet for a fucking *intense* forty-five minutes under
the aegis of one Johnsin. It was, straight-up, religious. I have never
percieved/recieved music in this manner; of such magnitude. Techstep. In
the house. Kids going ballistic. Rolling  sub-bass everywhere, handed down
with ferocious mixing. The surrounding blast radius of the soundsystem was,
in fact,  drenched in the most driving and energetic drum n' bass I have
ever heard. Simply awesome. And the other 200 or so kids did, in fact,
think so too...

Much respect. That was one of *those* moments. And I didn't happen to be
under any other influences than music at that particular moment...  Get his
tape people.

-Joshua

At 9:47 AM -0700 6/4/97, Shawn Bryant wrote:
>...Jungle DJ's in the Bay...
>
>1 Stareyes:  Funkstep madness, wicked inna dance...
Correction: Vivian spins Jump up drum n' bass.  Heavy Hip Hop influence...
with dreadbass lines.

>2 Flux:  Mad different flavas everytime out...Sets build till you just
>have to bust out...

mixtape names.

>3 Abstract:  Fuck the dark shit...Watch out!!!!  Massive RINSE OUT
>selections make me move...
Correction: At one point he was spin "Amen" hardstep.  But produces
darkshit and some Amen Hardstep.. Last track I heard he produced was on the
darktip.

>4 Jason Mouse:  Trancers, watch the ride...Trippy sets that hit you where
>it counts...The future of the SF Jungle sound  (Main Room @ the Gathering
>anyone?)
Correction: He isn't even from SF, longtime East Coaster.. Not bringing the
future of the SF sound.. He is bringing his own sound..

>5 UFO:  Pure junglists local hero...
Correction: Home town hero, Yes.. Otherwise he mostly spins the same as
Abstract.. "Amen"ed hardstep.

>6 Noel:  Veteran dj who saw the light...
Correction:  Good mixer, but spins the exact same stuff as all Phunkitech
djays.  "Amen" hardstep.

>7 Rinse:  Proper Hardstep Selector
Correction:  Sean spins Techstep and Darkstep Andy C style on his tapes,
but out he normally plays Jump Up.

>8 Thad:  Too SCARY!!!!
Correction:  Thad plays Techstep, its not scary, its just not San Fran.

>9 Mudfoot:  Still tryin' to forget Alec Empire @ Paradise...
Correction: RaggeeMeister..

>10  G.I.M.P. - Super Sounds Crew...Newstep, Funkstep....Jungle
>boogie!!!!!!!!!!!!
Correction; WHO THE FUCK IS GIMP!!
>
>Keepin' It Real,
>

Hey everyone,

Just got a fax in from The Mining Company, a new site located in
Florida. 

They state: " Guides such as Hyperreal (http://hyperreal.com) have their
place on the web as a stockhold of rave-culture information, but as the
years have passed, the links have become outdated, broken, or
inconsistent. This is where we come in. We present the latest
information for those new and old to the rave culture, as well as links
to other sites that present techno related subjects as they are
happening. We all know this is a fast paced culture that thrives on
change, and we are here to meet the challenge."

Decide for yourself:  http://ravehousetech.miningco.com

later...

Jonas

Hi!  ]=)

 The only dance club of note (if that is what you are seeking) is the 
Blue Lagoon just down the street from the Catalyst. They usually have 
house and/or techno going most nights. Best to call and see what is up 
with 'em.

 You can try going to Capricorn Records or Ion Excange for more local info.

 Hope this helps!

From: John Drefahl <johnsin@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Jungle isn't about Peace Love and Unity.. its about dealing with everyday
life, that is why jungle is not really "in" the rave scene in anyway..
Jungle has its roots in the rave scene but the feeling and over all
attitude in Jungle is completely opposite then the rave scene.  The rave
scene wants to escape, the jungle scene wants to cope.. thats the best way
I can describe it.  You can see this in the drug usage.  Within the jungle
scene using drugs other then cess is very looked down upon.. I can't really
explain it, you just have to live it.

Jungle has a high testostorone level.. ;)

heheh
thats all I can say.. You really got to know your shit, or you get cut down.

Johnsin

Anawayz,
I just have to add my own comments to the barrage of warmth 2 reviews,
sorry it's a bit l8... (Man, I've had a busy week so far!)  
A few things:

Rob, your opening live stuff was COOL!  It took me on a great little
mind-journey in the chill-room!  Along with the KIIILLER visuals (awesome 
work Ran and folx!), I tripped out naturally for about 2 hours before I
knew what happened!!  

Micron, that's the first time I've ever been able to catch your set, and
it ROCKED!  'Veray naahce...'

So many SFRavers there!!  My God!  So cool to see more folx I hadn't 
met yet!  :)  (There are so many, but I'm still terrible with remembering
names, tho...) Thanx Orson, for the sweet new laminate! You're too
cool...;)  
I wish I hadn't needed 2 go so early, but we had a TON of stuff 2 get  
done Sunday, so we *had* to truck on back to Davis a little bit after the
fuzz-oids arrived.  Would've *loved* to stick around, though; that
parachute-fan-trick over the folks crashed out in the chill-room looked
sooo phun!  :)

Well, I too will be heading back to the southern end of this bad-ass state
in just a few short weeks, so I just wanted to thank all of you for
leaving me with so many of those wonderful warm feelings of love, openness
and connectedness that this fantastic SF community so freely shares
together.  THANKS!!! =)

Hugz 2u all!

That's just the first half of sites they host beginning with the letter A.

Their mission statement of sorts:

>We're launching a revolutionary new Internet service where hundreds of
>real, live Guides are on a mission to take back the Net! And not a
>moment too soon.
>
>This is the first network of people-powered, special-interest Web sites
>with totally consistent look, feel, and function. The Mining Company's
>Guides lead sites on just about every topic imaginable, which you can
>see from our site map.

Interesting that rave culture is a big enough blip to warrant a guide on
their site, but it doesn't appear that they're looking at it from the
inside.

At 03:46 PM 6/4/97 -0700, you wrote:
>Jungle isn't about Peace Love and Unity.. its about dealing with everyday
>life, that is why jungle is not really "in" the rave scene in anyway..
>Jungle has its roots in the rave scene but the feeling and over all
>attitude in Jungle is completely opposite then the rave scene.  The rave
>scene wants to escape, the jungle scene wants to cope.. thats the best way
>I can describe it.  You can see this in the drug usage.  Within the jungle
>scene using drugs other then cess is very looked down upon.. I can't really
>explain it, you just have to live it.
>
>Jungle has a high testostorone level.. ;)
>
>heheh
>thats all I can say.. You really got to know your shit, or you get cut down.
>
>Johnsin

        I know what you're saying, but it's not like that for every jungle
DJ. It's your particular style. Some jungle is very mellow, and jazzstep and
intelligent jungle don't really give me this feeling you describe as much as
hardstep and other types do. I like to spin the really hip-hoppy ghettoy
stuff and most of my friends here who listen to trance don't really like it.
But they do like other jungle, and some of it does fit into the rave scene.

        but yes, it does have a higher testostorone level than most trance...

It seems to me that some of the ferocity in the *jungle scene* that has come to light today has
been on a very individual level.  John was talking about the evil politics inside the scene, and I have no doubts about that truth.  Cuz I mean, C.R.E.A.M. rite?  But I think that a lot of what was said could have been refrazed in a much more positive light.  None of this YOURE WRONG IM RIGHT bizness.  Every last junglist ive played with has been cool on the up and up.  It just seems like every other scene, youre gonna have your Grouch right? Thats just my take on it.  You got cool cool heads and youve got badseeds.

Peace
<meeks>

sorry, this made me cackle uncontrollably while i "work" in the
air-conditioned splendour of a cubicled office building in Bangalore India,
the quiet sari-clad women and button-up-shirt men in the cubes nearby are
shooting strange glances at me, wondering why i'm laughing like this while
staring at my screen. ah, the forbidden pleasures of e-mail!  damn, i could
swear this funky tale happened to me last time i took public transpo in
bangalore's teeming streets...

------- Forwarded Message
To: sjcam@pb.net
Cc: funky-music@MIT.EDU, Elise@btinternet.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Subject: Now that's funky!!!


I think it's fair to say that we've all had our fair share of
unsavoury public transport experiences.

In my teenage days taking the last Glen Waverley train home I
witnessed some acts of misbehaviour that'd straighten your pubes.
One time a pair of drunken young louts couldn't contain their need to
urinate so while one guy held the automatic door open with his foot
the other pissed out of the speeding train.

This story does not end predictably with the urinator having his cock
slammed shut in the fast closing automatic doors;  his true buddy
(and I can't think of a better test of friendship) did manage to keep
the guillotine edged doors from his susceptible penis by holding back
that door handle with his extended leg.

In this instance I suppose you'd have to say that the sting to this
little outer suburban anecdote is that as our protagonist relieved
his bursting bladder with an extended pee his steady stream was
directed by the train's propulsion and the natural laws of physics to
reenter the cabin via the open slide windows that had hitherto been
refreshing the tired travellers on this warm summer night.

What this meant is that half a dozen unsuspecting commuters were
suddenly being rained on and it didn't take too long for them to
determine that the at first welcomed cool splash of invigorating
liquid was in fact the urine of a drunken lout and that there was no
end in sight of this impressive curved stream he was remorselessly
pumping out by the luke warm litre.

Now if that torrid tale of true travel was a tad repulsive imagine my
perverse fascination with the following true life experience from
just last week recounted to me by my friend and first hand witness
Clarissa.
As was her normal routine Clarissa was on her way home from work on a
crowded peak hour tram.  She was lucky enough to secure a seat and
proceeded to read a book and ignore the distasteful world around her,
as you do.

A short while into her journey Clarissa was distracted from her
reading by an especially repugnant odour.  A mixture of stale vomit,
week old dried urine, fermented body odour and unformed stool
samples, this was pretty much the stink combo platter.

The offending odour was permeating from a silver bearded dread-locked
wino who was cut a clear path through the busy tram as commuters bent
themselves into pretzel shapes to avoid bodily contact with the
walking shitbag.  Every person on that tram was aware of this
repugnant man and not even the feral tram conductor was willing to
approach the sweaty bum to ask for his fare.

Now as everyone was slamming their noses into their own armpits to
avoid the rank stench of this stumbling drunkard one solitary lady
was oblivious to the wretched goings on about her.

This young bussinesswoman was feeling the strain of an arduous days
work in the corporate office and had been swayed into a blissful
state of somnambulant day dreamage by the rhythmic motion of the slow
moving tram.
Nodding peacefully this unsuspecting sleeping beauty evidenced her
proper upbringing by keeping her legs crossed and her hands clasped
and if it weren't for her angelic eyes being closed you'd never know
she was away in her own little world.

Our smelly wino happened to be hovering above this sleeping sweetie
when he was taken by a deep and resonant coughing fit which caused
his aged and blackened emphsyemic smoker's lungs to contract and
squeeze out what can only be described as a monumental thick
globulous ball of phlegm, a classic gorbie, it was a chunk of gooey
green lung matter an Ethiopian family could live off for a month.

As this stinking walking street refuse hocked up this gigantic gorbie
the entire tram reeled in horror and one gentleman even extended his
monogrammed handkerchief willing to sacrifice it to this fountain of
sickening splutter for the greater good.

Alas the offer came too late and that memorable green golf ball of
phlegm could not be contained.  Like a freed parrot this gorbie flew
from the scabbed lips of its drunken originator bypassing the
coagulated drool of the flea ridden beard and spun in the air as if
in slow motion end-over-end like a Martian high diver as the
assembled tram travellers watched repulsed, but spell-bound by the
sailing hunk of disgarded inner waste which was truly so loathsome as
to not even belong in the body of this human septic tank.

There was a jaw dropping eerie silence as that gorbie finally came to
rest viewed by more people than the entire audience of Water Rats.
It landed with an audible slap, but by the very nature of its
grotesque constituent elements it stuck heartily to the
surface.....the surface of the sleeping businesswoman's right hand!

Clarissa was mortified, but surpressed her natural desire to throw up
because she was unselfishly more worried about the dozing lady.  When
she finally woke up and spotted that green hunk of wino mucus resting
on the back of her hand there was a good chance she might just have a
heart attack and die.

This however was not the case.  When the tram pulled up promptly at
the next set of traffic lights the sudden halting of it's soothing
motion awoke our snoozing heroine who politely ran her tongue over
her lips before opening her tired eyes.  The first thing she saw when
she opened those bashful eyes was the gargantuan gorbie and she was
visibly startled.

But then as every person ,except the stinking bum lurching above her,
had their eyes glued sympathetically to this unfortunate innocent she
sheepishly yet casually raised her hand to her mouth and licked off
and then swallowed the entire green spongy mass of phlegm mistakenly
assuming that it had trickled from her own divine lips as she slept.

At this point the tram's silence turned to boisterous uproar and
Clarissa just made it off the tram at the next unscheduled stop in
time to vomit at the base of a small flowering tree.

Delivery Priority:         Normal
Delivery Report:           Basic

------- End of Forwarded Message

So I was reading Inter@Active Week, an industry trade mag, and found out
that "the Mining Company" (the company that did that web site that was 
touted as the "new Hyperreal") is a new commercial web directory project
started by an ex-exec from Prodigy (the online service, not the band).

The are advertising supported, and are basically trying to become a player
in the navigation/search engine industry -- they're going after the likes
of Yahoo!...

Laura

In a message dated 6/4/97 11:47:41 PM, you wrote:

<<Jungle isn't about Peace Love and Unity.. its about dealing with everyday

life, that is why jungle is not really "in" the rave scene in anyway..

Jungle has its roots in the rave scene but the feeling and over all

attitude in Jungle is completely opposite then the rave scene.  The rave

scene wants to escape, the jungle scene wants to cope.. thats the best way

I can describe it.  You can see this in the drug usage.  Within the jungle

scene using drugs other then cess is very looked down upon.. I can't really

explain it, you just have to live it.



Jungle has a high testostorone level.. ;)

thats all I can say.. You really got to know your shit, or you get cut down.

something different for sure. then he played some chicago tracks that i
like. in particular on of the new guidance records.  wish i could have
stayed,  when i left there was a fat line.

Subject: "Deans Mother Goose"

   Old Mother Hubbard
Went to the cupboard,
To feTHC her poor dog a bone;
But when she came there
The cupboard was bare
And so the poor dog had none.
   She went to the baker's
To buy him some bread;
But when she came back
The poor dog was dead.
   She went to the undertaker's
To buy him a coffin;
But when she came back 
The poor dog was laughing.
   She took a clean dish
To get him some tripe;
But when she came back
He was smoking a pipe.
   She went to the alehouse
To get him some beer;
But when she came back
The dog was in good cheer.
   She went to the tavern
For wine white and red;
But when she came back
The dog stood on his head.
   She went to the fruiterer's
To buy him some fruit;
But when she came back
He was playing the flute.
   She went to the tailors
To buy him a coat;
But when she came back
He was riding a goat.
   She went to the hatter's
To buy him a hat; 
But when she came back
He was feeding the cat.
   She went to the barber's
To buy him a wig;
But when she came back
He was dancing a jig.
   She went to the cobbler's
To buy him some shoes;
But when she came back
He was reading the newes.
   She went to the seamstress
To buy him some linen;
But when she came back
The dog was a-spinnin'.
   She went to the hosier's
To buy him some hose;
But when she came back
He was dressed in his clothes.
   The dame made a curtsey
The dog made a bow;
The dame said, "Your servent,"
The dog said, "Bow-wow!"

                                  MAMMAS BITHC Inc.

Here's a challenge for you all!  There's a great thread going around 
NYC-Raves right now on "blasts from the pasts" - memories of early 
parties!  So come on, SFR, let's get nostalgic :)

PS Yes, I subbed to NYC to check on the scene there   - the list is very low 
traffic, and so far a lot of it is advertisements :(  I guess SFR is one 
of a kind, huh??

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Thu, 5 Jun 1997 09:46:18 -0400
From: jami losurdo <jl@illusionfusion.com>
To: nyc-raves <nyc-raves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: (nyc) BLASTS FROM THE PAST

ok, these are a couple of early memories from way before i was even 
"going out", but i guess i was just testing the waters.

I'd been living in NYC less than a week (freshman year of college)
It was September 6th, 1992, Memorial Day Weekend.  And I picked up a 
flyer for Alan Sanctuary's PRIMAL party @ Chase Bar on 3rd Ave.  Now 
it's called Bar None, I believe.  The dj's were to my recollection, 
Denard, Mr. Kleen, and some others.  It was a pre-Wigstock party too.  
I think it was like $4 w/ a flyer for 2 people.  I went with some 
other NYU kids who were new to New York, and we really didnt' know 
what to expect.  We paid our money at the door, and the music was in 
the back room.  I think we arrived around 11pm or so?  Anyway, I 
didn't know the difference between techno, trance, breaks, house, 
whatever, I just remember the music was VERY FAST & VERY LOUD! There 
were these scantilly clad dancers on stages, and everyone seemed to 
have whistles.  I remember a bunch of small psychadelic visual screens 
set up too.  There was supposed to be a smart bar, but the room that 
it was in was decorated in tons of day-glow paint, with a bunch of 
people just sitting around drinking and smoking weed.
I remember it was so hot in there it was almost unbareable!  We danced 
for ahwile,and then somone brought me a club-soda from the bar up 
front.  Everyone was very colorfully dressed and very friendly but i 
really didn't make any new friends, I guess because I was a little 
scared.(small town girl on her 1st big night out in nyc)
When we left around 4am the front room was packed with people watching 
b&w porno movies. We headed back to our dorm, not quite sure of what 
we had just came from.  On our way out we picked up flyers for NASA, 
Communion, and maybe Disco 2000?
Anyway, when i finally got to bed at like 5am, I slept for like 15 
hours and when I woke up I had a fever of 104, double strep throat 
infection, double sinus infection, was completely dehydrated, and had 
mono.  I was really sick for like 2 months and i lost like 
15-20lbs!!!!  I had no idea what happened.  I had never been that sick 
b4!  I'm still convinced to this day, I somehow took a drug 
unknowingly at the party and totally put my system out of whack.

But stupid & young as i was, even though sick as a dog, I went to NASA 
the following Friday.  I still have the flyer it's a pink triangle and 
it folds out so you can read the dj's/times/etc...  I'll have to look 
at it to tell you who spun, but I think it was Mr. Kleen, Moby, and 
maybe Jason Jinx.  That place was even stranger than Primal.  Lot's 
more people.  We kind of wondered around for a few hours, danced a 
little,and went home really early.  I remember I did have a lot of 
fun, even though I was way too sick to be out at a club.  I remember 
thinking people danced really weird.  And the lights were blinding 
enough to make my eyes water.

ok. those are my earliest "rave" stories.

jami

Golly,

Maybe you should start up a list for people who are just in the know... I
always thought they were saying 'sinse' on those Cypress Hill records
(which would be short for sinsemilla), but I guess I'm wrong again.  Maybe
someday I'll get tough and mean like those jungle DJ's I like...

;)

I'm honestly confused how Jungle could be Massive if the scene is as
combative as you say.  I'd rather sort people out by who I like and who
I don't, who I respect and who I don't, and DJ's out by which one's make
me groove and which ones don't.  By the way, from what I've seen of the
jungle scene, it's diverse, positive, and about getting away from the
generic dance identity and some of the cliches it's fostered.  I'd like
to see this list and scene more supportive of jungle in general.  The only
part of the jungle scene that I've seen be competitive is the DJs who are
trying their asses off getting jungle into 'other' parties in general.
We've seen some progress from Stareyes, ReAch, Science, Siphon, Thad,
Mudfoot, Radon, Gamecat, and a slew of  others who have been doing a kick
ass job of expanding the scene.  Not coincedentally, they all maintain a
lot of connection outside of the form of music they choose to play.

Let's keep it Unified. We can't afford the various aspects of our scene
competing over venues, permits, crowds, etc.  We need to exercise our
sense of unity.  I've heard advocates of Jungle say that it's the
TRUE underground, or the next wave or whatever... well there's
Chemical Brothers and Underworld style issues in Jungleville as
well... Jungle is in the same trouble the rest of the scene is...
Bjork does jungle, and so does David Bowie.  If we present together as
family, we have strength, but as segregated scenes, we have only temporary
victories and soon, a degree of animosity and possesiveness between each
other.

Saying which Jungle DJs are the ones to definitely take notice of is kinda
unfair... seeing as the D&B/Jungle scene has grown vast enough to cover a
good deal of territory in taste, skills and style. It's gone past skills
now, to a point of individual taste (i.e. an art subject to taste as
opposed to a science subject to analysis).

See You All At the Beats Party Saturday...
I'll be there going off to my favorite music: diverse melting pot o'love
And my favorite DJs: People who love to spin the records they have
gathered for us, in the best way they know how.

Peace,
AndyW

E>PS Yes, I subbed to NYC to check on the scene there   - the list is very low 
E>traffic, and so far a lot of it is advertisements :(  I guess SFR is one 
E>of a kind, huh??

---
Well, here's my take on the characteristics of 3 RR Mailing Lists.
Netiquette: Please note your CC list when replying...
---

Well, Southern Cal Raves is very high traffic. A good handful of posts
every one or two hours at high tide. Right now its primarily NRR posts.
Few Advertisements lately. Too many random posts for my tastes. Seems a
lot more decentralized from a core group of posters than when I initialy
joined. The seemingly SCR Roll Calling phenomenon is annoying.

Arizona Raves is very low traffic, very intimate, a good handful of
messages per day, much like how SCR was 6 months ago. NRR Forwards
currently okay and welcome. Someone subbed AZR to a joke mailing list =)
Fun to the a lister on. Very welcoming.

San Francisco Raves (IMO) is very high traffic. Large traffic on reviews
of recent events. Primarily RR posts with various NRR forwards. Lots of
vibe. SFR tends to promote use of aliases and ASCII-graphics sig files.

Yes, I sub to three RR lists =) 
...Not to mention about 5 other lists

PLUR! =)
Laurence

Date: Thu, 5 Jun 1997 16:38:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Nancy's Blast from the Past
To: bassbabies <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706051635.A19656-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Inklings of the Future...
Los Angeles, late '89.  I'm a hip-hop mama at the time, going to 
mainstream clubs wearing spandex (oh yes).  One weekend we are hanging 
out at an apartment near USC and someone there says they know of a 
"party" nearby.  We drive to a pretty abandoned area of downtown, walk 
down alleyways littered with winos until we come to a big, dark building 
resonating with pulsating beats.  We get onto one of those platform-only 
elevators and go up a few stories, and it all seems pretty sketchy to 
me.  There to greet us is someone who says it costs $10 to get in.  We 
all laugh and offer $10 for the five of us, which he agrees to.  

Inside is a small crowd, about a hundred people.  Very early minimal 
techno is being spun.  Very early minimal single fractals are projected 
onto the walls.  It is dark.  I ask someone where the keg is, and they 
look at me strangely and say "there won't be any alcohol here."  I think, 
"$10 and no alcohol?  What a gip!!"  But people are friendly and we stay 
and dance for an hour or two, before heading back to get stoned and pass 
out.  

I forget all about this night as just another random weekend night, until
I'm seduced into the rave scene years later, and suddenly realize that I 
must have been at one of the very first raves in this country!

early memories for me were Mr. Floppys, the stone the first recycle
with Kyle and laurie. The second New years gathering ever way back in
90,91 not sure. A rave called sharon, getdown parties, old comunity
parties before malachie got hurt. Fool Moon Elmo line and parties.
Universal groove. Pull my finger, The First Funky TeKno at the
concourse. And my all time favorite who can forget the parties at 16
and harrison Jimmy and wallys place!!!

Love,
Macadio  BTW there are a lot more parties just cant remember

> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
> Date: Thu, 5 Jun 1997 09:46:18 -0400
> From: jami losurdo <jl@illusionfusion.com>
> To: nyc-raves <nyc-raves@hyperreal.com>
> Subject: Re: (nyc) BLASTS FROM THE PAST
> 
> ok, these are a couple of early memories from way before i was even 
> "going out", but i guess i was just testing the waters.
> 
> I'd been living in NYC less than a week (freshman year of college)
> It was September 6th, 1992, Memorial Day Weekend.  And I picked up a 
> flyer for Alan Sanctuary's PRIMAL party @ Chase Bar on 3rd Ave.  Now 
> it's called Bar None, I believe.  The dj's were to my recollection, 
> Denard, Mr. Kleen, and some others.  It was a pre-Wigstock party
too.  
> I think it was like $4 w/ a flyer for 2 people.  I went with some 
> other NYU kids who were new to New York, and we really didnt' know 
> what to expect.  We paid our money at the door, and the music was in 
> the back room.  I think we arrived around 11pm or so?  Anyway, I 
> didn't know the difference between techno, trance, breaks, house, 
> whatever, I just remember the music was VERY FAST & VERY LOUD! There 
> were these scantilly clad dancers on stages, and everyone seemed to 
> have whistles.  I remember a bunch of small psychadelic visual
screens 
> set up too.  There was supposed to be a smart bar, but the room that 
> it was in was decorated in tons of day-glow paint, with a bunch of 
> people just sitting around drinking and smoking weed.
> I remember it was so hot in there it was almost unbareable!  We
danced 
> for ahwile,and then somone brought me a club-soda from the bar up 
> front.  Everyone was very colorfully dressed and very friendly but i 
> really didn't make any new friends, I guess because I was a little 
> scared.(small town girl on her 1st big night out in nyc)
> When we left around 4am the front room was packed with people
watching 
> b&w porno movies. We headed back to our dorm, not quite sure of what 
> we had just came from.  On our way out we picked up flyers for NASA, 
> Communion, and maybe Disco 2000?
> Anyway, when i finally got to bed at like 5am, I slept for like 15 
> hours and when I woke up I had a fever of 104, double strep throat 
> infection, double sinus infection, was completely dehydrated, and
had 
> mono.  I was really sick for like 2 months and i lost like 
> 15-20lbs!!!!  I had no idea what happened.  I had never been that
sick 
> b4!  I'm still convinced to this day, I somehow took a drug 
> unknowingly at the party and totally put my system out of whack.
> 
> But stupid & young as i was, even though sick as a dog, I went to
NASA 
> the following Friday.  I still have the flyer it's a pink triangle
and 
> it folds out so you can read the dj's/times/etc...  I'll have to
look 
> at it to tell you who spun, but I think it was Mr. Kleen, Moby, and 
> maybe Jason Jinx.  That place was even stranger than Primal.  Lot's 
> more people.  We kind of wondered around for a few hours, danced a 
> little,and went home really early.  I remember I did have a lot of 
> fun, even though I was way too sick to be out at a club.  I remember 
> thinking people danced really weird.  And the lights were blinding 
> enough to make my eyes water.
> 
> ok. those are my earliest "rave" stories.
> 
> jami
> 
>

Chris (Sunny) of Solle Clothing and Pablo's Sugar Shack at VSF sent this
"feeler" to me about a free pre-rave meeting place for ravers every 
Saturday night at VSF, with dj's.  I think it sounds like a great idea, but 
because I'm outtie soon, I can't host it (though I would have loved to!)

It is true that VSF now is house and pretty mainstream, but read his 
message before you dismiss this.

So SFR, please read this and see what you all think, and respond to Chris.

:)
N


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 2 Jun 1997 17:30:05 -0500 (CDT)
From: Sunny <solle@ix.netcom.com>
To: nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU
Subject: NANCY - PLEASE READ

Hey Nancy-

As you probably already know I throw a party called Pablos Sugar 
Shack weekly every Saturday night at VSF (11th & Folsom) in SF.  I am 
toying with the idea of offering up my back room to SFRavers/ravers as 
a pre-party/rave stop.  My back room fits about 200 people and is 
outfitted with its own soundsystem, DJ coffin, etc.  Since on Saturday 
night the club really doesnt get goin until midnight I came up with 
this idea as it would provide a weekly meeting place to get a groove 
on before you move on, and to hook-up rides etc.  Right now the place 
is empty until around 12:30 a.m.  The idea as I see it would be to 
feature a lesser known (no offense) SFRaves community DJ weekly (or a 
couple) in the back room and have dollar drafts/drink specials goin 
and Id waive the cover charge for ravers before say 11 pm.  Ill 
benefit because while its not gonna make me rich in fact it may cost 
me, it will get people in the club earlier and give the place that vibe 
that I think is missing (one of our best parties is our monthly Funky 
Tekno Tribe afterparty).  Remember, at heart I am a raver not a 
clubber, I swear! Anyway, I need someone to help me kick off/host the 
night.  You, Leslie, a DJ like Macadio came to mind. Right now all I 
can offer to the Djs/host is free drinks and a free forum play in 
public and pre-party place for ravers. 

Let me know your thoughts, etc.
-Christopher Solle
VSF / Pablos Sugar Shack

6.7.97 Pablos line-up
[Jellybear, Jay-J, & Taj]

the new years gathering!!! that rocked.....

some of my fav's were the 1st and second freedom party's out at the
racetrack.  Candyland...WAAAY back when...it was at a drive in movie
theater and the after party was at thunder bay.  i was turned on to a
bunch of new ideas and experiences that night.

i hate to sound nostalgic...but i miss my innocence...i liked being
clue-less...made it more exciting.

The vibe party's at the stone...were some of the best "smaller"
party's.  Charter Oaks...tell me if anyone remembers this place??

I really didn't have that much fun at the first FTT at the concourse. 
I even had a few fun times at the end-up...like in '91.

8)~
dan

ahh memories.. i don't remember much to tell you the truth... my
memory has gone bad... that's what happens when you get old ;)

out the first time i met annie ting. thought she was rainbow bright :)
anyways those were the days...
now there's a new breed of ravers and there will be more more more
more more more...
but i still love you guys :)
<SMOOCH!>
um no i'm not that old school :) heehee
veann

In a message dated 6/4/97 11:47:41 PM, you wrote:

<<Jungle isn't about Peace Love and Unity.. its about dealing with everyday

life, that is why jungle is not really "in" the rave scene in anyway..

Jungle has its roots in the rave scene but the feeling and over all

attitude in Jungle is completely opposite then the rave scene.<<

Sweeping generalizations aside, what makes you think that you can speak for
an entire music genre/movement when you say that "Jungle isnt about Peace and
Unity", that "jungle is not really 'in' the rave scene anyway," and that "the
feeling and over all attitude in Jungle is completely opposite than the rave
scene." If Goldie was the one who made that post I'd be more apt to accept
that but....


>>The rave scene wants to escape, the jungle scene wants to cope.. thats the
best way I can describe it.  You can see this in the drug usage.<<

 If you think that Jungle/D&B isnt just as much about escapism, you are
sorely mistaken. It's music, which is at some level entertainment. You listen
to it in part because you want to be entertained. Entertainment is something
we use to escape from the daily pressures and stresses of life.  I understand
your implication though; raver kids do a lot of drugs, so they want to
escape. Poor logic becuase it by no means accounts for the many other reasons
why people both do drugs and go to parties.  

>>I can't really explain it, you just have to live it.<<

Give me a break. Like the people who are responsible for producing anything
other 




than Jungle and Hip-Hop can't "live it" either? Talk to people like Glenn
Underground from Chicago, Carl Craig, Mad Mike of UR and although he may
outwardly deny it, Alan Oldham from Detroit. These people "live it" at least
as much as anyone I see in any other music scene.


>>Within the jungle scene using drugs other then cess is very looked down
upon..<<

A friend of mine who is the marketing/advertising director at URB magazine
down in LA told a story recently about the Sunday night D&B club that URB is
throwing. He said that when a very well known UK Jungle DJ came and played at
the club, at one point he leaned over to pick up something he dropped and a
crack rock and pipe fell out of his front shirt pocket. This bloke then
proceeded to play it off by simply asking my friend for a light.  Drug use
other that Weed is looked down upon? Please...


>>Jungle has a high testostorone level.. <<
I'm sure people like Stareyes, Bonnie,  Kemistry & Storm and certainly DJ Rap
would disagree with you.


>>thats all I can say.. You really got to know your shit, or you get cut
down.<<

Precisely.

3 Strikes...
--Monty

          by etna.infoseek.com (8.8.5/8.8.4)
	  id SAA00675 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Thu, 5 Jun 1997 18:20:49 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Thu, 5 Jun 1997 18:20:49 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199706060120.SAA00675@etna.infoseek.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: blast from the past
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I started out on the East Coast.  The very first party I went to was on
a Thursday night, in Baltimore Maryland.  It was called "Orbit."  I drove
three hours each way from New Jersey for this, and went to work as usual 
the day after.  I was pretty wowed, especially that people were having so
much fun without getting drunk off their asses. (June 1992)

Two years -- and MANY parties -- later, I visited San Francisco for the first
time.  The first party I went to here was a "Your Sister's House," which
was held in some art gallery where there were lots of dildos on the wall.
It was also my first DJ gig in San Francisco.  I met SOOOOOO many nice people.
And funny, it was also a Thursday night :-) (August 1993)

Five months later I moved to San Francisco.  The first party I went to
was "The Blue Cube," held at this guy Steve's house in Noe Valley.  He
had soundproofed his garage with egg foam and you name it...there were two
or three "Blue Cube" parties, which eventually evolved into what became
"Friends and Family."  Steve is a sound engineer, and pressed my DJ set
to CD :-)  Anyway, it was amazing how much energy was packed into that
garage -- and that the neighbors didn't complain! (January 1994)

Meeemmmmmmories....light the corners of my mind......misty water colored
memmmmmmorrrieeeesss...of the way we raved......

Sigh.

Laura

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

So are you saying it's hard to become a Jungle DJ?

I find it rather easy. It's totally easier to spin jungle instead of house.
Yea, yea.. It gets alittle complicated at times matching the beats but. You
don't even need a talent for matching beats to be a good, creative jungle
DJ. Or so it seems.

The only thing I hate about mixing jungle though...Running out of records.

> Hey Nancy-
> 
> As you probably already know I throw a party called Pablos Sugar 
> Shack weekly every Saturday night at VSF (11th & Folsom) in SF.  I am 
> toying with the idea of offering up my back room to SFRavers/ravers as 
> a pre-party/rave stop.  My back room fits about 200 people and is 
> outfitted with its own soundsystem, DJ coffin, etc.  Since on Saturday 
> night the club really doesnt get goin until midnight I came up with 
> this idea as it would provide a weekly meeting place to get a groove 
> on before you move on, and to hook-up rides etc.  Right now the place 
> is empty until around 12:30 a.m.  The idea as I see it would be to 
> feature a lesser known (no offense) SFRaves community DJ weekly (or a 
> couple) in the back room and have dollar drafts/drink specials goin 
> and Id waive the cover charge for ravers before say 11 pm.  Ill 
> benefit because while its not gonna make me rich in fact it may cost 
> me, it will get people in the club earlier and give the place that vibe 
> that I think is missing (one of our best parties is our monthly Funky 
> Tekno Tribe afterparty).  Remember, at heart I am a raver not a 
> clubber, I swear! Anyway, I need someone to help me kick off/host the 
> night.  You, Leslie, a DJ like Macadio came to mind. Right now all I 
> can offer to the Djs/host is free drinks and a free forum play in 
> public and pre-party place for ravers.

At 06:20 PM 6/5/97 -0700, Laura LaGassa wrote:
>Five months later I moved to San Francisco.  The first party I went to
>was "The Blue Cube," held at this guy Steve's house in Noe Valley.

Ding!  Those were the best house parties I've ever been to, with the
possible exception of New Year's Eve at the Resort around that time.  I
went to several massives around that time but I don't feel nostalgic for them.

How about Planet 6 at Burning Man in 1993, when "rave camp" was one 14-foot
U-Haul with the DJ inside?  We were dancing, and someone came up to me and
said "Dude, you have to try this.  Close your eyes and start running."  So
I did, and after a few seconds of panic I felt like I was floating in the
void...you can't do that anywhere but the playa.

I still remember holding hands around the dying fire while waiting for the
sun to come up...there were only three of us left, but the DJ was still
spinning his beautiful mellow ambient set...then the fire died and we
watched the sun rise while cuddling under a blanket.  It was the most
beautiful sunrise I have experienced, and I regret losing track of the
people I shared it with.

// grigsbeast

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>

Precedence: bulk


Yeah, I remember riding my dinosaur to a few dank old caves in the first
metallysurgic phase of the neolithic era. Back then we wore big animal
skins. so I walk in wearing my baggy mammoth-trunk-trousers, and it had
been a rough day as they have the tendency to chaff a bit unless you get
the expensive shaved mammoth-trunk trousers, which i couldn't afford at the
time. if you came in wearing a regular old bear skin, people just wouldn't
talk to you and would assume you were some kind of neanderthal. when you
first get in the cave, you first notice this fire and a mirror projecting
the images of amoebas and primitive multicellular organisms in this glass
plate going sploimp and splork and squick to the beat. sometimes they'd
rise up from the projection system, mutated by the wicked sounds&beats, the
sweat, and the BO, and become a new species. This usually looked pretty
cool on the projection screen. the sounds were incredibly organic
techno. Back then, you'd loop the roar of a t-rex for the bass-line, line
up a bunch of tortoises and hit their shells with a mallet for the rhythm,
and that rhythmic 303 wail was being done by a group of trained bats that
were tied into a DJ coffin while being skillfully taunted into squeaking
with tasty morsels of food. Being PLUR meant you stopped dragging people
around by the hair and stealing their food for an hour because you were too
busy dancing and didn't want to spoil the vibe with survival traits (well
at least that hasn't changed). Best of all, were the "no clubbing people"
signs. Ahh, those were the days. Hell, you kids have it easy.

==    Niels Mayer ..... mayer@netcom.com ..... http://www.eit.com/~mayer   ==

        "Re:  Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR" (Jun  5,  8:22pm)
References: <970605202244_-894879957@emout18.mail.aol.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: Tekno313@aol.com, johnsin@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't usually chime in, but I'm with Monty on this.  Jungle long ago
stopped being what any one group thought it should be, as the interview
with LTJ Bukem in the new Muzik and the last chapter or two of the new
book "Altered State" (which I definitely recommend) would indicate.
And as the book indicates, Kemistry and Storm were in the jungle scene
from the very beginning, along with Fabio, Grooverider, Dego and Mark Mac
and quite a few others.  Junglists tried hard to protect the scene when
it was small and fragile and avoid some of the mistakes of the predecessor
house and techno scenes, but success breeds contradictions, that's for
sure.  Certain people in the jungle/d&b scene attempt to erect the
barricades with a lot of talk about how tough they are, but frankly, 
jungle turned away from the no-one-harder approach to things years ago
(though there is still some tough-business stuff in its composition today)
and as a result *grew dramatically* in its musical scope and accomplishment.
Otherwise all the tracks coming out now would still be full of gunfire
and "booyaka booyaka."  

Jungle comes from the depressed areas of the UK, especially the east end
of London, and it reflects that reality.  But like all great musical
styles it has gone well beyond that.  If people want to copy the speech
patterns and clothing style and street toughness of that area in order
to be "true junglists," well, that's just a bit sad isn't it?  I'd
rather address it on its own terms musically.  The cultural background is
important too, but it's hardly an excuse to create some kind of zone of
exclusivity around it.  

I've been playing jungle since 1994, it's just damn *good* and a real
breath of fresh air after the staleness that's overtaken house and techno
alike.  More recently, jungle and d&b have gotten into a few ruts too,
but that always happens.  The last couple of months have been better for
innovators in the style, from the stuff I'm hearing.  There will always
be temptation to copy the regional chauvinism that has depressed hip-hop
(and slowed down its evolution drastically, I might add) over the last
decade.  But jungle has already shown its potential to cross over the
increasingly rigid boundaries of dance music audiences, and even to the
"overground" -- I heard the Logical Progression CD when I was eating dinner
at Pomodoro on 9th & Irving last month.  Some people see this as selling
out.  There will be some of that, the music industry engulfs everything
that grows, to some degree.  

So the answer, as always, is to go deeper when that happens.  The brilliance
of house, for a while at least, was that it did so *inclusively*.  I would
hate to see jungle limited in its potential simply because its adherents
put up some kind of be-cool test that outsiders have to pass.  

I'm off da soapbox now . . .


phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun  6 01:02:58 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)

 What If God Smoked Cannabis?
 
 If God had a long hair, and a goatee
 And if his eyes were pretty glazed
 If He looked spaced out would you buy His story
 Would you believe he had an eye infection? 
 And yeah, yeah, God looks baked
 And yeah, yeah God smells good
 Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah
 What if God smoked Cannabis?
 Hit the bong like some of us?
 Drove a tie dyed microbus
 And He subscribes to Rolling Stone

 When God made this place, in the beginning
 Did He plant any seeds?
 Or did He put them there for Adam & Eve?
 So they'd be hungry for the apple that the snake
 Was always offerin'
 
 And Yeah, Yeah, God rolls great
 And Yeah, Yeah, God smells good, 
 Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah Yeah
 What if God smoked Cannabis?
 Do you s'pose he had a buzz
 When he made the Platypus
 Does He like Pearl Jam or the Stones
 And do you think He rolls His own?
 Up there in Heaven on the throne.
 
 And when the saints go marching home,
 Maybe He sits and smokes a bone.

>So are you saying it's hard to become a Jungle DJ?
>
>I find it rather easy. It's totally easier to spin jungle instead of 
house.
>Yea, yea.. It gets alittle complicated at times matching the beats but.

>don't even need a talent for matching beats to be a good, creative 
jungle
>DJ. Or so it seems.
>

records.
>What was this whole thread about anyways?

>Jeff here.

Sorry, but you're wrong. HAving spun house/techno for a couple years 
before d'nb I can tell you it's much harder to find records that work 
together. Granted, the mixing style is a lot more open: you can mix 
smooth like Bukem or scratch and cut...or all of the above. The problem 
is that b/c it's so new to these parts (relatively) a lot of dj's havent 
really developed their styles yet. It takes time. 

But I'd definately have to say that beat mathicng it important no matter 
which style you play.

Forwarded message:

So I was reading Inter@Active Week, an industry trade mag, and found out
that "the Mining Company" (the company that did that web site that was 
touted as the "new Hyperreal") is a new commercial web directory project
started by an ex-exec from Prodigy (the online service, not the band).

The are advertising supported, and are basically trying to become a player
in the navigation/search engine industry -- they're going after the likes
of Yahoo!...

Laura

>Hi allzs, has anyone heard of "theTechnoQueen" MARUSHA???

Yes sir, she has released two albums (that I know of...). 
Her first was called "Raveland", and that's the one that has "Somewhere
over the Rainbow" on it. It also has classics such as "It Takes Me Away"
(her first single if I'm not mistaken), and "Girl I House You". Her next
album, "Wir", is the better of the two. Not as poppy as the first one,
lots of house-influences, and also some heavy techno-beats. Tracks to
listen for include "Deep", "Secret", and "Unique".

>in any case...does anyone know what techno-music genre artists like
>Marusha, Scooter, Gompie, N-Trance, etc fall under???? these are mainly
>European techno peoples but what kind of techno do they play?

Well, in Europe this goes under EURODISNEY...I mean EURODISCO. And I would
assume that this name would work even in the US. =)

*huggies*
jonas THE EURORAVING SPACEBOY

At 10:19 AM -0700 6/6/97, LRITTING.US.ORACLE.COM wrote:
>I was wondering if anyone out there had received the email that is
>circulating
>about Pink Floyd's Dark Side Of The Moon and The Wizard Of Oz.  I haven't
>seen
>the message myself, but I've heard about it...  Anyone have this?

This is what I got.....

Put on the video of "The Wizard of Oz".  Once the M.G.M. lion roars for
the third time, start Pink Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" CD (it has to
be the CD). Turn the TV volume all the way down and the cd volume all the
way up, sit back, and ENJOY THE SHOW, MAN!  Remember to start the cd RIGHT
AFTER the lion roars for the third time.  You can either set the cd on
continual repeat OR after it runs ALL THE WAY THROUGH (to the end of the
heart beat), you can replace it with "Wish You Were Here" and start it
when the Tin man starts to faint (in the scene when he's first
discovered).  THEN, once that runs out, replace it with "Meddle" starting
with track 2.

Make sure that you've used the bathroom, everyone is focused, and you're
in a subjective state of mind, if you know what I mean.

For more information, see the web page.  Go to Yahoo! Choose "weekly
picks" at the bottom of the page, and there will be a link to the
"Synchronicity Archive".


Could be interesting ;)

*B*

Precedence: bulk

> i'd like to get all the DJ's (and even those who just spin for whatever 
> reason!) opinions of this.
> do you think its easier to spin sumthin' with that 4/4 beat or breakbeats?? 
> (we'll include jungle w/breaks since a lot of jungle's beats are hard and 
> fast breakbeats)

I think it's easier to spin stuff that has a constant 4/4 beat than something
syncopated (breakbeat/Jungle).  I also think it's easier to spin something
that runs around 135-145 BPM (techno/trance) than 118-130 (house/garage).  
When the records are faster, it's easier to correct when they start slipping
out of phase.

But maybe I just think this because that is what I spin?  And maybe the
person who thinks Jungle is the easiest said so because it is the easiest
for him?  Everyone has their own reaction to the music, as a musician, DJ,
dancer, or listener.

Laura

Does anyone remember the "Do not st in the Furniture" parties, or Glass
House?  What about ToonTown or Carefree?The ney years eve ToonTown at
the fashion center after the Nirvanah concert was incredible....Did
anybody go, it was back in 9O or 91?  What about Rave called Sharon -
devotion in Tracy, all the parties at the Truckadero. Juice &
Cosmofunkagroveathon 1 & 2 ( the first ever party at marina skate, mike
rosenburg and Josh).  Many were at dv8, and at one of them they blocked
of the entire parking lot in back and set up a sound system and bouncy
castles with visuals).  how about: Higidy Pigidy & Where the wild things
Are  1 & 2 (mark sabotnik) or dj bucks Church every sunday night at dv8,
Thursday Night Osmisis at dv8, the ryder truck Gathering at the pier
warehouse 5 blocks from the potrero hill police station?  Even Felix
parties (formerly FTT) were cool, i remeber the one at dome romanian
wall on divisidero, were DJ Dan played for the first time in SF (thats
when he used to spell his name DeeJay Dan).  The very first basix at the
art studio next to townsend.  wicked fool moon at gray whale cove, and
all other fool moon parties when wicked still was part of the sceene. 
The destiny and exuinox parties... they werew incredible!  and of course
don't forget the very firts CASPER holoween colaberation with Rave
called Sharon on marin st of south 3rd.  That was an incredible event, i
sould know, I Organized IT!  And what about the very first CoolWorlds,
man those parteis were good, and the first Cyberfest in that 30 acre
field at 4th and chanel next to the china basin building....That was not
just an incredible event, but a mile stone in san francisco dance
history! Anyone remeber Warpfactor X, with the hologram sticker flyer in
91, We brought out Franki Bones for the first time to the west coast for
that one....That party truly went off!!!!!  what about The X Men
adventures party, I know there must be some oldtimers that remeber this
one?  Tuesday night together in the basement of bigheart city, wed night
housing project at the endup, the first gathering at the location were
the sound factory was built.  Club Liquid in the basement of the
maritime hall!  Many raves were held there!  DNA sunday mornings for
Rebirth and Afterlife!  Sunday Nights at Mission Rock for Mallikies
Unity Parties, and after that SunDayZ @ 444 Deharo with resident dj Ray
Vonie (A club I used to put on) way before spunday was around.  Weres
Waldo on the Hornblower santa rosa, and the one at the airfield in
sancarlos in the hanger...back when the hardkiss brotheres used to throw
parties.  I remeber some of them were at THUNDER BAY in berkeley, Anyone
remeber the Aligator Bar? 808 State played at one of them.  How about
Love American style, with Roland, or small world and Elmo parties (now
we are getting into the 16th and Harison days). Wally world, Power, and
Massive Culture in livermore.   Im sure that many of you remeber the
first Harmony at the Brookdale Lodge.  And there have been so many other
great parties, but I can't even remeber them all, so i will stop
remenising right now.

Shit I could go on Forever, But im geting all choked up, so I'll just
stop now cause its kinda making me emotional.  This seen has seen 8
generations of raving in 6 years.  Im glad to have been a part of it.

Anyways, then was then, and Now Is Now.

Keep It real

Ray Vonie
Bad spelling is my trademark

Subject: Set mixer to Frappe (was: 4/4 VS. Breaks)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Laura La Gassa sez:
>I think it's easier to spin stuff that has a constant 4/4 beat than something
>syncopated (breakbeat/Jungle).  I also think it's easier to spin something
>that runs around 135-145 BPM (techno/trance) than 118-130 (house/garage).
>When the records are faster, it's easier to correct when they start slipping
>out of phase.


Hm. I find that the slower a track is, the easier it is to mix.  If you put
on 2 gabba records, they are WAY harder to keep "on" than two house
records. That's part of where different music styles lean toward different
mixing styles...  Jungle is pretty high up on the BPM counter. I find
jungle/fast-techno to be FAR more challenging than mixing house. Mixing
house/garage, or even dubby stuff (90-110) you can line it up and then go
the bathroom, and they'll still be on. =p

-Joshua

that's sooo funny that u say that about a 4/4 beat AND about 130-140
bpm
music.  I play a lot of trance and a lot of it is really full, i.e. a
lot of stuff going on and i find (of course) that it is the HARDEST to
spin.  I pulled out a bunch of my old house records last night that
have a pretty straight 4/4 beat and range 120-130 bpm and i couldn't
believe how easy it was for me to spin them. I also find that
breakbeats and D&B are the easiest for me to spin.  That's why when i
first started spinning i loved to spin breaks, they were the one thing
i could actually (well most of the time) beatmatch.  Synchopated
rhythms with that nice hi-hat seem easy to line up.

what's everyone else's experiences???

8)~
dan

From: Max McCauley <maxmcc@CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: PLUR vs JUNGLE?!
Message-ID: <Pine.PTX.3.95.970606115153.23831A-100000@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


To disclaim, I will say that I am a baby.  I will never stop believing
that I'm new to everything, for fear that I'll stop learning.  As far as
my life is concerned, being comfortable with something means losing
interest...I need that Golden Cow of Herb off in the distance somewhere, a
treasure chest and the end of an invisible rainbow.  If I know something
too well, I need to make it more complicated somehow, or else life becomes
routine.

SO ANYWAYS.

I think that this junglist versus stereotype 'raver' string is
fascinating, and it perfectly sums up several things that I see in the
dance music scene, as well as things I see about the Bay Area.

More or less, my belief is that as far as music goes, as far as LIFE
itself goes in the Bay Area, every artist, every fan, every dancer, every
interested party has a million hands in a million pockets.  The Bay Area
is the land of stylistic collision and that's what makes it so incredible
here.  Hiphop crews that are blackwhitemexicantonganicelandicjewish, and
don't mind.  House DJ's who have alter-egos spinning noisecore thranky
skrash music.  And a dog named Boo.

What I'm saying is that 'ravers' can talk about PLUR, and many can
genuinely mean it.  On the other hand, many can just be bighead 'gimme
some ass' dudes who want to hug/dip as many women as they can, like this
was Saturday Night Fever, while they talk about PLUR.

At the same time, many junglists can walk around with the gas-face on all
day, thinking that for shit to be real inna jungle, you have to be from
grit, of grit.  For some, jungle is definitely the music of the angry and
the oppressed, etc etc.  At the same time, there are other junglistas who
are just blowing their whistles and hugging each other and putting
themselves on vibrato at the very sound of jungle, the very sight of
people getting deep into it.

So there is crossover, and there must be.  It cracks me up, it literally
makes me GUFFAW, when I read these posts that seem to be checklists for
being a legitimate X Y or Z.  I don't mean to be giving advice that no one
asked for, but, my friends, let go of category.  Forget about 'being
real.'  Avoid the Noid.  Fuck the Man.  But please....this is our little
Bay, our nook of Mother Earth, and we have it real real extra good here.

And guess what? we can have it all, every which way, or we can have just a
piece, a bit that we throw all our love into...

But what we can't have is an idea that there is some ineffable DO THIS
DON'T DO THAT force out there that separates us while binding us together
in cliques. What we live in the Bay for is the chance to not adhere to the
styles of today, but rather to be ourselves, and clash with our friends
like we clash with our clothes.  And still be bloody gorgeous.


Now, get me the hell out the pulpit, before I hurt myself.

MAX...SAGA1

PS: Ten una buena fin de semana.


"There is no feeling with less satisfaction in it........than knowing
somewhere there remains.............a temptation we resisted."

> The National Institute of Health released the results of a
> controversial new study today, one that links the drug marijuana
> to sitting around and getting high.  The study, a comprehensive
> five-year survey of drug use among Americans, also suggests a
> possible connection between marijuana and getting baked off your
> ass.
>
> "We have found that where there's marijuana," explained Institute
> spokesperson Roger Krell, "there's also a good chance of finding
> stoners on a couch passing around a bong." Krell added that in
> such situations, "There is also a strong likelihood of finding
> incense, a TV, and some chips, usually Ruffles." Krell would
> neither confirm nor deny the alleged link between marijuana and
> Pink Floyd's The Wall.  He would confirm, however, that the album
> rules.  "There is some seriously fucked-up shit on that album,"
> he said.  "Especially side two.  Mother do you think they'll drop
> the bomb..."
>
> Marijuana, or "pot," as it is called on the street, is a harmless
> drug that helps you relax and feel mellow.  Its only known
> side-effects are occasional uncontrollable laughter and mild
> hunger, or "the munchies."
>
> Not everyone agrees with the survey's findings.  "Getting high is
> the least of marijuana's uses," said Matt Henner, President of
> Hemp For Victory and a total pothead.  "The ancient Egyptians used
> hemp to build the pyramids.  In the 1930s, the WPA used it to
> construct bridges and dams.  Today it is used for medicine and as
> a non-polluting alternative to gasoline." Henner then admitted he
> was "wasted beyond belief."
>
> According to experts, drug use among 15-24 year olds is cool.
> "That's really the cool age to do drugs," said U.S.  Drug Czar
> Bertrand Seaver.  "When you're young, that's the thing to do.  In
> fact, studies show that teenagers who smoke pot are far more likely
> to be accepted by the in-crowd."
>
> While drug use among young people is cool, experts say older people
> who still do drugs are losers.  "A young person who does drugs is
> healthy and normal," said Harvard sociologist Beth Henterpen. "But
> if a guy's like 45, and he's still getting high, it's like, 'Get
> a life!'" Marijuana also has been proven to have the wonderful
> side-effect of enhanced sexual sensations, enabling some users to
> achieve transcendental states of erotic bliss.  The study found
> that this link, however, was severely limited in many subjects
> because they had, due to sitting around all the time, never actually
> met members of the opposite sex.  "But if they did," said Krell,
> "then it'd be amazing."
>
> So far, the study has met with formal protest by only two groups.
> The Alabama-based Center for the Christian Family, claimed the
> findings to be terribly inaccurate, noting marijuana's ability to
> "make users think they can fly and jump out of buildings, like on
> Quincy, as well as its tendency to induce demon possession,
> homicidal rampages, and homosexuality."
>
> Another group to object to the study was California rapping group
> Cypress Hill.  "Marijuana's not linked to sitting around, man...
> It's linked to cruising the Barrio with a 40 and a 12 gauge,
> blowing pendejos away," said group member DJ Muggs.  "Hand onna
> pump, puffin' on a blunt...  la la la la laaaaaaaaaaa..."

Hey everybody.  This is kinda tangent, and maybe a little understood.
But arent most breaks (all the ones I think ive incountered) syncopated
in 4/4?  Are we saying 4/4 as in quarter note heaven? Thump-thump-thump-thump?
As far as beatmatching goes, it seems like the steadiness of a real basic four makes 
it easy to get the timing right..but some songs get to the point where you cant find the one.
This is where I see jungle makes up for its complexity (as far as beatmatching) in that
there is allways a one. Boom tap...and so on..even if it takes 2 bars or so to get back to it.

since ive been bsing all this music theory ish...
does anyone know a good URL For basic music theory? Im gonna do some hunting..
but It seems like it would make all of us better if we understood the music we enjoy.

Thnks
<meeks>

Precedence: bulk

I can beat match jungle easier than any other type of music.  It's faster,
so the beats are closer together and happen more frequenly, so it's easier
to monitor whether it's on or starting to get off.  House is slower so it
takes more time for the next beat to hit, thus allowing for more slipage of
the record.  My opinion of course.

Rick
