I can't remember who subscribed to this school of thought, but I find any
thing faster than house easy to mix.  Music under 130 bpm to me just seems
to be harder to mix.  I have no problem doing it, but I find I'm able to
correct myself quicker when I'm playing faster music.

And with music theory, yes breakbeat and 4/4 are all relative.  If you've
ever have had to look at sheet music, you'll find that these two different
representation of beats (4/4 vs. breakbeat) all occur within the same music
structure of the measure.  Personally, I sometime like to mix both of these
together at the same time to get some really funky beats.

-Todd

In-Reply-To: <199706062047.NAA14498@guilder.ucdavis.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 6 Jun 1997 14:17:01 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: 4/4 VS. Breaks (was: the Jungle battle hits SFR)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I find downtempo easiest to mix - there's more time spent on each beat. =)

Ambient and ambient dub get a bit tricky as key tends to be important in
order to avoid nasty dissonance (unless that sort of tension is what you're
after)

House is generally pretty easy to beatmatch, with its standard off-beat
high hat. (I always find myself listening to high hats to beat match when I
can)

I find techno a bit more difficult than house, and many of the tracks are
meant more as tools, so you have the ability to end up utlilizing more
tracks and relying on combinations to create a flow.

Jungle can be tricky with it's syncopation, but it's not as narrowly
structured as house and techno (part of their ease - it's almost all 4 or 8
bar phrases), so being off within a phrase isn't always as noticeable. I've
found jungle lends itself well to cuts and shorter mixes.

Most importantly, the ease of mixing a style seems to depend mainly on the
depth of familiarity with it. The more listening and practicing, the easier
it seems to become. And beatmatching is just a basic component of mixing.
Programming's just as vital.

On a tangent - have any old schoolers heard any of the greats from the
disco era play? I assume there wasn't much beatmatching done, yet from what
I'm read there were some incredible vibes created.

Joe

Hey foolish fish,

Did you hear about the interaction between dark side of the 
moon and the Wizard of Oz (see the email below forwarded to me 
by a friend of mine)?  It stikes me this would be a really 
interesting thing to do at a rave like party with all the 
multimedia set up and people in the mood for such a bizzare 
experience.


You pointed out that:

By midnight that had all changed and this turned out to be an 
incredibly
great party.

liked when they mixed in pink floyds dark side of the moon.

Original message >

From: <Dirk.d.b.Brown@camta4.amd.com>
To: <sinclair@creative.net>, <timothy_e_levine@amat.com>, 
<paul_gefken@qm.sri.com>
Cc: 
Date: 24 May 1997 10:34:10 -0700
Subject: Dark Side of the... Rainbow ?

Hey... 

We should try this one night after hitting the bars in the 
city.

- Dirk.
__________________________________________________________

Call it Dark Side of the Rainbow. Classic rockers are buzzing 
about the
amazingly weird connections that leap off the screen when you 
play Pink
Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" as the soundtrack to "The 
Wizard of Oz."
It sounds wacky, but there really is a bizarre synchronization 
there.
The lyrics and music join in cosmic synch with the action, 
forming dozens
upon dozens of startling coincidences the kind that make you 
go "Oh wow,
man"
even if you haven't been near a bong in 20 years.
Consider these examples:
Floyd sings "the lunatic is on the grass" just as the 
Scarecrow begins
his floppy jig near a green lawn.  The line "got to keep the 
loonies on the
path" comes just before Dorothy and the Scarecrow start 
traipsing down
the Yellow Brick Road.
When deejay George Taylor Morris at WZLX-FM in Boston first 
mentioned
the phenom on the air six weeks ago, he touched off a frenzy.
"The phones just blew off the wall. It started on a Friday, 
and that
first weekend you couldn't get a copy of 'The Wizard of Oz' 
anywhere in
Boston," he said. "People were staying home to check it out."  
It's fun,
he said, because everyone knows the movie,and the album which 
spent a
record-busting 591 straight weeks on the Billboard charts can
be found in practically every record collection.
Dave Herman at WNEW-FM in New York mentioned the buzz a few 
weeks ago.
The response more than 2,000 letters was the biggest ever in 
the deejay's
25-year on-air career.
"It has been just unbelievable," said WNEW program director 
Mark
Chernoff. "I've never seen anything like this. "
The station plans to show the movie using the album as 
soundtrack at a
small private screening tomorrow.
Rock fans always have loved to speculate about hidden messages 
in their
favorite albums. But seeking connections between the beloved 
1939
classic kid flick and the legendary 1973 acid-rock album 
pushes he envelope
of
the music conspiracy genre.
Nobody from the publicity-shy band would comment, but Morris 
asked
keyboardist Richard Wright about it on the air last month. He 
looked
flummoxed and said he'd never heard of any intentional 
connections
between the movie and the album.
But the fans aren't convinced it's just a cosmic coincidence. 
"I'm a
musician myself and I know how hard it is just to write music, 
let alone
music choreographed to action," said drummer Alex Harm, of 
Lowell,
Mass.,who put up one of the two Internet web pages devoted to 
the
synchroneities. "To make it match up so well, you'd have to 
plan it."
Morris is convinced that ex-frontman Roger Waters planned the 
whole
thing without letting his fellow band members in on the 
secret.
"It's too close. It's just too close. Look at the song titles. 
Look at
the cover. There's something going on there," Morris said.
Here's how it works. You start the album at the exact moment 
when the
MGM lion finishes its third and last roar. It might take a few 
times to get
everything lined up just right.  Then, just sit back and 
watch. It'll
blow your mind, man.
During "Breathe," Dorothy teeters along a fence to the lyric: 
"balanced
on the biggest wave."  The Wicked Witch, in human form, first 
appears on
her bike at the same moment a burst of alarm bells sounds on 
the album.
During "Time," Dorothy breaks into a trot to the line: "no one 
told you
when to run."  When Dorothy leaves the fortuneteller to go 
back to her
farm, the album is playing: "home, home again."
Glinda, the cloyingly saccharine Good Witch of the North, 
appears in her
bubble just as the band sings: "Don't give me that do goody 
goody bull
 ---t."
A few minutes later, the Good Witch confronts the Wicked Witch 
as the
band sings, "And who knows which is which" (or is that "witch 
is witch"?).
The song "Brain Damage" starts about the same time as the 
Scarecrow
launches into "If I Only Had a Brain."
But it's not just the weird lyrical coincidences. Songs end 
when scenes
switch, and even the Munchkins' dancing is perfectly 
choreographed to
the song "Us and Them."
The phenomenon is at its most startling during the tornado 
scene, when
the wordless singing in "The Great Gig in the Sky" swells and 
recedes in
strikingly perfect time with the movie.
When Dorothy opens the door into Oz, the movie switches to 
rich color
and and that exact moment the album starts in with the 
tinkling cash
register sound effects from "Money."
Anyone who has ever nursed a hangover watchin MTV with the 
sound off and
the radio on can tell you how quick the brain is to turn music 
into a
soundtrack for pictures. But this is uncanny.
The real fanatics will point out that side one of the vinyl 
album is the
exact length of the black-and-white portion of the movie. And 
then
there's that iconic album cover, with its prism and rainbow 
echoing the
movie's famous black-and-white-into-color switch not to 
mention Judy
Garland's
classic first song.
The real clincher, though, the moment where even the most 
skeptical of
cynics has to utter a small "whoa!," comes at the end of the 
album,
which tails off with the insistent sound of a beating heart. 
What's
happening
on screen? Yep, you guessed it: Dorothy's got her ear to the 
Tin Man's
chest, listening for a heartbeat.
Maybe it's just a string of coincidences. Maybe the mind is 
just playing
some really cool tricks. Maybe some people just have waaaay 
too much
time on their hands.  Or maybe, as Pink Floyd sings to close 
out the album,
everything under the sun really is in tune.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun  6 15:44:09 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id PAA08522;

i think mixing 4/4 tracky chicago style house is easier than mixing
breaks.
but why waste your money on records you won't want to play later.
you need to find the music you like 
any music you buy just to learn to spin will be a waste if it is not what
you want to play
it might be harder but you can learn with breakbeat
if thats your style you will need to figure out how to play it sometime
luckily for me i am deep into the vibe of house and that 4/4 beat makes
me feel good inside
so 
anyway
go buy some music that you like and that you would like to play (or hear
or whatever)
you will be glad you did later 
because instead of having a bunch of records that you want to sell back
to the store someday
you will have a bunch of classic hits!
good luck
gabe

At 2:17 PM -0700 6/6/97, Joe Rice wrote:
>On a tangent - have any old schoolers heard any of the greats from the
>disco era play? I assume there wasn't much beatmatching done, yet from what
>I'm read there were some incredible vibes created.

I've seen Grandmaster Flash spin, in the movie "Wild Style" and also in the
History of Rock and Roll PBS series last year... he claims to have created
the style employed my DJs like Q-bert, where he uses 2 copies of the same
song to loop one short section over and over.  Watching him spin, I believe
it.  The guy spins funk records with human musicians, so the beats aren't
at a constant tempo, and he still seems to beatmatch flawlessly, mixing
smoothly and also cutting and scratching, but always on-beat!

I read another interview once with a DJ from the 70's (maybe Tony
Humphries?), who claimed he was the first person to ever keep one song
going indefinitely using 2 copies... the song was "Night Fever" by the Bee
Gees.

On a more general note, anyone who wants to understand the possibilities of
jungle mixing should check out any of the "Drum and Bass Selection"
compilation series on Moonshine, especially #4 - a continuous mix by DJ
Hype.  Hype incorporates scratching, double copies, phasing and all kinds
of tricks into an exceptionally smooth mix.  I've never heard another
jungle DJ come close.

Keep it positive folks!
Jonathan aka Mudfoot



Jonathan Golub
Associate Producer, Beta Lounge
Wired Digital
http://www.betalounge.com/

From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Last Night's Odyssey
To: bassbabies <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706061655.A27974-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>

Precedence: bulk



Being hungover at work has to be the worst thing in the world.  This 
morning was a lovely combination of pretending to work while my head was 
spinning and casually walking to the bathroom to discreetly throw-up.  
But the worse you feel the next day, probably the better night you had, 
right?! ;)

I love my friend Chris.  This is because we meet after work sometimes for 
"just a drink" to talk and catch up, and it usually turns into a 
whirlwind tour of bars and a parade of mixed drinks, and ends up in some 
dance club somewhere - and always on the worst of nights, the weeknight.  

Well, last night was no exception.  It started innocently enough with us
still in our work clothes having a beer with dinner.  Six hours later I
find myself shaking it at the Trocadero, still in the stupid office outfit
surrounded by ravers :)

This weekly has some promise, but its opening night was more of a 
whimper than a bang.  First, the location.  I've heard there's been good 
parties at the Troc, but its rocker/goth/industrial/club vibe kinda 
permeates the space and makes it somehow feel rather gamey.  Second, the 
space is too large for the sparse crowd of last night, making it appear 
to be dead even when the dancefloor was going off.  Also, there was 
nothing ravey about the set-up: it was merely some rave music being spun 
in a not very attractive club.

Add to this that industrial-sounding techno gives me an instant headache. 
My alcohol-laden brain fuzzily determined that Cesar was spinning when we
were there (1 to 3), but I am in no way sure of this.  After some
interminable clashing appliances sound, the music did get funkier in a
junglie way and those who were dancing were having a lot of fun. 

However, the fact that this was 18 and up, and is a potential weekly for 
_ravers_ makes it exciting.  I would just really like to see Space 
Children actually put some production into this, and see the rave family 
pack this joint.  We _could_ take over the Troc, but it didn't happen 
last night.

The most fun _I_ had last night was at Bruno's, where we talked our way 
in for free :).  This retro-swanky Mission place was all 
twenty-somethings done up in coolcat clothes and drinking martinis and a 
absolutely fantastic late-60's takeoff band called the Kinetics that just 
jammed.  Word to the wise: there are many scenes and cool things out 
there - don't get stuck in one place ;)

love you, Nancy

Subject: Blast from the Past II
To: discobunnies <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706061745.A28297-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Lessons learned too late
Los Angeles, early '90's.  The rave scene is blowing up.  Summer of Love 
1992.  The music's called "Acid House" and people are actually breaking into 
unused warehouses to throw parties.  But I know nothing of this, except 
what I hear from the media.  The rave scene, I decide, fed on 
misinformation, is nothing but drugged-up teenagers listening to bad 
music.  I'm not interested in it, and neither are any of my friends.

Then one friend of a friend gets into it.  We tease him.  We call him "the
raver."  He tries to tell us, but we won't hear.  He tries to play
mixtapes for us, but it's just crashing noise to me - and much too loud. 
He finally convinces us one night to come out to a party.  We drive up in
two cars to the mappoint on Melrose.  The street is swarming with hundreds
of very trendy young teenagers.  Two try to sell us X as we sit in the
car.  I'm pretty turned off at this point and feeling justified in my 
anti-rave/techno prejudice, and when we find out the ticket is $20, we say 
fuck it and leave.

I didn't know then not to swallow the lies of the media.  I didn't know 
to approach everything with an open mind and heart and welcome what it 
may teach me.  I didn't know to how to create my own good time and 
contribute to the vibe, rather than having a "show me" attitude.  These 
lessons I would partially learn in the rave scene, but unfortunately, not 
for another few years.

supposedly it's better on drugs but I think either way it's pretty neat :)

In a message dated 97-06-06 22:41:56 EDT, you write:

 cya, N
 We went to the Starlight until 1:30 am. Then we went to the Trocadero until
it closed at 3:00am. Bondage A Go Go night!  Missed the Thrill Kill concert
but I heard it was packed and 100 degrees inside. Concert was good I was told
but very uncomfortable. 

We got to 1015 Folsom at 3:15am and it was packed. It was basically the same
format as Release on Saturday night. They only had two rooms going instead of
the five that Release has. Music was pretty much the same techno hip hop as
Release. Based on my limited experience the best combo pack in town on a
Saturday is DNA until midnight and then Release. I have yet to go to my first
Rave. I am hoping to go to the one in Santa Cruz this weekend. I am meeting
with Adam on Saturday to check out lighting for my own in home Raves. I have
an 8,000 sq ft house with a killer sound system ... ideal for small
gatherings of about 50 East Bayers.

I personally don't find jungle that hard to mix; the stuff i've heard tends
to be a lot of slam/cut-mixing, as opposed to smooth fade mixing like you
hear w/ the best house DJ's. Maybe I haven't heard enough jungle DJ's, but
it seems like jungle is too "busy" when it's off chattering away to do a
long-slow mix. Usually there's a nice convenient intro/outro section of
most jungle tracks that is at 80BPM, then it launches into the 160BPM
chatter that sounds like you're fast-forwarding a CD... seems like the 80
BPM slow part is where people do the mix. Agree?? Disagree??

I'm not dissing Jungle -- it's just that I don't think it's that good to
dance to.

I noticed a while back that someone posted a tracklist of a DJ Dan tape
that included Bahia BLack's "Capitao do Aspholto" -- what I want to know is
how da hell he managed to mix in that highly syncopated track (brazilian
stylee) with other "dance tempo" choons.

PS: I'm Still in Bangalore India, where there doesn't seem to be much of
any kind of a scene at all, unless you count the car horns honking all
day/night and stifling snarl of constant traffic. And bars blasting
wretched top-100 "dance music"... This is the fastest growing city in all
of asia and all i can say is that "progress" ain't all that it's cracked up
to be. It would be nice to go find some rave in Goa, but nooo... here I am
on the other side of the world, and I even have to work saturdays (it's
saturday 10AM right now, even though it's friday night for you
all...). What, me frustrated?? Never!

PPS: I'm now playing the Josh/Simon tape of that 6-part
Malachy/Come/Unity benefit party at the richmond civic back in '93 --
and I have to say, this "classic" stuff seriously kicks ass over all
the newfangled tunes coming out nowadays. Best $25.00 I ever spent on 6
tapes!

When I was an RA at UCDavis, a group of my residents tried this out and 
claimed some odd relationships between the musical passages and parts of 
the film... the story goes something like this:
you put on T.W.o.Oz and start the PF rekkid at just the right moment and 
badda-bing!  There are these strange spots that happen to line up, like 
theres a shot of a bell ringing just as these bells start chiming on the 
rekkid and stuff like that...
I couldn't really stomach the thought of listening to two straight hours 
of Pink Floyd so I didn't try it myself...

On Fri, 6 Jun 1997, Jonathan Golub wrote:

> On a more general note, anyone who wants to understand the possibilities of
> jungle mixing should check out any of the "Drum and Bass Selection"
> compilation series on Moonshine, especially #4 - a continuous mix by DJ
> Hype.  Hype incorporates scratching, double copies, phasing and all kinds
> of tricks into an exceptionally smooth mix.  I've never heard another
> jungle DJ come close.
> 

There's a group of Jungle DJs down here in SoCal land that call 
themselves the 119 guys or something like that.. They do all the 
scratching and double copies and phasing stuff, too.  Plus they are 
underground local-type folks.

From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: Jungle...
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706070005.A28913-0100000@netcom10>

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I recall back in like 1994 when it seemd to me that there were all these 
kids going out and buying turntables and a box of GOA rekkids and BAMMO!  
they were DJs!  They didn't know anything about the music, the scene, how 
to fix their decks... BUT they were superstar DJs with that cool muzic 
that everyone wanted to hear.
I think that Jungle is rapidly becoming to 1997 what GOA was to 1994.  
Today everyone wants to be a junglist!  It's the cool new trend!  
Meanwhile the old skool jungle DJs just keep on spinnin.  
Who knows, maybe someday the cool thing will be breakbeat!  How happy 
would I be?!

At 01:17 PM 6/6/97 -0400, you wrote:
>Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
>Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
>Content-Description: cc:Mail note part
>
>i'd like to get all the DJ's (and even those who just spin for whatever 
>reason!) opinions of this.
>do you think its easier to spin sumthin' with that 4/4 beat or breakbeats?? 
>(we'll include jungle w/breaks since a lot of jungle's beats are hard and 
>fast breakbeats)
>i'm just curious cuz i'm just starting to learn to spin and the first thing 
>i'm doin' when i get out to the bay area is gettin' me a pair of 1200s!! :)
>no, i'm not going to learn how to spin whatever easiest if that's what yur 
>thinkin! ;P 
>

        well, I've tried both because I wanted my style to develop from just
days of hunting around record stores trying to find what sounded good to me.
I tried mixing both 4/4 and jungle and breaks and basically, any 4/4 is very
much easier than the others. Some jungle is hard because being a little off
can really mess up the way the drums sound, while in trance it just makes
the bass drum fatter. Plus, most trance and house songs are pretty much self
contained, not a whole lot of mixing is necessary to keep it interesting.
That's what I think, anyways.

>since ive been bsing all this music theory ish...
>does anyone know a good URL For basic music theory? Im gonna do some hunting..
>but It seems like it would make all of us better if we understood the music
we enjoy.

        it's weird that you say that because I come from a musical
background, playing lots of jazz and learning theory. After 4 years of jazz
guitar, bass, and trombone, all of the theory became pretty natural. So when
I started spinning I was initially drawn to it because I thought the idea of
making music with other people's music was so odd. So I guess I have a
really weird take on techno, as I can't really apply too much music theory
to it, but lots of other concepts like intensity and 'tranciness' that
really isn't dealt with in normal musical theory. It fascinates me still
that so much is known about how to make trippy records but there isn't too
much that could really be discussed about it.

At 05:41 PM 6/6/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>Lessons learned too late

        It's weird that you say that, because I rememeber when I first went
to a rave in Santa Cruz, probably back around '92, I remember not
understanding a thing at all about what was going on. It took place on the
bottom story of a parking structure, and cost like $7. So I was a little
hesitant, and I remember just agonizing at the pounding beats which were
absolute torture to my punk ears at the time. I remember leaving very early.
Luckily a few years later I discovered the Full Moons and other raves that
came near Santa Cruz. I think one problem is that when I first heard techno
stuff back in '89 or so it really was a whole lot different than what we
have today. My friend spun a set for me and some friends of old techno and I
remembered a lot of the songs and they were quite cheesy compared to what we
have today. Except maybe for current happy hardcore. That's got to be the
pinnacle of cheesiness.

At 09:47 PM 6/6/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>I personally don't find jungle that hard to mix; the stuff i've heard tends
>to be a lot of slam/cut-mixing, as opposed to smooth fade mixing like you
>hear w/ the best house DJ's. Maybe I haven't heard enough jungle DJ's, but
>it seems like jungle is too "busy" when it's off chattering away to do a
>long-slow mix. Usually there's a nice convenient intro/outro section of
>most jungle tracks that is at 80BPM, then it launches into the 160BPM
>chatter that sounds like you're fast-forwarding a CD... seems like the 80
>BPM slow part is where people do the mix. Agree?? Disagree??

        Well, it really is meant to be danced to half-time. Although you can
speed it up when it gets too intense. But the beat of most jungle really is
half-time with lots of snare and bass going on to make it seem faster. But
listen to the bass lines and other stuff, it's usually quite slow(as opposed
to hardcore where they will actually speed up samples = helium divas)

>I'm not dissing Jungle -- it's just that I don't think it's that good to
>dance to.

        I'll agree that it isn't as easy to dance to. But not good to dance
to? hmm..

Precedence: bulk

I agree with Niels about the Come/Unity tape set.  As for jungle,
I've always thought it was pretty easy to mix, lots of things you
can do with the track structures -- it's more "open" than house
and less repetitive than a lot of techno and trance.  Layering
jungle tracks really adds punch to the mix if you get the right
ones.  Jungle's also the only style I ever use a cross-fader for
(unlike probably 90% of all DJs in my experience I just don't
use the crossfader).

phred

I'll be playing tonight (Saturday) at the Cyberbuss block party 
which is going to be at Griffith between Quesada and Revere (off
3rd near 3C---, er, Candlestick).  Event starts at 10 and goes
to 6, admission is $10 I believe.  B))merang will also be playing
there both with his band (Hear Are the Facts You Requested) and as
DJ I believe.  it sez here "The Cyberbuss will set the atmosphere
for many artistic groups and individuals who take absurdity
extremely seriously . . . the Costume Ball will be held in the
Industrial Bayview Warehouse District of San Francisco where a
spontaneous combustion of rhythm, chaos, mayhem, herd morality
and creativity will arise from the urban decay to form freaky
fairy-tale like harmony."  That and a buck will get you a ride
on the 91 Owl around the City... :)  But seriously, or not, 
I think the idea is to get dressed up and get down with a
diverse crowd, bands, DJs, videos (including one I really want
to see of the Portland Santacon), and so on.

The Cyberbuss crew are active with Burning Man and other such
stuff, and participated recently in the 
Defenestration event with the Cacaphony Society and so on.

Check it out: http://www.cyberbuss.com

I won't be playing any standard house or techno, but my one and
only Coil record is in the bag . . .

phred

E>What is the difference between white and yellow? Any preferances? Ennie
E>meenie minie mo?????

Well, white is generally accepted as a color representing purity,
cleanliness, a blank slate. White is the ultimate embodiment of the high
illumination levels of all colors on the visibile spectrum. True white
is compromised of all the colors in the light spectrum. True white can be
interpretted as having religious significance. Pure energy.

Yellow is not necessarily an aggression color, however it is a high
intensity color. If you're referring to H.I. Yellow (naturally). Or it can
be dull and energy-draining (darker, pale yellows) which function as
natural energy wells. Restaurants like McDonalds who use Yellow, Orange,
and Red theme colors do so because the presence of such high energy colors
has been proven scientifically to increase the customers desire to consume
food rapidly and leave quickly (thus allowing more customers to pass
through, thus more profit). Similar psychological effect as playing rock
music vs. say classical over dinner. Its Less filing vs. Tastes better.

PLUR!
Laurence =)

At 9:47 PM -0700 6/6/97, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
>I personally don't find jungle that hard to mix; the stuff i've heard tends
>to be a lot of slam/cut-mixing, as opposed to smooth fade mixing like you
>hear w/ the best house DJ's. Maybe I haven't heard enough jungle DJ's, but
>it seems like jungle is too "busy" when it's off chattering away to do a
>long-slow mix. Usually there's a nice convenient intro/outro section of
>most jungle tracks that is at 80BPM, then it launches into the 160BPM
>chatter that sounds like you're fast-forwarding a CD... seems like the 80
>BPM slow part is where people do the mix. Agree?? Disagree??
>

Not to toot my own horn, but Ind BOTh house and Jungle easy to mix.  It's
all beats anyway and in reality you can find 4/4 in jungle easily.  Now I
will not go so far as to say hat one is easier than the other.  It ismostly
a matter of having ones ear on enough to hear the overriding or underlying
rhythm patternand syncing up.  I have made at this point, zens of tapes
where I go from a straight house 4/4 to a trippy jungle tune.  Now
admittedly this cannot be done wi all records, but enough as to make it not
so difficult as people may think.  It's all (record mixing) a matter of
finesse moreso than anything.

Funny littel story, ther is one DJ who prides himself on his skills, and
talks about it quite a bit.  Anyway this house maven said he could mix
anything.  I asked him to get out of his house set and move it to jungle.
The resulting train wreckage and total lack of syncopation casued much
laughter.  Then this DJ dissed jungle and said all that was needed was 4/4
to the floor anyway.  Weakling I thought ;).  When given two jungle records
that are relatively easy to mix, the DJ couldn't do that either.  This is a
person who's been spinning for at least 5 years now and can really play
some serious grooves.

One of the things I cannot do is play like a hip-hop DJ.  Very physical,
very in touch with the actual vinyl, a master at the crossfader w/ quick
cuts.  I cannot do that, I doubt I have what it takes to do it...but I'm
learning.  Anyway I learned to mix jungle since I did not have the skills
to do otherwise.  My only choice was to mix, and mix jungle I can do quite
well.

Cool shit that you can do with jungle that house cannot and will probably
neve touch:
-Jungle sounds good at 160 bpm or 80 bpm.  Look at the range in tempo you
can work with!  This is what makes it emminently easy to mix with house
music.
-Jungle is far more complex rhythmically than house, as such you can really
work the rhythms alot more than you can house.
-The emotional content in jungle is quite real.  In house, it is all a
setup.  There is an intensity to jungle that cannot be denied.  Perhaps due
to it's street origins.  You can work moods in more varied forms in jungle
than you can house.
-The music is just plain trippier.  House is just plain predictable.

House music has just stalled out.  There aren;t many good records, and the
beats, much like plenty of hip-hop sound very recycled and very little
innovation or pushing-up seems to be going on in house.  Lay down a 4/4,
hi-hat at appropriate places, a kick drum for punch, and you've got a
track.  A simple melody as theme, repeat, build, crescendo, resolution with
theme....The music was better a while back.


>I'm not dissing Jungle -- it's just that I don't think it's that good to
>dance to.

Agreed, but it is good to:
-Cure glaucoma by (read 420).
-Drink by.
-Socialize to.
-Most importantly, listen to!
-Dance to?  Well, only if it's the "right" jungle music.

House music all night long?  Nope, house music for the first 3/4, the rest,
I want to chill out with some trippy intelligent jungle.  Photek, Goldie,
Rabbit In The Moon, A Man Called Adam, A Guy Called Gerald, Decoder...now
that's innovative.

Just my .02,
John

Maybe wrong to you. But..

 To me. My spirit. And my soul...
 It is WAY easier. I can (and have) mixed jungle flawlessly "without"
headphones on.. =] And I have even matched jungle beats without headphones
on (call it luck? partially).
 For one. I have a talent for "predicting" music. But... Who needs it when
you can read between the grooves on the record?

 It's kind of cheesy but.. What I meant by it being easier.. For
like..People just starting out on the tables (like me)  With jungle.. You
can cheat (lack of better words)!
 Ok...You have one record playing a phat beat right. You see signs from the
grooves in the record that..There is an ambient part coming up without any
drums. You can see it on the record it self right.
 So all you do is.. Get another record. Adjust your tempo to desired
tastes.. And! It's this simple. Just time it. Start fading in an ambient
section of your second record with enough time left to where your first
record is going to break into it's ambient part before your second record
comes in with the drums.
 Make sence? And it sounds grrrreat!
 I don't know. All I know is that.. I want to be a great jungle DJ. And I
have the power within my own selfcomfidence to do it.
 But I was far from wrong stating that jungle can be alot easier to mix. =]

Jeff

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jun  7 13:04:05 1997

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk

A while ago an old skooler complained(bragged?) about Raves not being 
what they used to be. And maybe that is true and maybe it isnt. Times 
change and so do peoples perceptions.

But what if they have? What if we keep recycling old ideas. Something 
Really Works so we bring that to the next production. Ad Infinitum.
The only thing that gets changed(religiously thank god) is the themes.

Anyway, it may be time to look to outside productions for new influences 
and 'fresh' ideas. Tonite is the CyberBus Ball, today and tomorrow is 
The "X" games at Pier 39. All summer long are Fairs and festivals. If 
you really cant live without Rave mussic maybe bring along a walkman. In 
fact a walkman might be a requirement. Sorta a filter. Like on a camera. 
"what does this picture look like with a filter?, how bout without?"

You could be standing at a dime toss at the fair, looking at the kooks 
trying to make a tv show out of dangerous sports, or watching people 
walk into the opera. Somewhere the idea that will freshen up the rave 
scene as we now know it will hit you! Hell even if all you get is a new 
idea for a prop, than your time was worth it.

Keep an eye out and dont be afraid to post what you see!

In-Reply-To: <v03102800afbedd323475@[205.162.25.57]> from "John S. Lee" at Jun 7, 97 10:07:32 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Warning!  Fairly long rant n' rave below.

While I agree with the broad sweep of John Lee's post, there's definitely 
a (IMHO) sense of generalisation.

> -The emotional content in jungle is quite real.  In house, it is all a
> setup.

Hmmmm...all records have to have emotional 'setup', no matter what the style.
The emotion isn't in the record, it's in you...it how you perceive the
record and how it affects you.  I've got some (what I consider) very
emotional house records...but they might just be emotional to me.   Then
again, I've also got some jungle records that have the same effect...
the knot in my gut/ache in my heart/throw me clear across the room
feeling I get every time I hear them (well, that's what it feels like to
me).

> There is an intensity to jungle that cannot be denied.
True...but again there can be an intensity to *all* forms of music.  Personally
I'm a huge Van Morrison fan (especially his old stuff) and I find his
music incredibly intense...it's more lyrically intense, but still... 

> Perhaps due
> to it's street origins.  You can work moods in more varied forms in jungle
> than you can house.

I really dislike this term 'street' when applied to music...all, *all*, all
music starts in the 'street'.  All of it.  Different people in different
places with different experiences and different ways of expressing that.
Music is fundamental to the soul (I know that's a sample from something, 
but I can't remember what).  If people creating new forms of music somehow
based on their experiences and emotions from their "environments" (for
want of a better word), isn't street, I don't know what is.  House may
have long ago become too popular to be really considered underground,
(especially compard to jungle), but jungle's going the same way.  In England
at Christmas there were already TV adverts with jungle soundtracks.  Does
this mean jungle is no longer street?

> -The music is just plain trippier.  House is just plain predictable.

BAD House music is predictable.  Bad Jungle is predictable.  Bad techno
is bloody predictable.  If, as you describe below, there's is no invention
in a record, no spark of creativity, then yes, it's going to be predictable.
This happens more and more as a type of music becomes popular.  The more
house/jungle records that are put out, the more likely it is that something
has already been done, and the harder it gets to put something truly
original out.  But, truly original stuff does still come out, it just
get harder to find.

> House music has just stalled out.  There aren;t many good records, and the
> beats, much like plenty of hip-hop sound very recycled and very little
> innovation or pushing-up seems to be going on in house.  Lay down a 4/4,
> hi-hat at appropriate places, a kick drum for punch, and you've got a
> track.  A simple melody as theme, repeat, build, crescendo, resolution with
> theme....The music was better a while back.
> 
There are plenty of good records out there, if not more than there
used to be.  BUT, there's even more really, really bad records out there,
which, as you say,  are totally recycled and not very interesting.
You say the music was better a while back, implying (as I understand it)
more variation in the music, but I believe part of the problem also
lies in people's classification of music having narrowed a lot more.

There was a post a couple of days ago about SF jungle dj's and what style 
they play.  There were (like) 10 different styles (most of which I know
nothing about)..and this is in jungle which hasn't really been around that
long.  For things to splinter so quickly is not a good thing.  Same with
all of it - garage, house, euro, hardcore, happy hardcore, trance, gabber and
on, and on, and on....One thing I really miss is Dj's playing ALL sorts of
records in a set...nowadays, it seems you get one type of music and one
type only from a dj/rave/club.  There's very little variety.  You may have a house room/jungle room etc...but why not have it all in one room?  If the scene
*is* about unity (supposedly) then why not have a night where the music starts
(say) with old disco/salsoul and gradually moves on to house, then techno
then jungle, then whatever AND THEN BACK AGAIN.  It all goes round..you
can trace the evolution of music and that is what I like to hear and I 
consider a really good dj to be one who can do that.  Who understands the
flow.  Who can teach about where it's coming from, where it's been and where
it's going (and usually as an extension where I'm coming from/been/going).
 Mixing is a bonus, but really *not* necessary (is that heresy?)


> House music all night long?  Nope, house music for the first 3/4, the rest,
> I want to chill out with some trippy intelligent jungle.  Photek, Goldie,
> Rabbit In The Moon, A Man Called Adam, A Guy Called Gerald, Decoder...now
> that's innovative.

Exactly my point.  In the beginning there was house? Nope, in the beginning
there was the blues (if you have to draw a line somewhere...)

> Just my .02,
> John

And just mine, hope I didn't bore.
All comments appreciated,
Cheers,
Neil
neil@nit.airtouch.com

I just wanted to clarify some things, if I may.

At 1:18 PM -0700 6/7/97, Neil Palmer wrote:
>Warning!  Fairly long rant n' rave below.
>
>While I agree with the broad sweep of John Lee's post, there's definitely
>a (IMHO) sense of generalisation.
>
>> -The emotional content in jungle is quite real.  In house, it is all a
>> setup.
>
>Hmmmm...all records have to have emotional 'setup', no matter what the style.
>The emotion isn't in the record, it's in you...it how you perceive the
>record and how it affects you.  I've got some (what I consider) very
>emotional house records...but they might just be emotional to me.   Then
>again, I've also got some jungle records that have the same effect...
>the knot in my gut/ache in my heart/throw me clear across the room
>feeling I get every time I hear them (well, that's what it feels like to
>me).

The purpose of my original statement was to show a tangible distinction
betwen the two styles.  Emotional content CAn be subjective, but my point
was some is more tangible than others.  For instance, the difference
between Anita Baker and Whitney Houston, or Fresh Prince/Hammer and Public
Enemy.  Jungle to me is like PE, or Anita Baker.  House, IMO, has become
very, very star searchish and formulaic.  I understand that many thigns
follow a formula, the big thing is are you expecting it, or does it suprise
you.


>
>> There is an intensity to jungle that cannot be denied.
>True...but again there can be an intensity to *all* forms of music.
>Personally
>I'm a huge Van Morrison fan (especially his old stuff) and I find his
>music incredibly intense...it's more lyrically intense, but still...
>
>> Perhaps due
>> to it's street origins.  You can work moods in more varied forms in jungle
>> than you can house.
>
>I really dislike this term 'street' when applied to music...all, *all*, all
>music starts in the 'street'.  All of it.

This is not true.  All music may have it's origins there, but often music
is manufactured in people's bedrooms, in deluxe studios, etc.  Alot of
people aren't from the street at all, and it shows in their music.  I would
even correct you to say that music doesn't start in the street but in
villages.  But were' getting into minutae of semantics.  We both beleive
the same thing at the core, I'm certain.

>Different people in different
>places with different experiences and different ways of expressing that.
>Music is fundamental to the soul (I know that's a sample from something,
>but I can't remember what).  If people creating new forms of music somehow
>based on their experiences and emotions from their "environments" (for
>want of a better word), isn't street, I don't know what is.

When I say street what I'm talking about is people's interaction with
others and presenting that interaction or observation.  If you never leave
your house what kind of street sensibility does one have anyway?  I think
of street as raw.  And that is the definition, many share (from what I've
read and experienced).

>House may
>have long ago become too popular to be really considered underground,
>(especially compard to jungle), but jungle's going the same way.  In England
>at Christmas there were already TV adverts with jungle soundtracks.  Does
>this mean jungle is no longer street?

Perhaps.  Just like hip-hop, which is harder to find these days, or at
least the good stuff, it became marginalized and sanitzed as soon as
everyone started weraring their baseball caps backwards and trying to, er
act, for lack of a better word, "urban" (read black/latino).

Just because it had street origins is no gurantee of purity.  As a matter
of fact one might say that the closer to the street some music is, the more
apt is is to change.  Much like the verbiage of street lingo changes
rapidly, so would the music.  Hip-hops beginnings tell us this.

>
>> -The music is just plain trippier.  House is just plain predictable.
>
>BAD House music is predictable.  Bad Jungle is predictable.  Bad techno
>is bloody predictable.  If, as you describe below, there's is no invention
>in a record, no spark of creativity, then yes, it's going to be predictable.
>This happens more and more as a type of music becomes popular.  The more
>house/jungle records that are put out, the more likely it is that something
>has already been done, and the harder it gets to put something truly
>original out.  But, truly original stuff does still come out, it just
>get harder to find.

I hark back to a time when there was wuality oover quantity.  The more
house music has been manufactured, the more it sounds the same.  I guess
it's a natural side effect, albeit distasteful. ;)

>
>> House music has just stalled out.  There aren;t many good records, and the
>> beats, much like plenty of hip-hop sound very recycled and very little
>> innovation or pushing-up seems to be going on in house.  Lay down a 4/4,
>> hi-hat at appropriate places, a kick drum for punch, and you've got a
>> track.  A simple melody as theme, repeat, build, crescendo, resolution with
>> theme....The music was better a while back.
>>
>There are plenty of good records out there, if not more than there
>used to be.

This is as subjective as the weather.  I hear complaints from the more
experienced that the pickings are few far more than there is an abundance
of good dance music.  It could be the negative always gets to the top, but
in house music, I don't think we can rely on this paradigm since DJ's want
you to know they have the bomb tracks more often than not.

>BUT, there's even more really, really bad records out there,
>which, as you say,  are totally recycled and not very interesting.
>You say the music was better a while back, implying (as I understand it)
>more variation in the music, but I believe part of the problem also
>lies in people's classification of music having narrowed a lot more.

Agreed.

<snip>

>> House music all night long?  Nope, house music for the first 3/4, the rest,
>> I want to chill out with some trippy intelligent jungle.  Photek, Goldie,
>> Rabbit In The Moon, A Man Called Adam, A Guy Called Gerald, Decoder...now
>> that's innovative.
>
>Exactly my point.  In the beginning there was house? Nope, in the beginning
>there was the blues (if you have to draw a line somewhere...)
>

No, in the beginning there was the drum.  Then man talked with the drum and
the drum answered.  The rest is history.


>> Just my .02,
>> John
>
>And just mine, hope I didn't bore.
>All comments appreciated,
>Cheers,
>Neil
>neil@nit.airtouch.com

Be safe,
John

"Inner city life, inner city pressure..."

Precedence: bulk

At 05:11 PM 6/7/97 PDT, you wrote:
>
>Yeah... This method works, and I admit I have used it a couple of times 
>myself to get out of a jam.....
>BUT
>
>You can't take the shortcut all the time...   
>What kicks ass is when you can bring in something during the ambient 
>part, and have it match when the beat comes back...
>Then you have SKILLS

        Really? This seems to be rather easy for me. A method taught to me
by DJ Flight from LA who just moved into our house here taught me a really
easy way to beatmatch, although it takes a while to get used to. I am pretty
sure it is the way most DJ's beat match but I haven't really heard people
talking about it on here.

        What I do is I while I have one record going I catch the 'one' beat
of the other, just like normal. If the 'one' beat does not happen to have
drums going, it can still be found, even in the ambient parts of jungle
songs(I mix jungle btw). I then listen for the phrase beginning on the
record playing, start running back and forth over the beat in time and
listening on my headphones. Then I let it go, but keep my finger on it near
the center(I never touch anywhere else on the record, just as far away from
the label I can go with out touching the grooves, even when scratching) to
keep the tempo aligned. This is the tricky part. you just have to get the
phrases to match up if there is no beat, but with a beat it's much easier.
Sometimes I'll cue up both into the headphones to help me do this. I use my
other hand to then slide the fader around until I feel like I no longer need
to give it any pressure to keep it going the right speed. This is the way I
do it know and it seems much easier after getting used to it. I can usually
beatmatch most of my favorite records in seconds, and maybe 30 seconds or so
if I am not sure on the tempo.

        -chris

Well I thought I would write about this shindig...

Saturday was simply a beautiful day.  I'd like to thank all that came.  I'd
say about 130-140 people were there maybe more, but I couldn't tell with
all that sun and evil beverages! ;)

Looks like we sold some discount tickets and gave out some free tapes.
Thanks to those that supported the camp out.  Don't worry folks you'll get
another chance to get discount tickets in the near future just keep your
ears and eyes open...Thanks Pao for the great work you did on the discount
tickets. =)

James: You the man!  That was the wackiest day set.  It went well with the vibe.
Sir_nod: Very nice breaks and did I hear trance? =)
Macadio: Well this was my first time hearing you.  Smooth mixing.
Micron: Smooth set.  Bouncing golf ball head went well with the melodies. ;)
Bio_Jeff: Nice set my friend, smooth as usual.  Nice progressive trance/house.
Siphon: ?

In any case the music was right on.  The vibe was right on.  The weather
was right on.  Hell this was a Dope party.  We even got out of there on
time.  The whole day went really well and we couldn't have done it with out
those that came and supported us, thanks.

Only one problem me and Tim were talking about; the BBQ pit is never being
left behind.  We really missed not having the pit there.  So next time we
will have the BBQ pit.  Sorry to those folks who brought food I hope it
didn't spoil.

It was good to see all those bright faces smiling and having a good time.
Thanks to those that stayed and helped clean-up and tear-down.  Take care
and keep a look out for our next shindig.

U h _ B u _ B y e !

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 8 Jun 1997 08:53:24 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: noah@cadence.com (Noah 'Siphon' Ruiz)
Subject: Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

All this talk about how simple it all is, and I haven't seen any signs of
programming.  Sure you can drop anything at the break_down of a song.  You
could use two break_downs and be really cheesy.

I'd like to say that mixing is more than beat_matching...

Beat_matching is essential to the process, but its not all that can be
done.  There is so many different things you can do.  And one of the most
important ones is getting the songs that compliment each other.  Learn to
program.  Get your phrases dialed in.  Know your measures you are at before
you drop the cued record in.  KNOW YOUR RECORDS!  If you find yourself
mixing to fast slow down be patient.  Don't rush the mix.  It all goes hand
in hand.  Then you can work on your own style.  Don't cheat the learning
process.  You need a concrete base before you start building.

Just my thought of the day.  And this goes for all styles of music...

Take care,


   S       i       p       h       o       n
________________________________________________
http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Alley/7995
____Should vegetarians eat animal crackers?_____

At 1:12 PM -0700 6/7/97, Blue Light Homeowners Association wrote:
>A while ago an old skooler complained(bragged?) about Raves not being
>what they used to be. And maybe that is true and maybe it isnt. Times
>change and so do peoples perceptions.
>

I hate damn old-skoolers.  They piss me off too.  All that talk about how
they used to do it, and all week long.  How the people were better, and the
moment was better, and the additives were better.  I wish they would either
get outside more often to some real digs, or just stay home and leave the
rest of us to have a good itme.  That's what I say! ;)


>But what if they have? What if we keep recycling old ideas. Something
>Really Works so we bring that to the next production. Ad Infinitum.
>The only thing that gets changed(religiously thank god) is the themes.
>
>Anyway, it may be time to look to outside productions for new influences
>and 'fresh' ideas. Tonite is the CyberBus Ball, today and tomorrow is
>The "X" games at Pier 39. All summer long are Fairs and festivals. If
>you really cant live without Rave mussic maybe bring along a walkman. In
>fact a walkman might be a requirement. Sorta a filter. Like on a camera.
>"what does this picture look like with a filter?, how bout without?"

May I offer another suggestion.  For all of those who can't do w/o
house/rave/whatever music MORE POWER TO YA!  Now all you gotta do is start
a party and keep it going.  Music all night and day long!  A walkman?  I
dunno, just another means to set yourself apart from a potential group
exeprience.  Unless of course everyone's wearing them, then it's a shared
experience of a different nature.

>
>You could be standing at a dime toss at the fair, looking at the kooks
>trying to make a tv show out of dangerous sports, or watching people
>walk into the opera. Somewhere the idea that will freshen up the rave
>scene as we now know it will hit you! Hell even if all you get is a new
>idea for a prop, than your time was worth it.
>
>Keep an eye out and dont be afraid to post what you see!

Peace,
John

Basics 5-year family reunion was incredible last night.  
For all of you that showed up I hope you guys had a wonderful time.  A
little stuffy inside the locale though, but the fans on the side helped out
a lot.

Andre Lucero started things up with some good tracks

Mark E. Quark played some tunes that took the crowd into second gear

Carlos- no explanation needed! Good to see him again.

Tony- This man is tops, and like no other.  He is able to take many people
to the higher level, and gets my vote this year for the "dj's that dance"
award, next to Carlos!  :-P 
Someone i.d. his track (kinda old) that goes, "What is house music? It's a
unique form, a unique form of music"  

Spun- Always has the jammin' tunes...

Josh- missed his set! :-(

Hi to: Dorena, Josh_E_Josh, Jondabomb (thanx for dj printouts n' stuff,
man), and to all others on this list that I missed.  I chilled to the right
of the dj's at the table most of the night w/ watermelons and the rest of
the mad mad people, and energy.

Finally, isn't it neat to check out people groovin'? Everyone has their own
unique style, move, and grace.  Everyone's dance says a little something
about them, and what they're like, am I correct?  

Tired Mr. E, goodnight!

Uncle Noah Eloquently Stated:
> Today everyone wants to be a junglist!  It's the cool new trend!  
> Meanwhile the old skool jungle DJs just keep on spinnin.  
> Who knows, maybe someday the cool thing will be breakbeat!  How happy 
> would I be?!
> 

Um... I thought breakbeat WAS the 'cool thing'.  Prodigy, Chemical Bros,
DJ Dan, etc.  Jungle gets a lot of respect right now, but I've seen a lot
of good jungle DJs play to empty rooms, or to chill rooms that might not
really need a good dose of hella dark techstep (I never know who to blame
for this... should the DJ change their style to the environment, or should
the promoter be open minded enough to book harder jungle DJs in the main
room... I dunno).  Not all jungle is out of sorts in a chill room... I
love to hear Bukem'ish stuff, or live D&B in the vein of what C-Lab or
Protolab have been doing lately...

Regardless of what current tastes are, I maintain a lot of respect for
those people who have something to say with their music thats bigger than
style or the latest trend.  A tip of the hat to people who spin out the
music they LOVE.

Even if it is breakbeat...

 ;)

AndyW

Whats up mr. Andy W!

	this is a pretty interesting thread.  I have run into this question a few times recently.

Jungle may be a current novelty, but will it EVER reach a main stage appreciation?

In thinking, I realize this may sound a little pessimistic, but I dont think it will.  Complex syncopations dont suit it for a front-and-center size appreciation in the raving community
(no matter now many times I dance to it ;)  I mean, maybe the next year (maybe even the next month) can prove me different, but as far as im concerned, we can just let people find their
own ways to the jungle. No need to bring the jungle to them, let it stay in the side room and the back alley for full appreciation by those who love it.

early morning words
alex<meeks>   

----------

i managed to trick my long time raving partner, who has been dormant the 
past 9 months to make a drive out to pt. molate.

now seeing as how he complains and always blames busted or bum parties 
on me (( i do love him though ) in a platonic way Byroni ) i opted to 
get there first and then get refreshments later....

the beats cru was there as promised amidst a guy who was building  a tee 
pee plus some friendly raver type  kids and stuff.

a dj was spinning, who i later found out to be Don associated with the 
cloud factory, some funky break type acid house type trance ( i hate 
labels ) basically he was ginvin' it what he's got and it was very 
enjoyable.  i was one of the few dance junkies, but then again i got 
there really rilly early.
 
later i met some really cool listers such as siphon and drenalin i also 
met  some nice three letered persons named ian and mia

i had an altogether great time for the limited time i was there....keep 
it goin' on beats cru.....i'm already packing for the big campout.  i 
got my glowing "lost world" watch soes i knows what time is it? my 
expatriated so-cal raves necklace and matching rubber gloves, a tent 
,some warm balnkets and a sack '0 green jeans......i think i'm 
ready......any suggestions.

i was told that posting once a week won't get you noticed, but intend to 
revert that statement. ....this is jonas joaquin robledo aka jake loco 
and i'm not stopping anytime soon......    :) for you and you and you 
over there looking oh so attractive.

>DJ Dan, etc.  Jungle gets a lot of respect right now, but I've seen a lot

>really need a good dose of hella dark techstep (I never know who to blame
>for this... should the DJ change their style to the environment, or should
>the promoter be open minded enough to book harder jungle DJs in the main

>Protolab have been doing lately...

Uncle Noah & AndyW:

Here here.  I also think that Jungle will probably never take off the way
that house music has here in this country.  I dunno why, but there still
doesn't seem to be the plethora of clubs that play this style, coupled with
jungles apparent non danceableness, I think it's safe to say it will
probably remain UG.  I certainly hope so.

Another item you might want to remember is that people are probably just
starting to come out of the closet moreso than everyone wanting to be a
junglist.  At least that is the case with me.  I have been buying jungle,
selectively, for 2 years, and I've said nary a word about it until
recently. Why?  I dunno.  Could be that the people I hang around don't
respect the music much to appreciate it, so I've become a closet collector.
Couple this with the fact that I've heard people spin the most 1
dimensional jungle/drums & bass sets that I see little need in hyping a
style that seems to have plenty of imitators and few innovators.

Also being on somewhat of a fringe it allows me to collect some of the
better cuts w/o everyone bum rushing to get the latest track.  It's nice
that the jungle/drums&bass community is smaller than the house scene, at
least to me.  And thus I want to guard against a bum rush of new-junglist
so that I can get my choons first.  Yep, I'm like that sometimes...anyway
just an alternate explantion or at least my .02.

Much peace,
John

Solid Grooves will match any price and they have some good stuff. You
might want to stick to the standard AT flight case those are pretty
cheap. I got my big old "shiny metal" one for $140 but you can't get
them for that price any more they are more like $200 now  :-(  But if
you dont want to get a box (which I reccomend only if your traveling)
then get these new PRythm bags that are so good. They hold more rekkid
then the Technics bags, they cost about $10 more but worth it. I am
getting one but they are backstocked so you have to get on a kind of
waiting list.

Macadio

I First want to start out by thanking Tim and the crew that help
setup/put on/bring out side for saturday. It was great good sound and
monitor. Next I wanted to thank everyone that came out it was a nice
sunny day but one thing I did not anticapate was the wind. I show up
in shorts and T-shirt which BTW is rare for my skinny ass   :P~ but I
did thinking it would be hot it was very windy and kind of cold but
real nice day. O another thing I sure was hungry and no-one bought any
food.  :-(  Tim had made a comment about wanting to be doing something
like BBQ'ing but do to the finances that was not possible I sure
wished some rave persons would have brought some vitals. But I guess I
should have eaten before coming and should have gotten up earler to
get there in plenty of time instead of 2 minutes before my set. Sorry
for the babbbling. It was a good party on a good day with a good
Crew/DJ's/Vibe/People
BTW I found my missing CD it was in my car.

Love,
Macadio

Hey y'all

I wanted to announce that I just finished my new mixtape:

	MUDFOOT MEETS THE DRAGON
	    -Deadly Drum and Bass-

96 minutes of new school jungle beats, from jump-up to weird experimental
darkstep and everywhere in between... including a couple of classics and
some fat white labels... here's the TRACK LISTING!

1
Flames of the Dragon - Lee "Scratch" Perry - Trojan
Show Me Whatcha Got - School of Hard Knocks - Area 51
12:00 Drive By - Forces of Nature - Beeswax
Punks - A-sides - Strictly Underground
??? - Bizzy B test pressing
Clear My Throat - Bizzy B - Joker
Bounce - LBC - Collusion
Sample Warfare - Master AK - Menace
Sweet Vibrations - Prisoners of Technology - Fresh Kutt 01
??? - Promo 11
Immortal - Zenith - Frontline
Survival of the Fit - Dream Team - Joker

2
International - MTS - Juice
Your Sound - J.Majik - Razor's Edge
??? - Promo 10
??? - Source Direct 06
Slamfunk - John B. - Formation
Brief Relapse - Kriss FM - Future Tense 01
??? - Indica's Rhythm - Splash
??? - Grooverider - Razor's Edge
Metropolis - Adam F - Metalheadz
Dub Plate Pressure -Mystical Influence -  Syn01
Da Nine Seven - Tommy Ill - Pimp 01
Activate - Nino Brown - Phat Trax 01

I worked really hard on this tape, and I had it professionally duplicated
on chrome tapes, so the sound quality is great, and I've gotten a great
response from everyone who's listened to it so far.  The price is $10
direct from me,  and I'll mail it anywhere for the price of postage.  Email
me for more info!

Thanks
Jonathan

P.S. You can also buy it in SF at Zebra, Housewares, Dropbeat, BPO, or the
Trance and Jungle Factory.

Subject: A BBQ & BEATS thank you
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I'd like to thank everyone that came out on Saturday to BEATS. It was
a great day with great music and people. I'd also like to thank the crew
for doing a great job with this event also, without there help this event
wouldn't have happened. Another thank you goes out to those that donated. I
hope you enjoy the mixtape, and I'll also be letting everyone that has the
discount ticket know how, when and where to use it when the tickets for the
campout are available.

One thing I will not do again, is not bring the BBQ.  Since we are trying
to save money for the campout, we named this event BEATS, because we were
not going to bring the BBQ. I did make a post to the list, but maybe should
have also put it on the VM too. Lesson learned.

Anyway, sorry for those that did bring food and expected the huge BBQ to be
there.  I will not throw another daytime event without it. I kinda felt
like there was something missing anyway.

If you weren't able to get the $5 discount ticket for the BBQ & BEATS
Campout and mixtape for donating $5, I'll be posting a message sometime
soon about how you can get one. The price of the Campout will be $10.

Again, I'd like to thank everyone that ventured out to spend there Saturday
with us.


Take care,


*****************************************************************
                         Tim (knucklehead)

  Knuckleheads Home Page:   http://www.club.net/~knucklehead
  BBQ & BEATS Home Page:  http://www.club.net/~knucklehead/BnB
*****************************************************************

greetings sfrave community. My name is Seamus Malone. I probably already 
know a few of you from NYC and maybe Chicago. I've been lurking a while 
evnying five dollar parties and all the outdoor venues.... eesh. Anyway, 
life in NY has turned into a fight for survival and i'm interested in 
doing something more than surviving. I haven't been able to settle here 
in three years because it just doesn't feel like home. westward-ho.

i'm a 29yr old multi-media producer, currently living in NYC originally 
from Michigan and Chicago. I was actually born half way between Chicago 
and Detroit and that's where i am musically, housey techno, techno-house. 

Anyway, I'm moving to San Francisco in July. Besides looking forward to 
meeting everyone, I'll go out on a limb and take everyone's word that sf 
is a lot more vibey scene and presume everyone will be anxious to help me :)

i'll be looking for an apartment in the city. any advise and or offers? 
input on neighborhoods etc. I've been loft-living for a long time, but 
could settle for a more central apt. I really don't want to be out of the 
city. A temporary roommate situation for a couple months or longer might 
be ideal while i sort out the city and where and how the best place for 
me to settle is. I do need space to set up my decks, a king size bed and I 
have two very sweet cats. I don't smoke and would prefer a non-smoker and 
absolutely can't live with a heavy smoker due to a pretty bad allergy to 
tobacco (err, i don't smoke anything much, but the allergy just 
seems to be to tobacco...)

i have a few freelance things lined up but i'll also be looking for web 
design work. i can direct anyone interested to a resume, samples, url, i 
won't take up bandwidth with all that. I am actually hoping not to jump 
right into a permanent job, so one thing i need is some idea how the 
freelance scene in sf works for multi-media. In chicago it was all 
through agencies, in NYC lately it's all been traffic on a few lists. 
I've found Craig's list, but it doesn't seem to have same role as WWWAC 
has in NY... am I missing the point? do i need to log onto another list?

PLUR
sm
(www.mediatekk.com/pure)

So many memories; where to start?

Liquid Air: at 24th & Ill, GGNRA, and that weird mud flat in Fremont. Small
parties with lots of vibe. ~'93

Happy Happy Joy Joy:  Ghost and Carlos goin off at secret studios on
Napoleon. I had a lot of fun working the door with my good friends Barry
and Dominic. '93-94

Carefree: No chance of this straight boy getting laid, but great music,
killer vibe, and no homophobes. ~'93

South Bay SFR lunches with Larry Ching, Bob Ramstad and many more. ~'93-94

Bulletproof opens up in '92 the first place in the Bay to get Phat rave
clothes.

All those Sunday raves in Golden Gate Park. The first place that I ever
heard of SFR.~'93

Dubtribe: at Cafe Bastile on New Years Eve, and in some warehouse. More fun
with maglights and doorshifts.~'93

Sir lrich Knight of the Turntables

"That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the cheif danger of the time."
                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

Hi.. I'd like to (sex) tell you about some weird psychological
phenomenon (sleep with me) that has been in the media forefront (I'm
your love slave) in the past few years. I'm talking about subliminal
suggestion. 

Subliminal suggestion (buy me a car) is a technique in which the
subconscious is made aware of a concept by having it exposed (and a
stereo) to them too fast or in a way the the conscious mind can pick
(you want me) up. Thus, the person so suggested (my room 8 tonite) finds
himself doing something that he ordinarily wouldn't do (bring clean
sheets). 

This technique was often seen being used (I'll get the champagne) in
movie theatres, where one frame of a film would have a message like "Buy
the popcorn." (and the cds). This one frame goes by so fast the the
conscious mind can't possibly assimilate it (I have incredible stamina),
but many believe that the subconscious picks it up and causes the mind
(I really want you) to act on it. 

Does it really (all night is not out of the question) work? Who knows...
(and we can bring the stuffed animals and the jello and do things
that they'll have to invent new names for when we're done and then we
can sleep for 3 hours and do it all again) The jury is still out on that
one. 

Thanks for your time and patience.

        that's not too crazy when you think about it. Most jungle songs
follow similar patterns. Usually they never lose the beat though, but
sometimes they through in extra measures of stuff(like most techstep)to
throw you off. Happy hardcore is the same way. Most of those songs have the
same length, same timing, and same things happening in the same general
areas(piano breaks, helium divas.) But it sure is fun!

Date: Mon, 9 Jun 1997 23:52:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: Uncle Noah visits Sandy Eggo
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>,
        Ravers in the Southland <socal-raves@ucsd.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706092319.A12300-0100000@netcom10>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Let me start off by saying the Rodtigo (rod) DeAlejandro, the Vice 
President of Mutual Administration (78 Port of Spain, Coronado, CA  92118 
vox619.575.3584 fax619.575.2568) gave me a business card at Forces of 
Nature and asked me to mention him, so there ya go toughguy!

This was a fun fun party!  I give it two tonearms up.

on with the review:
PARTY:  Forces of Nature
LOCATION:  Sandy Eggo Convention Center
WHEN: 6/7/97 9pm - 6/8/97 6am

SPACE:
The convention center is a confusing place to park at.  Also, be ready to 
shell out $4 (not mentioned on the info line).  I get my parking thing 
and it says "NO OVERNIGHT PARKING"  so I ask the dude what's up and he 
says, "Ah, nah it's okie dokie go ahead and park that Bug over there," he 
points into the lot.  I figure if someone want's to tow the Bug-O-Doom 
they're welcome to it.
Inside, they had part of the large hall partitioned with an air wall into 
two 'rooms' with a common back area where goodies like the snack bar and 
beer garden (yes kids, the beer garden) could be found.  I drank Snapple.
Plenty of room and pretty good acoustics for concrete floors and such.  
Not much bleed over from room to room either, unless you were standing 
right between them.  People kept milling about sweeping up candy wrappers 
and stuff so it looked fairly clean throughout the evening.

EYECANDY:
The decorations were pretty cool!  There needed to be more blacklights, 
though... some of those decorations seemd to be screaming for it!  The 
video stuff in the house/trance room was interesting but seemed to just 
be on a 5 minute continuous loop for most of the night.  Visuals in the 
Jungle room were fun, including nice snippets from the end of 2001: A 
Space Odyssey.

MUSIC:
-house/trace-
The kids seemed to be really getting into the groove here!  Some quality 
tracks and fun mixes (a few trainwrecks to bring in the morning, but hey 
what could I want!  I only spent $28 getting parked and in the door!  Who 
needs beatmatched mixes?  Anyway the thumpitty thum thump help you feel 
awake again after dancing all night!)

Now, I'm not trying to tell anyone what to do, but why does everyone have 
to spin CJ Bolland's "Sugar is Sweeter"?

DJ Icey got on the decks and opened with a really fun barrage of breaks, 
switching beats about every 8 counts or so... fun stuff rolling from 
groove to groove.  I feel this was the best part of his set.

I was under the impression that Juan Atkins was performing live, but I 
guess I misunderstood. :/  Ah well, maybe next time! :)

-jungle-
When Uncle Noah isn't listening to breaks, he like to hear the jungle.  
:)  I spent the first 20 minutes or so that I was there in the jungle 
room with my head just about as close to the speakers as I could get.  
It's fun to feel the bassline rumbling in your sinuses!!  yes yes yes 
jungle jungle jungle.  It's good stuff, kids, especially coming from a 
fine group of selecta's like they had there.

-MC's-
Jury's still out on my opinion here.  They were all really cool and very 
laid back.  I enjoied their vibe.  I liked hearing "Man what a phat 
track!" during a pause in the beats!  It made me feel all silly and 
happy.  But I don't really know if for me the MC's added or detracted 
from the tracks themselves...  this calls for more research.

SOUND SYSTEM:
Cerwin Vega.  The bassbins weren't big enough to climb into, and they 
were fenced off so no good speaker hugging opportunities, but it sounded 
very nice! :)

PEOPLE:
On the whole they were friendly!  I met a coule of folks that I've seen 
on the 'net and I met a few folks I had seen in photos from other 
parties, so that was fun.  Of course I got to visit with my Sandy Eggo 
raving family, which is always a big treat.

VIBE/CLOSING COMMENTS:
Good vibe, the energy seemed to go down a lot around 2:30-3am wich was 
kind of a bummer.  The jungle room cleared out pretty quick wich was too 
bad, but I kept bipping in to catch some groove.  

-bunky-
To those that like to selll bunky:  If someone wants to just feel speedy 
for a little while, they can take NoDoz.  If someone just wants a stomach 
ache and a littel speedy feeling, they can take Excedrin.  but if they are 
looking for MDMA, they probably don't want NoDoz or Excedrin.  Make sense?

This was a really cool party in a really fun and safe location.  Everyone 
seemd to get along well and the vibe was upbeat throughout the night!  
This party was 100% worth the drive down.

Subject: Karma Patrol Update

Hi everyone,

A number of people have expressed their interest in being part of a Karma
Patrol group ..... here's an update ...

i see this as being a group of people who make periodic commitments to be
part of a karma patrol team invited to be at parties .... checking on folks,
handing out water, candy and positive vibes .... and keeping an eye on those
who need a little help....

there would definitely be some sitting with people who are in a bad place
right then, and/or making sure their friends are with them, or checking if
they need medical attentin, etc...

The commitment is serious, not just a differnt way to hang out at
parties.... which is why no one will do it *all* the time ... if we have a
good core crew, then maybe 50% of the parties you go to ... or less if need
be...  Most important is the specific party where you're "on duty" as it were...

The logistics and style and methods are totally up to the group to decide,
and I know we can come up with ideas that work for everyone.  (and the name
is also not written in stone at all)

this is not what is being called the "Just Say Know" project, although we
would carry information about drugs that are to be given out as needed.

If i haven't already told you i have you on the list, pleaes send me an
email.  Rob Rayle has offered to host a meeting at his home in the east bay,
and I'm hoping to do it a week from Wednesday night (6/18 i think) ....
Dianna Greer has also offered to use her place, which we can do the next one
after that...

Please rsvp if you want to make this meeting ... we're also going to set up
a separate list for Karma Patrol courtesy of Steve Simitzis at Saturn5, so
we can keep our volume of messages off of SFRaves.

Love,

Leslie

	Tue, 10 Jun 1997 01:00:10 -0700 (PDT)
