	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id BAA19555
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 01:00:06 -0700 (PDT)
From: gaberramos@juno.com
Received: (from gaberramos@juno.com)
 by m18.boston.juno.com (queuemail) id DoC20641; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 03:59:59 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 00:56:54 -0700
Subject: Re: 4/4 VS. Breaks (in defence of house music)
Message-ID: <19970610.005654.3766.0.GabeRRamos@juno.com>
References: Your message of Fri, 06 Jun 1997 11:36:13 -0700
	<v03102800afbedd323475@[205.162.25.57]>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.38
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-5,7-19,28-32,39-48,60-61,66-67,69-81,92-95,99-102
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



>
>Not to toot my own horn
>

you started this tirade out by "tooting" your horn for about three
paragraphs.


>Cool shit that you can do with jungle that house cannot and will 
>probably
>neve touch:
>-Jungle sounds good at 160 bpm or 80 bpm.  Look at the range in tempo 
>you
>can work with!  This is what makes it emminently easy to mix with 
>house
>music.
>

jungle and house have a different rythmic structure.  house music has a
beat that is in sync with the high hat /congas etc.   Jungle on the other
hand has bass that is either half time or quarter time of the drums/high
hat/precussion.  When you say Jungle sounds good at 160 bpm or 80 bpm it
is because part of the song (the bass) is playing at 80 and part of the
song (the drum ) is playing at 160 bpm.  both of these are playing at the
same time. What you said still doesn't tell me how you are going to mix
this with a housebeat going at 120.  I would really like to hear jungle
playing at 120bpm. I don't think you will find alot of it.  


>Jungle is far more complex rhythmically than house

as I said house has precussion that is in sync (usually) with the
bassline.  I guess you could say it is more simple.  but whats wrong with
simple if people really GROOVE to it.   some of the most slammin songs
that i have heard are very minimal.  alot of house songs are designed to
be mixed and layered for a long time.  and if a song is too busy, it
might not always sound great with another song that has alot going on in
it,(even if they are on beat!)


>
-The emotional content in jungle is quite real.  In house, it is all a
>setup.  There is an intensity to jungle that cannot be denied.  
>Perhaps due
>to it's street origins.


i really wish you had more tact when you talk about other people's music.
  house music is fueled by emotion.  perhaps its not the emotions that
you are in touch with.  "House is a feelin' that no one can understand
unless they are deep in the vibe of House"  (thats from a song but it is
how I feel)   house is a dynamic vibe that is felt by and through people
getting down.  you see,  house music came from the gay/black/latino disco
scene from chicago and NY.    house music comes from the street.    the
emotions in house music are not about saddness or anger or fear.   House
music is an expression of love and joy.  do you think that it is easy
being gay and black in chicago?    House music was created by people that
would rather experience joy than dwell in the  sorrow of their everyday
existance.  

 Johnsin (sp?)  eluded to something like this  when he talked about
ravers trying to escape and drum and bass people "dealing with it."   
House people deal with thier problems away from the dancefloor.   in fact
house gives us the strength to keep on.  when there is no one there for
you you still have a home in house.

As for house music being  "all a setup", I really wish i understood
better what you meant by that, because i don't see it at all.


>-The music is just plain trippier.  House is just plain predictable.
>
>House music has just stalled out.  There aren;t many good records, and 
>the
>beats, much like plenty of hip-hop sound very recycled and very little
>innovation or pushing-up seems to be going on in house.  Lay down a 
>4/4,
>hi-hat at appropriate places, a kick drum for punch, and you've got a
>track. 

house and jungle have different structures and i will admit that jungle
sometimes is very experimental.  but there is house music out there that
is REALLY crazy.  Jungle is newer and there is alot of stuff that people
are hearing for the first time.  but as jungle grows in popularity alot
of it will get recycled.  this is true with house too.  the trick is to
buy the records that do push the edge. There are alot of house dj's and
finding records that really hit, can sometimes involve knowing when the
shipment is coming in. Maybe you have trouble finding good house records
but they are there.   house can in some instances be as simple as you
describe it in the above paragraph, but a good dj finds the records that
offer something else.  and blends them together creatively.

  House dj's invented mixing records.

everyone grooves on a different vibe.  so please don't diss what you
don't truly understand.   the only music that i diss is pop and that is
not because of the music, it is because of the MTV machine that feeds it
down peoples throat.

peace
gabe

Greetings Friends!

Here's the latest media release about the major International Drug 
Peace Rally in San Francisco on June 15th. Please help spread the 
good word!

Warm regards,

Julia Carter
Event Coordinator
International Drug Peace Rally

----------------------< Media Release >--------------------------

           ANNOUNCING THE INTERNATIONAL DRUG PEACE RALLY!
                      Sunday, June 15th, 1997
  
To celebrate Global Anti-Prohibition Day on June 15th, 1997, The 
Legalize! Initiative is sponsoring an International Drug Peace Rally 
in San Francisco that is being coordinated with anti-prohibition events 
in cities around the world including New York and Amsterdam. This major
event will be held from noon until 6pm at the Civic Center Plaza, which 
is located at the corner of Polk and Grove, and will feature widely-known
and respected speakers including:

John Perry Barlow, Marsha Rosenbaum, J. Tony Serra, Terence Hallinan,
Denis Peron, Chris Conrad, Dr. Eugene Schoenfeld, Dr. John Berisford, 
Leo Mercado, Elizabeth Gips and a number of other excellent speakers.

The International Drug Peace Rally will commence at noon with dance 
music from the Funky Nixons, followed at 12:30pm by a lively March for 
Drug Truce led by the Nomad Festival. Everyone is encouraged to show 
up for the March with white flags that symbolize our united quest for 
a truce in the Drug War. The speaking portion of the event is scheduled 
to begin at 1:15pm and will run until 6:00pm, including a Global
Meditation for Drug Peace at 4:20pm and The Haight Ashbury Experience 
with Elizabeth Gips at 5:10pm.  The Rally will also host a Rave Dance
Celebration from 1:30-5:30pm that will feature the well-known DJs Douglas
from CCC and DJ Tom from Koinonea spinning psychedelic trance music.  

Also of significant interest will be numerous information booths and
exhibits by organizations that support Peace in the Drug War.  This event 
is intended to be law-abiding and is free of charge to participants of 
all ages.  Just call the event hotline at (510) 412-1055 for further 
details or to leave a message.


******<  Join the International Drug Peace Rally on June 15th!  >******

Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 04:14:39 -0700 (PDT)
From: KNiGHTS TEMPLAR <madox@netcom.com>
Subject: My opinion of Basics.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706100404.A13938-0100000@netcom6>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

okay, so i havent been to a "real rave" in over a year. went to the 
chemical brothers thing, but i wouldnt call that a rave. so anyway, my 
girlfriend, some guy from holland and myself decided to go to basics. we 
got there at about 10:45pm, and noticed that hardly anyone was dancing. 
we also noticed that the dj was playing the same type of music. just 
plain old BOOM BOOM BOOM B00M.  thats it. just BOOM BOOM BOOM B00M.  
which is probably why no one was really dancing. also noticed that people 
were starting to sit in the middle of the floor. so the three of us were 
talking about the fact that the dj didnt seem to care that no one was 
dancing to what he was playing, basicly, i feel, because what he played 
(to put it bluntly) sucked. no offense or anything (hah). as our holland 
friend was telling us that in the clubs out there, if people stop 
dancing, the dj will very promptly switch styles of music. so im 
wondering (for those of you that were at Basics) is what the first dj was 
playing (music wise) popular now?  i personaly would think not because of 
the reaction of the crowd.  so now then, the second dj comes on and 
slowly transitions into more danceable music which the people at the rave 
respond to by dancing. or perhaps because their drug(s) kicked in? (heh). 
the third dj (carlos i think?)....well, everyone really enjoyed what he 
was playing.  hell, i enjoyed it too. i must say tho that not going out 
for a rave in over a year, and then going to Basics was really something 
to get me in the mood to start raving again. also must say that whoever 
did the paintings did a nice job.  the lazers were really great. (nice to 
look at while the first dj was spinning and no one was dancing).

yeah. sorry for babbling.

	by ng.netgate.net (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id KAA11018
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 10:53:02 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <3.0.1.32.19970609195755.00a5c770@ng.netgate.net>
X-Sender: grigsby@ng.netgate.net
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 3.0.1 (32)
Date: Mon, 09 Jun 1997 19:57:55 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Subject: Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR
In-Reply-To: <199706070707.AAA00480@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>        Yeah, jungle records go quick because they get boring really fast(at
>least the ones I have). So it seems like you're always running out. My
>problem is I get some of my records in my head as my favorites. So I always
>feel like after I've gone through those I don't know where to go from there.

Most jungle I've heard has no progression to it: it goes like this.

About half the drum line comes in.  This is where you beat match.
The other half of the drum line comes in, and the noises.  Fade out the old
track here so the bass lines don't wreck together.
The bass drops.  Repeat for a while.
Break!  Drop out the drums.
Drums come back.  Repeat until you're bored.

There are exceptions, but not many.  So you have to mix a bit faster in
order to keep a progression happening.  Also 'minimal' seems to be the
trend of the year; none of those super-dense gonzo Amen workouts of years
past, just beats and percussive melody fragments.

And: Since the tempo is so much faster than house, you repeat 16 bars of
drum-n-bass much faster than 16 bars of house, and boredom can set in.

// grigs



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 10 10:53:15 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id KAA21344;
	Tue, 10 Jun 1997 10:53:15 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ng.netgate.net (root@ng.netgate.net [204.145.147.10])
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id KAA21328
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 10:53:09 -0700 (PDT)

I see a lot of DJs who beat-match with one ear to the 'phones and one ear
off.  Often this means their head is wedged up against their shoulder
holding it there.

How widespread is this?  Would it help to hack a mute switch onto the cord?
 This would take about fifteen seconds if you can solder, or if you want to
be really slick you can take apart the headphone assembly and put the
switch there.

// grigs

hey guys - this is sort of related and i'm bored, so i thought i'd
transcribe it to you:

from the may-june issue of the _utne reader_:
*the dance of hope*
"british ravers with a social conscience are shaping a counter culture that
works

"a small group of twentysomethings in luton, england, is proving that
partying can change the world. what started as a way to lift the spirits of
unemployed young people in this struggling london suburb has become a
powerful grassroots movement to improve the community - and a new model for
social activism in britain and beyond.
        as sophie poklewski koziel reports in _resurgence_, the exodus
collective assembled a makeshift sound system and began organizing free
raves in 1993 as a way to combat the numbing boredom faced by young people
ion luton, a former center of the british auto industry where today the
unemployment rate is about 40%. they covered their costs by passing a hat
through the crowd. "the idea was to put on free parties to give people a
focus, something to do, to get together," says exodus member glenn jenkins.
"exodus has come up with some practical solutions."
        the dances answered the need for community (some credit the
collective with ending a three-day riot in 1995), and before long they were
attracting large audiences from the surrounding area. an average of 2,000
people attend each exodus rave, and some have drawn up to 10,000. when the
police confiscated the sound equipment after one particularly raucous
event, 4,000 people staged a peaceful demonstration outside the luton
police station. the police returned the sound system the following day.
        with its coffers filling rapidly, the collective focused its
considerable energy on other issues, incluyding the need for more
affordable housing. last year collective members took over the manor, an
abandoned retirment home, and negotiated permission to renovate the bldg
into 40 units and a main hall. proceeds from exodus dances, together with
the residents' government housing benmefits, are used for upkeep and
renovation. the 30 residents of the bldg, now dubbed HAZ (housing action
zone) manor, live communally and do all the remodeling. eventually the bldg
will be collectively owned and self-sustaining. exodus has also developed
long meadow community farm, a destination for field trips and a place where
people can interact with animals without reaching into their pocketbooks.
(there is a zoo in luton, but few young people can afford the admission
price.) in 1993 exodus was given a temporary liscense to use the farm,
which features a barn built with recycled pallets, pot-bellied pigs, and a
working forge.
        but these successes have not come without costs. early last year a
fire-bomb exploded in the farmhouse, leaving it gutted. and in september,
reports _squall_, luton police - searching for drugs and stolen car parts -
raided the farm while the collective was in zurich organizing an event. the
police left with one bag of suger, one bag of coffee whitener, and an old
car hood. local authorities are currently trying to evict the group from
the property.
        though exodus has been credited with contributing to a 6% decrease
in the local crime rate, its members have been continually harrassed by
police. according to mark white, writing in _mixmag_, "nearly every
collective member has been arrested on warrants for minor charges: one 18
year old, alleged to have stolen a sandwich, had 30 police officers and a
police helicopter sent after him." another exodus member was charged with
murder in 1995 and later aquitted. the harrassment, in fact, has been so
blatant that the bedfordshire county council has asked for an independant
inquiry into police actions. "we always knew it would be a battle,"
explains jenkins. "it's a reaction to the commercialization of rave
culture. that's why i'm not surprised it's been so hard some times."
        but the collective is not easily giving up what it has built.
indeed, jenkins believes the group is creating a model of mutual aid and
community spirit that will be replicated by young people all across
england. "i think exodus will become the first iof many," he says. "that's
why it's been such a battle. it turns out we've tapped into something old
here. i love it. i wish other people could learn to love it as much as we
do."

and that's all folks!

cheers - e. :)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 8 Jun 1997 03:11:55 -0400 (EDT)
From:KaisrSolze@aol.com
To: nyc-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: (nyc) US Techno-industrial complex

> WASHINGTON, DC--With first-quarter Club Rotation Index figures the lowest
> in seven years, and imports outselling domestic 12-inches more than
> two-to-one, economic observers throughout the U.S. are sounding the alarm
> over the nation's rapidly declining techno-industrial base.
> 
> "America faces a grave moment of crisis," said DJ Nathan Brackett,
> Secretary of Industrial and Hardcore, in a recent speech before Congress.
> "Vinyl imports from both Europe and Japan are threatening our nation's
> once-great techno-industrial power base. Our Gross National Beats Per
> Minute is at its lowest point since 1991. The message is clear: We must
> fuck up the mix, or all is lost."
> 
> In its late-'80s/early-'90s heyday, America's techno-industrial complex
> seemed unstoppable. Led by such formidable powers as Nine Inch Nails and
> Ministry, the U.S. achieved near-total dominance of the global dance-mix
> marketplace. Even in the traditionally insular Eurodisco field, the loud,
> banging, clamorous sound of American-made techno strongly influenced such
> foreign industrial powers as Front 242 and KMFDM.
> 
> Less than a decade later, however, the glory days of the American
> techno-industrial complex seem far away. With over 20,000 former clubgoing
> elite out of work in the warehouse district of Chicago, and the Detroit
> house scene over $7 billion in debt, bitterness over the nation's eroding
> techno-industrial base can be felt throughout its once-thriving industrial
> centers.
> 
> And with the rise of such overseas dope on wax as drum 'n' bass, ambient
> and jungle, the problem, experts say, is not going to go away any time
soon.
> 
> In fact, many fear that foreign competition from such heavy-hitting imports
> as England's Prodigy and Chemical Brothers, Germany's Atari Teenage Riot
> and Japan's DJ Krush--whose rare vinyl imports fetch up to $29.99
> domestically, even for a remix track--will overtake America's floundering
> techno-industrial base by the year 2000.
> 
> Many, including NYC illbient's DJ Spooky, contend that fault lies in
> American industrial's inability to adapt to the changing realities of
> modern times.
> 
> "We must retool America's angry, metallic, hard-edged industrial mix to
> better reflect the mellowtronic, groovadelic peace memes of the emergent
> global cyber-age," he said.
> 
> California's DJ Shadow agreed. "We are being beaten at our own game.
> Trip-hop was invented here, but right now, the British are simply doing it
> better," he said. "America has got to seriously remix its priorities."
> 
> In the face of the foreign dance-floor dominance, President Clinton is
> urging Congress to pump money into the revitalization of the nation's
> techno-industrial infrastructure.
> 
> "It is not enough to say, 'We must drop bass.' It is not enough to say, 'We
> must rock the crazy beats,'" President Clinton said Monday in a secret live
> appearance at D.C.'s famed underground The 930 Club. "If American techno is
> to become the world's leader once again, we must drop much bass; we must
> rock mad, phat-ass, crazy beats; and we must do so quick-fast in a hurry,
> 24-7, 365. And I am out."
> 
> Many conservatives in Congress, however, oppose to such change. "U.S.
> techno-industrial is hardcore, and it must stay hardcore," said Sen. Orrin
> Hatch (R-UT). "Would Al Jourgensen wear a T-shirt depicting smiley aliens
> telepathing 'Love' to their baggy-pantsed children? Techno should be about
> hate, not love. Techno is about wearing black and screaming, not standing
> in one place and swaying peacefully. I say, bring back the days of Skinny
> Puppy."
> 
> "Techno? Industrial? I am not familiar with these strange terms," said
> Rolling Stone magazine's Jann Wenner, speaking from one of his boats. "I do
> understand, however, that something called 'electronica' is the Next Big
> Thing. It says so right on the cover of our latest issue."

Folks, with this post and the one about happy hardcore, I feel I have to 
write something!

Well, Iris and Ben were kind enough to bring over a bunch of British
fliers for me and a mixtape... You probably all know that "raves" there
are 10,000-person plus, but you wouldn't believe the fliers!  Every one
dwarfed "Cool World" - almost poster-sized with fold-outs!  In addition,
there was bus and hotel info on a lot of them, and they cost in the $30
range.  I guess this doesn't compromise the scene there, but can you
imagine the same thing here??  We don't know what mainstream means over 
here, that's for sure.

Also, jungle was prominent on every flier (of course, it's much more 
mainstream and popular there).  But the biggest surprise were the 
numerous "MC's" at every party.  And they're draws, listed on the fliers 
along with the DJ's - a lot of the time in teams.  Their role seems to be 
to rap and to hype up the crowd.  That is one thing that has rarely been 
seen over here.

I asked for a sample of European techno... and got happy hardcore!  I've 
never heard this stuff at a party before.  Very very fast, like 180BPM, 
with uplifting happy house lyrics... WILD107-type songs but with a 
frentically-fast beat.  

It all screamed commercial to me, but maybe that's just all I got a 
sample of.  Stay tuned for a report when I get back from Europe in August!!

-N

Jesus, good luck!  South Florida sucks.  Of course, when I go I have to
stay at the Senior Jewish Retirement Homes (ahh, grandparents) in a
godawful town called Plantation (p.s. no-one there finds this name
offensive!), so maybe I'm biased.  But in a quest for info, I found the
best places were the TWO dj stores around Ft. Lauderdale - one called (how
original) The DJ Store.  There you'll find fliers.  As of last year, there
were NO ug's and just massive crap in Miami and Orlando (with bus service
from Ft. Lauderdale!)

The only thing going on was put on by this dj I met, Mike something (a 
top dj there but now I can't remember his name!), who did a weekly at a 
club in Ft.L.  However, alcohol is served in Florida til 4AM - so his 
"rave weekly" went from 4AN - noon!!  Now, ravers are known for being 
night owls (ah, speed anyone??), but that is ridiculous.

There are probably people on the list who went to the Winter Music
Conference in Miami, so they probably have much better info.  But all I 
saw in Fort Lauderdale were bleached blondes and buff dudes drinking bad 
beer to classic rock.  Have fun.

-N

Message-ID: <19970610.133706.3702.0.GabeRRamos@juno.com>

this is my first NRR post so i feel a little wierd writing this but i was
wondering if anyone saw the REALLY wierd light in the sky in santa cruz
around 12:30-1:00.    me and my friends were dosed that day but i was
done by then.  I will describe it.  there was a really intense blue/green
flash that covered the whole sky at once, then the streetlights flickered
for a while. then they went out and the sky flashed again this happened
one more time. and then the power was out.  it was right before the
cresent moon party,  we were all outside getting ready to go.   when the
first flash hit i kinda ignored it like maybe my eyes were just "funny"
right then.   but after i heard everyone yelling "holy shit ! ...what was
that" i knew something must be wierd.  at first i thought maybe there had
been some terrible nuclear accident and the shockwave would hit soon, but
nothing ever happened....it wasn't  lightning because there was no
thunder and lightning is not bright aqua green.   later that night i went
to my friends house to crash and he lives in the mountains.  he and his
housemates saw it and they were totally blown away too.  if anyone saw
this or heard what it was i would really like to hear about it.
peace
gabe

At 09:54 PM 6/9/97 -0700, you wrote:
>I love to dance to Jungle.
>
> It's weird. After about five minutes of bobing my head. I will finally get
>the rythm going through me. And I can't stop. But one distraction or screw
>up. It will take me another five minutes to get it going agian.

        well, to me it's just different dancing. For trance, or any 4/4
boom-boom bass drum beat, I will generally hop around and flail in time with
the music. Usually I will get more intense as the music gets more intense(as
does everyone else). So for Goa, Detroit techno, hard acid, or any of the
harder stuff I usually go nuts.

        For jungle or breaks or anything without a constant bass drum, I
like to strut my 'beginning breakdancing' moves, really shuffle my feet all
over the place and jam! It's fun but it wears me out much quicker. That's
why I've really caught on to jungle DJing. You can dance for a little while,
then stop to get the next record!

        -chris

> If you wanna spin house though. Don't get no cheap Gemini like Tim. My

        I have a Numark DM1080 which really isn't great, but it is a solid
mixer. And boy, when that asshole spilled beer on the crossfader, boy, was I
happy that it came out unlike my friend's Gemini. I will never again buy a
mixer without a detatchable crossfader.

        As far as sound? I have never really noticed too many differences,
but I haven't spun at many raves where the sound system is larger than the
one in my room so I could tell a difference. The limitations I have now is
my personal soundsystem(two Bose 901's and a 2x15 sub-woofer) which is good,
but won't really get up to the volume that any other actual club sound
system could. So I dunno if it's good or bad in that way.

        I remember before I first spun away from my tables I use here, I
freaked out and went to Leo's to try out all the mixers they had so I would
be ready for any unusual configurations(I am a big fan of using all
available switches.) The one I ended up using at the party was a weird
Gemini that had buttons for sound effects that you could mix in. Boy was
that thing shabby!

        -chris

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

        I feel there are some good points being made here.
        

>jungle and house have a different rythmic structure.  house music has a
>beat that is in sync with the high hat /congas etc.   Jungle on the other
>hand has bass that is either half time or quarter time of the drums/high
>hat/precussion.  When you say Jungle sounds good at 160 bpm or 80 bpm it
>is because part of the song (the bass) is playing at 80 and part of the
>song (the drum ) is playing at 160 bpm.  both of these are playing at the
>same time. What you said still doesn't tell me how you are going to mix
>this with a housebeat going at 120.  I would really like to hear jungle
>playing at 120bpm. I don't think you will find alot of it.  

        playing jungle at half-time(33 on a 45)will make it sound like a
really weird break, with too low bass. My friend does this from time to
time, but I think someone was actually doing this last night at Mad. It's
the first time I've seen someone do this at an actual party.

>as I said house has precussion that is in sync (usually) with the
>bassline.  I guess you could say it is more simple.  but whats wrong with
>simple if people really GROOVE to it.   some of the most slammin songs

        exactly. Any song that people can groove to is the best. Most of the
jungle I like is the real simplistic dance-able stuff, so I don't collect
too much techstep or darkstep. Just big fat simple hardstep.




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 10 14:50:45 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id OAA24300;
	Tue, 10 Jun 1997 14:50:45 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu (uclink4.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.155.12])
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id OAA24274
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 14:50:20 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from kckrm105.berkeley.edu (kckrm105.HIP.Berkeley.EDU [136.152.103.131]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.8.4/8.6.12) with SMTP id OAA03652; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 14:49:35 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 14:49:35 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199706102149.OAA03652@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
X-Sender: lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
From: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: the Jungle battle hits SFR
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Most jungle I've heard has no progression to it: it goes like this.
>
>About half the drum line comes in.  This is where you beat match.
>The other half of the drum line comes in, and the noises.  Fade out the old
>track here so the bass lines don't wreck together.
>The bass drops.  Repeat for a while.
>Break!  Drop out the drums.
>Drums come back.  Repeat until you're bored.
>

        yeah, it is kind of like that. I made a mix and notice I hit the
build of every song so I had to scrap that. The build, or I guess in jungle
it should be called 'the drums drop out and the vocal sample goes into an
echo or something weird until the song suddenly jumps back in with full-on
drums and bass' part, always takes place in the same part of the song. Some
differences usually occur when there are multiple tracks on a side. MY
favorite record has 4 tracks, and only 2 of them I like, and their on the
same side. These tracks have much quicker intros, which need more active mixing.

        I find jungle just requires more mixing than usual. You really can't
just let each track play out. I am trying to discover different things to do
for jungle to keep it interesting and most importantly, keep it pumpin'. One
of my friends here in the house spins goa, and he basically just lets each
track play out and mixes at the end, but thats really what most goa DJ's do.
On the other hand we have Ian, or DJ Timestretch, who will really mix up the
jungle good to keep it interesting and listenable.

        Now I am speaking for hardstep exclusively. I know some techstep,
dark, jazzstep, and intelligent tracks that could easily stand well on their
own.

        -chris

At 08:08 PM 6/9/97 -0700, you wrote:
>
>I see a lot of DJs who beat-match with one ear to the 'phones and one ear
>off.  Often this means their head is wedged up against their shoulder
>holding it there.
>
>How widespread is this?  Would it help to hack a mute switch onto the cord?
> This would take about fifteen seconds if you can solder, or if you want to
>be really slick you can take apart the headphone assembly and put the
>switch there.

        well, I do it to listen to the other music through the house
speakers. I don't know if other DJ's do this or listen to both at the same
time in the headphones. I don't, it's too chaotic for me. putting a mute
switch on one ear would still cut out alot of the outside sound coming from
the speakers if you had the phones over both ears.

        -chris

	Tue, 10 Jun 1997 15:06:09 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 15:02:45 -0500
From: Pengo <Pengo@ten.net>

X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0Gold (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
CC: pengo@ten.net
Subject: House Party Part 2
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

7:00PM I arrive at BBQ & Beats to quickly pass around some of my cheaply
made flyers.

8:45PM I arrive back at home just in time to meet DeepFog at the door.
We set up the place and he starts spinning at 9PM

10PM No ones here. I start to feel depresed, like its going to be one
of _thoes_ parties. So I run over to Burger King to grab some grub.

10:45PM I arrive back home to see about 7 people outside my door. Ok
cool people are here now. Im asked by Matt: "So wheres the party?"
Uh

11:30PM I finish up the last few things I need to take care of around
the house. More people come, and more, and more.

12:30 Top head count reaches 55

3:30 Ari Newman comes and tells me the bad news, my speakers are fried.
Oh well. But Ari being extra cool goes and gets his very excellent set
of speakers and the party goes on.

4:20 Party has been going on strong. Myself and 3 others climb up on my
roof for 420.

5:45 I look outside and see way too many people outside. Suffice it to
say that suburbanites dont care much for glitter kids shouting "I LOVE
YOU!" at 6 in the morning on Sunday.

6:30 Most people have left. Matt cleans up the deck (Thanks Matt!!)

So, my 2nd house party has come and gone. Awsome Vibe all night. I
really with Keri would have made it over. :(

Good Things: The PEOPLE!!! Thank you all so much for comming!! I knew as
soon as I started going to parties that I was gonna do this. I can't
remember who brought the black lights but they LIT THE HOUSE UP! 

Bad Things: Found a burnt spoon in the bathroom. Un-cool. People outside
at 6am being loud. One neibhor walk outside to see what the fuck was
going on outside her house. If this gets back to Mom n Pop, no more
house parties. And then my speakers are gone, but thats no big deal.

Thanks again everyone!!!!

-=Pengo=-

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 10 15:23:11 1997

"WATER" Frequently Asked Questions  -  alt.drugs

	This file is intended to answer typical questions about Water to
reduce traffic on alt.drugs.  This FAQ is continually maintained; new
information about Water should be mailed to "csk@eecs.nwu.edu".

                                    CONTENTS

	1)	What is Water?
	2)	Is Water dangerous?
	3)	Can I put Water in my bong?
	4)	A FOAF got some laced Water.  How frequently does
		this happen?
	5)	How is Water synthesized?
	6)	Is homebrewed "bathtub" Water as effective as "the
		real thing?"
	7)	What is 'kind' Water?
	8)	Are there different types of Water?
	9)	What is the LD50 of Water?
	A1)	Descriptions of Water 'trips'
	A2)	Street Prices, June 3, 1994
	A3)	International Legality Update
	A4)	List of Contributors



                                     ANSWERS


1) What is Water?

	Water, W, Hot Ice, Liquid Crystal... all these "street" terms
refer to
the same substance, known chemically as H20.  Water is a highly addictive
and
toxic chemical, which in its natural state is completely odorless,
tasteless,
and clear.


2) Is Water dangerous?

	Yes.  A scientific survey recently concluded that every creature
on
earth contains Water, and almost every creature imbibes more during its
life. 
Moreover, every animal that has ever ingested this substance has
invariably
tried to get more.  Organisms unable to get more Water show signs of
withdrawal, or "dehydration," and eventually die.  Organisms that ingest
more
Water inevitably die anyway.
	Aside from the biological considerations, remember that Water is
composed of Hydrogen and Oxygen, which are used together as rocket fuel. 

Enough cannot be said about the volatile nature of this chemical.


3) Can I put Water in my bong?

	Mixing drugs is never recommended, but if you must attempt this,
note
the following:

	-Water acts as a coolant and filter.  You are likely to get
larger,
	 smoother hits than normal.

	-Water may actually blend into the smoke, imparting its own
qualities
	 to the hit.

	-Water may splash up and get in your mouth.  Yuck.


4) A FOAF got some laced Water.  How frequently does this happen?

	Almost all Water contains some contaminants.  Generally, since
Water
has no taste or odor, the presence of either of these may indicate
foreign
substances.  Water is so strong, and so cheap to produce, that the story
of
the dealer who dusted his grass to make it salable doesn't really apply.


5) How is Water synthesized?

	The simplest synthesis is as follows:

	-Fill a pot from the kitchen tap.

	-Boil for fifteen minutes.

	The Water is now suitable for ingestion.

	Steve J. Quest gives a more involved recipe yielding a
higher-grade
	intoxicant:

                    Preparation of Hydrogen Oxide (Water)
                    ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
        An Erlenmeyer flask is first filled with a few grams of zinc
        metal chips and is then fitted with a two hole rubber stopper. A
        thistle tube is introduced through one hole and pushed to a
        level where the end of the tube is just above the zinc chips. A
        rubber tube is introduced through the other hole and connected
        to a horizontal copper pipe filled with loose fitting chunk
        cupric oxide.  The other end of the copper pipe is connected to
        a Liebig condenser mounted in a distilling fashion (open end
        pointing down) which is suspended above a capture beaker.

        A bunsen flame is placed under the cupric oxide reaction pipe,
        and any kind of cold liquid is allowed to circulate through the
        condenser.  (some would use cold tap Water, but I can not
        recommend that procedure here due to legalities involved.)

        Sufficient quantities of concentrated sulfuric acid are then
        introduced through the thistle tube to completely cover the zinc
        chips to a level ABOVE the end of the thistle tube. Condensation
        will start to occur within the condenser and run out into the
        beaker.  The crude product represents a technical grade of
        hydrogen oxide, suitable for recreational purposes.

        The reaction sequence is as follows:

        Zn + H2SO4 -> ZnSO4 + H2        H2 + CuO -> Cu + H2O


6) Is homebrewed "bathtub" Water as effective as "the real thing?"

	In the author's opinion, "bathtub" Water ("slosh") will never be
able
to compete with legendary types like Owsley, Naya, and Perrier, but there
is
of course a certain satisfaction in synthesizing your own.


7) What is 'kind' Water?

	According to Peter McDermott:

	There are actually two major kinds. 'Soft' Water and 'Hard' 
	Water. The 'soft' Water does less damage (to kettles, pipes,
etc.)
	but the hard Water is a better hit. 

	Some people argue that there is something called a 'gatevalve'
syndrome,
	where some people who begin on the relatively harmless 'soft'
Water are
	likely to escalate to the hard stuff. However, this isn't true of
everybody.
	Personally, I've been drinking soft Water for years without ever
trying 
	anything harder.


8) Are there different types of Water?

	Christopher K. Koenigsberg explains:

	There are apparently variations in the chemical makeup of W sold
in
	stores, so someone should look into this for the FAQ (W's still
	available over the counter, no prescription necessary, not yet
	regulated by the FDA, nor scheduled by the DEA, I guess? How much
	longer before they catch on? Maybe we should be more cautious and
not
	talk about it so openly, before they start having congressional
	hearings or something?)

	For example I've seen W labelled "Steam Distilled" but on the
same
	shelf also seen W labelled "Drinking Water" and even "Spring
Water",
	and a more expensive kind for Babies (yes they are even hooking
	innocent infants) and there may or may not be differences beyond
just
	the labels and packaging. There are variations in the price even
for
	the same kind of stuff, the local store brand is always the
cheapest,
	regional "Artesian Wells" etc. are more expensive, and the
imported
	kind is most expensive.

	There are vending machines outside some grocery stores (hey! you
don't
	even have to show an ID to prove your age!) which will disburse W
	either Distilled or for Drinking, into your own choice of
unlabelled
	container (so you can pretend it's something else). And the
Drinking
	kind supposedly has mineral additives. I don't know if this is
	Strychnine, among the additives, which maybe causes the cramps
when
	you drink too much, too fast, or too cold.... but I hear that's
just a
	myth.


9) What is the LD50 of Water?

TOXICITY DATA
REC-WMN LDLO:180 GM/KG/28H                    JAMAAP 104,1569,35
IPR-MUS LD50:190 GM/KG                        NTIS** AD628-313
IVN-MUS LD50:25 GM/KG                         MIVRA6 8,320,74
REVIEWS, STANDARDS, AND REGULATIONS
NOHS 1974: HZD M1000; NIS 561; TNF 436805; NOS 294; TNE 7313166
NOES 1983: HZD M1000; NIS 500; TNF 313467; NOS 324; TNE 8785413; TFE
3032116
EPA GENETOX PROGRAM 1988, INCONCLUSIVE: B SUBTILIS REC ASSAY
EPA TSCA CHEMICAL INVENTORY, JUNE 1990
EPA TSCA TEST SUBMISSION (TSCATS) DATA BASE, JANUARY 1993
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
LD50
4180 MG/KG (    ) (     )
>       99999 MG/KG  (IPR-MUS)

CHRONIC EFFECTS
OTHER HEALTH HAZARDS
PRIMARY INFECTIONS OF CYTOMEGALOVIRUS (CMV) ARE USUALLY ASYMPTOMATIC
BUT IN RARE CASES, SUBSEQUENT INFECTIONS MAY CAUSE MONONUCLEOSIS-LIKE
DISEASE. CMV CAN ALSO RESULT IN LATENT INFECTIONS AND HAS BEEN
IMPLICATED IN CERTAIN TYPES OF CANCER.

This is of course in mice and may not apply directly to humans.  W can be
very dangerous, so play nice and be safe.



              APPENDIX 1:  Descriptions of Water 'trips' and usage


	Kevin Jernigan, alt.drugs #85634:

   I drank Water for the first time at a party last night, and it was
great!!
Some of my friends who do W told me about the experience earlier, but I
now
realize that it was beyond my wildest expectations.  I was a little bit
scared,
at first, because I heard about some of the bad side effects that it can
cause.
A few people said they choked on it, and one guy said that he dribbled it
all   
over his clothes and got them wet.  Luckily, none of these things
happened to 
me.  They started passing glasses around to everyone and I decided to
take one  
The Water was very clear in color. They said it was scored from a guy who
got
it from a spring in Canada.  I don't know whether it was really Canadian 
Water, but it was definitely good quality, judging by the color.  I used
about 500g of it.  When I put the glass up to my mouth, and swallowed,
the
first sensation I felt was of something wet traveling down my throat. 
This 
sensation started before I had even removed the glass from my mouth.  I
was
able to acheive the same feeling again, by taking another swallow.  As
the 
trip progressed, I noticed several other things.  The W produced a state
of
mind that I believe could best be described as a lack of thirst.  The
trip
didn't last for very long, but I think that it would be safe to say that
the experience gave me some important insights into my consciousness.  
Chief among these, is the realization that Water can relieve thirst. 


	Ray Mialki, email contribution:

Although I don't partake, some of my neighbours down quite a bit of the
stuff, filling swimming pools and such.  I use it in great moderation,
not even having an outside hose spigot to wash the car with.  Daily
showers seem to be my habitual use.  


	Peter McDermott, alt.drugs #unknown:

A recent major survey (n=1) has showed that Water addiction runs in
families.
At present, NIDA funded scientists are working flat out on the genesis of
this crippling condition.

Unlike other addictions, W abuse is believed to affect all sections of
society,
rich and poor alike. However, scientists have discovered that a gene may
well
be responsible for a predisposition to drinking W.

Although 12 step 'W' recovery programmes have been around for some time
now, major cities have begun to witness a growth in self-help programs
for
Adult Children of Waterholics. "Henry" is a member of such a group.

	"Well, I've just got so much rage about this, y'know? I was never
	able to confront them about it at the time. I thought that 
	drinking Water was normal. 

	Now I'm angry. Ours is a sick culture. The French would never
dream
	of exposing their children to 'W' at dinner. There, the kids go
from
	breast milk to wine. But every single day, there it was, sitting
at 
	the dinner table in front of me. Of course, they wouldn't let me
have
	any, but after watching them do it, I saw where they got it from.
I 
	began sneaking to the tap, and taking a sip. Before I knew where
I was
	I was into the hard stuff - you know, Water sports. Baths,
showers,
	stuff like that. 

	Well, eventually, I hit bottom. I out in town and the craving
came on
	me and I found myself licking it up from puddles. Then it was
toilet
	bowls. There are no wells too deep for the 'W' addict. So I went
and
	got help. I've been in recovery for like.. 3 days now, but I
wasn't
	making any progress. Then my therapist told me about A CoW and
since
	then, it's been nothing but milk. And not mother's milk
either..."

However, not everybody accepts that 'W' use is a problem. 'Mary' has been
using 'W' for a month now. She feels that the dangers of 'W' have been
much exaggerated.

	"It's all propaganda, isn't it? I've been doing 'W' for ages now,
and
	it's just a bit of a buzz, innit. It's harmless man. There isn't
a
	single study that *proves* 'W" has any effect on the bladder, and
as
	for people who say it makes you piss. Well, they are just dirty
minded.
	As I said, I've been doing 'W' for a month, and I've never had a
piss,
	ever.

	We've started a pressure group called 'Fair Play for Water' and
it's our
	aim to force the government to tell the truth about 'W'. If there
are
	risks, tell us what they are, and how we can minimize them.
Prohibition doesn't
	work. The government knows that. Why else would they have
repealed the
	laws against heroin and cocaine? Unfortunately, there are
political 
	careers to be made out of that issue. Vote Libertarian. Privatise
the
	Water companies. Stop all government regulation of Water now!!!!



                    APPENDIX 2:  Street Prices, June 4, 1993


	Chicago, IL, North Shore Area
		-Typical Naya, $1 US per liter.

	Springdale Township, Pennsylvania 
		$5 per 1000 gallons.



                   APPENDIX 3:  International Legality Update


	In Europe W is becoming something of a threat real fast. I myself

have witnessed tourists trying to score W desperately the last couple 
of hot days here this week. As of yet there is no shortage of W, but I've

heard that in Greece it's getting scary. 
	The police are starting to recognise this situation and have
called for 
more forces on the street, weeding out W-pushers and sentencing them to 
severe punishments straight away!

Well when I first learned how to beatmatch and spinn on my friends mixer 
he didn't have a headphone cue where you could listen to both tracks in 
the headphones.  So I'd listen to one plate in one ear and beat match it 
with the other rekkid comming out the monitor - listening to it in the 
other ear.  The taco neck syndrom(TNS) look is just because usually at 
parties the sound is really loud and it's hard to distinguish the beats in the 
phones with out smashing the speaker up to your ear w/ your shoulder.  

I'm used to this style and I've seen most dj's do this.  When I work on a 
mixer that has the headphone cue control I often check my mix in the 
headphones to see how well it sounds before I cross fade it all the way 
over.   My mixer doesn't have this control either so I've always done the 
shoulder thing.  But my roommate doesn't like "LOUD" music so I don't 
play it loud and I have no need to crunch my neck.  

Or I could be all wrong and maybe it's from a DJ's diet, which might  
consit of only eating taco's at Taco Bell, hence the TNS.

peace 

austin

I just wanted to post to the list 2 very sweet people I enjoyed having 
stay with me and my other half in Marin.  Iris and Ben from England. We 
took them to Beats last Saturday and they also attended the Basics 
party.  They will be staying in San Jose with Julie Hayes from the list 
and are looking at every chance they can to meet new sf ravers until 
their departure at the end of July.  They like Star Trek, Sci Fi books, 
and happy house techno. I hope many of you get a chance to meet them 
because they're very cool.  Also, if anyone on this list or if you know 
anyone who wouldn't mind them staying a few nights while on their CA 
journey, you could email the list to page Iris as she is checking her 
email along the way.  PS - they do have a tent with them and camping 
outdoors is fine too!

self-explanatory


Subject: Nazi Usenet Group

 A few Neo-Nazi groups are trying to create (again) a usenet
 group where they want to keep in contact with each other
 regarding their activities. I believe it is not necessary
 to dwell further on these activities.

 The group is rec.music.white-power.

 To create such a group, they have to win a referendum that is
 always organised when a new usenet group is created. All persons
 with an email address, and only those, can vote in this
 referendum.

 It is IMPORTANT to vote only once, otherwise the vote is
 cancelled.

 To prevent the creation of this group, you have to:b      1. Send this
message to people you know
     2. Send an email to the following address:

              music-vote@sub-rosa.com

       with as contents (not 'subject') ONLY the following line:

            I vote NO on rec.music.white-power

     Since the vote is automatic, it is important to send the exact
     line as it is given above, without adding anything, not even
     a name.
     And please send it only once or it becomes invalid ! Also, please
        FORWARD THIS LETTER TO EVERYONE YOU KNOW WITH AN E-MAIL
        ADDRESS

      to prevent the founders from creating this group.

      Thanks for your collaboration.

I wanted to post to sfraves about 2 very sweet people that my other half 
and I had stay with us in Marin.  Iris and Ben. These two are 
backpacking through CA. and are interested in meeting as many sf ravers 
as possible.  They love Star Trek, Sci Fi books, jungle and happy 
hardcore.  We took them to the Marin Headlands, the Beats picnic last 
Sat., the Basics party and the Haight Street Fair.  They seemed to have 
really enjoyed themselves.  I do hope that other folks on this list do 
get a chance to meet them because they are very cool.  

They've just left our place to head down to San Jose to stay with Julie 
Hayes.  If you would like to or know of anyone else who would like to 
accomodate them for a few days, please email this list and page Iris as 
she checks her email regularly.  They also have a tent with them to camp 
outdoors.

Peace,

Subject: Blasts from the Past III/Farewell
To: discobunnies <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


(warning: long and autobiographical - I couldn't help myself :P!)


Seduction of a Newbie 

Berkeley, fall '94.  A disastrous first year in Northern California, spent
friendless and alone in an anonymous apartmentment drowning in scholarly
tomes, has slowly crept by.  After a year of involuntary oppression of the
hardcore partier lurking within, I am more than ready to bust out.  I'm
just waiting for the spark. 

The co-ops save me.  After a year in an apartment so silent and dark I
sometimes feel the walls caving in on me, I move into Party Central.  I'm
happy again.  New friends take me to the city one Saturday night, close to
my 25th birthday.  I am not told we are going to a rave.  I dress for your
usual drinker club - a black miniskirt, high boots and (!) a black
turtleneck sweater.  In the rave, I look like some of those cheesy bar
people you see sometimes who obviously have no idea what they have
stumbled upon - just like I was! 

We are at Cesar's Palace.  I couldn't tell you the name of the party.  I 
couldn't tell you what dj's spun.  I couldn't even tell you what kind of 
music it was!  I was completely ignorant.

Inside is more swirling color than I have ever seen.  I gaze around, 
amazed from the start.  People were still wearing costumes then, and I 
see people with wigs and people with those 3-foot tall platforms and 
people dressed like angels and fairies.  My friends find drugs and I jump 
in with the enthusiasm of someone jailed for the last year.  Already 
experienced, I gulp down two e's and a hit of acid with glee, and 
(surprise surprise) proceed to have the time of my life.  I meet people.  
I eat candy.  I bond with the people I came with.  I become acquainted 
with the speaker box.  I become one with the beat.  I am enraptured 
with the visuals and the light show.  I am enraptured with every 
person there.

By morning, I'm a raver.  There seems to be two types of people at their
first real party: the ones who go, "yeah, this is okay," and the ones who
dive in headfirst and embrace it with complete abandon.  Guess which one I
was??  Around the same time, I win the lottery: the horrible year of
internment with only my schoolbooks for company turned into a 4.0 GPA, and
suddenly I receive thousands of dollars in unforeseen scholarships.  I am
the worst combination: a newbie raver with money to burn. 

I spend the next six months going out every single weekend, eating e's 
every time.  I go to every huge massive, I go to the roller rink, I 
return to Cesar's several times.  I don't have favorite dj's or 
prejudices against this promoter or that venue.  It's all beautiful in 
my drug-haze.  Sometimes I miss those days of unvarnished idealism, where 
every party was magical and no judgements impeded on the experience.  But 
slowly I see that there are cracks in the "community," and some music and 
parties now leave me cold.  I yearn for what I feel is the possibility in 
the scene, but what I'm not quite experiencing for real.

The Newbie Discovers the Underground 
busted Friends and Family, spring 1995 

The fantasy realized (if only for a few hours).  Here, for the first time,
I experience what "family" can mean in the scene.  The first taste of the
underground is addictive and I follow the thread away from commercial
parties.  I discover Sunsets and Gateway and Harmony and more Friends and
Family.  But I also find strong opinions about parties and music and
venues.... suddenly I'm sniffing at parties that a year before would have
been the greatest night ever.  

Over time, though, my love affair with substances has faded.  I see that a
lot of that good time at every party calling itself a "rave" was had with
the help of fuzzy e-goggles.  With more experience in the scene, I start
to discover what real community can be and what can be created by a
positive-minded group of people, and it's something real from the heart,
not from drugs.  Though I now see the cracks and the pessimism and the
politics not visible to me on my newbie high, what goodness remains has
become more real and treasured to me.  The truth of the experience 
outlives any drug high.

With a barrage of discoveries in the scene, I discover that I'm changing. 
I become friendlier to people in real life, letting a lot of the suspicion
and fear that characterized growing up in L.A. fade away.  My penchant for
black clothing gives way suddenly to bright happy colors.  I start getting
silly, remembering how to play.  I discover how to dance - by letting
myself go and feeling the music - and I become a dancing fiend.  I learn
again that reality is all what we create and are intent upon, and I
resolve to create from a loving and happy heart.   I find these things 
anew when I go out, like at Warmth recently - or sometimes I just find fun, 
which has become a definite priority in life :)  


The Old-Skooler on SFR 
Finally a bonafide UG raver full of glitter and mystical revelations and
shit, I end up (where else??) on SFR.  Now it's been a year and a half on
here and I feel old-school!  SFR has been a lifeline - the heart of
the scene for me.  Most of the people I've met have been through this
list!!  It's been incredible to have a daily conversation with the people
who love this scene the most: the party throwers, dj's and all the ravers
who'll commit to 100 messages a day.  You all rock :)

I guess this has turned into a goodbye note - 3 days early.  It's been an 
incredible three years of dancing and growth and optimism and fun fun 
fun!!  

Much love to all of you SFRavers ;)
Like Vlad says, KEEP IT REAL
-Nancy

From: Jonas the Spaceboy <hanning@SONOMA.EDU>
Subject: Re: MC's and DJ's/the British scene
X-Sender: hanning@sonoma.edu
To: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-id: <3.0.32.19970611024238.007644dc@sonoma.edu>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0 (32)
Content-type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Among other things, Nancy said...
>I asked for a sample of European techno... and got happy hardcore!  I've 
>never heard this stuff at a party before.  Very very fast, like 180BPM, 
>with uplifting happy house lyrics... WILD107-type songs but with a 
>frentically-fast beat.  

Happy hardcore a good example of european techno??? In the UK, clubs are
the prominent place to go for dance music. What you'll hear in clubs is
mostly euro-house (NOT euro-disco pablo, so don't get on that plane just
yet...*smile*). Lisa Marie Experience, Way Out West, Todd Terry (and all
of them yucky EBTG-remixes), Robert Miles, stuff like that. And the
occasional US import (labels like strictly rhythm and am:pm are very
much favored by UK club djs). The underground scene in the UK is just
that, UNDERGROUND. Parties (not massives) are strictly word-of-mouth,
and it takes a big chunk of love for the music to find them. =) They're
also FREE for the most part. =)
Unfortunately (or maybe not), a lot of the people fed up with clubs and
the commercial "crap" that's played there don't have the energy or interest
to seek out the real underground parties. So they go to massives. And what's
better than happy hardcore to bog out to if you hate slick house? Nothing.
It's SO anti-mainstream, but at the same time it has a sort of candy-sweet
appeal (no offense to ANY of the candy ravers out there...) that attracts
the masses. 
Back to the underground parties though. In the UK, these are mostly trance
and acid parties. We're not talking cybertrance though, we're talking GOA 
TRANCE. Yes, the goa scene is still very much alive in the UK. And as far
as the acid parties go, it's the kind of acid that _I_ like to get down to,
hella trancey, around 145-160bpm. 
And then there's the rest of Europe. Although it's the land of poppy trance
records, parties in Germany have always been THE place for HARDASS TECHNO. 
But in the last couple of years however, things have changed. drum'n'bass 
has arrived, and most parties have a drum'n'bass dj.

And oh, Sweden... Home of Loop Records, Hybrid Records, Plumphouse Records,
Dunkla Recordings and a whole bunch of other techno labels. If you find a
party here (they're not underground, they're just not thrown very often),
it will either be a party with 8 hours of minimal techno or goa. I picked
up a few flyers this last weekend (when cricket came to see me! yay!), and
parties are $20 for a ONE-room party. 

I'm not sure this was a good response to anything anyone said, but I just
felt that I had to _try_ to explain that European "techno" is _NOT_ happy
hardcore. Most TRANCE is produced in Germany and the UK, most DRUM'N'BASS
obviously comes out of the UK. The best TECHNO (unless you're into detroit
stuff) comes from Germany and Sweden. The dance-hits you listen to on live
105 (everything from labouche to the macarena) is from europe. =)

*huggies*
jonas THE SPACEBOY

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 17:55:16 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from localhost (andy@localhost)
          by atari.saturn5.com (8.8.5/8.8.4) with SMTP
	  id RAA22761; Tue, 10 Jun 1997 17:59:07 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 17:59:05 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-Sender: andy@atari
To: The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Headphone Q for DJs
In-Reply-To: <3.0.1.32.19970609200856.00a33210@ng.netgate.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970610174215.22618A-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Mon, 9 Jun 1997, The Grigsbeast wrote:

> 
> I see a lot of DJs who beat-match with one ear to the 'phones and one ear
> off.  Often this means their head is wedged up against their shoulder
> holding it there.

I'd say (and this is in my limited experience), that I like to have my
queing record at two possible settings... one is reference volume, with
the headphone resting lightly on my ear, and the other is when I'm
listening to find how "tight" the bass drums are together, or if the
basslines work together (I get this 'bassier' tone by crushing the
headphone between my ear and shoulder... yes it actually serves a
purpose, I control the amount of headphone volume getting to my brain by 
varying pressure on my shoulder).

Meanwhile, the other ear gets a clear shot of what the outside is playing.

I usually don't HAVE to do this if the mixer allows for a good gradual mix
of the two records in the queue (like the Blue has), but other mixers,
especially mixers with more than two channels, usually employ a push
button queue system that requires resorting to the low tech one ear
method (unless they have a program/cue mix, but those have their faults
too).

The only time I wear my headphones on both ears is to test a mix I
know to be kinda easy to screw up prior to bringing it in, or if it's
HELLA loud behind the decks, in which case I'm using the headphones as
defensive sheilds to protect my ears.  Or sometimes, if they are really
big klunky headphones, they just won't do the one ear thing and you don't
have a choice.

I don't think the switch would be good for me... I know different
people mix differently though...

Sony V-6's are still my fave headphones.
No amount of technology will sway me.
I just wonder why the ear padding always rips in the same spot on every
pair I've ever seen...

I'll shut up now.

:)

AndyW

Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 21:19:45 -0400 (EDT)
Message-ID: <970610211858_470568192@emout03.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Fwd: NRR:mastering to h/d
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If you are recording/making a mix straight to the harddrive  30 seconds of
digitized audio takes up 1.4 mb of space.  Compression can play a factor in
the final edit.  U might want to try burning it directly to a cdrom (upto 640
mb of space)  or using an external drive for portability.  Sound actually
takes up a LOT of hd space and the playback rate is another factor to
consider.  But I am speaking solely of digitized audio files.  PC and Mac
platforms are a bit different too.

;-)

Just my 2 cents...

Steffffff
vinylmidi@aol.com
http://members.aol.com/vinylmidi/index.htm

Subject: Re: MC's and DJ's/the British scene
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Nancy sez:
>numerous "MC's" at every party.  And they're draws, listed on the fliers
>along with the DJ's - a lot of the time in teams.  Their role seems to be
>to rap and to hype up the crowd.  That is one thing that has rarely been
>seen over here.

That may be true of SF (i haven't been to enough strictly jungle events
here to say for sure)... But, if one was in Chicago during 1994-95, you'd
have heard the likes of Snuggles, Phantom45, RP Smack, and the Wildchild on
the mike during any jungle set... Chicago's Dj Hyperactive has been MC'ing
over straight techno/acid sets since time began. MC's also appear with the
likes of Lenny Dee, or HH/4beet jocks like the UK's Slipmatt... I think
when its done right, it can be really exciting, but it's also really easy
for an MC to annoy the hell out of me. Its a fine line.


"The MC is on the mike, but the dj is doing the talking..."
-Snuggles @ trust, February '94

Joshua

> regarding their activities. I believe it is not necessary

> The group is rec.music.white-power.

Careful where you point the censorship gun -- it might get turned on you.

A few Raver groups are trying to create (again) a usenet
group where they want to keep in contact with each other
regarding their activities.  As we all know, Raves are simply
loud parties where young people go to consume illegal drugs.

The group is rec.music.rave.

Mail your vote to vote@bogus.com so we can keep this seductive 
culture of hypnotic, repetitive beats and dangerous drugs away
from our children.

Thank you.

// grigsbeast

Thought I'd forward this along for any of you younger ravers who might
be interested in getting into the internet business someday.

Steve

------- Start of forwarded message -------
Date: Tue, 10 Jun 1997 20:34:07 -0800
From: Steven Horn <shorn@imagine-inc.com>
To: craigs-list jobs <cnewmark-job-i@steam.mobius.net>
Reply-To: Steven Horn <shorn@imagine-inc.com>
Subject: (job) Editorial Intern

((Craig: for your younger readers...))

Editorial Intern: Get paid to surf! Break into the Net business!
Do you love the Net? Would you rather surf than hang out at the mall? Are
your parents always bugging you to get off the Net and come to dinner?
How'd you like the coolest job in the world this summer?

Imagine Publishing is launching The ImagineZone. Come help us build it.
We'll need you to surf the Net for about 20 hours per week here in our
Brisbane office. You'll get a state of the art PC and an awesome T1
connection (that'll smoke your 28.8, bud.) All you need to do is tell us
which sites you think would fit certain criteria as we build out the
ultimate independent website showcase.

In addition to $6 an hour, you'll get free magazines + CD-ROMs (PC Gamer, Next
Generation, The Net, Ultra Game Players, MacAddict, and Boot), cheap soft
drinks, and the chance to work alongside a bunch of computing and gaming
superfreaks.

You'll need to know how to turn on a computer and surf the Net. That's it.
If you have worked with Excel, that's perfect. You'll need to be at least
16 years old. Imagine is an equal opportunity employer and certified
tie-free office.

Come, join us in the land of the Coconut Monkey.

Contact:
Steven Horn
Editor, ImagineZone
shorn@imagine-inc.com



____________________________________________________
for more on craigs-list browse http://www.cnewmark.com  [jobs posting 358]

------- End of forwarded message -------

Firstly, thanks to all who replyed to my request for rave info in the
States. I've plenty to go on.

Secondly, a question. I maintain the internet site for the Ministry of
Sound. Last month we did a live broadcast from the club. We had three
cameras, sound taken from the decks and mixed with sound from microphones.
Junior Vasquez was at the decks and the whole thing was fu*king amazing and
technically perfect for over seven hours.

My question is this..

Is this the first live audio and video broadcast from a night club to the
internet in the world?

I think its the first in the UK, but I could be wrong.

Check out the archive -- over an hour of video and sound. The projection
visuals and the golden scans look v.good, although the light is a bit poor.

www.ministryofsound.co.uk

If anyone knows of any other club doing this let me know, feedback about
the reception of streaming audio and video in the states would also be
appreciated.

Later,

Will.

i find this all kind of amusing - (or maybe it isn't?) i actually had a
dentist tell me that i was grinding my teeth too much and she gave me this
piece that fits in to protect my not-so-pearly whites.... anyway, i _know_
that i don't grind my teeth regularly in my sleep, and this didn't seem to
become a problem until - oh - about 7 years ago - which happens to coincide
with my first rave... :P

cheers - e. :)

ps - why is it that i grind on acid as well? i've always been told that it
was the strichnine (sp?). really, you never know what you're putting into
your body with these things - i usually chew - anything - ice, gum,
whatever - might make for a sore jaw in the morning, but oh well!

From: macadio  <macadio6@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Re: Headphone Q for DJs
To: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>, The Grigsbeast <grigsby@netgate.net>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I personally like to keep one headphone on my head as oppossed to
clinching my shoulder against my ear. Sometime you need to do the
shoulder clinch thing if the sound system is real loud and the monitor
controls are not that good. A mute button would not be that effective
(IMO) cause you wouldn't be able to hear the current record and
outside noise as chris stated. I like to play with the head phone on
all the time through out the mix instead of taking the headphones
completely off my head and just depending on the monitor cause you get
a lot of excess noise that way. Once again (IMO)

Macadio

>
> At 08:08 PM 6/9/97 -0700, you wrote:
> >
> >I see a lot of DJs who beat-match with one ear to the 'phones and
one ear
> >off.  Often this means their head is wedged up against their
shoulder
> >holding it there.
> >
> >How widespread is this?  Would it help to hack a mute switch onto
the cord?
> > This would take about fifteen seconds if you can solder, or if you
want to
> >be really slick you can take apart the headphone assembly and put
the
> >switch there.
> 
>         well, I do it to listen to the other music through the house
> speakers. I don't know if other DJ's do this or listen to both at
the same
> time in the headphones. I don't, it's too chaotic for me. putting a
mute
> switch on one ear would still cut out alot of the outside sound
coming from
> the speakers if you had the phones over both ears.

Um... every time I hear WILD 107 late at night, they seem to be playing a
lot of the stuff you said you like...

Or you could unplug yourself from the consumer loop (the sponsor pays the
station, the station plays the music and you pay the sponsor makes awfully
poor sense to me), and shop from record stores that actually let you
listen before you buy and play only music you like, all day long.

Also, support college and public radio stations.  If there's something you
want to hear, push to have it played.  They tend to have more interesting
mixes of music anyway...

More BSP in my quest to catch up with Macadio and Micron =)

Tonight at V/SF a whole gang of people from A.R.M, Jungle Love, Umoja
Hi-Fi, Consciousness Lab, and the Justice League are throwing Cuzins,
offering drum & bass, downtempo, electro, and some more experimental forms
of music. There will be two rooms - in the more drum & bass oriented room
are: Gamecat, Bonnie, Sifu, and Joe Rice and in the downtempo/experimental
room will be Brad (C-Lab), Shoam, Daum (Freaky Chakra), and Tomas. It's $3,
from 10pm-3am and 21+ 278 11th St. at Folsom.

I'll also be playing at Monophonic tonight at Liquid (16th and S. Van Ness)
from 10-12. It's 21+, I'm afraid I don't know the cover, but I think it's
cheap.

I'll be on the Beta Lounge ( http://www.betalounge.com/ ) tomorrow - my
first internet set, which is pretty exciting!

Anyway, hope to see some of you somewhere, sometime. =)

Thanks,

Joe

for us in-betweeners?  I really wanted to check out the Ninja Stealth tour
but that was 21+ as well.  Why can't I just wear a bright glowing orange
vest that says "don't serve me alcohol"?  Anyway, thanx in advance. Take
Care all.... Love Toy =)  *transplanted from txraves for the summer*

I picked up an issue of Mixmag yesterday and damn!  now I'm jealous.  The 
Britsh clubscene looks soooo much cooler than ours :(   This 
could be wrong, especially considering Jonas' post, but that's 
sure how it looks from the pictures and the reviews!!  Hundreds of clubs 
listed in England, with top rave djs actually spinning at them, and 
people dressed crazily.  A far cry from our sad clubscene of suburbanites 
and weak music, aside from the occasional desperate night at 1015 hoping 
it'll be cool, and the too-rare big Spundae parties (which is how I'd love 
clubs to be!!).  

Though they have the same issues with the barpeople - but they're referred 
to as "beer monsters" and "the tacky people"  :)

There really is virtually nothing in the big club scene in SF.  It's too bad.

Hmmm...

 I only have to rest my head on my shoulder when. Well.. I do it to.. Smash
the headphones onto my ear more. It brings out the bass in the headphones
more that way. So I do it to double make sure the bass ain't gonna crash.
Just turning up the CUE does not give me the same effect. But when you
smash that left headspeaker onto your face...The bass comes through loud
and clear..
 Hmmm..  I wonder if anyone else does it for that reason.
 Keeping the headphones balanced on my face reguires just as much attention
as beat matching though.

I got a sick azz beat going yesterday /w some house records though. Not
sure wha records. Everyone got up and started going WOO!!! with there hands
in the air. I just let the shorter record play out to the end while I
looked for my next rekkid.
One records was going boom x4... The other. Boom, boom, boom, ba doom ba
doom. boom, ect. Yea know. 
 Mixing rules. It really brings out charactor.

Gotta have the house speakers going through your headphones when yer
scratchin though.
Jeff nStuff

--- My Own Original Commentary ---

Welp, lesse :

* I have it on the (fairly mundane... I like that word) LPM comp "The Best
Of Jungle - Disc One".  Ive played that song so many times my CD player is
beginning to mix it on its own :-)

* What is an LPM comp you ask?  LPM = Low Price Music... an outfit outta
London (?) that puts some of the cooler (read : more popular) tracks on 4
disc comps.  Not perfect by any metric but nice if you are el cheapo and
wanna quickly supplement your collection.  I havent seen any of the better
ones (HH stuff) lately.  But I *have* to believe that a track as good as
"Above The Clouds" is on discs all over the place.  Im sure someone else
can help out.... *wink wink*

- David

Who Is Calling All The People

At the risk of beating a dead horse (is that a 4/4 beat or a jungle beat?) I
highly suggest you go out and buy the Warmth cd.  Music this good on cd does
not come out often!  It's tunes for us non-DJ types.  It has so many awsome 
tracks.  It slices, it dices, it even purees.  Watch is cut this can in half...
And if your unwanted hair ever grows back return it for a full refund.

Prices slightly higher in Hawaii and Alaska

I'd be very surprised if you were; streaming audio and video is relatively
well understood tech at this point.  

I know x-radio (www.x-radio.com) has done some netcasts from clubs, but i
dunno if they've done video as well.  

Organizations like Dimension 7 (http://www.dimension7.com/), specialize in
this sort of thing and have done many events in the past; check out
http://www.dimension7.com/perform.htm for a list of stuff they've done.

Whoops.  Looks like you've been beat:

> Ninja Tunes, 8/96
>
> D7 employed Real Audio, CU-See-Me, and an FTP of digital stills via
> Ricochet to Netcast
> England's premier group of Trip-Hop DJs (Food, Coldcut and Porcini) for
> this Bulletproof event.
> D7 mixed video and lasers for this outdoors event at San Francisco's
> historic boatyard at Mission
> Rock.

And I doubt the above was the *first* club audio/video netcast; 's just
the first thing i stumbled across.  

But in the end, just cuz you ain't the first don't really mean nuthin',
eh?

--goolz

> Firstly, thanks to all who replyed to my request for rave info in the

> Secondly, a question. I maintain the internet site for the Ministry of
> Sound. Last month we did a live broadcast from the club. We had three
> cameras, sound taken from the decks and mixed with sound from microphones.
> Junior Vasquez was at the decks and the whole thing was fu*king amazing and
> technically perfect for over seven hours.
> 
> My question is this..
> 
> Is this the first live audio and video broadcast from a night club to the
> internet in the world?
>

> visuals and the golden scans look v.good, although the light is a bit poor.

Will,
The netcast may be the first in the UK, but it's definitely not the first
in the world. We've done several netcasts from night clubs here in SF...
the Ninja Tunes tour, the Recombinant/DJ battle (X-Men, Invisible Skratch
Picklz, Beat Junkies) netcast, the mixmaster morris netcast, others. And I
wouldn't claim us as the first either... I know that Mediacast
(http://www.mediacast.com/) has done some as well. And there are probably
tons more out there. In LA I know there's a site that has been doing it for
a while now as well (http://www.rave-network.com/).


Ninja Tunes:
http://wwww.hotwired.com/talk/presents/97/08/index1a.html

Mixmaster Morris:
http://wwww.hotwired.com/talk/presents/97/01/index2a.html

Recombinant:
http://www.asphodel.com/recombinant/index.html


And of course, there's the Beta Lounge, a weekly netcast of drum n bass,
hip-hop, dub, techno, etc. It's been up now for about 8 months:

http://www.betalounge.com/

Subject: Re: Live broadcast (BSP!)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Will,
The netcast may be the first in the UK, but it's definitely not the first
in the world. We've done several netcasts from night clubs here in SF...
the Ninja Tunes tour, the Recombinant/DJ battle (X-Men, Invisible Skratch
Picklz, Beat Junkies) netcast, the mixmaster morris netcast, others. And I
wouldn't claim us as the first either... I know that Mediacast
(http://www.mediacast.com/) has done some as well. And there are probably
tons more out there. In LA I know there's a site that has been doing it for
a while now as well (http://www.rave-network.com/).


Ninja Tunes:
http://wwww.hotwired.com/talk/presents/97/08/index1a.html

Mixmaster Morris:
http://wwww.hotwired.com/talk/presents/97/01/index2a.html

Recombinant:
http://www.asphodel.com/recombinant/index.html


And of course, there's the Beta Lounge, a weekly netcast of drum n bass,
hip-hop, dub, techno, etc. It's been up now for about 8 months:

http://www.betalounge.com/


At 6:28 AM -0800 6/11/97, Will Lovegrove wrote:
>Firstly, thanks to all who replyed to my request for rave info in the
>States. I've plenty to go on.
>
>Secondly, a question. I maintain the internet site for the Ministry of
>Sound. Last month we did a live broadcast from the club. We had three
>cameras, sound taken from the decks and mixed with sound from microphones.
>Junior Vasquez was at the decks and the whole thing was fu*king amazing and
>technically perfect for over seven hours.
>
>My question is this..
>
>Is this the first live audio and video broadcast from a night club to the
>internet in the world?
>
>I think its the first in the UK, but I could be wrong.
>
>Check out the archive -- over an hour of video and sound. The projection
>visuals and the golden scans look v.good, although the light is a bit poor.
>
>www.ministryofsound.co.uk
>
>If anyone knows of any other club doing this let me know, feedback about
>the reception of streaming audio and video in the states would also be
>appreciated.
>
>Later,
>
>Will.
