To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: music definitions
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, I've been listening to house, trance, techno, jungle, breakbeat, etc. for a 
long time, and when I listen to a song, I can usually tell which category
to put it in.  But here's my problem, for a long time now, I've had different
friends ask me what the difference between house and techno or trance and house
or trance and techno.  Now I know what each one sound's like in my head, but
I don't know how to verbalize this to others.  So here's what I'm asking. If 
people would be so kind as give me you own personal definition or description of
the following types of music.  When giving a definition or description try not 
to campare it to another type
of music and also please be as technical and wordy as possible.

Techno
Trance
House
Acid House
Breakbeat
Fast Trance (hard trance)
Hard Core
Jungle
Trip Hop
Ambient
Drum and Bass
Deep House
And any other categories of Electronic music that frequent our rave scene.

I will send out a prize to the person that gives me the best definitions.
Thank you in advance for spending your time on this.

PLUR X 5,000,000,000 (that's a lot)

Mattloaf

p.s. Don't ask me what the prize is, because I have thought of one yet, but
trust me, it will be cool what ever it is =)

Content-Type: text/plain

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey, all you music experts, help out a poor, confused newbie:

1.  What's the difference (if there is one) between deep house, acid 
house, 
and plain ol' house?
------------------

I think/hope that these definitions are correct.  Anyone help me if I'm 
wrong.  	
	I know that any kind of House music has a steady beat sort of like 
"Boom...Boom...Boom...Boom...Boom",  unlike a BreakBeat which will sound 
like  "Boom..Clap.Boom.Boom..Clap..Boom.Clap...Boom..Boom..Boom..Clap"
	Deep House is House music with Deep Ass Bass.  Bass so Low you can feel 
it vibrate in your stomach and groin.
	Acid House is House music that has a screeching sound that goes 
rearnt...rearnt.  Like the screaching sound from "A Higher State of 
Conciousness".
	And Plain ol' House would just be catchy House tunes that are really 
Great to listen to. =0)


2.  Are there any other offshoots of house music besides deep house and 
acid 
house?
----------------

There is also Tribal House that has a lot of drums in it like the song 
"In Da' Jungle" and there's Hard House that the Bass hits really hard.  
There's also Latin House which has Latin tunes and rhythms in it.  And I 
also know of Progressive House.  But can't really explain it.  (not sure 
of what the difference really is)


3.  What artists specialize in deep house?  What about acid house, and 
any 
other type of house?

Don't know too many artists.

4.  What djs specialize in those types of music?
-------------------

DJ Spun is a Good example of Deep House..he goes really Deep.
Jazz-E plays some Acid House
I think Steve Loria, Kimo and Josh play Good ol' House
Jeno & Tony play a lot of Tribal House and 
Carlos plays Hard House & Latin House
DJ Dan's new Weed Wacker tape is Progressive House


5.  Where's the next party where I can get another fix of deep house?
-----------------------

Saturday, July 5th - choice San Francisco presents Freedom Future 
Freakout Festival 97
6th Year Anniversary
Tony, Josh, Spun, Jon Williams, Doran, Joe Rice, Noel (B.A.S.S.Kru), 
Jason (Come/Unity), Daniel (Moontribe), Stacey Pullen (Detroit), Roy 
Davis Jr. (Chicago), more tba. 
E.S.W.H./E.S.D.S./H.O.B.M./H.O.M.E./organic food/free water
http://www.communion.com/gathering 
                                       415.905.9629 415.522.3994



I would have posted this privately, but I know/think/believe that there 
are a lot of people that might wonder about the differences.  Hopefully 
I know what I'm talking about and am not giving any false info.  If I am 
giving false info, please let me know so that I won't be confused 
anymore.  Thank you for your time.

I really liked those tan colored ones from the A/V lab back at my old

like them to be big but not too heavy and cover your ear.

tote the V-6's (about $79.00 at Fry's).

And this is just my opinion!
Sony V-756's ($95)I try to buy as close to wholesale as I can.
used V-6's (Careful--when they start to go they GO!) $45to$50. I know 
where one is this very moment.
Sony V-600 great for exxagerated Bass but little else. I will sell you 
mine for 50$$.

These are closed ear types.

My favorite under 500$ headphones are only 130$ BUT they are open ear(?)
they are the Beyerdynamic 990's.  While you are picking up your new 
headphones try these out. You cannot use them in a loud situation but on 
a walkman or tracking in a studio they cannot be beat!

as it is, i dont need some over jelious, attention seeking, please feel sorry

>has really hurt me in a big way and by doing this i hope i have 
>brought some
>relization on what doing something like this can do to someone, and i 
>thank
>you all for listening.
>
>much love 
>amanda

Date: Sat, 24 May 1997 20:32:43 +0000
From: Peter Webster <vignes@monaco.mc>
Subject: REVIEW: Raving in the LRB

London Review of Books 22 May 1997
contact:        edit@lrb.co.uk

RAVING, by Hari Kunzru

Reviews of:
ALTERED STATE: THE STORY OF ECSTASY CULTURE AND ACID HOUSE
by Matthew Collin and John Godfrey.
Serpents Tail, 314 pp., 18.99, 10 April, 1 85242 377 3

	and

DISCO BISCUITS
edited by Jane Champion.
Sceptre, 300 pp., 6.99, 5 February, 0 340 68265 6


'ECSTASY' is a brand name. According to tradition, the tag first
became attached to the drug MDMA (3-4
methylenedioxymethamphetamine) some time in the early Eighties,
when it moved out of the American psychotherapeutic community, in
which it had circulated for over a decade, and into wider use as a
recreational drug. The street-dealers needed something punchy, and
with its connotations of sexual abandon, the word 'ecstasy' propelled
the drug into mass use, international prohibition and ultimately a social
significance only matched, in the pharmaceutical stakes, by the
flowering of an LSD culture during the Sixties.
	First synthesised in 1912 by the Merck pharmaceutical
company of Darmstadt, MDMA---intended merely as a base for the
preparation of other medicaments---had been largely forgotten until
Alexander Shulgin, a Californian chemist, made up a batch in I966.
Shulgin, whose unusual psychopharmacological research had begun to
get him into trouble with his employer, the Dole Chemical Company,
was the first to recognise MDMA's mood-altering effects; he called itan
'empathogen'. So deeply affected was he by his MDMA experiences
that he eventually resigned his job, built a laboratory in his garden shed,
and embarked on thirty years of research into the drug and related
compounds, In PIHKAL ('Phenethylamines I Have Known And
Loved'), his autobiography-cum-pharmacopoeia, he gives details of
179 of them.
	In 1977, Shulgin gave MDMA to Leo Zoff, an elderly
psychologist. Zoff, on the verge of retiring, instead became the drug's
most zealous convert, travelling around America, introducing the
substance, which was beginning to be known as 'Adam', to an
estimated four thousand other psychologists and psychiatrists. This
community of believers, many of whom had seen their hopes for LSD
therapy dashed when LSD became a drug of mass abuse, tried hard to
keep Adam a secret, discouraging press coverage and even the
publication of scientific papers. But Adam's transformation into Ecstasy
had its own momentum, and in I985 possession was made a criminal
offense in the United States.
	Saatchi and Saatchi could not have improved on the choice of
the word 'ecstasy'. In the ten years since the drug burst into the British
popular consciousness, the 'ecstatic' aspect of MDMA has gripped the
imagination of the press. The enduring tabloid version of Ecstasy use
depicts the interior of a club; semi-naked girls with Iycra tops and water
bottles; boys with their shirts off, chewing gum; dilated pupils,
hormones and sweat. The drug's name is enough to make
commentators feel they understand what is going on---an unhealthily
Pavlovian form of pleasure-taking, vacuous, escapist and pernicious.
Combine this with the shyly smiling face of Leah Betts, who took 'just
one tablet' on her 18th birthday and promptly died, and you have a
powerful story. Here is a drug that transforms your daughter from a
well brought-up girl into a banshee nymphet, and in the process could
very possibly kill her: a persuasive argument for prohibition. Public
debate now places Ecstasy firmly in a medico-legal context- the only
acceptable framework for discussion of any proscribed substance. As a
means of understanding the drug's impact on society, this has obvious
limitations: the rhetoric of 'escapism', 'illegality' and 'self-harm' is
powerless to explain the rich and diverse culture which has rapidly
developed around the drug.
	At the centre of this culture is music. The evolution of House
and Techno, synthetic descendants of Seventies disco and European
electronic pop, has been largely driven by the Ecstasy experience. In a
process begun by the pioneers of black dance music in the Sixties,
familiar elements of traditional popular song---verse-chorus-verse
structure, harmonic resolutions---were stripped away, leaving eerie
cyclical patterns of bass and drums, overlaid with the barest remnants
of melody. These hypnotic, trance-inducing rhythms and sparse,
repetitive melodic loops, almost incomprehensible to ears accustomed
to more conventional musical forms, can make startling and beautiful
sense when combined with MDMA.
	House music (the term has come to stand for only one genre,
but is a plausible generic label) has no regard for the ideal of virtuosiq
which governs not only 'classical' music, but rock and jazz. In place of
the guitar hero, and the quasi-religious cults of personality which drive
popular music marketing, are artists who may never 'perform' in
public, may make music under a plethora of different names, and
distribute their work through an underground network of DJs and
specialist record shops. At the receiving end, the listeners and dancers
may never even have a sense of the individual 'work' at all,
experiencing it merely as an element in a DJ's mix of sounds, which,
though usually derived from recorded media, may also include live
elements produced by manipulating electronics or (more rarely)
traditional instruments.
	Music is only one element in the most visible product of
Ecstasy culture---the parties. From the famous M25 raves of the late
Eighties to the current proliferation of commercial nightclubs, Ecstasy
has changed the patterns of British leisure. For many people, Saturday
night now continues until sunrise, rather than stopping when the pubs
shut. Though the combination of music, lightshow and dancing has
well-documented origins in the psychedelic all-nighters of the Sixties, in
its modern form the illegal rave (now an endangered species) can be an
experience of unprecedented potency. The sense of affirmation and
shared purpose, of celebration, almost of religious ritual, not to
mention the sheer uncomplicated fun of a large number of people
brazenly doing something illicit, together produce events which, while
centring on a drug, are not fairly represented by the mindless lotus-
eating of tabloid myth.
	A 1994 Home Office survey estimates that up to a million
Britons have tried E; and something like a million tablets are consumed
every weekend. At ten pounds a dose, that represents an industry
turning over half a billion pounds annually, supported by 2 per cent of
the population, all of whom are breaking the law to participate.
'Ecstasy culture', then, is a name for rather more than a collection of
ephemeral trends in music, fashion or the visual arts.
	Matthew Collin and John Godfrey have interviewed many of
the key figures in Ecstasy's journey from a Californian 'penicillin for the
soul' to a black-market leisure industry. From this material and their
own experiences, they have put together a fascinating history. While
the authors make no secret of their allegiances (the book is dedicated
to 'all the friends who lived it with us'), Altered State examines
policing strategies, media coverage and health scares with the same care
that it devotes to the diverse cultural roots of Acid House music and its
more recent offshoots.
	Unlike LSD, which from Aldous Huxley onwards attracted a
self-appointed avant garde, concerned with shaping and directing the
'consciousness revolution', Ecstasy, in its post-Shulgin incarnation, has
been a resoundingly democratic drug. Collin and Godfrey emphasise
the diversity of its devotees, from snobbish New Romantic starlets in
the VIP rooms of mid-Eighties London nightclubs to itinerant thieves on
the beaches of Ibiza. A classless drug for a newly-proclaimed classless
society.
	As Collin and Godfrey put it, 'Ecstasy culture seemed to ghost
the Thatcher narrative - echoing its ethos of choice and market
freedom, yet expressing desires for a collective experience that
Thatcher rejected and consumerism could not provide.' The
proponents of LSD-driven psychedelic revolution have tended to
excoriate E culture's lack of ideology, portraying its appropriation of
the love-and-peace rhetoric of the Sixties as debased or superficial. An
American researcher, quoted in Altered State, recalls that 'the man
who first named it "Ecstasy" told me that he chose the name because it
would sell better than calling it "Empathy". "Empathy" would be more
appropriate, but how many people know what it means?'
	In the climate of Tory Britain, MDMA's biochemical effect
took on an oppositional character. Shulgin's 'empathogen' provided a
powerful counter-argument to the bleak vision of atomised individuals
competing for scarce resources. Hugging a complete stranger in the
centre of a crowded dance-floor is still something worth driving zoo
miles for; it is worth the risk of arrest on drugs charges, worth a face-
off with the police in a muddy field. Indeed, the fact that the state has
seemed so concerned to prevent the formation of such obviously
communal events is a source of moral confusion for many young
people.
	The language of epic struggle---War on Drugs v. Freedom to
Party---is deployed on both sides of the Ecstasy divide. In the late
Eighties and early Nineties, a period of huge, illegal outdoor raves,
there was a sense that a battle was being waged for the soul of Britain.
Local worthies whose communities were disrupted believed they were
engaged in a last-ditch defence of the citadel. To the ravers the issues
seemed equally clear. When the drug that catalyses your most intense
and positive experiences is declared illegal, when (in the absence of
unbiased medical information) government-sponsored doctors seem to
be brokering scare stories, when the police attempt to prevent you and
your friends from coming together, could you not be forgiven for
feeling that you are at war?
	Conspiracy theories aside, the spectacle of parental authority in
the guise of the police attempting to halt parties is almost a parody of
youth culture's primal scene the kids v. the straights, the town where
the preacher and the police chief ban dancing. Yet this opposition, the
stuffof musicals or light comedy, has now been enshrined in law. The
Criminal Justice and Public Order Act of 1994 includes various anti-
rave provisions and, notoriously, the first ever legal definition of a
genre of music, enabling the police to break up gatherings where
people are listening to amplified sounds 'wholly or predominantly
characterized by the emission of a succession of repetitive beats'.
	This description of House or Techno music is included in the
CJA's list of criteria by which a policeman can tell he is in- the
presence of a 'rave', and may legitimately close it down (it must also
be at least 'partly' outdoors and disturbing local residents). It doesn't
always work, however, as I discovered at a small park on the South
Coast. Things were well underway, with the sound-system pumping and
two or three hundred wide-eyed people dancing by firelight when, as
expected, the police arrived. Immediately the DJ switched from techno
to 20th-century choral music. The bemused coppers were treated to
the spectacle of a couple of hundred people stumbling around to the
work of the Estonian composer, Arvo Part. They hung about for ten
minutes, powerless to stop the event then left, much to the
disappointment of a group of partygoers who had been enjoying the
flashing blue lights.
	The CJA definition has confirmed what the dancers already
suspected: that as far as the authorities are concerned, drugs are not
the only problem. Implicit in the whole lifestyle, the parties, the
hedonism, even the simple act of staying up all night is a rejection of
the 'traditional' values of continence, moderation and the moral value
of work which it was, for 18 years, the mission of Conservative
government to inculcate. With the CJA, dancing became, in a small
way, a political action, and 'ravers' (in 1997 already a quaint word)
joined travellers, immigrants, single mothers and the unemployed in
Conservative demonology.

	MUSIC, fashion, photography, computer animation and club
visuals have all done well out of E. Writers, on the other hand, have
relatively little to offer the scene, except in an after-the-fact way as
reporters, chroniclers or mythologists. The sleeve note and the club
review don't offer much scope for verbal creativity, which in a party
setting is the sole preserve of the MCs who whip up the crowd in clubs
and rap over the music on pirate radio. Disco Biscuits, a collection of
new fiction from the chemical generation', is a conscious attempt to
create the canon of Ecstasy fiction which has conspicuously failed to
appear in the last ten years. It is a difficult project. To many observers,
the lack of 'serious' E-related cultural material (which almost invariably
means writing) is an indicator that the experience of Ecstasy is
ultimately vacuous. When I mentioned Disco Biscuits at a (non-
dancing) party, I was asked whether 'people who take E' actually read
books. From Shulgin onwards, grandiose statements have been made
about E's ability to enhance emotional articulacy---why, then, the
literary silence?
	Disco Biscuits is unlikely to make many converts. The writing is
at its best when, as in Gavin Hills's 'White Burger Danny', it restricts
itself to a near-documentary account of parties and people. E culture's
variety is well represented, and Martin Millar's squatland South
London, Alex Garland's backpacker Thailand, Jonathan Brook's Ibiza
and Jeff Noon's fantastical Manchester have little in common, apart
>from the constant presence of narcotics. Ecstasy is only part of the
roster of drugs, real and imaginary, which seems to form the
collection's primary raison d'etre. At times this obsession with the
brute act of drug-taking degenerates into something very like chemical
pornography, texts which exist only to record heroic feats of
consumption. The reader comes away with little from 'Two Fingers'
Puff' or Nicholas Blincoe's 'Ardwick Green' other than a desire to skin
up and to avoid mixing acid, speed, Ecstasy, cocaine, smack and amyl
in the men's room of a provincial nightclub.

	A SENSE OF PLEASURES guiltily taken pervades the book, as
if the sheer weight of moral sanction against drug use had forced much
of the writing into its present shape. Several of the stories get no
further than attempting to convey sense impressions of paradoxically
compressed and edgy good times. Many seem to be struggling against
the influence of the canonical drug-writings of the Beat and Hippy eras.
Burroughs looms large, as do Kerouac and Hunter S. Thompson. In
these respects, the book is accurate: the guild darkness hovering at the
edges of pleasure, and the Oedipal battle with a generation of former
rebels turned cultural arbiters, are authentic aspects of Nineties
experience. After Aids and the massive come-down ofthe Eighties, the
sense of childlike celebration which characterises many classic Sixties
drug-culture texts is no longer available. We are not allowed to forget
that pleasure has a price, nor do we have the luxury of believing in
permanent revolution or the imminent dawning of the age of Aquarius.
	The aura of teen rebellion which surrounds the battle between
E culture and British Conservatism tends to obscure the seriousness of
the issues it raises. While Disco Biscuits rarely rises above the ephemera
of the scene, Altered Statc keeps politics in the foreground even as it
tells picaresque stories of rave promoters with suitcases of cash,
Manchester lads breaking into warehouses or Spiral Tribe's Iain
Sinclairish attempt to topple the state by setting up a sound-system on
an occult spot near that symbol of Eighties greed, Canary Wharf. As
the idealism of the early years of Acid House fades, buried by mass-
market clubbing and the current revival in the popularity of cocaine,
this kind of stock-taking is needed if we are to understand the long-
term impact of an era which pitted the state against the young, and
created an endemic distrust of authority.

i had heard it was ron hardy who first mixed records but after reading
hyperreal i think that i was probably wrong about house dj's mixing
records first .   what i really meant was beatmatching.  I don't know but
i have a feeling that disco dj's might have invented this.   House was so
disco waaay back in the day that i bet for a time the lines between the
two were blurred.  but i am not an expert the jamaicans could have
started beatmatching.   hip-hop/rap mixing is a whole different thing
too.  I guess i should have been more careful with what i said.

HOUSE IS A FEELIN' THAT NOBODY CAN UNDERSTAND UNLESS THEY ARE DEEP IN THE
VIBE OF HOUSE


anyway that's what house is.

but when we are talking about house music we can talk about all kinds of
different house music.
just some examples

(in no particular order)
1.chicago house
2.new york house
3.acid house
4.u.k. house
5.deep house
6. tribal house
7. progressive house
8. pop/radio house

+some more that i cannot think of.

house music started in chicago around the mid eighties. it is called
house because it is the style of music played at The Warehouse in
chicago. a clup where the legendary frankie knuckles tore up the decks. 
meanwhile a similar evolution was taking place in NYC where the legendary
Larry Levan played at the Paradise Garage.   the term garage refers to
this place.  house music is all of the music that was inspired by and
written for this kind of vibe.  something really special happened at
these places. and house was born.


CATEGORIES OF HOUSE

1. Chicago house_
house would not be called house without chicago.  but today the term
chicago is not refering to old school house roots.  Chicago has its own
thing goin on.   Chicago house tends to have more of a 4/4 beat than any
other kind of house.  One word that can be used to describe alot of
chicago house is "tracky".  Tracky is a hard word to describe but it
means that the sounds sound like they are all "on track".  chicago house
is harder and can often be characterized as more raw.    chicago house is
meant to be mixed ALOT (thats why they make it so tracky)  
some examples of chicago house 
*anything on the casual label
*dj sneak(the master of the tracky track)
*derrick carter
*green velvet

dj's  mark farina and harry who and john howard (although mark farina and
harry play alot of deep house)

2. new york house
new york house music has less of a 4/4 beat sometimes and is often more
vocal.  the production on new york house tracks is less simple, less raw,
not really tracky at all.  i think new york house songs stand alone
better.
some examples
fade 2 black
nuyorican soul
armand van helden (when he is not busy selling out)
felix da housecat
dj duke
brooklyn A  train

3.  acid house came out in like 1989 and it featured the sounds of the
roland 202 and 303 drum machines.  acid is a particular kind of sound. 
it sounds like spaceships shooting at eachother (or your brain melting)  
 acid is common all throughout the realm of dance music these days.  
trance techno house and breakbeat all have songs that feature the kind of
sounds that are known as acid.   if you ever hear a song by josh winx you
are listening to acid.   to me when i think of acid house i think of the
original shit that sounds like it comes from 1989 
examples (old school shit)
anything on trax records
wetbrook bam -bam
 
examples (new stuff)
josh winx is a perfect example

4.UK HOUSE  house took off way more in england than it did here.    house
songs from england have much more polished production.  (less raw)  
england has (or had) much more outdoor parties and therefore alot of
english house is the kind of stuff you want to play outside.   also
england comes with more dub influences.  and more instumental sounding
stuff.  the SF scene plays alot of UK house (largely because of the
wicked crew)
examples
ashley beedle (black science orchestra, the Jahmeka boyz)
harvey
the idjut boys
the basement jax 


5. DEEP HOUSE  deep house sounds real mellow when you hear without a loud
system.  the reason it is called deep is not because of the deep bass
(almost  all house has deep bass, thats what makes you move your ass) . 
deep house is characterized by sounds that sound kinda liquid. lots of
chords.  like i said sounds mellow in the store or at home but you put it
on a loud system and suddenley you are underwater in a sea of liquid bass
puddles. kinda hypnotic? this is another one that someone should show you
to have you understand.
examples 
guidance records makes alot of DEEP chicago house (my favorite label)
moodyman
deep inside (barbara tucker and lil louis vega)

dj's mark farina plays alot of deep house.  his "seasons" mixtape/cd is
really good .  lots of deep chicago house

6.TRIBAL HOUSE congas are real big in tribal house (just cause something
has congas doesn't mean it is tribal)   wierd animal and "native people"
noises are found alot.  also other afro drum rythms.  tribal is often a
little more uptempo and often borders on the techno fringe.  like someone
mentioned "deep in the jungle" (actually called Playboy in the Jungle) is
a good example that i can think of from today.

dj tom from raindance(santa cruz) plays sooo tribal (he is not kidding
about it)


7. progressive house is where techno and house meet.  think of it as
techno that is playing about 125 bpm 
can't think of much in the way of examples here because i don't really
buy this kind

8. pop house/radio house
right said fred, haddaway , THE FUNK PHENOMENON,armand van helden (when
he is busy selling out)   don't ever listen to this kind of music.  House
is an underground art form (at least the good stuff)  give your radio
away and only listen to tapes.  radio and mtv are all just one big ad
anyway.


make sure you don't get caught up on these words.  these categories are
descriptions of styles.  thats all they are.   they are tools for
describing what kind of music someone likes or doesn't like.  people
blend styles all the time.  


hope this helped
gabe

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id AAA11854;
	Thu, 12 Jun 1997 00:50:33 -0700 (PDT)

Ok peepz, classify these

-- Way Out West :: these folx wrote my fav vocal house song "let Yourself Go"
		i wish i could find a bunch of their songs on CD because
		i like their sound -- very simple, but very uplifting.
		my fav mix of this is off of a Sound Dimensions (UK)
		mix CD called retrospective of house '91-'96  a 3 disk
		set. the mix i like best is by DJ "Sister Bliss".

		I disagree with whoever classified them as "EuroDisco"
		As far as I can tell, they play solid foundational house.

-- Cevin Fisher -- "The Way We Used To DO It" -- this one is really hard
		to Mix. off kilter syncopation. of course, i only have
		it on a mixed CD, so perhaps having a real intro/outro
		to mix would help. big earth shaking bass.

-- That song "Smokebelch" -- forgot the name of the group that did this.
		Definitely Prog House, right??

	Sincrely yours, 
	Mixless, houseless, and almost musicless in Bangalore India
	Niels.

PS: when you get right down to it, the only kind of rave music that I
find at all deep is house music. i love house music. not the cheezy
stuff, but real honest to goodness make-a-grown-man cry for joy house
music. yesirree. everything else just sounds like it's waiting to be
made into a soundtrack for a commercial. i'd rather have a nice simple
uplifting house choon than the  vapid & emotionless rococo of sound
that defines the trendy newfangled shit.

Precedence: bulk


Back before I got shipped off to india to do software consulting for a
large  multinational,  I went to Fry's (Palo ALto) and noticed they
still sell Sony MDR-V6's. Pretty reasonable price too.

I also saw some Technics "1200 series DJ" headphones. Has anybody tried
these? Are they an better than the MDR-V6's?? Looks like the only
advantage is they have this rotating earpiece that can swivel forward
so you can listen in 1 ear. I just rotate the V6's earpiece around (via
the swivel) to do that.

PS: the best thing to do on a 30-40 hour trans-global flight  (e.g.
SF-->London-->Delhi-->Bangalore) is  to build a battery pack for your
Roland MC-303, strap yourself in the airplane seat, and program beats
and acid breaks for 10 hours straight. People look at you really funny
and all the stewardesses drop by just to make sure you're not arming a
bomb....

	Randomly Yours,
	Beatful and bountiful in beautiful Bangalore,
	Niels.

>>>
>>>>  House dj's invented mixing records.
>>>
>>
>>Correction, disco DJ's were the first to mix records.  Then came rapppers,
>>then came house.
>>
>
>        it was defenitely first done in Jamaica. Have you ever heard U-Roy?
>He mixed together stuff and MC'd over it, and that was back in the late
>50's! I also thought Grandmaster Flash or Afrika Bambaataa or something said
>they'd started mixing stuff in the early 70's as well, and they defenitely
>don't do disco.

Maybe someone can settle this.  Now what you are talking about is toasting
which was done over A record, not two.  So you continue to say mixing as if
the toaster was MC'ing over two records.  I doubt it since it was done over
1.

Next Disco was before rap.  Period.  Afrikka & Zulu Nation and all those
boys came out at around the time disco was fading(take your oldest Afrikka
B. record and I'll beat you out two years with some old ass disco tunes
'73-'74+).  By that time mixing was already being done by famous DJ's
(Frankie Knuckles & Mr. Fingers for one).  Disco (early 70's) was before
rap, rap (mid/late 70's) came next.

Peace,
John

>>Quotes from the past about innovative ideas.
>>
>> "Computers in the future may weigh no more than 1.5 tons." --Popular
>> Mechanics, forecasting the relentless march of science, 1949
>>
>> "I think there is a world market for maybe five computers." --Thomas
>> Watson, chairman of IBM, 1943
>>
>> "I have traveled the length and breadth of this country and talked with
>> the best people, and I can assure you that data processing is a fad that
>>won't
>> last out the year." --The editor in charge of business books for Prentice
>> Hall, 1957
>>
>> "But what ... is it good for?" --Engineer at the Advanced Computing
>Systems > Division of IBM, 1968, commenting on the microchip.
>>
>> "There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home." --Ken
>> Olson, president, chairman and founder of Digital Equipment Corp., 1977
>>
>> "This 'telephone' has too many shortcomings to be seriously considered as
>> a means of communication. The device is inherently of no value to us."
>> --Western Union internal memo, 1876.
>>
>> "The wireless music box has no imaginable commercial value. Who would pay
>> for a message sent to nobody in particular?" --David Sarnoff's associates
>> in response to his urgings for investment in the radio in the 1920s.
>>
>> "The concept is interesting and well-formed, but in order to earn better
>> than a 'C,' the idea must be feasible." --A Yale University management
>> professor in response to Fred Smith's paper proposing reliable overnight
>> delivery service. (Smith went on to found Federal Express Corp.)
>>
>> "Who the hell wants to hear actors talk?" --H.M. Warner, Warner Brothers,
>> 1927.
>>
>> "I'm just glad it'll be Clark Gable who's falling on his face and not
>> Gary Cooper." --Gary Cooper on his decision not to take the leading role
>in
>> "Gone With The Wind."
>>
>> "A cookie store is a bad idea. Besides, the market research reports say
>> America likes crispy cookies, not soft and chewy cookies like you make."
>> --Response to Debbi Fields' idea of starting Mrs. Fields' Cookies.
>>
>> "We don't like their sound, and guitar music is on the way out." --Decca
>> Recording Co. rejecting the Beatles, 1962.
>>
>> "Heavier-than-air flying machines are impossible." --Lord Kelvin,
>> president, Royal Society, 1895.
>>
>> "If I had thought about it, I wouldn't have done the experiment. The
>> literature was full of examples that said you can't do this." --Spencer
>> Silver on the work that led to the unique adhesives for 3-M "Post-It"
>> Notepads.
>>
>> "So we went to Atari and said, 'Hey, we've got this amazing thing, even
>> built with some of your parts, and what do you think about funding us? Or
>> we' ll give it to you. We just want to do it. Pay our salary, we'll come
>> work for you.' And they said, 'No.' So then we went to Hewlett-Packard,
>> and they said, 'Hey, we don't need you. You haven't got through college
>> yet.'"
>> --Apple Computer Inc. founder Steve Jobs on attempts to get Atari and H-P
>> interested in his and Steve Wozniak's personal computer.
>>
>> "Professor Goddard does not know the relation between action and reaction
>> and the need to have something better than a vacuum against which to
>> react.
>>
>> He seems to lack the basic knowledge ladled out daily in high schools."
>> --1921 New York Times editorial about Robert Goddard's revolutionary
>> rocket work.
>>
>> "You want to have consistent and uniform muscle development across all of
>> your muscles? It can't be done. It's just a fact of life. You just have
>> to accept inconsistent muscle development as an unalterable condition of
>> weight training." --Response to Arthur Jones, who solved the "unsolvable"
>> problem by inventing Nautilus.
>>
>> "Drill for oil? You mean drill into the ground to try and find oil?
>> You're crazy." --Drillers who Edwin L. Drake tried to enlist to his
>>project to
>> drill for oil in 1859.
>>
>> "Stocks have reached what looks like a permanently high plateau."
>> -Irving Fisher, Professor of Economics, Yale University, 1929.
>>
>> "Airplanes are interesting toys but of no military value." --Marechal
>> Ferdinand Foch, Professor of Strategy, Ecole Superieure de Guerre.
>>
>> "Everything that can be invented has been invented." --Charles H. Duell,
>> Commissioner, U.S. Office of Patents, 1899.
>>
>> "Louis Pasteur's theory of germs is ridiculous fiction". --Pierre Pachet,
>> Professor of Physiology at Toulouse, 1872
>>
>> "The abdomen, the chest, and the brain will forever be shut from the
>> intrusion of the wise and humane surgeon". --Sir John Eric Ericksen,
>> British surgeon, appointed Surgeon- Extraordinary to Queen Victoria 1873.
>>
>>
>> "640K ought to be enough for anybody." -- Bill Gates, 1981


Kisses,
Julie

I am trully sorry for this post!! My company Computer & Business
Communications is now in stage 2 of chapter 13 Bankruptcy because of
this issue. I house a server for several lage firms and this attack has
totally shut down the backbone entirely from California accsess.  I am
now going on my 4th week of server downtime. I know that very few people
amy have information about this, but I am trying to get the word out!!

					Thanks Ahead,
						Mr. Matthew Lewis Downer
						President
						Computer & Business Communications
Dearborn, MI  May 28th, 1997: Worldwide Internet access provider AGIS
(Apex GlobalInternet Services, Inc.), announced a total reward pool of
$25,000 for information leading
to the arrest and conviction of persons involved with the recent attack
on AGIS' network.
The FBI has set up a hot line, encouraging anyone with information to
call 313-965-3028. 

The Michigan-based Internet access provider, founded in 1994, is one of
the original "big
six" companies exchanging Internet traffic at the major Internet
exchange points.

AGIS again confirmed that the attackers did not gain access to any
virtual private networks,
and that no private information was compromised. The company has
increased security
measures, but has not been at liberty to disclose the details of the
investigation. 

Phil Lawlor, AGIS President and CEO said, "Unfortunately, we are not
able to disclose
any specifics relative to the recent attacks on our network; it is
paramount that we keep this
information confidential so as not to compromise the investigation. We
encourage anyone
with information to come forward," Lawlor added. 

AGIS (www.agis.net), founded in 1994, provides Internet access to
millions of users via
its extensive customer base of Regional Bell Operating Companies,
content providers,
large corporations, and Internet service providers. A technology leader
and innovator,
AGIS is the first Internet access provider to deploy ATM technology to
operate a national
backbone network, the first to offer commercial 155 Mbps connections to
the 'Net, the first
to reduce points of failure in a network by using switching
technologies, the first to design
a wholesale business model (so as not to compete with customers by
selling retail access),
and the first to provide multiple distribution centers for content
replication
(CooLocation). AGIS offers Internet connectivity from 56 Kbps to 155
Kbps.

AGIS is headquartered at 3601 Pelham Road, Dearborn, Michigan 48124
Phone: 800/380-AGIS; Fax: 313-563-6119; E-mail: info@agis.net


pr@agis.net 



All other trademarks are the sole property of their respective owners.

From: 	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com on behalf of marbs@cats.ucsc.edu
Sent: 	Wednesday, June 11, 1997 5:39 PM
To: 	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: 	music definitions

Ok, I've been listening to house, trance, techno, jungle, breakbeat, etc. for 
a 
long time, and when I listen to a song, I can usually tell which category
to put it in.  But here's my problem, for a long time now, I've had different
friends ask me what the difference between house and techno or trance and 
house
or trance and techno.  Now I know what each one sound's like in my head, but
I don't know how to verbalize this to others.  So here's what I'm asking. If 
people would be so kind as give me you own personal definition or description 
of
the following types of music.  When giving a definition or description try not 

to campare it to another type
of music and also please be as technical and wordy as possible.

Techno
Trance
House
Acid House
Breakbeat
Fast Trance (hard trance)
Hard Core
Jungle
Trip Hop
Ambient
Drum and Bass
Deep House
And any other categories of Electronic music that frequent our rave scene.

I will send out a prize to the person that gives me the best definitions.
Thank you in advance for spending your time on this.

PLUR X 5,000,000,000 (that's a lot)

Mattloaf

p.s. Don't ask me what the prize is, because I have thought of one yet, but
trust me, it will be cool what ever it is =)

In-Reply-To: <19970612.003754.11782.1.GabeRRamos@juno.com>

>5. DEEP HOUSE  deep house sounds real mellow when you hear without a loud
>system.  the reason it is called deep is not because of the deep bass
>(almost  all house has deep bass, thats what makes you move your ass) . 
>deep house is characterized by sounds that sound kinda liquid. lots of
>chords.  like i said sounds mellow in the store or at home but you put it
>on a loud system and suddenley you are underwater in a sea of liquid bass
>puddles. kinda hypnotic? this is another one that someone should show you
>to have you understand.
>examples 
>guidance records makes alot of DEEP chicago house (my favorite label)
>moodyman
>deep inside (barbara tucker and lil louis vega)

also deep house has a lot of diva's belting away the vocals.

>7. progressive house is where techno and house meet.  think of it as
>techno that is playing about 125 bpm 
>can't think of much in the way of examples here because i don't really
>buy this kind

there is a lot of layering in this type of house as well.  You know hit
hats for 4 measures, and then bass added with hi hats for another 4
measures and then a repeating vocal added, you know the deal, it
"progresses".  Also this type of house is great to mix with because there
is a lot of layering. Some people call progressive house anything that
cannot be labeled as one of the other types of house music.  Since house
music is always changing, the newest style is often called progressive.

>8. pop house/radio house
>right said fred, haddaway , THE FUNK PHENOMENON,armand van helden (when
>he is busy selling out)   don't ever listen to this kind of music.  House
>is an underground art form (at least the good stuff)  give your radio
>away and only listen to tapes.  radio and mtv are all just one big ad
>anyway.
>
The Funk Phenomenon is not pop house, it is more of a progressive, hard,
trakky, funky sort of house.  It has the typical "Armand" type sound.
Pop house is like Real Mccoy or The Captain Hollywood Project.  The bass is
really cheesy sounding and it isn't deep bass, it kind of sounds like
crappy fake drums, if you know what I mean.  Also there is the planet soul,
angelina, blah blah blah type of house that always has the same breakdown:
First there is a diva singing and it goes from an acid house type of sound,
then it breaks down and has a slow hip hop beat, and then it builds back up
to a normal 120-125 bpm acid beat.

You forgot the last type of house (my favorite)- HARD house!!!!

This is the type that is just a banging, hard ass 4/4 that is 130-150 bpm.
Bad Boy Bill plays this, as well as Richard "Humpty" Vission.  Some of it
is cheesy but if you find the good stuff, I gaurantee that people will move
their asses all night.

i.e. -Trancesetters- The Search
     -DJ Funk- Work It
     -CZR- Chicago Southside

this is my opinion...

I have to admit I like some of that radio-er, club house too (I always called 
it dance music).  Like I know I'll get it for saying this, but I looooove Real 
McCoy.  And I like "Funk Phenomenon."  And that "Professional Widow" remix is 
all that--I love the beat and I love Tori (w/ or w/o remixing).  As for 
Haddaway, my mom got sprung off of that "What is Love" song and everytime I 
hear it I think of her booming that tape in her car and bobbing her head (go 
Momma, go Momma, it's your birthday)--it's an okay song.

But I'm more into deep house and acid house (hee hee, I know what I'm talking 
about now--thanx Gabe and all the rest), and like I always say, "the less diva 
the better."

btw, I picked up a 2-cd compilation at Tower the other day--it's an import 
called "Distance to Technoland" or something like that, and it has house-type 
remixes of an assorted bunch of songs.  My fave right now is the Daft Punk 
remix of "Chord Memory."  And there's a remix of an Orbital song ("Papua New 
Guinea") that sounds just like this old Delerium song (on the Semantic Spaces 
album).  I highly reccommend it.  Only thing that sux is that the songs aren't 
mixed together (as in pauses between songs) and there's a funky Aphex Twin 
song on there (I like Aphex Twin--e.g. Girl/Boy Song and Ventolin (sp?), but 
this song was just bad).

xoxo--Miccaela
unregistered version
----------

1) Any large firm should be multi-homed and not susceptible to
   system-wide network outage due the failure of a single provider.  

2) AGIS is and has aided and abetted individuals that are involved in 
   theft of service and the misuse of other peoples systems as relays
   agents for SPAM. Beyond refusing to take any action against their
   rogue customers, they have gone so far as to give rogue customers
   such as Cyberpromo alternate netblocks in order to bypass filters that
   victims and those wishing to avoid such misuse of their services have 
   placed in their routers.

While I do not endorse the actions of those attacking AGIS, AGIS is solely
responsible for bringing the attacks upon themselves, leaving their
customers, such as yourself, to suffer as a result of their irresponsible
and possibly actionable activities.

Nancy wrote: 

>There is really virtually nothing in the big club scene in SF.  It's 
>too bad.

Well heres a chance to fix that. Pablos Sugar Shack presents:

**The VSF/SFR Lounge**
[6.14 - Micron & Macadio]

(1)Weekly Pablos will feature 1-2 SFRaves Djs (past & present members) 
spinning between 9:45 pm to 12:30 am. (approx.) every Saturday night.
(2)The $10 cover charge will be waived b4 11pm for SFRavers that say 
the magic word SFRaves List to our cashier upon entrance. Note: 
Please do not abuse this privilege by sharing this password w/ others.
(3)Arrangements have been made to offer cheap $2 drafts or $1 water b4 
11pm. 

Heres the idea>>> From the start our party Pablos Sugar Shack has 
been based in music and not the scene. Believe it or not, a lot of 
clubs in SF arent.  We have no dress policy, martini lounges, VIP 
lists, etc. Just a core group of friends trying to throw a good party 
on a Saturday night. Many of whom, myself included, are ravers and 
SFRaves veterans.

To that end weve decided to open our space up to the list as a place 
toGet Your Groove On Before You Move On. A place to hook up with 
people from the list while checking out some good music, arranging 
rides, etc. Generally, a place to meet up on your way to some place 
else. Youre also welcome to stay, should you choose to do so. 

Note: when this idea was initially posted to the list I received a 
flood of positive mail (surprisingly not one negative response) 
offering DJ services, decoration help, promotion help, etc.  
Unfortunately, Like a total loser, I accidentally erased them all. So 
if you are interested in any of the above mentioned items please send 
mail to:   mpengra@aol.com  (include phone #)

The only regret that I have is that our space is restricted to persons 
who are 21 and over. That aside, I invite you to help affect a change 
in the SF scene for the better and I look forward to meeting you on 
Saturday nig
ht

Location: VSF, 278 11th Street, SOMA, SF (Saturdays)

This Week: 6.14.97
Micron (SFR), Macadio (SFR), Taj, Funky Tekno Tribe Afterparty
9:30p-6am

Next Week: 6.21.97 (solstice party) 
Simon, John Howard, Taj, Hector, Moises, Lele, (SFR)TBA
9:30p-4am
infoline: 415.668.2476

Bring your smiles & friends & let's create something special.

SEE YA THERE!!!
-Sunny

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 12 13:13:49 1997

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id NAA00762;
	Thu, 12 Jun 1997 13:13:49 -0700 (PDT)

Message-ID: <339FE822.69AE@best.com>
Date: Thu, 12 Jun 1997 13:16:07 +0100
From: Alex Ward <bwret@best.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.01 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: breaks@xmission.com
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Top 10 Record Bag
References: <199706121909.PAA07488@csa.bu.edu>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Massive,

In no order:

1. Scorpio- Li Li- V

Gots to be my favorite track off this godly comp. Mix-friendly intro
with a drum roll out of the last measure. Drops into a typical but
nonetheless excellent Size roller.

2. SS krew- England

Label side is a wicked analogue-sounding jump-up number in the vein of
Elementz' 'Chillin' and Mental Power's Silver. The flip is a MASSIVE
tune which you will want to let play through. Starts off steppy with a
cool filter sweep. Later it tears out into a stormer. Devastating.

3. 3D and Snuggles- Defender- Ghetto Safari

I'm eatin up domestic plates like a cop eatin donuts. This shit is PHAT!
A-side is a deep, deep number...gorgeous. My current fave is the first
track on the flip, a sparse boomin track which will tear up the dance
floor. Much respect.

4. Neotech- Valves- Shadow

Dom and Ed...what more can I say. Two stormy, moody tracks which get the
job done. Very nice production and a better pressing than usual (last
couple tracks have been shoddy).

5. Padded Room- BLIM- Emotif

What is it about this song that I've been listening to it five times a
day for the past two weeks. Sometimes people just do it right. Here are
two on the tech-bleepy side, but very mellow. Melodic and brilliantly
arranged- my favorite at the moment.

6. Jekyl & Hyde- Borderline- KUS

Forget the Dj Fresh tracks and flip straight to the J&H bizness. This
track is solid and has been blowing shit up left and right. Simple but
effective, it's got chopped up drums and a spooky synth stab. Add drum
rolls and intelligent breakdowns and you get a wicked combination. 
Tearout!

7. Smokey Joe- Freestyle- Smokers Inc.

Two deep steppy tracks which jus' put you in the mood. Freestyle has
these great synchopated drums which drop into a deep growling stepper.
Flip-side is more atmospheric. Nodders light up!

8.Splash Collective- It's for Us- Splash

Dreamy vocal drone at the beginning with cool warped bass stabs. Drops
into a RUFF roller a la 'Flava' by D'bridge. Squeeze this one for all
its got. Flip is a mellow Majistrate roller with Star Trek samples.

9. Wyld Pitch- Darb Down- Arcane

Still up there after a few weeks, this track is the bomb. Toeing the
line between jump-up and tech-step this thing will devestate any dance
floor. Starts off dubby and half-time, it eventually drops into an
absolute stormer with sirens to boot. Flip it for a murky tech stepper.

10. Aenosis- Shatter- Octopus

The same Aenosis that used to do breakbeat? Dunno, but this plate is
fresh. Starts off with some mellow keys, but opens into a techy
two-step. Halfway though the drums go ballistic: dreamy yet pounding!
One for the armchair krew.

More props:

Elementz- Sights&Sounds-Emotif (dark)
Dom&Optical-Quadrant6-Shadows (classic in the making)
Grooves rmx of Share the Fall (tearing it up in the UK)
Shimon&AndyC-Genetix-Ram (flip this one for a twisted roller)
Boyerang's rmx of Technology (one for the dance-halls)
R Notorious J w/ Kingsize-Shockwave-Primitive (Domestic J-up bizness)

And..

V-Classic: Already mentioned, but I've got to say this is the classiest
posse around. Mad props for this collection of great tunes. Shame to
see'em become the next big thing, but they deserve it.

-peace-

SCiEnCe

a *.DRM form. I could route it through another computer an record it as a
midi or wav, but I'd like to save or convert it to aone of those so I can
use other programs to add to it. It's a pretty good track and I want to add
some of the other tracks I've been working on to it, but need to save it as
one of the other file types first.

file to a *.WAV or *.MID file that would be great.

Mime-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

Just to fill out some of the corners o' history jslee took us to.

I imagine people have been playing dance records at parties since the
first jazz, polka, samba and other such styles were pressed onto disks
in the early part of the century.

The real dividing line comes with the honest-to-goodness fullblown sound
system.  There were British DJs using mobile systems to play dance halls
and such in the early 1950s.  But the real origin of what we're now
doing started in Jamaica in the mid-1950s.  This is a quote from Dick
Hebdige's excellent book Cut 'n' Mix which explains it exactly:

  As the years passed, the demand for black American r&b in Jamaica
  grew stronger.  But there were no local groups who could play the
  music competently.  So large mobile discotheques called "sound
  systems" were set up to supply the need.  The sound systems played
  imported r&b records at large dances which were held in hired halls 
  or out in the open in the slum yards.  The music had to be heavily
  amplified at these venues if it was to convey the right sense of
  conviction.  And if people were to dance they had to hear the bass,
  which carried the important "shuffle" rhythm.  So the systems got
  bigger, louder and "heavier".  Junior Lincoln, a Jamaican record
  producer, explains:

   "A sound system is just like what you call a disco.  But the
    only thing is, it is not as sophisticated as a disco set. The 
    amplifiers are huge, well now amplifiers are as big as 2,000
    watts.  They emphasize a lot on the bass.  And they play
    sometimes twenty or twenty-four inch speakers.  So it really
    thump, y'know.  The bass line is really heavy.  You've never
    heard anything so heavy in all your life."

The idea of mixing records together at the same tempo really started with
*underground* disco (not the Saturday Night Fever era) in the mid-1970s.
By that time some of the more adventurous DJs were beat-matching using
standard turntables and dragging their fingers on the platters to match
up the records.  The popularity of this approach can be seen in the
advanced features of the 1200, which was first produced nearly 20 years
ago.  What hip hop did was to take the new DJ-turntable technology and
expose its broader possibilities.  Then electro, house and techno came
along to build electronically-based music best suited for the new
turntable techniques, and so on.

It wasn't until rereading the passage above from Hebdige's book, by the
way, that a longstanding mystery finally became clear to me.  The early
electro, garage, house and techno records don't *have* much bass in them.
The Roland "bass" sound is scarcely a shadow of real acoustic or electric
bass.  That was gradually introduced at the end of the acid house era.
It's particularly evident in something like DJ Pierre's groundbreaking
work from about 1990, which has none of the clanky bass sound
of the 1988-era acid house.  The early UK progressive house epitomized
by Guerilla's output ("Annihilating Rhythm," "Intoxication," that sort of
thing) has big phaaaat basslines.  My guess is that UK crowds, much more
attuned to the "sound system" approach of reggae and dub which had been
imported from Jamaica as part of the post-World War II Caribbean diaspora,
really drove the increasing emphasis on bass that underlies modern house
and techno.  

Put all those elements together and you have -- jungle.

phred

   9pm-2am, 18+, $5. 510.464.4682

Located @: 1st and Harrison, entry on the 1st st. side, in the basement of
Maritime.

Looks like ViRUS and I are going to be doing our hardacid 2 x 4, to open up
for the F8 guys, should be great fun! See you there!

-Joshua

 . ..  ...In your galaxy every-other Thursday evening from 9pm-2am!


            The location is at Maritime Hall, with an entrance on
            1st street (Not Harrison). We're on the lower level
            where it's nice and spacious,extra intimate and cozy.
            The price is only $5 all night and we have a full bar
            for the 21+ crowd. But if you're 18+ you'll have just
            as much fun with the intoxication of the fantasic
            music that's being broadcasted at *your* frequency...

Good selection throughout the weekend, starting tonight.  On Friday, 
electropolis might be good - electronic music seems to be getting some
official recognition from the Center for the Arts.  I hope the exhibition
is good too...  On Saturday Funky Tekno Tribe presents Lady Miss Kier and
Space Children present a big lineup of global talent.  Then on Sunday, people
can get back together for the Drug Peace Rally at Civic Center.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

want to

>>switch there.
>
>        well, I do it to listen to the other music through the house

same
>time in the headphones. I don't, it's too chaotic for me. putting a 
mute
>switch on one ear would still cut out alot of the outside sound coming 
from
>the speakers if you had the phones over both ears.
>
>        -chris

I mix with only one ear in the phones also... It is the way I started, 
and it works... It also might have something to do with the fact that 
only one ear works in my cheap ass headphones.. Gotta be real careful in 
places where you get echos though, makes you think that your mix is 
right on, until you hit the crossfader.. ARGH!!!

Maybe one day I will break down and buy new phones... Anybody have a 
pair/brand they particularly like??? 

Greg

year, once or twice a week. Questions:

1) Any lasting negative side effects?
i.e. memory loss? digestive problems? concentration? personality changes?
health problems?

2) Do you need more to get the same effect or will the same amount continue
to produce the same effect?

3) Any problems saying..."No more, I've had enough"?

I have read just about everything on the subject but I would be interested in
hearing from real people.

Short version:

 This is my second houseleaving party in the past few months!  Anyway, my
housemates had a live band lined up and decided to do the party _this_
Friday.  I live in a few rooms off to the (north?) side and also have a
garage/carport area that all integrates pretty well... and they've asked me
to be the "dance" area for ppl who want to just dance or hang in a trippy
cool environment (either after, or in lieu of the band..)  So to make this
"short version" shorter, I'm inviting SFR!  Everyone I've met on this list
has been really cool, and since this is an open party for our friends, I
feel the more the merrier!  Here are a few brief words from our housemate
Jessica, from an email she sent describing the party:

 Well, "The Mansion", as we affectionately call it, has been our home for
 the last 2 years, but the time has come for us all to go seperate ways.
 We've had some great times there, and some fantastic parties. 
 The Mansion is a 6000 square foot house on 50 acres overlooking
 pristine undeveloped hills and the Pacific Ocean. The rooms are
 giant, with 14 ft ceilings and big chandeleirs and floor to 
 cieling windows. It was _designed_ for parties!

Long version:

 Well I've got a beautiful space (my home), a beautiful view (if you stay
for sunrise) - most of my friends in one place, a small horde of computers
(mini demo party!@# :), and sound on it's way.  Here's some more detail
from Jessica's email still:
(note jessica isn't a raver, but she's super cool!)
"Live Music: This party is going to be particularly special, in that we
  will have a great band playing live for us -- a woman named
  Haale and her band "The Sundial Orchestra". I haven't heard them
  before personally, but I hear that Haale is very talented and
  a poetic writer and performer, and that we're very lucky to have
  her performing at the party. Haale will be performing with
  Neil Young at Shoreline this summer, so she is not a nobody!
 Recorded Music: The house is HUGE, so we're able to also provide a dance
  floor with recorded music -- complete with colored lights and
  disco ball!! If the live music doesn't suit you, or you just
  want to dance into the next morning, there will be a place for you!
 NotMusic: Did I mention the house is HUGE? If you're not into any of the
  music, there will be plenty of space for you to explore and
  play in. There will be quieter areas to hang out and talk
  or play games. 
 Food and Drink: We'll be providing munchies and drinks, and a big indoor
  barbeque grill. We'll have BBQ chicken breasts and burgers (beef
  and veggie) for the first 30 or so guests. So if you're going
  to show up on time, there'll be dinner available. If you're
  coming a little later, or just have something specific you
  want to grill, please bring it!  There will be plenty of
  beer, wine, soda and other non-alcoholoc drinks available. 
  There will also be some but potentially limited supplies for
  mixed drinks, and again you are welcome to bring any additions
  you'd like. All forms of foods are welcome if you'd like
  to bring a favorite dish!
 Your Hosts:  Myself (Jessica) -- moving to ???
     Hilary Somers -- moving to Atherton
     Travis Lee-Paul -- moving to ???
     Max Vision  -- moving to San Francisco     <- me me me  :)
     Tim Spencer -- moving to San Francisco
     Stephany Burge -- moving to Russia (Just for the summer!) 
     Bill Wisner -- moving to Holland (Bill will not be at the party)."
 Directions (omitted - please let me know if you want to come and I'll send
     them asap!)

OK, so I know a lot of us won't be into the band (but who knows) - which is
pretty much why I'm making my area into a separate production - also don't
be intimidated by the disco ball or bubblemachine or whatever, it's all in
good fun! hehe  (we've also considered renting The Wizard of Oz and seeing
if it really does match up to Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon...)

jungle, house, etc), then some from cd (I don't have decks nor vinyl) - and
we'll probably hook the demos to the soundsystem too for that part :)  (for
those who are not familiar with pc demos, think of them as realtime rave
graphics and sound being generated on the fly on a computer, the
programming haven been done by brilliant 14 year olds in the netherlands or
other obscure locations of the world, in their spare time)  If someone does
want to bring tables and spin though let me know and we can do that too!

like it's falling into place.  Talk about short notice!  Sorry to do this
again, but hey, my last party was notice of less than one day and it was

At 09:59 PM 6/12/97 -0700, I wrote:
>we'll probably hook the demos to the soundsystem too for that part :)  (for
>those who are not familiar with pc demos, think of them as realtime rave
>graphics and sound being generated on the fly on a computer, the
>programming haven been done by brilliant 14 year olds in the netherlands or
>other obscure locations of the world, in their spare time)
>

So I just realized that wasn't the best description...  but hey for those
who have pc's, here is a _great_ place to check some of them out:
http://www.cdrom.com/pub/demos/

and please check out http://www.cdrom.com/pub/demos/hornet/html/demos.html
which describes (complete with graphics and sound clips) what demos are all
about...  it's beautiful when you think about what's being done.

The following is from the Demo FAQ, which can be found at the above site

-----------

What is a Demo?

A demo is a program that displays a sound, music, and light show, usually
in 3D. Demos are very fun to watch, because they seemingly do things that
aren't possible on the machine they were programmed on.

Essentially, demos "show off". They do so in usually one, two, or all three
of three methods: 

o They show off the computer's hardware abilities (3D objects, multi-channel
  sound, etc.) 
o They show off the creative abilities of the demo group (artists, musicians)
o They show off the programmer's abilities (fast 3D shaded polygons, complex
  motion, etc.) 

Demos are an art form. They blend mathematics, programming skill, and
creativity into something incredible to watch and listen to.

Grant Smith puts it another way:

        Jonny looks around, confused, his train of thought disrupted. He
collects himself, and stares at the teacher with a steady eye. "I want
to code demos," he says, his words becoming stronger and more confidant
as he speaks. "I want to write something that will change people's
perception of reality. I want them to walk away from the computer dazed,
unsure of their footing and eyesight. I want to write something that
will reach out of the screen and grab them, making heartbeats and
breathing slow to almost a halt. I want to write something that, when it
is finished, they are reluctant to leave, knowing that nothing they
experience that day will be quite as real, as insightful, as good. I
want to write demos."

        Silence. The class and the teacher stare at Jonny, stunned. It
is the teachers turn to be confused. Jonny blushes, feeling that
something more is required.  "Either that or I want to be a fireman."

                                        - Grant Smith, 
                                                14:32, 
                                                11/21/93

Subject: Anybody know the real deal with the "AGIS attack" (was Re: NRR!!! $25,000 Reward !!!)
Reply-To: mayer@netcom.com
Date: Thu, 12 Jun 97 22:18:21 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


The postings below imply that some hackers have tried to "shut down" a
backbone provider, perhaps because that provider was condoning the use of
spam-email using its networks.

Anybody have any more details on this? I don't get to hear much news like
this in Bangalore India, since the newspapers talk entirely about
this-and-that local political scandal of the day, and the latest case of
bride-torture and bride-immolation for non-payment of dowry...

Although I don't know anything about this AGIS thing, I truly
appreciate the fact that legitimate businesses might be dissuaded from
using the services of providers that support SPAMMING (because their
infrastructure might be susceptible to "terrorist" attack by the
anti-SPAMMING forces). They might take their business elsewhere to
other providers/backbones that  explicitly state that they do not
support spamming. (and therefore will be seen by the hacker/terrorists
as being friendly to the cause and therefore not subject to attack).

Since the US government seems to be unwilling to take action on this form of
electronic pollution/harassment (the right to annoy people with advertising
seems to be the only part of "freedom of speech" the US Govt actually takes
seriously, viz, the CDA)... perhaps the issue will turn into "voting with
your dollars."

Ultimately this seems to be the only vote that counts in the USA anyways --
the political corollary of unbridled capitalism is either purest form of
democracy (1 dollar, 1 vote) or the purest form of corruption, and the US is
leading the charge wool-pulled over-the-eyes, and all-thumbs-on-the-pulse of
the nation.

PS: FYI, The main difference between India and the USA is that "voting" (aka
corruption) in India involves direct bribes, whereas in the USA, the bribes
occur through a formalized process involving payment of huge sums of money
to lawyers and/or political action committees who manipulate the truth and
the intent of jurisprudence to suit those that can afford the most
representation. Hell, i say eliminate the middleman. India is far better off
in this regard with its direct and overt corruption. With no
middleman-lawyer or PAC in the way, more people in India can afford to make
themselves heard through their dollars than in the US. In this way, India is
actually more democratic than the US. :-)

Dearborn, MI  May 28th, 1997: Worldwide Internet access provider AGIS
(Apex GlobalInternet Services, Inc.), announced a total reward pool of
$25,000 for information leading
to the arrest and conviction of persons involved with the recent attack
on AGIS' network.
The FBI has set up a hot line, encouraging anyone with information to
call 313-965-3028. 

The Michigan-based Internet access provider, founded in 1994, is one of
the original "big
six" companies exchanging Internet traffic at the major Internet
exchange points.

AGIS again confirmed that the attackers did not gain access to any
virtual private networks,
and that no private information was compromised. The company has
increased security
measures, but has not been at liberty to disclose the details of the
investigation. 

Phil Lawlor, AGIS President and CEO said, "Unfortunately, we are not
able to disclose
any specifics relative to the recent attacks on our network; it is
paramount that we keep this
information confidential so as not to compromise the investigation. We
encourage anyone
with information to come forward," Lawlor added. 

AGIS (www.agis.net), founded in 1994, provides Internet access to
millions of users via
its extensive customer base of Regional Bell Operating Companies,
content providers,
large corporations, and Internet service providers. A technology leader
and innovator,
AGIS is the first Internet access provider to deploy ATM technology to
operate a national
backbone network, the first to offer commercial 155 Mbps connections to
the 'Net, the first
to reduce points of failure in a network by using switching
technologies, the first to design
a wholesale business model (so as not to compete with customers by
selling retail access),
and the first to provide multiple distribution centers for content
replication
(CooLocation). AGIS offers Internet connectivity from 56 Kbps to 155
Kbps.

AGIS is headquartered at 3601 Pelham Road, Dearborn, Michigan 48124
Phone: 800/380-AGIS; Fax: 313-563-6119; E-mail: info@agis.net
