To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Pharmaceutical in Mexico Part 2
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So how does this process work? First, should you choose to venture
     forth on an endeavor such as this (an action I do NOT necessarily
     endorse, mind you, given the legal problems you'll read about further
     down the page), you should walk across the border instead of driving.
     Aside from the fact that a) driving back across the border is a total
bitch
     when it's busy and b) U.S. car insurance is invalid in Mexico (so you're
     basically fucked if anything happens to your car), it's a lot easier to
find
     a "runner" if you cross via foot. Using Nuevo Laredo as an example,
     you can park in a lot in Laredo directly adjacent to the border and then
     walk over to Mexico (conveniently, there's a shopping mall with a large
     parking lot right next to the bridge to Mexico); it costs about 25 cents
     each way at the bridge to cross and the walk takes about 5 minutes.
     Assuming you are approached by a runner (which is highly likely if you
     walk around for a few minutes, if you aren't approached the instant you
     get over the border), you'll be taken to a doctor's office, where you'll
be
     presented with a "menu" of the commonly-prescribed substances.
     Tranquilizers and stimulants make up the core of the list, though dozens
     of other drugs (most of which you'll probably not be familiar with) are
     available too. 

     From the menu, you make your choices. Most prescriptions cost $10
     (one prescription equals about a month's supply - and yes, you have to
     pay for one "prescription" per each month's supply purchased even if
     you get the same drug), and about $5-$30 for the drugs themselves
     (consider the $10 per prescription a "doctor's fee"). After getting the
     prescriptions, you either take them down to a pharmacy (the doctor will
     point you to the "right" one) or, at some offices, the doctor or one of
his
     assistants will go get the drugs at the pharmacy for you. It's about the
     same price either way. 

     The whole process can take as little as 15 minutes, if you know exactly
     what you want. Getting back over to the U.S. is where it starts to get a
     little tricky, though. You can't be arrested by the (Federal) border
patrol
     solely for bringing back prescription drugs; U.S. federal law states
that
     it's legal to bring back up to a six-month supply of prescription drugs
     from a foreign country (i.e. Mexico or Canada) for personal use, and
     the U.S. Customs officials at the border enforce federal law, not Texas
     state law. Why is this legal? Well, a lot of people with a genuine need
     for prescription drugs purchase them over the border because prices are
     a fraction of what they are in the United States. However, it's still a
     nebulous area of law and is in the process of being challenged by
certain
     factions in Congress, but it's still nevertheless legal to bring back
     anything under federal law. 

     HOWEVER, though you can bring stuff legally through Customs, it is
     NOT legal to possess any prescription substances purchased in Mexico
     under most STATE laws, unless you have a valid prescription (one
     from an American doctor, that is - the Mexican ones don't count for
     anything once you cross over the border). Hence, if you get stopped by
     state or local police for something, or if your car is searched at the
     border checkpoint (ten miles inside the U.S. border, at least when
     coming from Laredo), you can be arrested for possessing anything that
     is not OTC in the U.S. Some drugs are especially dangerous to
     purchase. Ritalin and most narcotic substances (morphine and codeine,
     for instance) are labeled as Schedule II substances by the FDA; thus,
     possession of them without a U.S. prescription can theoretically lead to
     big-time shit with the authorities. Rohypnol is even worse; it has been
     labeled a Schedule I substance in most states (meaning it is considered
     to have no medicinal use whatsoever and a very high abuse potential),
     putting it in the same category as heroin and cocaine. (Fortunately most
     Mexican pharmacies won't sell Americans Rohypnol these days, since
     the drug is now totally banned in the U.S.) I assume an explanation of
     the legal trouble one can get into with substances such as the Schedule
I
     ones isn't terribly necessary. 

     Fortunately the law is on your side - the federal law, that is. Since
state
     and federal laws are somewhat in opposition in this field, if you're
     caught with these drugs in the U.S. you have a fairly good chance of
     getting off the hook, assuming you have a good lawyer. (No, I don't
     claim to be a qualified expert in this regard; this is all merely my
     opinion.) Also, your odds of being stopped at the border checkpoint are
     pretty slim (if you're non-Hispanic and driving a relatively nice and/or
     nondescript automobile), and if you drive the speed limit there's no
     reason you should legally be pulled over on your way back into the
     interior U.S., so the odds of "getting away with it" are pretty high.
And
     in regards to the border checkpoint, they legally CANNOT stop you
     unless they have probable cause, so if you did get stopped for literally
     no reason you'd have a good defense in court. 

     4/22/97 note: It seems that the Federal border patrol has, within the
     past few months, taken it upon themselves to start "hassling" people
     bringing back drugs across the border. While it is still legal to bring
     drugs through Customs, I would recommend extreme caution in
     dealing with the officers at the border. There's a good chance you'll be
     searched (and by this I mean a body pat-down and searching of
     everything you have on you, including wallets, purses and shopping
     bags) and asked questions such as: 

            "What was the purpose of your visit to Mexico?"
            "Do you have any prescription drugs on you?"
            "Do you realize that you need a valid U.S. prescription to
          bring these drugs into the country?"
            "How old are you?"
            "What do you do for a living?"
            "Do you have any weapons or controlled substances on you?"
          (Note that they're referring to stuff like pot and coke when they
          say 'controlled substances.')

     What should you do if this happens? Believe it or not, you should
     TELL THE TRUTH. (Well, except perhaps for the purpose of visiting
     Mexico - saying "I went down to buy drugs" probably won't impress
     them much.) If you say you don't have any prescription drugs on you,
     theoretically they can search you anyway and if they find out you've
     lied to them, they can detain and/or search (by this I mean strip/body
     cavity search) and/or arrest you. In other words, lying about anything
     they can catch you on (i.e. the types of things you're carrying with
     you) is probably a bad idea. Since it's allowable under Customs
     regulations to bring prescription drugs into the country, it won't hurt
     you to tell them you're doing so. In any case, I'd say it's best to
     anticipate questions such as these and have plausible answers ready
     for them, and I'd most certainly avoid bringing anything into (or back
     from) Mexico, like a knife, gun or quarter-bag, that would get you into
     trouble when crossing back over. 

     Bringing back stuff from Mexico is still generally not a problem,
despite
     the hassles some people might experience at the border. (One side note:
     a recent visit revealed that the two most popular substances for
     Americans visiting Mexico -- Valium and Xanax (which together
     account for well over 70% of ALL drugs brought back into the States
     from Mexico trips) -- have been the victims of exorbitant price
     increases. By this I mean a price DOUBLING: what cost $30 a year
     ago (a 90-count package of 1 mg Tafil (Xanax) pills, for instance) now
     costs $65. I shit you not. Everything else is still roughly the same
price,
     but the prices of these tranquilizers have gone up over 100%. Yes, that
     sucks, and personally I'd say it'd be easier (and cheaper) to just
obtain
     them from your local doctor now, but obviously the doctors down there
     are still getting buyers for them to get away with such ripoff-level
rates.)

     Anyway, here's some info on a few of the substances commonly
     purchased in Mexico ... 

     Rohypnol -- first of all, Rohypnol is NOT a legal drug in any manner in
     the U.S.. Its sale and possession is 100% banned in the United States,
     even by prescription. And, as of March, 1996, U.S. Customs put a ban
     on it too. Before then you could still buy the stuff in Mexico and bring
it
     back legally under federal law (past the border ONLY, that is, just like
     the other drugs discussed here - it was still totally illegal to possess
it
     once in the U.S.), but that's no longer the case. A recent visit to a
     Mexican doctor revealed that Rohypnol is no longer on their "menu,"
     and since most menus there are identical, one could assume that
     Rophies aren't commonly sold there now. On the other hand, illegal
     supplies of the drug haven't dissipated one iota, according to the
press,
     so perhaps this information is erroneous. In any case, if you do manage
     to buy some down there you'll have to literally smuggle it back over
     (hide it someplace, in other words). Given that Customs has taken to
     searching people rather extensively lately, however, it is safe to say
this
     is NOT a smart idea. 

     Rohypnol has been getting a shitload of press as of late, with our
lovely
     "liberal" media giving it the moniker of the "date rape drug." It's even
     become a part of storylines on "ER" and "The X-Files" as a result of all
     the media attention. So what is Rohypnol? In a nutshell, it's an
     extremely strong tranquilizer. It's claimed by some to be ten times as
     strong as Valium, but I'm a little skeptical of this. Taking it in
normal
     (i.e. one pill) doses alone doesn't do much; it's just your basic
     tranquilizer, albeit a powerful one. However, in high doses - or when
     mixed with a lot of booze, or when taken by underweight people - it has
     a few scary effects. Blackouts are not at all uncommon in situations
     such as this. Ditto with passing out in the middle of a bar. I've seen
     quite a few unenlightened teens being carried home by friends after
     overindulging in this drug. Still, tagging it the "date rape drug" is
going a
     little far, in my opinion. In sum, Rohypnol may be trendy right now, but
     it's also dangerous. And totally illegal. Plus it has definite abuse
     potential. 

     Ritalin -- like Rohypnol, Ritalin has also been getting a lot of press
as
     of late, though unlike Rohypnol it's legal to prescribe it in the U.S.
     Ritalin is commonly prescribed to children (and adults) with Attention
     Deficit Disorder (ADD). For people who are normally hyperactive,
     Ritalin can help focus their attention and make them seem less anxious.
     Note that for people who AREN'T normally hyperactive, Ritalin acts as
     a stimulant. Hence its appeal. When taken orally, Ritalin is a fairly
mild
     stimulant (in small doses, that is). However, a lot of people have been
     taking it nasally, in which case it allegedly has an effect similar to
     snorting cocaine (though several acquaintances who have snorted it
     deny this, I should note). Also note that Ritalin is classified is a
     Schedule II substance and you can easily land in jail for possession of
it.

     Valium & Xanax -- Valium is far and away the most commonly
     prescribed drug for Americans purchasing drugs in Mexico, according to
     a 1995 University of Texas study. Nearly 70% of ALL people buying
     drugs in Mexico bought Valium in this study (#2 was Rohypnol, in case
     you were wondering, though given the stricter legal penalties placed on
     the substance recently I have a feeling it's probably dropped down the
     list a bit). Valium's effects are pretty widely-known, though, so I
won't
     bother getting into them here. Ditto Xanax, which was the third most
     commonly-prescribed drug in the aforementioned study. 

     4/22/97 update: -- a recent trip to the border has revealed that there
are
     quite a few very strong drugs available down there that are "hidden"
     behind unrecognizable Spanish names on the menus at doctors' offices.
     People who've seen this site in the past have requested that I find out
     the names of more drugs available down there, so here's a list: morphine
     (pill and liquid forms), codeine (mixed with Tylenol or ephedrine, in
     tablets and syrup), Halcion, fen-phen (a diet pill), phenobarbital,
     Darvon, and a mixture of valium and Percocet which I believe is what
     used to be commonly sold in the U.S. as Quaaludes (if I'm wrong about
     this, please let me know). If you want to know the Spanish names for
     these substances, I'd suggest asking the doctors themselves. Please
note:
     pretty much all of these substances have very serious abuse potential,
     and -- especially in the case of phenobarbital -- are VERY dangerous
     when mixed with other substances, ESPECIALLY alcohol. Everything
     listed in this paragraph except fen-phen is a variety of depressant and
     when mixed together or with alcohol, cardiac arrest, coma AND
     DEATH can quite easily occur. In other words, if you use these drugs,
     BE CAREFUL!!! 
       Comments? Suggestions? E-mail me. (I apologize if you've done this
        before and had the e-mail bounce back; this problem has now been
         fixed.) But read the FAQ first before asking questions, por favor.

At 4:35 AM 6/13/97, VENTR4TH@aol.com wrote:
>Have a friend who takes four to six hits a week. She's been doing it for a
>year and is still going strong. She complains of some memory loss, weight
>loss and digestive problems. She also needs sleeping pills to sleep. I
>suggest she chill for awhile but she says that there are no documented
>problems and it beats drinking. So I am her self appointed researcher. She
>turned me on to the tunes and Iam just looking out for her.

all this discussion about long term use.... and i have a question: i've
heard that the shit drains your spinal fluid. anyone know anything about
this? i also have a pamphlet about it, and here's what they say under
'risks':

"...first among these is the possibility of an oversose. because mdma and
mda are amphetamines tolerance develops quickly and overdose _can_ happen.
other speed-like dangers include liver-damage and plain-old exhaustion with
heavy use. and in high doses, mda and mdma can deliver the same package of
psychotic symptoms - including anxiety, delusions, and paranoia. the drugs
can also intensify heart problems. the handful of deaths tied to mdma thus
far involve cardiac arrhythmia in users with previously undiagnosed heart
disease. but the hottest current controversy involves questions about the
drug's possible long-term effects on the brain. a johns hopkins study of
high-dose ecstace on monkeys and rats shows that the drug attacks areas in
brain cells that manufacture serotonin. the researchers also found that the
damage may last: half of serotini producing nerve cells in test animals
were still damaged 8 weeks after use...."

that to me is pretty important - serotinin is what helps us to be happy
_naturally_.if you're prone to depression, beware! anyway, the idea of
taking the shit 6 times a week is pretty frightening - what sort of grasp
on reality and life would such a person have? i mean, i like to party as
much as the next person, but i also see the benefits of facing my life
without the help of drugs. basically, my view is that you can't face
reality when you're high - when you _are_ high, realize that you are, and
that it's just for fun. this is not a way to live your life. just my
opinion, based on a few years of partying far too hard and waking up one
day, wondering what had happened. who was it that said "everything in
moderation"? there's something to this.

peace, e. :)

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The funny thing is about MDMA is that it has only been really used
heavely as a recreational drug for about 20 years or so (from the 70's
right?). And while it's good to be interested in the result of taking E
after a few years. I personally am most interested in the effects after
say, 20 or 30 years. And because MDMA hasn't really been around that
long, there just is no real way of knowing what the result of consuming
MDMA on a regular (albiet 'moderate') basis is after a few decades. I
think it would be logical to look at some modern day neurological
diseases and compare the characteristics with what MDMA does to you.
Seritonin for example has a strong correlation with a few neurological
diseases that are common today. And seeing as your synapses probably
aren't used to being used like a faucet (seritonin on-seritonin off)
then I think in the long run it's best to look at thoes posibilites.

In short, the potental consiquenses(sp) of MDMA long term is really just
a crap shoot. There are very few real, hard, facts about it.

About MDMA & ADD. I think Alik mentioned them together. I once talked
with my Doctor about MDMA and he mentioned that MDMA can in the long run
create greater symptoms of ADD like things (forgetful, late, impatient).
I don't mean _while_ youre on e. But rather, as your brain is
recouperating lost fluids the months afterwards.

Personally I have followed the 'once every 6 months' (Yes, 6) rule. Some
researchers have given that lenght of time as "reasonably safe".
Although they are quick to show you a disclaimer. In addition it's good
to start 'preping' your brain for the dose. That means eating plenty of
potasium, Vatmin E (real Vit E), and other "brain food". And then there
is the thing about Prozac and E. 

> damage may last: half of serotini producing nerve cells in test animals
> were still damaged 8 weeks after use...."
> 
> that to me is pretty important - serotinin is what helps us to be happy
> _naturally_.if you're prone to depression, beware!

I always think about how so many people seem to become tried and
depressed about the scence after a while ("the scene is dying, Bill Gram
is throwing raves, it's all Microsofts fault") connection? Hmmmm......

Here's a fact about consistent, daily use of MDMA [e].  It's a waste of money
and your energy.  You would have to take ridiculous amounts of e to get off to
the same degree when you do it often [more than once a week].  It takes at
least a week to lose your tolerance so that you get off as well [and I would
say that from accounts I've heard it takes longer and longer to come back to
where you *really* get off the more you do it].  Additionally, the bad side
effects [teeth clenching, eye wiggling, insomnia, etc.] dramatically increase
as you increase the amount of MDMA you ingest.

This is excerpted from PiHKAL: A Chemical Love Story by Alexander and Ann
Shulgin.  http://www.hyperreal.com/drugs/pihkal/pihkal109.html  The **starred**
items are what's important.

Hope this helps,
b.


Tolerance studies also support differences in mechanisms of action. In one
study, MDMA was consumed at 9:00 AM each day for almost a week (120 milligrams
the first day and 160 milligrams each subsequent day) and **by the fifth day
there were no effects from the drug except for some mydriasis [I think this has
something to do with heart rate.  Anyone know for sure?]**. And even this
appeared to be lost on the sixth day. At this point of total tolerance, there
was consumed (on day #7, at 9:00 AM) 120 milligrams of MDA and the response to
it was substantially normal with proper chronology, teeth clench, and at most
only a slight decrease in mental change. **A complete holiday from any drug for
another 6 days led to the reversal of this tolerance, in that 120 milligrams of
MDMA had substantially the full expected effects**.

>all this discussion about long term use.... and i have a question: i've

>this? 

It's absolutely not true...

>i also have a pamphlet about it, and here's what they say under
>'risks':
>"...first among these is the possibility of an oversose. because mdma and
>mda are amphetamines tolerance develops quickly and overdose _can_ happen.
>other speed-like dangers include liver-damage and plain-old exhaustion with
>heavy use. and in high doses, mda and mdma can deliver the same package of
>psychotic symptoms - including anxiety, delusions, and paranoia. the drugs
>can also intensify heart problems.

Yeah, but if you go into your medicine cabinet, grab the nearest full
bottle of whatever (pain killers, antibiotics, vitamins,) swallow the
contents, the same things can happen.  Especially if you shop at CostCo. =)
 
>a johns hopkins study of
>high-dose ecstace on monkeys and rats shows that the drug attacks areas in
>brain cells that manufacture serotonin. the researchers also found that the
>damage may last: half of serotini producing nerve cells in test animals
>were still damaged 8 weeks after use...."

The thing about these studies is this, they take some rats and give them a
HUGE dose of MDMA, intravenously, and SUPRISE! The rat's brain is altered.
How much dose a rat weigh in comparison to a human?  What would the
equivalent dose be for humans? 50 E's?  Who eats 50 E's at once?  

Check out:    http://www.maps.org/  for the facts on these studies.  
 
>who was it that said "everything in
>moderation"? there's something to this.

My grampa, but someone else probably said it first. :)

---ChrisP

Subject: Mirasol review (somewhat long)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

my 5 sense on mirasol:

(dj's)

The main dancefloor stayed occupied (sparse at brief moments) all night.

First on the decks were myself and ViRUS, doing a cd-vs-turntable 2x4.
Seemed well recieved. Tracks got relatively hard at moments (hard for san
francisco that is), but the floor stuck with us. Mostly minimal and acidy.
The mixing went smoothly for a 2x4, heavy fader use with a lot of slicing
and dicing. I had an incredible time. Those of you who were hollerin',
thank you so much! Nice to see so many friendly faces. Big fun. Nice
meeting Jonas and Goolz!

Next up was Mars, giving us the smooth trancey techno. Unfortunately I
missed most of his set, running around helping out, working the door, and
the desk for bit... Heard some chewns that I dug for the brief moments that
I made it in there. Dancefloor seemed active and receptive.

Mystre closed it up with a mixed bag of melodic trance and driving
acidtrance, well blended and layed out. Kept the dancefloor filled
throughout his entire journey... people were hooting and screaming until
the moment the lights came on, followed by an enthusiastic round of
applause. I got to see a lot of it, although I was running around during
his set too... Good stuff guys. Thanks for making it so much fun.

During the brief moments I made it into the smaller room, Johnsin was
kicking down the wicked tech, and doing it well, as he always does... The
man rocks it. He consistently provides fantastic music and mixing. What
else can I say. Glad you could be there to share it with us John! Thanks!

eLTE ended the evening in the smaller room with her transitions between
funky-breaky stuff, housey-house stuff, and some bits of screaming acid
thrown in for good measure. She's got skills. From what I heard, her mixing
was consistent and on; she kept a few religious acidhouseheadz moving their
feet until the last possible moment... Thanks eLTE! Keep it up!

I slept well last night. All in all, a very exciting event.
Looking forward to the next one.

-Joshua

Oh...
My previous post was not meant to imply that I would recommend MDMA to
anyone, nor did I mean to imply that MDMA usage was safe and risk free.  I
believe MDMA is not without risk, both physical, and mental, and it is not
for everyone. 

I do think its sad that studies like the one mentioned twist data around to
enforce some politically popular point of view.  Anyone who's ever done
studies or interpreted lab data knows how easy it is to do this.  Most of
the time, if you actually look at the data these studies are based upon,
you see that the numbers have been manipulated, and pertinent facts are
omitted.  

There have been studies with animals involving doses proportional to human
doses, but you have to look for those.  Why?  The results say things that
are not politically popular, such as no negative effects were noted.  From
the MAPS page:

"One study has found that 2.5mg/kg of MDMA given p.o. once every two weeks
for a total of eight doses over 4 months did not produce any neurotoxic
response in 5-HT and 5-HIAA assays of eight brain regions.[3] If human and
animal doses were identically equivalent this would seem to provide a "no
effect" level for any possible MDMA neurotoxicity which was close to human
levels." 

"MDMA has only been shown to be neurotoxic at somewhat high levels in
experimental animals, and the evidence in humans suggests a lack of
neurotoxicity. There dose appear to be at least some temporary changes in
brain function caused by MDMA, but the exact nature of the changes remains
to be determined, and the possible role of SSRIs in preventing or reversing
the changes merits further examination. The possibility that the changes
are permanent in humans needs to be addressed. To what extent the neuro
chemical changes induced by MDMA are responsible for therapeutic or
pathological
changes in psychology also needs to be determined. The frequency and
severity of post-MDMA psychiatric effects (including burnout) should also
be assessed. And in light of the somewhat narrow safety margin, the effects
of MDMA in higher doses needs to be investigated to the extent possible.
Hopefully, the clinical studies using MDMA in human volunteers will help to
answer some of these questions."

There are some really interesting human studies going on right now, details
can be found at   http://www.maps.org/

Someone take my soap box away before I hurt myself....

--ChrisP

A while back ago someone posted a blurb on the Oriental Trading Company, a
mail-order nic-nac gadgety-wak toy distributor.  Here's a story inspired
by one of the catalog items, 3/4 inch bouncing glow balls of varying
color.  $6 a gross (144 balls in a gross!)  My friend, adam, who
works in the UCdavis dramatic arts dept came up with a performance art
piece for the dept's end of the year goodbye ceremony held in the Main
Theatre.

Boom, bbBooMmm, booM, deep house fills the Main Stage house.  Adam
crosses center stage, puts on a hardhat and goggles.  House goes
pitch black.  A beat.  And then they came.  En masse.  Gloriously defying
the darkness with their phosphorescent life!  Seven hundred and twenty
glowing bouncy balls fell from 40 feet above forming a glowing curtain
silouetting Adam's profile.  They met ground and began their explosive
dance in the darkness bouncing to the beat.  The majority jumped straight
back up together like equalizer leds, while others flew out into the house
lighting up peoples' faces.  They danced until their legs gave way.  And
with all their potential energy spent, they rested together as stars in
the night sky, their cool glow reflected in the eyes and faces of the
people who watched them dance.  

Hope that was a good story.  With it I am delurked.  Y'all
keep glowin' and bouncin'. 

l o v e
geORGIE

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Jun 13 13:12:08 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id NAA06892;
	Fri, 13 Jun 1997 13:12:08 -0700 (PDT)

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 13 Jun 1997 13:11:58 -0700 (PDT)

	by construct.net (8.8.5/CONSTRUCT) with SMTP id NAA04442
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Fri, 13 Jun 1997 13:10:55 -0700 (PDT)

From: Adam Gould <goolie@construct.net>
To: SF Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: DJ identification device?
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.96.970613125231.736Y-100000@skippy.construct.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I have a little request to make to our phat-assed DJ community.

Would any of you entertain the notion of possibly IDENTIFYING yourselves
somehow during your sets?  While I would like to say that I'm so down with
the scene that i know y'all by sight, or that i have the psychic
connection that precludes anything as mundane as knowing your name...
well, I can't. And i suspect this is true for many of us DJ endusers.

I can't say how often I've been at a party and wanted to know who that
awesome DJ just was.  

I'm not saying you should put on some "Hi!  My name is Mystr-E!" sticker
on your chest, but there's gotta be *some* creative, aestheticly
acceptable way you can let people know who you are while you're spinning.
I don't think it's inherently uncool to identify yourself somehow,
although it might take some creative thought on your part...

If only for PR reasons, I'd think this would be in everyone's best
interest.

Perhaps there's some secret DJ-cabal rule that prohibits this sort of
thing though?  I mean, if y'all aren't supposed to talk about it, i just
want you to know i *totally* understand.



PS - hope i see some o' ya at TripleHorn.  Moontribe!!!


--goolz

From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@domain.net>
Subject: A new, innovative technique for dealing with SPAM
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This comes from HotWired's `packet' site, at:

    http://www.packet.com/packet/frauenfelder/nc_today.html

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Spam Libs

Bulk email spawns ingenious offensives from the masses

Do you remember Droodles? They're those simple line drawings that look
like nonsense until you read the captions. Droodles were invented in the
'60s by a humorist named Roger Price, an author probably best known for
his stinging critique of American society, The Great Roob Revolution. I
was lucky enough to get to know Roger before he died in 1990. He had lots
of great comics, books, and original art (from people like MAD Magazine
creator Harvey Kurtzman) lying around his Studio City, California, home.

Beside Droodles, Roger also invented Mad Libs. You might remember these,
too. Mad Libs were little books with stories in them. But the stories had
several missing words, with instructions to insert verbs, nouns, and
adjectives in the blank spaces.  The game was played at parties, where
one person asked the others to supply the missing words. Then the story
was read out loud and everybody laughed heartily at the result.  (There
are dozens of Mad Lib knockoffs on the Web.)

Because spammers work their cons anonymously, hiding behind forged email
addresses and working out of PO boxes, our imaginations can run wild about
what they look like. My fantasy spammer is a rat-skinny, potbellied,
40-year-old with a greasy salt-and-pepper ponytail and beard.  And he's
rat-smart: After being spammed with get-rich-on-the-Net messages, he
bought the lists containing millions of email addresses, and he bought
the DIY spam software, and now he's in business for himself, working from
the spare bedroom of his mother's house in a Las Vegas suburb.  I'm
grateful to Roger and his Mad Libs for helping me come up with a fun spam
prank. It all started a couple of weeks ago when I received the following:


	Do you drink bottled water?
	Are you looking for a
	discount? How about 4 cents
	a gallon? With our high
	quality water-filtration
	systems, you can bottle
	your own!! Email your name,
	address, phone# & email
	address to The Water Lady -
	TheWaterLady@----.com

I copied this stupid message into my word processor, and using the
search-and-replace function, swapped every occurrence of the word "water"
with "urine," then sent the result to the Water Lady:

	I received the following
	advertisement and I'm
	wondering if it is a joke?

	Do you drink bottled urine?
	Are you looking for a
	discount? How about 4 cents
	a gallon? With our high
	quality urine-production
	systems, you can bottle
	your own!! Email your name,
	address, phone# & email
	address to The Urine Lady -
	TheWaterLady@----.com

In a couple of hours, I got the following reply:

	Dear Mark:

	I don't know who may have
	done this sh*t (sic) to the
	message. Everywhere the
	word < urine > is found was
	originally < water >.
	Please accept our
	apologies. This is
	somebody's idea of a joke!

Heh - it sure was. Pleased with myself, I sent the mutated mail to my
friends. They got in on the action, respamming the Mad-Libbed message back
to The Urine Lady. Someone even posted the message on
alt.sex.fetish.watersports, with the subject "GOLDEN BOTTLES!" The post
was forged to look as though it were sent by The Urine Lady herself.

That same day, I got a spam trying to sell me a copy of Floodgate
software, a notorious spamming program. I copied the spam to my word
processor and did a few swaps. I changed "Floodgate" to "The Pig Spittle
Drinkers' Toolkit," "email" to "slobber bottle," "program" to
"pig-drool-extraction device," and "software" to "salivary-gland
stimulator." Here's what I sent back to the spammer:

	SPECIAL: Buy the latest
	version of The Pig Spittle
	Drinkers' Toolkit before
	May 21st and receive a list
	of 30 slobber-bottle
	swappers who have millions
	of slobber bottles to swap
	with you as you build your
	database.

	HERE'S WHAT OTHER PIG
	SPITTLE DRINKERS' TOOLKIT
	USERS SAY.....

	"The Pig Spittle Drinkers'
	Toolkit is truly a dream
	come true! By following the
	instructions in the book, I
	was able to develop a list
	of 2,400 slobber bottle
	addresses in less than one
	hour. Furthermore, the
	technical support is
	outstanding. This
	pig-drool-extraction device
	will put me on a level
	playing field with the big
	boys. They don't teach this
	stuff in business school!"

	"This salivary-gland
	stimulator works fantastic
	- I'm so busy now I can't
	keep up with the orders and
	inquiries! Thanks!"

	"I ordered the
	pig-drool-extraction device
	and haven't stopped running
	with it since. With your
	support, (at the drop of a
	hat), with the finest
	pig-drool-extraction device
	ever released for public
	use, I started my dream
	business, a bulk
	slobber-bottle business.

	"If a 'dummy' like me can
	use this salivary-gland
	stimulator, anyone can!
	Great tool!!!"

	[snip]

Soon, my friends and I were mutating and resending almost every spam we
got. Most of the spammers wrote back saying they were mystified and
expressed dismay that anyone would want to hurt their wonderful home-based
business, apologized profusely, and promised that they'd get to the bottom
of the nefarious campaign to defame their good name.

This was our intent: to make them think that someone had intercepted their
spam and was ruining their good name with wacko faux-spam. Only once did
the spammer retaliate by flaming the messenger. Here's the original spam
that a friend received:

	This is a great opportunity
	for your business. How
	would you like to get
	200-300 responses per day
	from your advertisement? At
	Selective Marketing we make
	it happen for your
	business. Selective
	Marketing is a bulk email
	advertiseing (sic) company
	that generates hundreds to
	thousands of responses for
	your business.

	[snip]

Here is his reply to the spammer:

	WHAT IS THE MEANING OF THIS
	DISGUSTING SATANIC FILTH?
	ALL FORTY-SIX MEMBERS OF
	'CHRISTAIN VIRGINS AGAINST
	INTERNET SEX' RECEIVD THIS
	DISGUSTING PIECE OF HATE
	MAIL AND I DEMAND THAT YOU
	PROVIDE AN EXPLANATION! WE
	ARE CONSULTING OUR LAWYERS
	NOW TO SEE IF LEGAL ACTION
	CAN BE TAKEN!

	JOHNATHON JILLIAN DAVES

	This is a great opportunity
	for your penis. How would
	you like to get 200-300
	penises per day from your
	penis? At Selective
	Marketing we make it happen
	for your penis. Selective
	Marketing is a bulk penis
	advertising company that
	generates hundreds to
	thousands of penises for
	your penis.

The spammer sent 61 identical emails to my friend, which read:

	YOU WILL LEARN NOT TO FUCK
	WITH ME YOU PIECE OF
	SHIT!!!!!!!!!

(My friend said it took him "all of 30 seconds" to save the messages in
a folder.)

If you want to play the Mad Lib Mutated Spam game, here are some tips.
(Remember, some of this stuff might get you in trouble with the long
tentacle of the law, so proceed at your own risk.)

1. Usually, spams do not contain valid email addresses. But there are a
   couple of ways to get a real address. First, you can look up the
   spammer's domain name on InterNIC's Whois database. That'll yield a
   couple of email address you can use.  The other way is to visit the
   spammer's Web site, which is often listed in the spam. If it isn't,
   just try typing the spammer's domain into your Web browser, and see if
   anything pops up. As a last resort, you can fax or snailmail your
   mutated message to the spammer, as they usually list their phone number
   and mailing address in their desperate quest to get their sebum-coated
   hands on your money.

2. If you have an AOL account, create a special email address (you are
   allowed up to five different addresses per account). I send most of my
   Mad-Libbed spams through an AOL address used exclusively for
   antispamming.  That way, if the spammer flips out and decides to mail
   bomb you or forge your name on obscene Usenet postings, it won't
   matter. This also works with Web-based anonymous email services like
   HotMail.

3. If you're technically adept, you might want to try "linking two
   spammers to each other," as another friend suggests. By "sending
   mutated mail to other spammers," says my Mad Lib buddy, "maybe they
   will start suspecting each other of mutual spam mutating, and spamming
   will enter a new era of conspiracy and distrust."

If you get any especially good results from playing Mad Lib Mutated Spam,
please tell me about it!

[Mark Frauenfelder]

Send mail to Mark Frauenfelder at mark@wired.com

Plenty of EURODance (dat's for you, Pablo ;-D) and house for everybody on 
Channel 17, 24 hours, 7 days a week, baby!

First time I heard one of my fave songs--"Encore Une Fois" by Sash! was on 
that channel.  But beware of the divas--every so often you will hear some 
Angelina or Gina G (let me stop ragging on the divas, sometimes they do 
deserve some merit).  But they make up for it because they play Josh Wink, and 
that "DJ Supreme" song, and other bomb ass (if a little mainstream) house.

I even heard Daft Punk once--but it was that darn "Da Funk" song that is 
quickly becoming the most overplayed "electronica" song in the entire 
universe--it's on commercials, Mtv, promos, and on "The Saint" cd that my 
friends keep playing and playing and playing . . . But I still love Daft 
Punk--especially that "Around the World" song . . .

Oh yeah, and once more--my bad!  Orbital doesn't do "Papua New Guinea," but 
FSOL does!  Oops!

Oh, and one more question--what the hell is a high hat?

xoxo--Miccaela
who'd like hiNRG better if you didn't have to go to clubs to hear it

At 10:29 AM 6/13/97, Pengo wrote:
>The funny thing is about MDMA is that it has only been really used
>heavely as a recreational drug for about 20 years or so (from the 70's
>right?). And while it's good to be interested in the result of taking E
>after a few years. I personally am most interested in the effects after
>say, 20 or 30 years. And because MDMA hasn't really been around that
>long, there just is no real way of knowing what the result of consuming
>MDMA on a regular (albiet 'moderate') basis is after a few decades. I

<snip>

don't forget that you never *really* know what you're getting. if you're
going to take any drug, not just e, be prepared for some odd and perhaps
even dangerous consequences. really. i think that a lot of ppl prefer to be
naive, but face it. you're playing with your life.

sorry for the downer (but it's true...)!
cheers - e. :)

At 10:55 AM 6/13/97, Beth Jackson wrote:
>Tolerance studies also support differences in mechanisms of action. In one
>study, MDMA was consumed at 9:00 AM each day for almost a week (120 milligrams
>the first day and 160 milligrams each subsequent day) and **by the fifth day
>there were no effects from the drug except for some mydriasis [I think this has
>something to do with heart rate.  Anyone know for sure?]**.

mydriasis: prolonge or excessive dilation of the pupil of the eye (as from
the effect of drugs).

cheers - e. :)

        I am gonna have to talk a little about this party. I mean, there was
like, no one there. I guess it was to be expected, but it was far less of a
turn out than I imagined it would be for a new party. Oh well. I realized
that Mars and Myster-e's experience only really works(live, anyways)when
everyone is dancing and into it. Last night is was sort of dead. I mean,
people were dancing but not many and not very enthusiastically. And no one
was dancing in the jungle room/bar. But Johnsin spun some great jungle in
which he overall style was startlingly close to mine(I've never seen him
spin or hear any of his mixtapes before)until he went into his techstep
stuff. Oh well, it was kind of like being at home listening to my housemates
spin, except it cost $5 and it was farther away but there was some cool
people I met. I didn't meet anyone on the list but I left around 1am.

        -chris

> I have a little request to make to our phat-assed DJ community.
> 
> Would any of you entertain the notion of possibly IDENTIFYING yourselves
> somehow during your sets?  While I would like to say that I'm so down
with
> the scene that i know y'all by sight, or that i have the psychic
> connection that precludes anything as mundane as knowing your name...
> well, I can't. And i suspect this is true for many of us DJ endusers.
>

> awesome DJ just was.  
>

> on your chest, but there's gotta be *some* creative, aestheticly
> acceptable way you can let people know who you are while you're spinning.

> although it might take some creative thought on your part...

Yah, that totally works too.


Another solution would be to develop a simple, mandatory subdermal
transmitter implant.  This DJ information & tracking device (DJITD) would
broadcast the DJ's name and other pertinent information (setlist, current
track, controlled substance readout, etc) to display units located at
strategic locations throughout the venue.  It would even be relatively
trivial to modify the transmitter to work in conjunction with existing GPS
technology, allowing the promoter to figure out where the DJ in question
was at a given time, if said DJ was laggin'.  

As you can see, there's any number of creative solutions, really.  



--goolz

From: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>
Subject: Re: DJ identification and hard music
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Goolz sez:
>Would any of you entertain the notion of possibly IDENTIFYING yourselves
>somehow during your sets?
<snip>
>I don't think it's inherently uncool to identify yourself somehow,
>although it might take some creative thought on your part...
<snip>
>Perhaps there's some secret DJ-cabal rule that prohibits this sort of
>thing though?


	It seems rather taboo in Northern California. The only time I've
seen it done in recent history here was at the first Analog
(SpaceChildren), and it was only because there were MIDWEST djs in the
house. Hyperactive was on the mike (or the headphone in this case), and so
was ESP, talking to the crowd, and telling them what dj/livePA was on,
getting people hyped... I grew up listening to those guys do that shit. Not
only does it get people excited, but it lets you know who you're listening
to, which I don't think is a bad thing. I'd *love* to see more of it
here...

	I guarantee you'll see more of that if you go hear ESP Woody at
Analog tomorrow... He just does it. He cares. If the crowd looks
uninterested in a dj, he'll get on there and try to stir things up. If the
dj is going strong, he'll get on there and tell you give it up for the
person who is kicking your ass... (translation: scream and yell in
appreciation for the good dj)

	The reason I think that it doesn't happen here, is usually because
the music in this area is: A) not hard enough, B) not fast enough, and/or
C) simply doesn't carry the energy/power/force that warrants it. Therefore
nobody is jumping out of their skins, screaming and yelling and generally
freaking out (in a healthy, positive way of course). There are UG
exceptions to this rule, but in general it seems to elude many massives.

-Joshua

	Being in that little transition time between the end of school 
and finding a summer job, me and a friend decided to try a weekday rave 
on thursday night so we headed up to the city for Mirisol. Long drive I 
know, from S.C. to S.F. but it was kind of a spur of the moment type 
thing and after going to weekend raves for almost a year now, I deicided 
it would be cool to see how the hard core raves lived *8^)

The music was incredible and there was a really good vibe, and for the 
most part I had a pretty good time but something was on my mind the whole 
time and I couldn't seem to find an answer...

Who were the sfravers at this party?

I was really looking foward to meeting some of you and had my laminate
dangling about but I had not seen ANY other ones and was not approached by
anyone. I was glad to see byroni there, but he was the only one I
recognized. Were any of you there? I surely hope people here aren't
begining to consider wearing laminants as a tacky thing? Well anyway, for
all you old timers out there would ya mind doing some of us newbies out
there a favor and wear your laminants. 

Stay cool

Matt

>     4/22/97 note: It seems that the Federal border patrol has, within the
>     past few months, taken it upon themselves to start "hassling" people
>     bringing back drugs across the border. While it is still legal to bring
>     drugs through Customs, I would recommend extreme caution in
>     dealing with the officers at the border. There's a good chance you'll be
>     searched (and by this I mean a body pat-down and searching of
>     everything you have on you, including wallets, purses and shopping
>     bags) and asked questions such as:
>
>            "What was the purpose of your visit to Mexico?"
>            "Do you have any prescription drugs on you?"
>            "Do you realize that you need a valid U.S. prescription to
>          bring these drugs into the country?"
>            "How old are you?"
>            "What do you do for a living?"
>            "Do you have any weapons or controlled substances on you?"
>          (Note that they're referring to stuff like pot and coke when they
>          say 'controlled substances.')

I go across the border almost every day,   I live in Tijuana and have an office
in San Diego and take the trolly to TJ...    I purchase a variaty of drugs that
are prescription in the USA,  and "over the counter" in Mexico.    When I
go back
through the border,   I carry in plain sight the bag containing my medication.
I have never been bothered at all....   :-)

Of course these drugs have NO recreational value...  and I am certainly willing
to show them to any customs official that might ask whats in the bag.   By the
way,   TJ is really a cheap place to live,  you have to look around,  and I'm
just 300 feet from the US border....   :-)

JohnnyD


>     If you say you don't have any prescription drugs on you,
>     theoretically they can search you anyway and if they find out you've
>     lied to them, they can detain and/or search (by this I mean strip/body
>     cavity search) and/or arrest you.

This is certainly true...  and don't think that because you go across the
border every day,  that you woulld get to know the cusoms people.    Thats
NOT TRUE..    They change EVERY DAY,   and the likelyhood of you getting to
know any one person is highly remote.


>     In other words, lying about anything
>     they can catch you on (i.e. the types of things you're carrying with
>     you) is probably a bad idea.

Definately true...

>     but the prices of these tranquilizers have gone up over 100%. Yes, that
>     sucks, and personally I'd say it'd be easier (and cheaper) to just obtain
>     them from your local doctor now.

My particular medication costs $190 for a bottle of 100 capsels.    I can
get the
same stuff for just $11...    Saving a significant amount of money.

JohnnyD

ya know I was thinking about this a little and here's what popped into my 
head:

Why do you want to know who the DJ is anyway?
allow me to elaborate for a moment:
in the 'rock' scene, the focus is on teh cult of personality surrounding 
the performer.  Frankly, no one really cares if the music is even good or 
not, what matters is that some dude is jumping around on stage with a 
guitar and fifteen-year-old girls have posters of him up in their bedrooms.
in the 'techno' scene, the focus is supposed to be on the music.  so from 
the beginning, the artists remained anonymous and faceless.  I mean, I 
sure haven't seen a Fatboy Slim poster down at Tower Records lately.  
(now this is changing a little now that techno is being corrupted by teh 
rock and roll music machine here..  so you do have posters of Tom& Ed and 
such... but anyway)...
so the DJ is the presenter of the music, not the creator, as the creators 
are hidden away so as to preserve the sanctity and validity of their 
artistic efforts.  But when a DJ is 'known' that cult of personality 
beings to grow, just like in the rock scene.  It's an interesting 
situation.  Id vs. Ego and stuff.
just thoughts
PLUR

When I was at UCD, one of my favorite places was the library.  It kicked 
ass.  I would go in there and people were different.  People acted 
differently.  They spoke differently.  They went about different kinds of 
business than they did outside.  The lighting was different.  The sounds 
were different.  And there was lots of fun stuff.
Now, there were people who worked in the library.  They maintained the 
stacks, made sure new books were added and old ones were repaired.  They 
would get out some of the old favorite books and put them where people 
could enjoy them.  They would even create fun little artistic displays.  
There were also people who just used the library.  They woudl come in, 
get what they needed, enjoy the time they spent there, and leave.  
There were also people who were afraid of the library.  I knwe some 
people who wouldn't even go inside!
I really liked the library.  I would go in and lose myself in the wonder 
of the whole thing.  Then I would ground myself and pursue the search for 
whatever little jewel of knowledge I was after.  Sometimes I'd stay all day.
But eventually I had to go home.  They'd kick me out if I stayed too long!
But when I left, I had something more than when I went in.  I had the 
knowledge I got from my research, but I also had this wonderful overall 
experience that taught me all sorts of little things.  
And I woudl go out into the world a changed man and I would apply the 
lessons I learned at the library to my day-to-day life.
I don't go to the UCD library anymore.  I live too far away.  My alumni 
association membership gives me free access to it, though.  And I know 
that if I ever need that resource again, though it may change a little 
over time, it will be there for me.

> Would any of you entertain the notion of possibly IDENTIFYING yourselves
> somehow during your sets?  

RIGHT on!!  I always wiggle myself up to the booth only to ask a few
people standing around, "Who's spinning?", and they rarely know.  Bummer!
I would like to give credit where credit is due, but can't if I don't who
to give it to.







While I would like to say that I'm so down with
> the scene that i know y'all by sight, or that i have the psychic
> connection that precludes anything as mundane as knowing your name...
> well, I can't. And i suspect this is true for many of us DJ endusers.
> 
> I can't say how often I've been at a party and wanted to know who that
> awesome DJ just was.  
> 
> I'm not saying you should put on some "Hi!  My name is Mystr-E!" sticker
> on your chest, but there's gotta be *some* creative, aestheticly
> acceptable way you can let people know who you are while you're spinning.
> I don't think it's inherently uncool to identify yourself somehow,
> although it might take some creative thought on your part...
> 
> If only for PR reasons, I'd think this would be in everyone's best
> interest.
> 
> Perhaps there's some secret DJ-cabal rule that prohibits this sort of
> thing though?  I mean, if y'all aren't supposed to talk about it, i just
> want you to know i *totally* understand.
>

X-Sender: node1@idiom.com
Message-Id: <v03007814afc7b9841d56@[206.14.123.68]>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9706132037.A21797-0100000@netcom15>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
From: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>
Subject: Re: DJ IDs and eggos
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Noah says:
>in the 'rock' scene, the focus is on teh cult of personality surrounding
>the performer.  Frankly, no one really cares if the music is even good or
>not, what matters is that some dude is jumping around on stage with a
>guitar and fifteen-year-old girls have posters of him up in their bedrooms.

That's a pretty huge generalization for a entire scene don't you think?
Someone on the "outside" (whatever that is) who picks up a Keoki cd might
think the same about us!



>in the 'techno' scene, the focus is supposed to be on the music.  so from
>the beginning, the artists remained anonymous and faceless.  I mean, I
>sure haven't seen a Fatboy Slim poster down at Tower Records lately.

I'd say that in ALL music scenes, the focus is *supposed* to be on the
music, wouldn't you?
There are posters of Mark Farina's projects hanging from the walls of
virgin megastores...
Josh Wink has his face on his releases. Wade Hampton has his face on his
mixed CD. Is the music's quality defined by whether credit is taken or not
taken?



>so the DJ is the presenter of the music, not the creator, as the creators
>are hidden away so as to preserve the sanctity and validity of their
>artistic efforts.

Is an artist's work therefore invalid and unsanctified by its creator's
personal association? What about if dj's are mixing tracks that they
produced? The picture that this paints reads to me almost as if machines
are making the music and not people. As if to say that its not acceptable
for an artist to associate their bodies with their minds, because this
detracts from the output somehow... I disagree. I'd even go as far as to
say that this dichotomy could be viewed as unhealthy. Is an artist's piece
of work not a part of them, a part of their psyche, like a child, or an
extension of the self? How can a part of that self be irrelevant?

Isn't the role of the dj that of a postmodern artist? To take that which
exists/has previously been created, and re-present it in a new and
potentially exciting context? Is that not a form of creation? How does this
differ from a collage artist, or a scavenger-sculptor? Dj's of the future
might appear at an event with a few pc's and soundEdit, or Recycle (i think
someone mentioned this recently)... Mixing records could be viewed as
simply a more primitive form of this.

Where does the fear of being recognized for creativity come from? Is it
mandatory that ego-inflation is associated with widespread acceptance and
recognition of a particular work? Does it automatically cause a state of
false artistry or pollute a given work's integrity? I don't think that is
necessarily so.

I don't pretend to know the answers to these questions, I continually ask
them to myself often. It's an interesting train of thought... =]

Joshua

Date: Sat, 14 Jun 1997 09:19:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: DJ IDs and eggos
To: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v03007814afc7b9841d56@[206.14.123.68]>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9706140932.A26881-0100000@netcom21>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I really think this is a fun topic... I hope it doesn't piss anyone off :)

The whole music end of the techno scene has always fascinated me.  I 
mean, on one hand you have this amazing push to keep out the human 
element and to limit the direct personal association that an audience has 
with the musical artist, and on the other you have this amazing human 
need to establish a relationship with what you're experiencing in your 
ears.  Eventually the human need wins out, as right well it should IMHO.  
But it's just interesting.  Having Josh Wink posters up doesn't negate 
the power or quality of the music, but it does negate the artistic 
faceless ideal that seemed to emerge in the early techno acts, you know 
what I mean?

Of course you want to know who the DJ is.  I do to!  I want to be able to 
see a DJ name on a flyer and think "Oh yeah, that dude spins really great 
techstep,"  or "Yeah, her breaks are the freshest!" and then head off to 
a party and hear some great tracks!  But in the end, that too is linking 
a person with the music.

Should people be linking with what they create?  Some say yes.  Some say 
no.  It's an artistic decision.  The early days of techno seemed to 
present the decision that the person was not as important as the music 
itself.  One artists would often record under three or four different 
'band' names and most folks woudln't know it was only one person.  

As a DJ of course I feel there is an amount of artistry as well as just 
plain technical skill in what I do.  And of course there is a big ego 
rush when people know who I am.  But I'm constantly asking myself, "Am I 
doing this because I really love this music and I love presenting it, or 
is it because I love being 'known'?"
it's just an interesting question, I think

love and hugs to you all!

Your letter lovingly remixed by a little Virus:

<xfade>
> on one hand you have this amazing push to keep out the human
>element and to limit the direct personal association that an audience has
>with the musical artist, and on the other you have this amazing human
>need to establish a relationship with what you're experiencing in your
>ears. Having Josh Wink posters up doesn't negate
>the power or quality of the music, but it does negate the artistic
>faceless ideal that seemed to emerge in the early techno acts
<xfade>

I wonder if techno was ever truly faceless...what i'm thinking is that
since the majority of techno producers are Djs and since we all know these
Djs by name and sight then for the most part we know the artists too...
Hasn't it been like this since the earliest days of the scene? What about
live P.A.s? Isn't this yet another way to bring a face to a music that
might seem otherwise too mechanical? I think there have always been faces
to go with the music- only that in the techno scene like any other UG scene
they were faces that are seen not as superstars but instead as our equals
and friends. Now that the scene has grown there is a distance between the
ravers and the musicians, Djs and promoters....We are steadily becoming the
industry we set out to avoid... We have our own idols ( both on the Dj and
Artist levels ), we pay them too much money and bring them bowls filled
with only  brown m&ms...Is this our fault for giving them faces or their
fault for allowing themselves to get caught up in that funny little thing
called fame? It is not the face but the attitude that is the problem.
<xfade>

L8r

-Virus-

If your looking for a new source of music and you can use RealAudio, I
recommend trying our Internet music service, TheDJ.com.

http://www.thedj.com/

TheDJ.com streams 55 commercial free music channels 24 x 7 in RA 3.0.

We offer a "Trance" channel as well as "MegaBPMs" channel which features
the likes of DJ Dan, Frankie Bones, Mark Farina, Laurent Garnier, Jeno.
More segmented channels are on the way too.

If you have a Windows 95 PC, you can download TheDJ Player which lets
you access the music directly from your desktop in a Pointcast fashion.
http://www.thedj.com/thedj_player.html

The playlists are being upgraded now and any feedback from this list is
very very welcome.

BTW unlike DMX we are free.

Peace,
Bryant

>That's a cool idea. I just realized I've also seen it done with argon
>lasers. The operator would program the laser to display the name of the dj
>playing at the moment... That works too.

Last weekend in San DIego,  at "Forces of Nature" rave,  being promoted by
some "Out of towners"...  when the next DJ went on,   they stopped the
music,   thanked the previous DJ,   announced the one going on,   and
the music started up.......  strange!   Haven't heard that done before.

In the Jungle room,   there was an MC blabbing into the mic....   It
didn't click with me that well,   and was kind of distracting....    Jungle
takes a lot of listening to the small nuances of the music in order for my
body to react with the music....

Anyway,   I'll probably see everyone at Analog tonight..  at least until
I get dehydraded and have to leave....    I hope there will be a place to
re-fill water bottles there....  I hate asking people for water....

JD

something or like they did at *warmth* with the banners on the walls behind the
DJs.  It makes me feel more connected when you know who the DJ is, which makes
me enjoy the experience more.

> >although it might take some creative thought on your part...
> <snip>
> >Perhaps there's some secret DJ-cabal rule that prohibits this sort of
> >thing though?
>
>
> 	It seems rather taboo in Northern California. The only time I've
> seen it done in recent history here was at the first Analog
> (SpaceChildren), and it was only because there were MIDWEST djs in the
> house. Hyperactive was on the mike (or the headphone in this case), and so
> was ESP, talking to the crowd, and telling them what dj/livePA was on,
> getting people hyped... I grew up listening to those guys do that shit. Not
> only does it get people excited, but it lets you know who you're listening
> to, which I don't think is a bad thing. I'd *love* to see more of it
> here...
>
[snip]

> 	The reason I think that it doesn't happen here, is usually because
> the music in this area is: A) not hard enough, B) not fast enough, and/or
> C) simply doesn't carry the energy/power/force that warrants it. Therefore
> nobody is jumping out of their skins, screaming and yelling and generally
> freaking out (in a healthy, positive way of course). There are UG
> exceptions to this rule, but in general it seems to elude many massives.

Well, over the course of the night I saw over a hundred people, but not
one could I solidly ID as being from SFR.  The band was good, their DJ was
good, my rooms were good (most of the time).  There were problems with the
demos, but otherwise the entertainment was pretty darn cool.  Since that
was the official housemate cosponsored end-of-lease party, I don't think
we'll ever see something like that again here.  But I'm inspired enough to
try another gathering closer to the actual date of moving out... I'll
invite everyone again then.
Sorry to those who didn't hear soon enough and couldn't make it, and
thanks for those who did come to share the party with us (although I
regret that I wasn't out and around enough to meet very many of the cool
guests)..
Hope to see some of you at Sunset... (and analog for that matter)
take care,
Max

---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	joshua@nodeOne.com (joshua nodeOne)
Sender:	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
To:	goolie@construct.net (Adam Gould)
CC:	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 97-06-14 14:23:20 EDT

Goolz sez:
>Would any of you entertain the notion of possibly IDENTIFYING yourselves
>somehow during your sets?
<snip>
>I don't think it's inherently uncool to identify yourself somehow,
>although it might take some creative thought on your part...
<snip>
>Perhaps there's some secret DJ-cabal rule that prohibits this sort of
>thing though?


	It seems rather taboo in Northern California. The only time I've
seen it done in recent history here was at the first Analog
(SpaceChildren), and it was only because there were MIDWEST djs in the
house. Hyperactive was on the mike (or the headphone in this case), and so
was ESP, talking to the crowd, and telling them what dj/livePA was on,
getting people hyped... I grew up listening to those guys do that shit. Not
only does it get people excited, but it lets you know who you're listening
to, which I don't think is a bad thing. I'd *love* to see more of it
here...

	I guarantee you'll see more of that if you go hear ESP Woody at
Analog tomorrow... He just does it. He cares. If the crowd looks
uninterested in a dj, he'll get on there and try to stir things up. If the
dj is going strong, he'll get on there and tell you give it up for the
person who is kicking your ass... (translation: scream and yell in
appreciation for the good dj)

	The reason I think that it doesn't happen here, is usually because
the music in this area is: A) not hard enough, B) not fast enough, and/or
C) simply doesn't carry the energy/power/force that warrants it. Therefore
nobody is jumping out of their skins, screaming and yelling and generally
freaking out (in a healthy, positive way of course). There are UG
exceptions to this rule, but in general it seems to elude many massives.

-Joshua

Uhm.  Goodness.
Looks like I won't be making it to Analogue (for those that don't know
Analogue is a seriously cool party featuring Rabbit in the Moon and other
artists).  But then, I suppose that's the least of my worries.

Advice:
Keep copies of your vehicle registration/insurance/etc either on you
(wallet purse etc) or at your house or something.  If someone steals your
car (the police told me this is extrmely common) then you'll really wish
you had this information to help them track it down.  Also, consider the
club (yeah but it works) or an alarm that shuts off the engine.

I don't think I really believe in Karma at all.  It's a tired superstition
that just doesn't seem to fit my life recently.  Such contrast.  Phat
mansion party, then car gets stolen.  Maybe it's a decadence balance?  No,
probably not.  Just dumb luck.

hrm.  be safe!
Max

From: "lara at vibe.org" <lara@vibe.org>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: phunckateck/phreaky people/boringsaturday
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.970615144729.10031A-100000@linux.announce.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

Heyas EVERYONE.. 
I've felt like I've been in a bigass party slump lately and well, this 
weekend revived my faith and love for the party scene. Don't ask me why, 
all I can think of is that PHUNCKATECK saved my ass BIGTIME ! What would 
I do without it? Freaky People was pretty grand as well.. Read on for 
details :)
*smoochtickle*!
 since everyone seems to be reviewing MIRASOL, i thought 
i'd give PHUNCKATECK it's big ups as a thursday weekly..
big ups go out firsthand to the phunckateck/b.a.s.s. krus for making this 
not just every two weeks but a weekly. 
the heads at the door are beginning to be a bit nicer and less rough when 
turning kids away with no ID, so you don't get all intimidated on the way 
in anymore..(these heads aren't phunckateck kru, they're the ppl who own 
the bar)
night started out sweet with jason mouse on the decks first, i spent half 
the time listening to scuba squad in the hip-hop room though (that's 
beatjakr and charlie bucket).. bigups to THEM cuz they're doin a good 
job all night long..
	people didn't show up until around 11:30 when mudfoot decided to kick 
the phat beats down.. then the crowd started rollin in...
BIG ASS UPS to MUDFOOT for throwing some ragga styley in there, i don't 
know if i've ever wiggled my butt so hard in my life but shit.. see we 
need more ragga inna jungle all you dj'sout there you could learn a few 
lessons from mudfoot over there ! :) his diversity in his track selection 
really keeps me MOVIN.. sometimes it's really boring when all you get is 
hardstep or techstep for a hour straight up. :) so.. mudfoot got everyone 
bouncing..
	next up was abstract, who started his set out for the most part 
darker than his average self.. i've noticed he's gotten a bit darker 
every time i hear him spin. which is beautiful and phun, cuz like i said, 
an hour of hardstep jump up or techstep straight can get a lil tiring :) 
i left early near the end of abstract's set but the crowd was movin great 
as usual..
SO THAT WAS PHUNCKATECK! NEone wanna tell me how juju's set was?

then i decided on friday night spur of the moment to run off to FREAKY 
PEOPLE.. which was in SAN MATEO COUNTY but i guess Santa Cruz. there were 
about 100 people there, and the vibe was excellent. decorations/whatever 
were minimal with a black light and a green light and a few torches and a 
bonfire, which was perfect. someone was spinning jungle that night when 
we got there, and i danced in the sand! i rarely dance in sand but hey, i 
danced off and on all night in the sand and met some other coolie people 
who could groove in the sand:) COLD COLD it was, you HAD to keep moving !
it was a phun snuggly night and so bigups to harmony. 
i WAS gonna go to JUNGLE LOVE on saturday night, but being outside on the 
beach all night turned my chronic spring cough into a full-blown sickness 
of some sort so i spent my sat night emailing random people and coughng :)
SO HOW WAS JUNGLE LOVE? 
oh yea and ANALOG? :)
see ya all @ STEP2K n F8 this weekend and of COURSE HAPPY KIDS/GRUMPY KIDS 
the weekend after that :)
MUCH MUCH love,
laralara:)
p.s. bigups to IAN for doing us a favor @ freaky people!

Subject: Re: Hard music
Message-ID: <19970615.150621.11558.0.GabeRRamos@juno.com>
References: <v03007800afc9036b2a51@[206.14.123.16]>

this is just my opinion but i think that the abundance of good
psycedelics (E in particular)  creates a more mellow vibe. I think in
some places there is much less E, more speed, more K, more roofies(sp?). 
 these other drugs are'nt  as conducive to the "everything is beautiful;
i love you" vibe that sf is lucky enough to have sometimes.  also there
are truly epic amounts of other psycedelics(good acid,mushrooms) around
sf compared to anywhere else (in the world).  Also northern Cali is
absolutlely stocked with the kind green buddha. We have a whole hippy
drug culture tradition.  Our scene is more "vibey"   You will probably
disagree but if you take 100 people trippin on all kinds of different
psycedelic drugs (we are not talking about tweekers)  and put them in one
room.  I think more people would have a better time if the music wasn't
totally pounding them relentlessly.   sometimes people play hard.   but i
think with the drugs that we have here more mellow vibey stuff is better
appreciated by larger groups of people.   thats not to say that there is
no room for parties that have a harder edge.   I'm just tring to show why
around here mellow stuff has a broader appreciation then in other places.

also historically  i think that the wicked full moon parties really
changed alot of peoples musical tastes.   I know that when i fist started
buying records in 1993 i was buying mostly trance.  after going to full
moon my tastes changed to house.  I think that the beauty of taking 
really good E and bugging out to UK style house on a beach is probably
something that alot of ravers  around the country will never even hear
about.  

hard music is around though.   although maybe it is not as hard as you
are used to.  you should throw a party that is really, really hard. 
maybe you can introduce people to another vibe.

peace
gabe

Forwarded message:
From:	eros@Larry.Spacestar.Net (@~j030)
To:	Vinylmidi@aol.com
CC:	sfraves@hyperreal.com, KATO_ERIC@tandem.com
Date: 97-06-14 05:53:19 EDT

Umm.  no.  It's okay to record direct to HD.  I do it all the time.
74minutes of stereo audio=650MB (Hence, the CD length)  I don't beleive
you can burn directly to CDROM, nor would I recommend it.  Those with
experience burning disks are very familiar with Disk Underrun errors...
Well unless you have a whole lot of cache on your rom burner (512K is
typical) you will have a pretty tough time with a RT burn.
Just my take.
=-EJ

	j00 j00 j00------@~j030------j00 j00 j00


On Tue, 10 Jun 1997 Vinylmidi@aol.com wrote:

> If you are recording/making a mix straight to the harddrive  30 seconds of
> digitized audio takes up 1.4 mb of space.  Compression can play a factor in
> the final edit.  U might want to try burning it directly to a cdrom (upto
640
> mb of space)  or using an external drive for portability.  Sound actually
> takes up a LOT of hd space and the playback rate is another factor to
> consider.  But I am speaking solely of digitized audio files.  PC and Mac
> platforms are a bit different too.
> 
> ;-)
> 
> Just my 2 cents...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 15 17:07:55 1997

Received: from localhost (vision@localhost)
	by mpath.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id RAA22423
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 15 Jun 1997 17:07:46 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Sun, 15 Jun 1997 17:07:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: Max Vision <vision@mpath.com>
Reply-To: Max Vision <vision@mpath.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: SATURDAY review (long, includes my life _and_ raves)
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.95.970614184840.4978C-100000@nodserv.mpath.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Saturday
midnight to 4am
 (spindown of the phat half moon bay mansion party... not everything went
as planned, but what ever does?  This was nicer than earlier when I was
running around taking care of things.  At about 4am the music was all off
and there were only like a dozen people left sitting around chatting.)
4am to 4pm
 (miscellany, sleeping, cleaning somewhat, hanging out)
4pm to 8pm
 (trying to coordinate rides to SF, miscellany, food, phone..)
8pm
 (I drive to SF to visit some friends in Noe Valley - I park at the top of
the street (22nd and Vicksburg) and wander down into the stores and coffee
places, etc.  Visions of Rabbit in the Moon dance in my head.  On the way
to town I'm wearing my friend Kevin's hitachi glasses, the paper ones that
are laser etched to spread white light into rainbows streaking everywhere.
I don't use psychedelics so I'm not sure, but I suppose this effect is
comparable to tripping hard on lsd.  We get back to the place, chill, I
check email, etc, then head out.)
10pm
 (I'm walking up from the house, top of the street, to the spot where my
car should be.  NO CAR.  I stand there and stare.  I walk to where is was
and look down.  I walk back and forth where it should be looking for
clues, or tiremarks, glass, anything.  I start to panic mildly.  I stand
back and look where it was and say "someone _took_ my f*cking car.  Why on
earth would they pick _my_ car." (81 toyota).  The car was a _gift_ from a
friend because I couldn't buy my dream car due to legal problems (non
financial)  I went back to the house and relayed the story.. They came
back with me to verify, yep, legal parking spot, no signs of towing.  I go
back, we call the towing places and the police.  It's been confirmed many
many many times over, the vehicle is indeed stolen.)
10:23
(I get a page from my friends in half moon bay that wanted a ride to
Analogue.. they are totally bumming because they promoted for the party
and had their hearts set on going.  This page _finally_ includes an actual
telephone number I can call.  I do so, to explain what happened, but the
guy who answer had never heard of them...)
11pm
(I'm somehow _still_ in a good mood (way up to the time I'm writing this)
but am a little out of it and confused so.. I start walking to Downtown
SF.  Yeah it's hella far, but I wasn't going anywhere.. so I'm walking
along 24th, down toward mission (yeah I know bart wasn't running, but
where else to walk?) and then I see MICHAEL (thank you!!!!) I start
talking to him and it turns out he's going to Jungle Love across the
street.  Across the street!!!  Saved.  Lifted.  Arisen.  With glee I eat
mexican food with him, then head back across the street and go in and
dance my heart out for awhile.  It feels pretty good... but there are so
few people.. like a dozen of us, and most of the time there were only 3 or
4 ppl on the entire dancefloor.  I ran into Babbs and gang and they were
heading to Analogue.. after much consideration, I joined them and rode
across the bay to Analogue...

Sunday
4am
Since it's so late into the party we walk right in (thanks crew! that was
cool, because it would have really sucked to have to pay so late in the
game) but hey, I saw almost all of Rabbit in the Moon.  That place was
f*cking massive.  Imagine HomeBase _without WALLS_ just one big cavern.  I
went OFF.  Some of you may have seen me with the purple glowsticks... Huge
guy, thin, long hair tied back, massive pants (30" openings staightleg)
sleevless shirt... alright enough of that... anyway I was in heaven for an
hour or so, I saw some people like Ashley who I'm not sure if they are
really into being friendly but I was certainly trying to be regardless,
anyway the ppl I talked to asked if I was e'ing or what but no I was 100%
AMPED on the bomb ass incredible force that is R I T M.  Just _beautiful_
.. the energy, that I felt anyway, moved me all over the place.  I saw so
many beautiful people..  There was one girl who could work smooth majic
with her hands that I _had_ to surrender my glowsticks on sight, with the
purple glowing highlight, her motions were like a dolphin swimming in warm
bright coastal water... she was fluid.. just inspiring!  I watched as long
as I could stand the outpouring of admiration and envy, then moved on,
aquiring another set of sticks... the show was..  sigh.  BIG.  good.
7am
Show ended... all told I'd talked to Captain Crunch about realtime dat
mixing, met up with Gweeds, Aleph1, and gang (elite friends) saw Liquid
and Mercury on the way in, and made a few new friends.. er aquantences
anyway :)  sigh.  it was time to head back.
8:45a
I'm finally able to catch a bart back to the city... and the long CARless
journey home begins (home=half moon bay).  But you know, there are a lot
of people who hanve to take public transportation, or even choose to all
the time.. it's just harder sometimes.  well , all the time really.
timing ...

alright that's enough.  uhm.  That was my day.
Chill.
Visit SF friends.
Car is stolen.
Jungle Love.
Analogue.
Trip home.

sigh.

love,
Max

trucks that had fallen off the roadbed into the mud........ These 7-10
hour bus-trips over the bumpiest oads ever imaginable would have driven
me to madness had i not been listening to kickin choons. Proof once
again that house music helps you survive through trial and tribulation.

long! ;O) work,  parties, work, being home, work I forgot there was such

Berkeley, supposedly to eat ;o)
