To: KATO_ERIC@tandem.com
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Digital Mastering and Hard-Disk Recording (was Re: Sorry...nrr techy)
In-reply-to: Your message of 13 Jun 1997 15:05:00 -0700
Reply-To: mayer@netcom.com
Date: Sun, 15 Jun 97 22:40:25 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Now I'm stuck in deciding
> between the Crystal Lake or S/B 64 Gold.  Any suggestions?

They suck. Like I said in my last message, all the consumer grade sound
boards have crappy A/D and D/A -- after your computer's high noize floor
gets masked by putting in loud signals (and your master gets that horrible
digital clipping sound as a result) you'll end up with about 12-14 bits of
usable digital resolution, often less if you've got a "noisy" computer, bad
power supply, etc. THis is Ok for games, but not ok for music.

You can hear the distortion w/ this level of resolution. digital distortion
sounds like crap -- Not all distortions are equal. Digital distortion is the
worst sounding of the lot, transistor distortion next, tape distortion next,
then tube distortion (even harmonic) last. The less even harmonic distortion
you get, the worse it sounds, that's why tape and tube
distortion/compression actually sounds good... DIgital distortion is
harmonically the most grating you can possibly devise. This is what consumer
sound boards give you.

>From the consumer cards, the CardD is supposedly one step better. It does
one thing well -- record and play back digital audio. Other multipurpose
sound cards do lots of things badly. THey're really only good for games and
those silly multimedia demos nobody uses on their computer once the novelty
wears off...Better yet, get a digital-only CardD and an external a/d and d/a
converter. this is the only way to do computer sound properly short of
getting a mac and blowing megabucks on pro-tools... with the A/D and D/A
external to the computer, your computer's noise will not pollute your sound,
and you can keep your audio-sound and computer-noise signals separated, as
they should be.

Without some kind of compress/limit/soft-clipping before your a/d converter
(or as part of the a/d convert process) your sound will be weak. To prevent
digital clipping you have to adjust your levels way low... and you'll end up
w/ a track that sounds very dull and quiet, with softer parts sounding
grainy and distorted (since the quiet parts have to give up resolution in
order to keep your peaks from clipping). The end result is not at all punchy
the way something would sound mastered to reel-to-reel mag (analog) tape.
that's because you tend to let the tape do the compression for you when
mastering to mag-tape. In digital, you need an external
compressor/limiter/brick-wall before the A/D converter to make sure you
optimize your levels and gain before going digital. 

In the end, after wasting lots of money and time, you may well end up
getting a tc electronics finalizer like I did to give you compression and
clip-free sound straight into your SPDIF or AES/EBU digital inputs on a
computer's sound card. If you know this is something you want to do, best
save the money you'd waste on a bad consumer audio card and use it towards a
finalizer. or at least make sure your sound card supports direct digital
in/out ... so you can attach a finalizer or other external a/d-d/a after you
get tired of the cheapo A/D and D/A quality you get on most computer sound
cards.

Going digital can be far better than analog. However, it requires
technique and understanding of what's going on if you don't want to 
make your sound suffer in order to digitally manipulate the sound.

PS: Beginning in July, contact mayer@netcom.com, for help and studio for
mastering music to digital...

==    Niels Mayer ..... mayer@netcom.com ..... http://www.eit.com/~mayer   ==

okay, i might just regret this after hitting the 'send' button, but i
haven't much to lose, so here goes my shameless 'personal'! i've got a good
friend in austin who's actually running one in the paper there with the
hopes of finding a beau, and i'll start of that that's not why i'm posting
this. anyway, what's life if you don't make an ass of yourself once in a
while?

i've now been out here for about 5 weeks - 2 in san jose before i found my
lovely apartment in what i was _told_ was lower nob hill but what i later
discovered is really the tenderloin. it's really not as bad as ppl think,
but then i'm a paranoid new yorker and don't walk about at night by myself
anyway. at least i found something. i'm married, but i won't go into that
because i don't see the need to open my personal life too much to 450
strangers. and in the traditional personal lingo, wasp female, 30, a bit
shy, sort of small.... :P

i was, as i said in my intro from austin, introduced to raving in '90 or so
up in toronto after (or during) an 808 state concert. been in and out
since. before that, i was a bit of a clubkid, although i sometimes found
myself relentlessly following the dead as well. go figure. basically, i
like happy music, happy ppl, and i like to dance. :) other obsessions of
mine are as follows: design and typography (as those of you who are
familiar can probably tell from my addy), ballet, and ... raving, partying,
design and ballet. modern art (particularly conceptual). books. that's why
i design them. politically to the left. my musical taste is not at all
limited to 'techno' - all happy music. :) not too poppy tho. and i'm
rambling.

so, here i am. and aside from one really sweet person on this list, i
haven't met anyone to hang with. i'm probably feeling desparate 'coz i
haven't found a job yet and am incredibly bored. i don't usually venture
out by myself - during the day, sometimes - but definetely not at night,
and not into social situations (it's that shyness i mentioned). my hubby
doesn't share any of my interests - he'd much rather watch football/soccer
on the tv (gooooooaaaaaalll). anyway, i'll probably be in better shape when
i have a job, as i said, and hence money to spend, and hopefully that won't
be too far off into the future. but even with all the money in the world,
it kinda helps to have ppl to go out with.... told you this was shameless!
anyway, i'm hoping to get involved through this group that helps ppl out at
parties, and that'll be good. anyone else out there in my neighborhood?
hehe.

well, apologies for wasting your bandwidth with such dribble, but that's my
personal! (probably cost an arm and a leg in the paper, and then who knows
what sort of responses you might get! but then again, who knows who's
really reading _this_!)

cheers - e. :)

.............................................................................

Its been a while since we have done one of these, but a few of us got 
together last week for lunch and decided we would try to set one up 
again.  So...

When: Tuesday June 17th, 1997 at 12:00pm
Where: Pedro's on Freedom Circle
Directions:
101N (or S) to Great America Parkway.  If you are on 101N turn right 
off of the exit.  From 101S turn left. You want to be heading towards 
Great America.
Turn right on Mission College. It will be the first or second light.
Turn right on Freedom Circle.
Pedro's will be on your right a little ways down the road.
Ask for the SFRaves party..

If you can make it let me know by tomorrow morning before say 10:30 or 
so..

We'll try to let people know a little more ahead of time next time we 
do this.  Also if anyone has suggestions for places to eat next time 
let me know.


j

Hey all you party Phreaks,
Let me tell you about ana-log it was at the new "Homebase" the massive
wherehouse down the street from the actual homebase. I had never been
to this new spot and it was real Big!!! it was decortated pretty well.
I think it was just a little to Big. They had two wild spinning lasers
like at the Harmony party in both corners of the room good lighting.
The crowd was good they even had a house room that was not so packed
the party was good not to hot and crowded. They had large fans and the
roll up gates open so it was real cool. I saw a lot of "listers" there
which was kewl. I had never seen rabbit in the moon before and let me
tell you if you have never seen them you are truley missing out. They
put on by far one of the best concert type shows I have ever seen. I
am usually not into the live P.A thing but they were interactive with
the crowd and the dancers and performers that they had with them were
great. I encourage anyone that has never seen them perform to check
them out the next time they come to town. the other Jocks were real
good. The DJ that stole the show was the Surgeon. He F*cking rocked
the house He is a TeKno/Trance producer from UK or Germany not sure?
He must have played like 80 rekkids in like half hour he was mixing
slicing and dicing some hard Trancey Tekno. He is by far one of the
best Tekno/Trance DJ's I have seen in a long time. So I advise you all
to check him out a party coming up real soon. I don't want to give the
party name cause he is a suprise guest!! It was worth the admission
price they put on a good show and party. 

Love you all,
Macadio

okay, i came from my death bed, to have a sooper dooper weekend! =) 
first, friday was bfd.. DOPE!!! blur, erasure, the cure.. gawd! my 
favorite brit bands all together.. ohmygoodness! =) then sat. was 
graduation... that was exciting... then the parents took markie mark 
and i out to dinner.. then to the apartment we went for a nap, and at 1 
am, we decided to go on our way for rabbit in the moon.. woo hoo.. we 
got there around 1:30, 1:45... we heard the party wasn't that great, 
but then rabbit in the moon came on.. definitely a trip! =) we left the 
party at about 6:30.. went back to the apartment, took a shower, and 
had cracked out conversations while we waited for the mall to open, so 
i could get a daddy's day gift... finally opened, got a present, 
finally went back to my house for the bbq my parents were having for 
graduation... bumped some steve loria in the backyard (dj tune too, 
what a dope tape! you go boy! and thanks bill!).. then we decided to go 
to sunset.. i really love that spot.. i love the berkeley marina, and 
although it's cold, it's my fav. spot for a sunset.. it was just 
beautiful.. so many happy (cold!) people.. and goofy rabbit and monk 
were there getting their grooves on.. silly boys! all in all, this was 
a super great weekend! thanks everyone for being a part of it! =)

                                 much love,
                            anissa, princess of the universe!

interested in a sfraves San Francisco area Lunch?  If it's been/being
done, fill me in!!

I'm trying to get back into the scene and would like to re-connect with
all of you beautiful people!  My attitude has been a little off lately
and I really need some positive energy thrown my way to get me in a
better frame of mind!  New friends would help too. Hopefully you won't
see this as a self-serving idea ;-( I think it would be a great thing!
Give me some general feeling on this and if anyone's interested let's do
it!  

BTW, love the messages and news!  This is absolutely lovely! 

Melissa ;-p

        It would probably be easy to identify me. I would have various
braids in my hair in weird places, that all look weird because I usually do
them myself in the morning and take them out when I sleep. I also can't spin
without being stoned, because I learned spinning while in my worst stoner
phase ever(smoking literally all the time). So I would probably be smoking
between every two or three records(one onlooker asked me for a hit once, so
I gave her my pipe, she took a few hits and sat right in front of me. After
she noticed I was taking numerous hits all the time, she asked me how I was
still standing, let alone spinning.)

        But seriously, I more like the idea which I see from time to time at
parties, the DJ lineup schedule with times posted outside the rooms. Maybe
even a sign near the entrance to a room with "Now Spinning : " on it so we
could just post who is currently spinning. But that's a little weird, I
think I like the schedule instead, even though it's usually off because of
delays.

approach everyone who has an SFRaves laminate to say hi and introduce myself.

From: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: DJ IDs
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Why do you want to know who the DJ is anyway?
>allow me to elaborate for a moment:
>in the 'rock' scene, the focus is on teh cult of personality surrounding 
>the performer.  Frankly, no one really cares if the music is even good or 
>not, what matters is that some dude is jumping around on stage with a 
>guitar and fifteen-year-old girls have posters of him up in their bedrooms.
>in the 'techno' scene, the focus is supposed to be on the music.  so from 
>the beginning, the artists remained anonymous and faceless.  I mean, I 
>sure haven't seen a Fatboy Slim poster down at Tower Records lately.  
>(now this is changing a little now that techno is being corrupted by teh 
>rock and roll music machine here..  so you do have posters of Tom& Ed and 
>such... but anyway)...
>so the DJ is the presenter of the music, not the creator, as the creators 
>are hidden away so as to preserve the sanctity and validity of their 
>artistic efforts.  But when a DJ is 'known' that cult of personality 
>beings to grow, just like in the rock scene.  It's an interesting 
>situation.  Id vs. Ego and stuff.

        I defenitely agree with you about the danger of pretentiousness or
ego in the rave scene. When I saw Rabbit in the Moon at Analog on Saturday,
I was at first extremely confused. For the first 30 minutes before they
started, there was just lots of guys trying to look cool on stage standing
in the fog and letting the spotlights hit them in a dramatic way. At first
"Ninja Squirrel"(is that the name of that guy in Rabbit in the Moon?), the
'performance artist' struck me as having an extreme ego problem. He was
always doing crazy things and being in the spotlight, but I guess that's
what he does. Basically their act was one part Prodigy and one part arena
rock show. But oh well, I guess that's how it works in Florida.

        In the Bay Area scene, we probably have some the least problems with
DJ and artist ego getting in the way of music. That's what almost always
strikes me about the 'headlining act' at these larger raves; they usually
aren't that good. I instead spent my time dancing to Woody McBride who
didn't have 10 minute long pretentious intros, and didn't rely on throwing
money out into the audience(like Rabbit in the Moon did)to win them over, he
just relied on his music. It's good to see that a member of Hardfloor will
still get up there and spin like a normal DJ instead of the whole show thing
happening.

        It may be important to remember that Rabbit in the Moon are from
Florida, and we all know that Florida is weird. Marilyn Manson is from
Florida, and Florida is known for its huge death metal scene(many of the
great death metal bands came from Florida, like Obituary and Death. Don't
ask why I know this, okay damnit, I used to play in a death metal band in
high school, when I was young and the testosterone flowed freely)

        -chris

extremely high in price now. They aren't being made anymore but Roland

quite right(Unless you are willing to shell out for a Roland D3 or something)

I decided it would be fun to look into getting some personal...and let me 
stress...personal...equipment to play records an spin at my home for my 
own enjoyment, and maybe possibly a few friends if they can bare it :). 
Anyway, I asked around a bit about equipment ( turntables mainly, I know 
a good deal about mixers and speakers,) and all I could come up with was 
an answer that technics are the only turntables to buy. So I look around 
and found the 600 dollar technics, was thrown back a little bit buy the 
price, and was wondering if any of you had a little more information. 
Keep in mind that I only plan to use these in the comfort of my own home.

I did however see some sony tables that had many of the same features of 
the technics and they were 400 dollars less. Could someone explain to me  
( in technical terms please, I will understand you,) what I'm paying for 
if I spend 400 dollars more? And if there are other alternatives, where 
do i go to check them out?...

Thanks and Stay cool!

On Tue, 3 Jun 1997, Rubilanna Vasquez wrote:

> Hey all you beautiful ravers!!!!!!
> 
>   Wow, I wish I had as much fun as all of you at Warmth :( It was such a 
> great party, but unfortunately I was unable to enjoy it due to 
> circumstances beyond my control.  Some crazy ass stuff went down that 
> night. It was so awful that baisically the whole party was ruined for 
> me, but what I would like to do is thank all of you who were there for 
> me when that mother fu*ker tried to get me, you were all so sweet to me 
> and very helpful in getting that Jerk out of the rave. You guys saved my 
> night :)
> 
> 
>          
	I know this is somewhat of a late comment but I've wanted to get
it out since warmth and I think it's kinda important. I remember the 
incident pretty clearly and in fact was one of the guys who threw this 
ass hole back out on the street. There's only one thing that bothered me 
about this situation and I think it's REALLY REALLY imnportant that we 
take a little time to think about and help out with this at following 
raves...the thing that struck me is that this guy was obviously not a 
safe person to have around and by the looks of him ( older man, unshaven, 
dirty clothes...etc...) he obviously was supposed to be there. 

	So all I ask for the safety of myself, my friends, Ruby, and all
the rest of you is that we all keep a close eye out for suspisious looking
people at parties. I don't mean, bothering everysingle person that looks
the least bit out of place. But if you notice someone who OBVIOUSLY looks
like they might cause trouble,find someone who's in charge, or if no-one
is around, KINDLY present your, laminant or something like that to the
person, tell them who you are, and simply ask to see thier ticket. Let's 
all try to help out and never let something like what happened that night 
happen again. Thanks guys and gals :)

Stay cool,

Matt

I record directly to CD regularly. However, I don't involve my computer
at all, since everything I read made this sound like a real
hit-and-miss process that totally ties up your computer for the length 
of the recording proces (you can try to use the computer while
recording, but there's a good chance  windows will start swapping or do
some other antisocial thing to fuck up your audio recordins.... To say
nothing about the wasted time and wasted CD blanks at $5.00 a pop.

There are audio CD recorders out there. There's a pioneer for about
$1000.00, and pro-audio ones from Marantz (CDR-615, CDR-620) that work
quite delightfully. They even have direct digital in/out so you can
copy direct from DAT, or to a digital duplicate of a CD. The CDR-620
has a SCSI port which allows you to hook two of them together  and
duplicate any CD, CD-Rom, etc at double speed. unfortunately, they're
prtetty expensive so it's hard enough to afford one, let alone two. at
least it doubles as a phillips cdd-2000-compatible CDR and CDRom drive
via the SCSI port.... It's actually not a bad thing if you do a lot
of CD recording. you won't need to have 700Mb of disk free to hold your audio
before txfering to the CDR, and you won't need to have your computer sit idle
(well, at least uninteractive) for over an hour while you burn your disk.
and it's also a really great-sounding CD player.

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

I like my roland MC-303. Despite what all the analog wankers and snobs
out there say about it (they're probably just pissed they farted away
$1000.00 on a piece-of-crap-unreliable-noisy tb-303 or 808, or 909)
just to find out you can get a much cleaner sounding box that is brand
new, midi-capable, supported, and reliable for $500.00). I personally
think it's a pretty cool drum machine and a decent little "rave box"
and it's supposedly similar for doing drum loops to the 808 and 909. i
think the only mistake roland made is calling it a "303" since it isn't
a stripped-down analog bass synth. There's much better analog gizmoids
out there than the tb-303 anyways, e.g. the Roland JP-8000, Nord Lead
II, Waldorf Pulse, etc. So the real question for the snobs is why are
you playing with a toy analog synth when you really should have a
modular, a moog, a matrix, or one of the newfangled digital-simulated
analogs.

For more than twice the money, you can also get the Rave-O-Lution 909,
which seems pretty cool as well
(http://www.keyboardmag.com/studio/raveo.html).

some links on this and related items:

http://www.teknet.ch/tb303.htm
http://www.teknet.ch/tb-303/mc-303/mc-303.htm
http://www.teknet.ch/tb-303/mc-303/mcreview.htm
http://www.tb303.com/frames.html
http://inside.hku.nl/~bram/mc303/index.htm
http://inside.hku.nl/~bram/mc303/midi.htm
http://inside.hku.nl/~bram/mc303/links.htm
http://people.zeelandnet.nl/bdeloos/mc303/versions.htm
http://people.zeelandnet.nl/bdeloos/mc303/maillist.htm
http://www.inforoute.cgs.fr/blanchot/mc303faq.htm
http://utopia.knoware.nl/~mmello/smcdl.html
http://utopia.knoware.nl/~mmello/smc303.html

So I've been to a few parties down here where there's lots of hardcore.  
I guess that's a benefit to living in SoCal.  It's really a different 
kind of scene with all the kids crowded around the speakers yelling 
"Hardcore Hardcore Muthafuckin Hardcore!"  I dunno.  Personally I'd 
rather dig to some phatty grooves and boogie and then cuddle and stuff.  
Also there's a whoooooooole lot of bunky down here.  I think at last 
count my SoCal hit/miss ratio comes out somewhere around 70% in favor of 
bunky.  So your average partygoer actually makes a better investment by 
looking for other stuff.  Possibly this explains part of the draw toward 
speed.  I dunno.  I've tried getting into the hardcore stuff.  I mean, I 
feel it's kind of required since I'm in SoCal, but I'm sorry, I just 
can't do it.  BUT I have to admit, it's hard not to laugh at that "Three 
Girls..." rekkid that Ron D Core put out last year... :)

> Rock out to those pre-fab grooves dood!

Some of the pre-fab grooves are cool, but I've been programming my own
loops for a while now. But you probably didn't know that the mc303 had
a decent 808/909-style pattern-based sequencer because you were too
busy listening to all the 303-is-the-electric-guitar-of-our-generation
worshippers whine "it's not a 303" on the internet, even though they
probably spent an hour in the store, couldn't figure it out, and went
back to popping E's and twiddling thos knobs on their tb-303 while
visions of whordes of 12 year old girlz at a prodigy concert rushed
through their heads.

as far as i can tell, this anti mc-303 schtick that people have is a
defensive maneuver to cover their wallets and psyches after blowing
$1000.00 on a cheaply made toy synthesizer.

PS: i have copied some accented hi-hat lines from some presets because
i was too lazy to go in and accent them myself. but then again, i also
use a sampler to steal other people's soundz. i guess you make your
sounds out of flour and baking soda and water, like a "real man".


		Sincerely,
		Niels Mayer
		Deus SysEx Machina

help in any fasion I'll try and help.

we are going to be starting a new weekly in a south bay coffee house on 
wednesday nights going from 8pm-10pm..
it is called Slow Roasted and will feature a changing line up. we are 
going to try a stick with the more down tempo stuff, but we will see as 
we go.
the schedule for the next three weeks are as follows: 
                 6-18 Science and Andy W
                 6-25 Siphon and Lola
                 7-2 Matt Schmitt and Hak.408
the address is 5237 Stevens Creek Blvd., Santa Clara   408.248.4500
directions are as follows: from the northbay, take 280s to lawerence 
expressway exit/stevens creek. take a left. go through 2 lights and take 
your first left into the parking lot were there is a payless. the coffe 
shop is located right next to rocking tacos.
from the south bay take 280n to lawerence expressway/stevens creek exit 
and take a right at the light. make your immediate left into the parking 
lot.
hope to see a lot of you there. remember we start at 8pm.

matt 8^)

>>

>        Woody McBride?

Hardfloor is Ramon Zenker and Oliver Bondzio...they are both from
Germany... Woody is from Minneapolis, the owner of Communique records as
well as many other significant labels. In my book he is on the same level
as Hardfloor ( more down to earth: i told him that i saw god during a live
set that he played at a party in Wisconsin and he gave me a hug and a CD =]
) as far as acid producers go but unfortunately he is not part of the band.
=]

anyways, Woody is the epitome of what i expect from a Dj. Friendly, humble,
and skillful ( and he has some bombin' tracks )


-Virus-

hello all-

just wanted to invite you all to a north bay raver / geek gathering of the
hungry stomachs in san francisco.

where? yerba buena gardens, third st and mission

when? thursday, june 19 at 12:30 pm until 1:30 or so

why? cause it's a cool place to eat lunch, and there will be groovy
ambient music performed live!

what? lunch, bring something for yourself and something to share, either a
drink, a snack, or a little thingee (remember all your vegan, vegeterian,
and carnivorous buddies)

who? look for the distinct sign of the raver (water bottles) and look for
the geeky guy with the laptop in one hand and the cell phone in the other
(that's me!)

rsvp? why don't you let me know if you wanna come!  i'd love to hang out
with those of you that i know, and meet those of you that i don't!

love-

 matt =)

> > >visions of whordes of 12 year old girlz at a prodigy concert rushed
> > >through their heads.
> > >
> > >as far as i can tell, this anti mc-303 schtick that people have is a
> > >defensive maneuver to cover their wallets and psyches after blowing
> > >$1000.00 on a cheaply made toy synthesizer.
> > >
> > >PS: i have copied some accented hi-hat lines from some presets because
> > >i was too lazy to go in and accent them myself. but then again, i also
> > >use a sampler to steal other people's soundz. i guess you make your
> > >sounds out of flour and baking soda and water, like a "real man".
> > >
> > >
> > >               Sincerely,
> > >               Niels Mayer
> > >               Deus SysEx Machina
> 
> I am a new member to this list and would really prefer to hear
> positives......if you want to have a PRIVATE battle with this person,
> please feel free to do so, but please, please, please don't start being
> negative....it'll only bring others to try it too.

 Go up to the sony and push down on the table.

Knock on the technics. Listen to the sound it makes when your nuckle hits
the frame.
Do the same thing to the sony.

The Jungle Factory sells Technics for $450
Find that ADD. Goto The GoodGuys. Pay five hundred bucks for a 3year
limited x-ship warranty. Instant replacement. They will... Uh match any
price.

Well put.

 So. The MC-303. I am not much of a follower. So. If you say it's good. I
will look into it.
 I know what you mean though. So thats it? It's just getting shallow
reviews?

 Here is the big MC-303 question. Because I HAVE looked into it. But. I
could not seem to filter through all the "Pre-Fabs" to get to any possition
to..Make something from scratch..
 Can I make "phat beats" from the ground up? Or do you just select loops
and add to them? Can I make patterns of my own? Can I "erase" all the
preset to get them out of my way? 
 You know what I mean?
 I can some what see why people call it impractical. You know. It seems
kinna toyish. Because of the fact that. It's all in there. You know? I am
looking for a drum machine that can pump out alot of great sounds.  I am
not asking for an "all in one" karoke machine. Just some professional drum
machines. 

 But. If you Niels. Proud owner of the dreamy JP-8000 say it's a good tool.
Then. I might just buy one. No matter what main stream thinks.

 So. You really think it's a great sounding "DRUM-MACHINE" worth my money?
 I can't make compleat songs without DRUMS! =]:..
 So it's a good drum machine then? For "professional" use...

Let me know.
Thanx
Jeff

my girlfriend just subscribed to sfraves and when she got her new member
mail, i was shocked to find absolutely no mention of house music there. 
there was "underground/rave/club/trance/ trip-hop/jungle/goa/and techno"
but no mention of house.  this really bugs me.  house music is a vital
force in the san francisco scene.  the calendar is filled with events
that feature house music.  I don't have it in front of me but i would bet
there are more house events than trip hop parties, or goa parties, or
jungle parties.  Maybe this is just an oversight. maybe I am the only one
who cares about house music.  or maybe this is a case of house
discrimination.  if it is,  what did we do to be discluded from our place
in the discussion of the underground music scene here in sf?  

HOUSE MUSIC WILL NEVER DIE (no matter what you try to do to stop it)
gabe

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

Precedence: bulk

I choose to go free through love...
the quiet joyful uplifting of my loving.
Love is experienced only as a part of me.
I no longer look for it to come to me...
I realize I am my own source of love.
I can only feel my own feelings of love.
As I open my lovingness I find my love swells up
with each sunrise, each summer sky,
each and every smile I see.
My love carries me to a unity with all that is.
I can only transcend to realization with love.
I choose to free of my limitations through love.
I see that as I send love I am the one feeling love.
Anyone can accept or ignore the love I send;
yet I am blessed with my feelings of love.
Love is not the sunrise, the flowers, the friends....
Love is my expression of self.
The true inner self in which I accept and rejoice.
I open my inner self to shine lovingness for all
who choose to recognize it.
Another's disharmony reinforces my love.
It cries out for loving acceptance.
As we see behind the masks,
that unifying energy lifts us all free,
for we are all one another.
Today is my day to love... self... others... the one!

I choose to go free through love.

							--- ???

is to see the joining link about which the mind is completely blind."

Message-ID: <970617210711_201963760@emout10.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Analog Review*
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It was massive. Very massive. The whole place wasn't full, but the warehouse
was huuuge! The soundsystem was awesome, the bass reverberated through me and
made me sm;)e! Teehee. Rabbit in The Moon was pretty good, but not as great
as I expected them to be. The techy thing they were trying to do got old,
because the music they played wasn't that great. Honestly, I think They're a
little bit overhyped. In fact, this entire party was waaay too hyped. It was
good and all, but I expected it to be a little better, in terms of
decorations and music. 

I give props to the little jungle room, because even though there weren't a
lot of people there, everyone was grooving. The overall crowd of this was
pretty cool for a massive. Not too many stone faced rhythm deprived
individuals taking up all the space.

To those who weren't able to come, don't worry, it wasn't that phat of a
party you missed out in a way, but not too much =)~~~~~

                -=Till next time=-
***Glitterpower*** and Mad Fuzzies,
                    LaUrEa!

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

At 3:35 PM -0700 6/16/97, Chris wrote:

>        But seriously, I more like the idea which I see from time to time at
>parties, the DJ lineup schedule with times posted outside the rooms. Maybe
>even a sign near the entrance to a room with "Now Spinning : " on it so we
>could just post who is currently spinning. But that's a little weird, I
>think I like the schedule instead, even though it's usually off because of
>delays.

this is an idea, although imo it works best at outdoor events for some
strange reason....

a few other ideas are for djs to bring a few things to place in front of
the decks as a sort of transient make.shift altar....which of course
contains therein something including their name.  i have seen this done
before and i think it is a really neat way to not only know who is spinning
but _get to know_ who is spinning as well...beyond their music, that is.

another idea is something neat that a friend did for me.  she was madly
bored at the record store she worked at one day and made me a truly
discoflymama nametag to wear out of a bunch of promo stickers (about the
only cool thing about u2's new album were the holographic stickers they
produced to promote it -- perfect for cutting up and putting to good
use)...  anyhoo,i took it to kinko's, paid about a buck fitty to have it
laminated nicely, punched a few holes in it, took a safety pin off of an
item of old garb, and whoOomp!  i am identifiable if i only could remember
to put it on....*hic*

thought this might inspire some of you....maybe next time you are at a
party and are really enomored of an unknown dj, when you find out you could
go home and make them a pimpin' tag yo.  not only would you be spreading
some of that moOoshy loOove, but you'd also make it easier for the next
person in your position to id the dj....ooooh, and then djs could have a
nametag contest ;>  "hey man, i scored 13 tags last night.  how many did
*you* get?"  okay, maybe not.

nanu nanu.
lola

In a message dated 06-17-97 10:04:10 PM, stuff@hooked.net (Mr nStuff@work)
wrote:

>Here is the big MC-303 question. Because I HAVE looked into it. But. I
>could not seem to filter through all the "Pre-Fabs" to get to any possition
>to..Make something from scratch..
> Can I make "phat beats" from the ground up? Or do you just select loops
>and add to them? Can I make patterns of my own? Can I "erase" all the
>preset to get them out of my way? 
> You know what I mean?

Yes, No, Yes, No, Yes... though i wish you could! ;)

> I can some what see why people call it impractical. You know. It seems
>kinna toyish. Because of the fact that. It's all in there. You know? I am
>looking for a drum machine that can pump out alot of great sounds.  I am
>not asking for an "all in one" karoke machine. Just some professional drum
>machines. 

the mc-303 is a good intro synth at an affordable price, you can learn
a lot about sequencing and some stuff about lfos, adsr, effects processors,
etc...
because of this, it may seem like a toy to some, and it has some "karaoke"
mchine
like qualities, but it also has some really cool "professional" sounds, at an

affordable price, the really cool thing is that, not only does it have the
drum parts,
or the bass parts, it's got some cool "lead" sounds too.

>
> But. If you Niels. Proud owner of the dreamy JP-8000 say it's a good tool.
>Then. I might just buy one. No matter what main stream thinks.
>
> So. You really think it's a great sounding "DRUM-MACHINE" worth my money?
> I can't make compleat songs without DRUMS! =]:..
> So it's a good drum machine then? For "professional" use...

can be, any synth is what you make it!  some of the coolest sounds i've ever
heard came out of an old reel to reel! or a transistor radio with some wires
crossed! the sound is what YOU make it... the machines are only tools, and
you
can tunnel out of jail with wooden spoon if you have to, know what i mean?

mad luv
dc

South Bay lunch IS San Jose central.  We generally stay to the San
Jose area.  Look for a BSP soon in your future.  We'd love to have you.
We've decided since Jay got back and it was a good time to start having
them again.  They are every Tuesday (that might change if Branka keeps
using it as an excuse not to show though).  They tend to be right at 12
noon till 1:00 or so.

Also, if others are inspired to start their own regional rave list
lunches, that's cool but could you please put the region in the header
(bad Matt, bad Matt... think just because it's actually in SF you could
skip the locale eh?).

Finally, credit where credit is due, but these were derivative of the
Monday night dinner idea, so just some credit where credit is due.

AndyW

p.s. Don't forget to visit City Espresso in Santa Clara tonight to support
some local SJ morons... er... talent spinning some mellower records
tonight.

Date: 06.18.1997 10:22 AM
From: Byron Flores
HOPEFULLY THIS WILL HELP YOUR EVERYDAY LIVING, THINK ABOUT IT!!!!!!

BYRON 

"I don't know the key to success, but the key to failure is trying to
please everybody"                   -Bill Cosby

ATTITUDE IS EVERYTHING
By Francie Baltazar-Schwartz

Jerry was the kind of guy you love to hate.  He was always in a good
mood and always had something positive to say.  When someone would ask
him how he was doing, he would reply, "If I were any better, I would be
twins!"

He was a unique manager because he had several waiters who had  followed
him around from restaurant  to restaurant. The reason the waiters
followed Jerry was because of his attitude. He was a natural  motivator.
If an employee was having a bad day, Jerry was there telling the
employee how to look on the positive side of the situation.

Seeing this style really made me curious, so one day I went up to Jerry
and asked him, "I don't get it! You can't be a positive person all of
the time. How do you do it?" Jerry replied, "Each morning I wake up and
say to myself, Jerry,  you have two choices  today.  You can choose to
be in a good mood or you can choose to be in a bad mood.

I choose to be in a good mood. Each time something bad happens, I can
choose to be a victim or I can choose to  learn from it. I choose to
learn from it. Every  time someone comes to me complaining, I can choose
to accept their complaining  or I can point out the positive side of
life. I choose the positive side of life."

"Yeah, right, it's not that easy," I protested.

"Yes it is," Jerry said. "Life is all about choices. When you cut away
all the junk, every situation is a choice.  You choose how you react to
situations. You choose how people will affect your mood. You choose to
be in a good mood or bad mood. The bottom line:  It's your choice how
you live life."

I reflected on what Jerry said.  Soon thereafter, I left the restaurant
industry to start my own business. We lost touch, but often  thought
about him when I made a choice about life instead of reacting to it.
Several years later, I heard that Jerry did something you are never
supposed to do in a restaurant business:  he left the back door open one
morning and was held up at gunpoint by three armed robbers. While trying
to open the safe, his hand, shaking from  nervousness, slipped off the
combination. The robbers panicked and shot him.

Luckily, Jerry was found relatively quickly and rushed to the local
trauma center. After 18 hours of surgery and weeks of intensive care,
Jerry was released from the hospital with fragments of the bullets still
in his body. I saw Jerry about six months after the accident. When I
asked him how he was, he replied, "If I were any better, I'd be twins.
Wanna see my scars?"

I declined to see his wounds, but did ask him what had gone through his
mind as the robbery took place. "The first thing that went through my
mind was that I should have locked the back door," Jerry replied. "Then,
as I lay on the floor, I remembered that I had two choices:  I could
choose to live, or I could choose to die. I chose to live.

"Weren't you scared?  Did you lose consciousness?" I asked.

Jerry continued,  "The paramedics were great.  They kept telling me I
was going to be  fine. But when they wheeled me  into the emergency room
and I saw the expressions on the faces of the doctors and nurses, I got
really scared. In their eyes, I read, 'He's a dead man. " I knew I
needed to take action."

"What did you do?" I asked.

"Well, there was a big, burly nurse shouting questions at me," said
Jerry. "She asked if I was allergic to anything. 'Yes,' I replied. The
doctors and nurses stopped working as they waited for my reply...  I
took a deep breath and yelled, 'Bullets!'   Over their laughter, I told
them, 'I am choosing to live.  Operate on me as if I am alive, not
dead."

Jerry lived thanks to the skill of his doctors, but also because of his
amazing attitude. I learned from him that every day we have the  choice
to live fully.  Attitude, after all, is everything.

You have 2 choices now:

   1. save or delete this mail from your mail box.
   2. forward it to your dear ones and choose to pass this on

Hope, you will choose choice 2.

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>

Subject: Random RR or SFRR Rambling and Recognitions
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I haven't posted in a while, and I feel the need to use up some 
bandwidth.  But I couldn't come up w/ any warm fuzzy poems, so . . . :-)  No, 
really, this is just some stuff I really wanted to say:

1.  Hey, it looks like the flame content has gone down on the list!  Props to 
everyone for keeping it cool.  Yeah, I know there's a lil tiff about that 
whole 303 thing, but it's not getting out of hand.  And the whole jungle vs. 
house thing didn't get as volatile as I thought it was going to get.  But I 
guess everything looks calm after that pre-moderation explosion after FGE . . 
. eek!

2.  Speaking of house, I don't know why it gets such a bad rap.  Yeah, so some 
of it is commercial.  And preppy suburbanites go to clubs that play house.  So 
what?  Take an example from hip hop.  All kinds people listen to Wu-Tang Clan, 
righ righ?  Hell, they used to play it at my school dances--played it at 
Junior Prom, matter of fact ("Ice Cream"--is that song not the shit?).  But 
that doesn't exactly make them commercial and mainstream . . . anyone who 
knows about Wu-Tang knows they're nowhere near that.  So why does house get no 
respect?  And you can't judge the whole genre of house by a few crappy 
mainstream artists (I don't think I have to name any, u know which type I'm 
talking about).  I don't see anyone judging rap music by MC Hammer, Warren G, 
and Freak Nasty . . . ugh

Is everyone going to start disrespecting breakbeat?  Just wondering, since 
it's becoming popular and all.  That'll be too bad, cuz I like breakbeat too.

Anyways, most types of techno/electronica or whatever you want to call it was 
at least influenced (if not given birth to) by house.  Or so it appears.  I 
could be wrong.  Lemme know if I am.

Just because a type of music may seem a little more UG doesn't mean it's 
superior to those that are becoming more mainstream.

3.  I always do this, but I just want to give another shout out to all the 
Sacramento and other non-Bay Area ravers on the list, trying to help build up 
our own lil scenes . . . and props also to you Bay Area ravers for making your 
scene so phat.

4.  Props to Leslie for helping organize the Karma Patrol.  You go girl.

5.  Much love to all of yous who respond to my posts, thanks for taking out 
the time and effort--especially Mr. E, Macadio, Byroni, Gregory (aka DJ 
Lunatik), Matthew W., and Scott.  And to all those who flamed me, thanks for 
exposing me to another point of view, and it was appreciated (reluctantly ;-) 
).

6.  Thanx to all those I've never spoken w/ but make the list great to 
read--specifically Mr Jeff nStuff, Foolish Fish, Leslie Ayres, Alik (aka 
Earthlyn), John S. Lee, Veann, Anissa, Christine the Candygirl, Stariana, 
Pablo, and I'm sure I forgot someone, or misspelled something, or whatever, 
but you know what I mean . . . 

7.  Oh, and see you all at Wonderland, yes?  Will I FINALLY get to met you 
folks?  Hey, can I still buy presales the day of the event?  That's the only 
day I'll be in that area . . .

sfravers and house music are the bomb!  don't let anyone tell you different! 
:-)
xoxo--Miccaela
wondering if this might be a warm fuzzy after all . . . oops >;-)

At 11:06 AM -0700 6/18/97, PabloPop wrote:

>F8
>PROS:						CONS:
>* Mars and MystrE!!!!!!!!!!!			* Cold, muddy, dirty.
>* Beautiful Outdoors, trees, nature, etc.	* 4 hours away from SF
>* Lots of cool ravers				* 2 days long...
>* fun						* $20 bucks! :(

I would move cons - 2 days long - top pros :).  What's wrong with having it
more than 1 night.  That's when things get better :).

As for the location, I was there at Tribal Future and I don't remember it
being cold, or muddy (unless you went to mud baths).  I hope it doesn't
rain, because that could turn it into a mud place.

I can't wait to go :).  When I heard where it was going to be it made me
even happier - that space *rocks*.  And is there anything better than a
great DJ line-up, in beautiful place, under the stars?  I don't think so....

There are so many places I would love to be this weekend, but this was my
first choice...

I hope all of you have fun, wherever you go - the weekend will be great.

If you are at F-8 come by and say HI. :)....   Just look for a girl with
long, brown hair, glow-sticks :)....

=) Branka

At 04:56 PM 6/16/97 -0700, you wrote:
>I did however see some sony tables that had many of the same features of 
>the technics and they were 400 dollars less. Could someone explain to me  
>( in technical terms please, I will understand you,) what I'm paying for 
>if I spend 400 dollars more? And if there are other alternatives, where 
>do i go to check them out?...

Well, I dunno about the sony tables, but gemini (yea, I know...) has just
come out with their version of the 1200, looks almost identical, and felt
almost identical. I didn't get a chance to play on them, but the platter
felt similar to a 1200, similar pitch control (which goes +/- 10%, instead
of 8%).. and they're about $150-$200 cheaper... I don't know where you could
check them out, I saw them here in Florida... I think they're definatly
worth checking out tho, considering the price difference.

dave

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 18 Jun 1997 14:58:05 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID: <19970618215632.6272.rocketmail@send2.rocketmail.com>
Received: from [148.147.1.15] by web1; Wed, 18 Jun 1997 14:56:32 PDT
Date: Wed, 18 Jun 1997 14:56:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: "oOo i'm getting plushy" <chloebaby@rocketmail.com>
Subject: why i'm a raver not a clubber
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

all my bestest friends came back from college out of state (yay!)
and...  they all want to go to city nights.

oh ick. now i remember why i stopped going to clubs and started going
to ugparties instead. 

*everyone dances the way they want to and feels comfortable doing it
without tons of *cool* people staring down at them going "ha! look at
the dork!" 

*it's not a meat market where all the guys stand against the wall
while girls in push up bras strut pass them. "hey bay-bee, yoo so fly!"

*you make soooo many new friends rather than just some guy who wants
your number and turns out to be some gad awful player who thinks he's
"the bomb"

*rather than being greeted by a nod (you know, that thing that those
guys do to acknowlege your existence... when they tilt up their head
fer like a second) you get big sqoOoshy hugs 

*everyone seems to know everyone or even if they didn't you still get
a big sqOOOoooOoshy hug :)

*no bad vibes. no fronts. no i'm so cool, i'm too cool to talk to you
so i'll just stand here with my hands in my pockets and stare at that
hoochie momma over there.

*better music (okay so i'm biased. i don't like high energy music with
high pitched whiny voices... my bad)

*no alcohol sold. no high testosterone high alcohol leveled guys
starting fights.

*i hate that circle (i'll say it once again:) when two people are in
the center dancing and everyone else seems to crowd around them and
just watch.  ooo big pet peeve :P

did i mention i loved you guys? did i mention i'd rather spend my
saturday nights laughing and talking and giggling and smiling and
dancing and chain smoking and gulping down gallons of water with all
you beautiful people rather than go to city nights?
well i do
<hugs>

(:>veann<:)

Dave Arias writes:
+ Well, I dunno about the sony tables, but gemini (yea, I know...) has just
+ come out with their version of the 1200, looks almost identical, and felt
+ almost identical. I didn't get a chance to play on them, but the platter
+ felt similar to a 1200, similar pitch control (which goes +/- 10%, instead
+ of 8%).. and they're about $150-$200 cheaper... I don't know where you
could
+ check them out, I saw them here in Florida... I think they're definatly
+ worth checking out tho, considering the price difference.
+ dave

> guys do to acknowlege your existence... when they tilt up their head

Quoth Dave Arias
>Well, I dunno about the sony tables, but gemini (yea, I know...) has just
>come out with their version of the 1200, looks almost identical, and felt
>almost identical. I didn't get a chance to play on them, but the platter
>felt similar to a 1200, similar pitch control (which goes +/- 10%, instead
>of 8%).. and they're about $150-$200 cheaper... I don't know where you could
>check them out, I saw them here in Florida... I think they're definatly
>worth checking out tho, considering the price difference.

I checked out the new Geminis at Guitar Centre, and had a completly
different reaction. The platter was obviously much lighter than a 1200s.
Pretty much everything was cheap and flimsy. And no quartz lock unless the
pitch control is at zero. Pure shite, if you ask me. Check my article in
this months XLR8R for thre whole story.


lrich

To: Michael Standish <standish@netwiz.net>
cc: Suppa Freaky Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Another newbie equipment question :)
In-Reply-To: <v03020902afce7862e5ad@[208.136.104.2]>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970619085112.25251C-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't know if these end up to be more or less than 1200's, but I played
on a pair of Vestax decks a while back (don't remember the model) and they
were pretty damn cool.  They didn't feel AS solid as a Technics, but they
did have one thing done better...

the pitch control went +/- 8 like a normal 1200 ( I think), but it didn't
have that 'zone' right around zero... it went straight through so you
could beatmatch right around the zero mark.  If you wanted quartz locked
perfect pitch, you press a button for it.

I just though that was cool, but I'm glad I have 1200's (Vestax also makes
a model with a reverse mode for playing records backwards... I want to
check that out someday).

I wouldn't recommend those Gemini's at all.  The platter is too light,
they're not well made, and when I tried them in the store they seemed so
hokey.  If you are going to buy them, buy them at Guitar Center or another
place that has a thirty day money back, and keep the box.  I just don't
think they are even in the same category.  If you're getting 1200's, I'd
recommend a mom and pop store, even if it is a few bucks more because the
mom and pop store is dying to the GoodGuys/Fry's/Guitar Center monoliths
and that sucks.

Get real decks, real slipmats (thank you Noah and Alex for getting me wise
to this) and a cheap mixer if you're low on money. You can always go back
and get a better mixer, but spending money on cheap decks is like flushing
it.  If you buy good used 1200's, you can always sell them for what you
paid for them.  I'm sure a reasonably priced 1200 wouldn't take to long to
sell on this list...

AndyW

Subject: The CLUB/RAVE love-hate thread...(a bit long I guess)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey allzs, I'm not trying to start a flame war or anything,
I just wanted to let both sides come before you alls...

I've noticed that people have been putting down clubbies on the list.
I think that is very UNPLur :( mainly because *I go to clubs* every
week in fact. its not fair! cause I Am also a *raver*. I LOVE parties
sooo much! but I like clubs as well.

its all about our differences. and we all must learn to accept them.
some of us might not like the club-scene and stuff but it isn't fair to
say that the club scene suxs and that everyone in it is rude,
inconsiderate and stupid and that ravers are cooler and better. thats
not
the raver attitude I go to parties for :(

life isn't only about RAVES and PARTIES. life isn't only about positive
and good emotions. there is also the other side that we must not ignore.
ignoring things doesn't make them go away... it lets them pile up
'till they get worst...the more we ignore, the more negative it seems.

that is why I go to clubs :) to spread the good vibe the place needs!
so thats why I think, RAVES aren't just parties, they are places where
we *learn* about the good things in life and we must take that knowledge
and spread it and share it with the rest of the world :)

Just my .02 cents and a quarter :)
C-yas
PabloCLubKIdraver

I was looking through a semi-recent issue of the brilliant UK mag
"MixMag", when I stumbled upon an article about Lil' Louis and his
experiences in the UK. The article started off with...

"Do you ever wonder what all these American DJs must think of us
all? Back in the States clubbing is a little different. Oh sure,
they're into their music, appreciate a good DJ and have a good
dance but that's about it. Over there they don't have blokes
jumping around the dancefloor dressed as road workers, they don't
have fellow DJs who collapse mid set because they're too out of
it to play and they definitely don't get girls walking around in
fluffy bras. Which is their loss I think you'll agree."

Are we missing out or not? I don't know. Personally, I don't really
like the club scene, no matter where in the world it is. But hey,
a snatchy girl in a fluffy bra would be nice. JUST KIDDING!!!

*spacelove*
jonas THE SWEDISH BOY

Got a question for all the beautiful people out there.

I am thinking of throwing a party once every other Saturday during the afternoon for free in my loft space. I figure I could hold up to 100 people with out much of a problem. The way I want to do it is by RSVP. 

You basically send me Private E-Mail with a request to attend and I will post you back with the address and directions. I figure the party would go from 12 to 6.  
We will be doing something very interesting things at this.

#1 -> Live mixing over the Internet, I will give the address out just as soon as we have this up and fully tested.
#2 -> Let New DJ's get a shot. ( Send me your name and you got the chance )
#3 -> 2 Regular Bomb DJ's the Area has never seen before, just sit back and listen.
#4 -> Free Drinks and Munchies
#5 -> Surprise DJ's ( Local Hero's or Villains depending on your Taste )

This is called the House PET Project, please write me back with your comments, the First one I am thinking of doing is in 2 weeks from this Saturday. We are always looking for volunteer to help out as well. This is back to the true nature of the Rave, No big Lights with Productions, just a bunch of People gathering in the HOUSE PARTY SETTING! As JACK say, IN MY HOUSE!

Pete

Subject: new jungle reviews
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sorry if you've received this already. New this week in the US:

Audio Cotour #2

One sided limited edition blue vinyl AND it's good? Yup. Nice piece from
the moving shadow offshoot. Smooth layering gives this one a trancy
almost old-school feel. Supposedly limited to 750, buy this beautiful
track if you see it.

DJ Kane- Film Score rmx- 24 Karat

Great stuff from newschooler (relatively) dj kane- and better than his
last offering on TOV. Great stacatto intro gives way to a dark-tinged
bouncy affair. Top-notch. The original mix on the flip is just as good,
but very different. Atmospheric strings float on most of the track and
there's this cool noir-ish trumpet sample (boo radleys maybe?) which
really throws you off. Yes Yes.

Majistrate- Diagnostics- Splash Promo

Maj delivers exactly what we've come to expect over the past year: solid
rollers. A-side uses that female 'spacecraft check-list' sample that
everybody and their mother has fiddled with, but Maj pitches it down and
makes it subtle. Great utility piece. Flip side is the VIP mix of Hold
it Now and it easliy the best version of the 3 released. One for the
blunted massive. 

-peace-

SCiEnCe

>Well, I dunno about the sony tables, but gemini (yea, I know...) has just
>come out with their version of the 1200, looks almost identical, and felt
>almost identical. I didn't get a chance to play on them, but the platter
>felt similar to a 1200, similar pitch control (which goes +/- 10%, instead
>of 8%).. and they're about $150-$200 cheaper... I don't know where you could
>check them out, I saw them here in Florida... I think they're definatly
>worth checking out tho, considering the price difference.

        The new Gemini tables, the ones that look like the 1200's, are
really crappy. The tone arm is the biggest joke. It has pieces of plastic on
it painted to look like metal to make it seem like it has all the
adjustments and stuff that the technics tone arm has. However, by fiddling
with it you can tell it's not mounted anywhere near as solid as the 1200s.
Plus, it only has quartz pitch locking at 0%. Which means if you had the
pitch slide at maybe +3%, and you were in the middle of beatmatching, if the
line voltage changes any(which is very common)it will throw it off. So that
would make it exceptionally hard to beatmatch. I'd recommend sticking with
1200s if at all possible.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 19 14:21:16 1997

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id OAA13626

	id OAA10767; Thu, 19 Jun 1997 14:20:43 -0700
