To: "Mr nStuff@work" <stuff@hooked.net>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Musical Question 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Tue, 17 Jun 97 11:19:46 PDT."
             <199706171819.LAA24046@mom.hooked.net> 
Date: Thu, 19 Jun 97 14:20:39 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> So. The MC-303. I am not much of a follower. So. If you say it's good. I
> will look into it.
> I know what you mean though. So thats it? It's just getting shallow
> reviews?

It's getting mixed reviews, just like anything. Basically, a review
that's entirely negative probably means the author missed the point,
and a review that is entirely positive probably means the author got
paid off. I think my review of the mc-303 is fair.  I've also attached 
a somewhat negatively biased review of the 303 that I still consider
"somewhat fair"... it's unfair in the sense that it makes comparisons
to the 303, 808, 909 boxes which aren't available any more, and are
not supported, and are generally overpriced given that they were
mc-303 like "toys" back when they released. Buy one of these and it breaks,
and there's a good chance you'll have to throw it in the trash and buy
another one. Meanwhile the mc-303 is guaranteed, and if you break it
after warranty. you can still send it back to roland for service. 

having ongoing support is also nice. i'm having the new 1.03 ROM sent
to me for free by my retailer (www.sweetwater.com) because roland has
released an upgrade since I bought my box.

>  Here is the big MC-303 question. Because I HAVE looked into it. But. I
> could not seem to filter through all the "Pre-Fabs" to get to any possition
> to..Make something from scratch..

That's what the record button is for. You can record in real time, or
record in step time, or step through the note events and
alter/add/delete params directly.

The interface is pretty funky and kinda modal, so you probably need to
at least skim the manual, or play around. It all seems to make sense to
me now, because there's a lot of conceptually-related buttons serving
double and triple purpose.  I'm kinda "telepathic" when it comes to
figuring out funky UI's and electronic gizmos, so I actually figured
out a lot of things by myself first, then I read the manual and found
out some useful shortcuts.

>  Can I make "phat beats" from the ground up? Or do you just select loops
> and add to them?

You can make beats. "phat" is up to you. Use the record and playback buttons.
you can also create realtime patterns and assign them to buttons to play
back from the keyboard directly. (Just like the jp8000).

you can then take your loops and sequence them together into a song. or
you can copy bits and pieces of presets, add your own stuff, and make
into song. or you can take existing presets, subtract lots of parts, and
make them into your song. it's very flexible.

> Can I make patterns of my own?

Yes. You have 50 slots for your own patterns containing up to 8 traks each.
You have another 50-100 slots to record variations of your patterns
(same sequence and realtime-controls, but ability to mute 1 or more parts,
change effects, change tones, etc). After twiddling all non-sequencer
based things on one of your patterns, you can use "Vari Write" to save
your settings. this is good for taking a track and adding/subbing/changing
different layers.

> Can I "erase" all the preset to get them out of my way? 

No. But when you  get rid of all the "variation patterns" on the presets
and replace with your own. and you have U1-U50 for storing your own patterns.

That may not be enough if you have no other MIDI equipment, but I can
always do a MIDI SysEx dump of the contents of my mc-303 into my
computer. Good luck trying to do this with a tb-303.

>  You know what I mean?

Sometimes. :-)

> I can some what see why people call it impractical. You know. It seems
> kinna toyish. 

If you think it's impractical you should check out the tb-303. that thing
is truly a toy, and it's got an even more obtuse UI. and no midi whatsoever
so your SOL for doing any kind of reasonable backups. and good luck trying
to take a loop you put together and dump it to your computer's sequencer.

No MIDI pretty much defines "toy" in my mind.

> Because of the fact that. It's all in there. You know? I am
> looking for a drum machine that can pump out alot of great sounds.  I am
> not asking for an "all in one" karoke machine. Just some professional drum
> machines. 

There's lots of drum machines out there. Roland/Boss, Alesis, Yamaha,
Roland, Emu, etc.

Or just get a sampler and some drum samples and hook it up to your
computer for sequencing. Sometimes, it's nice to have an all-in-one
box. For example, I got to make an otherwise unbearable 35-40 hour trip
back from india somewhat bearable by writing some choons and playing
around with this box. (You can tell some of the reviewers have their
heads up their asses cuz they start whining about how the mc-303 can't
have battery power -- all you need to do, is go down to Fry's or Radio
Shack, get a 6-DCell battery holder, solder on a coax-power jack (the
polarity is printed on the outside of the box) and you've got yourself
a portable groove machine that'll run for at least 20 hours
continuously on batteries, even w/ the volume cranked up).

>  But. If you Niels. Proud owner of the dreamy JP-8000 say it's a good tool.
> Then. I might just buy one. No matter what main stream thinks.

Fuck the main stream. And "the main stream" depends on where you look.
The whiny wankers that diss the mc-303 have attitude and outdated
equipment. There's also people out there that like this machine, or at
least accept it as a useful, though slightly limited box. Like I said,
it is what it is, does what it does. That's good enough for me, and if
it's not good enough for you (that's you mr "cathode" -- even though
probably don't even know what a cathode is, nor its etymology) then
don't run around dissing people that don't have your treasured
303-cock-throbber and acting all superior like you're of the
one-true-faith ...) then that's your problem not mine.

> So. You really think it's a great sounding "DRUM-MACHINE" worth my money?
>  I can't make compleat songs without DRUMS! =]:..
> So it's a good drum machine then? For "professional" use...

If you want drums for professional use, buy a sampler. and a computer
and software and a midi interface, and some effects boxes, and some 
cd-rom collections of samples. it'll certainly put you out more than
$500.00, and it'll be giving you headaches half the time, and you'll
totally lose inspiration of making a cool sound because you'll be
tracking down some weird midi glitch, or tinkering with some random
sampler parameter that is making your sound get all fucked up....  and
you won't be able to carry it to the john and write beats while you're
on the throne.

The 303, 808, 909 weren't for professional use either, and neither is
the casio cz-101. however, plenty of your favorite sounds have been
made with toys.

It's like this-- a boombox is no substitute for a stereo w/ separate
tuner, preamp, amp, lp-player, cd-player, and cassette. nonetheless i
have both because they both have their uses. and the $200.00 boombox
might be a better way to get into music than going out and laying out
$5000.00 on "professional" stereo gear.


	Niels Mayer
	Deus SysEx Machina

--------------------

oh, here's that review, which I don't exactly fully agree with, but  at
least he is going into it in more objective detail than the usual
303-wanker's "duuuuh, it sucks"... also, it would seem that this person
isn't reviewing the box I have w/ the almost-latest ROM v 1.02 or the
latest v 1.03...

--------------------

ROLAND MC-303 REVIEW - BY DARWIN GROSSE

{Note: This is sent to analogue heaven, given the discussion about its
merits vs. the TR/TB series.  Feel free to forward to any non-commercial
list/site if you think it is of any worth.}

Roland MC-303 Review
by Darwin Grosse


INTRODUCTION

I have been, and I'm sure you've been, disappointed with the current spate
of reviews of the new Roland MC-303 'Groovebox'.  It is just too difficult
to make a buying decision based on one large picture, and eight paragraphs
about its cool sound.  I received an MC-303 a few weeks ago, and have spent
a significant amount of time working with it.  I've used it for recording,
live performance and as a MIDI driver for other boxes.  This is the most
detailed and extensive review I've seen anywhere, and I hope you find it
useful.

For what it's worth, I've got very little invested in the MC-303.  I got it
as part of a barter deal, so I have very little money invested in it.  I
also don't see making a lot of money with it, so I have little economic
interest either.  I say this because of some other synths that I've
talked-about/defended in the past (like that VAST machine so many of you
love...).

If you haven't seen one, the MC-303 is an attempt by Roland to capitalize
on the current excitement for old Roland 'x0x' boxes.  This 303 is a
multitimbral synth, with built in sequencer (with both real-time and
step-time programming modes), arpeggiator and effects processor.  It also
has a few 'special' features, such as real-time filter control and the RPS
- a real-time phrase playback mechanism.

I will format this review in the same way that I learned the machine - by
comparing various features against other devices I've used.  This review
will also be somewhat time-locked, since Roland is expected to update the
operating system as bugs are found and fixed.  The scope of this instrument
is pretty wide, and therefore difficult to review in detail.  I hope that
you will forgive the length of the review in exchange for some measure of
completeness.  Also, since they are irrelevant to me,  I'll spend zero time
reviewing the internal patterns and sequences -- if you want to hear them,
check them out at a local music shop.

Roland MC-303, Groovebox, TR-909, TB-303 and others are either trademarks
of Roland, or their lawyers ought to get off their asses and get something
done.  Woody McBride's and Richie Hawtin's names are used without
permission -- sorry for the inconvenience, guys.  2Unlimited's name is
simply used without permission.  If I've angered anyone else, sue me -- you
can have my car payments!  This document is copyright 1997 by Darwin
Grosse.  All rights are reserved, as if anyone wanted them...


MC-303 AS DRUM MACHINE (the 909 factor)

Upon receiving the MC-303, I immediately dove into the drum programming.  I
really appreciated the TR-909's drum pattern programming system, and have
recently been using some computer models (Logic Environments and MAX
programs) to simulate this functionality.  I was very curious as to the
effectiveness of the MC-303 for this type of percussion programming.

Like the 909, the MC-303 features a number of buttons with embedded LED's.
These lights are used for two purposes - to show the currently playing
beat, and to show drum hits that have been programmed in step-time.  On the
MC-303, the step-time programming paradigm is kept pretty intact.  You
select a drum instrument and hit the keys representing the step where it
should sound.  Given that the MC-303 is a digital, sample-based system, you
have access to many more sounds than the TR-909 makes available - 108 sound
are available on the rhythm programming channel.

108 sounds are a bonanza, but there is a very dark secret here - and one
that I will often repeat.  The sounds, and their layout on the virtual
keyboard, are not editable without some fancy-pants computer editor.  Even
then, a number of parameters simply cannot be permanently changed.  No way
to replace that over-used laughter sample (MIDI note #101 on all of the
internal rhythm sets) to something more useful.  No way to tune the kick to
the rest of the song.  No way to down-sample the snare into a
death-marching-drum.  A large issue for anyone looking to use the MC-303
for extensive recording!

The sounds of the supplied kits are good, if somewhat dated.  The 909 and
CR-78 sounds (especially with the additional sounds at the lower end of the
key range) are very useful, and the Jungle kit makes the whole thing sound,
well, correct.

Accenting on the MC-303 is very different from the TR-909's system.  With
the 909, you could accent (when available) a single beat by hitting that
button a second time.  There was also an accent 'instrument' which would
affect all instruments on a specific beat.  On the MC-303, there is no
equivalent of the accent 'instrument'.  However, for individual beats,
there are four velocity levels available.  By selecting the appropriate
accent level, it's easy to create a snare roll with a groove, or punch up a
hi-hat pattern.  However, the lack of overall accent makes "back-beat push"
a more tedious process.

The step -time programmer suffers from a significant load-time issue.  The
TR-909 had, for lack of a better term, an 'on-the-fly' character.  When I
used the 909, I generally stayed in WRITE mode, and made adjustments to a
pattern close to real-time.  I'd groove along with a pattern, then quickly
add or remove drum hits as I chose.  The MC-303 seems to use a different
process.  Each time the MC-303 is about to begin playing a measure, it
appears to 'snapshot' it into memory, and will then play back that 'image'
of that measure.  Hence, if I'm adding a snare roll to the end of a measure
while that measure is loaded into memory, only those drum hits that existed
at the time of the 'snapshot' will be played back.  This is much less
'organic' than the 909, and proves to be disturbing when trying to play the
303 as a real-time drum programming device.

Unfortunately, there are other reasons that will probably preclude me from
ever using the 303 as a real-time, write-mode device.  Basically, the rest
of the synthesizer is 'turned off' when you are doing step-time recording.
The means that you cannot change kits, adjust effects or filters or change
muting.  Since all of these options would be very necessary for write-mode
performance, the MC-303 loses major points as a live creativity tool.

On the other hand, as a straight rhythm programmer, the MC-303 has a number
of excellent extensions to the TR-909 interface.  A rhythm pattern can be
up to 32 measures in length.  These patterns can be in 2/4, 3/4 or 4/4
time, and can have up to a two measure count-in (for real-time entry).
There is also a real-time option that will wait for a note to be pressed to
start pattern entry.

The MC-303 also has a very nice muting system.  Rhythm programming is
available only on the 'Rhythm Part'.  However, when you use this 'Rhythm
Part', you have access to a second tier of mutes -- allowing you to
interactively mute/unmute any one of eight 'type' of sound (kicks, snares,
hats, claps, cymbals, toms/percussion, hits and 'other').  When using a
stored pattern during live performance, this muting function is great
modifying the rhythm dynamics.  The individual rhythm pattern mutes can be
stored with a pattern, or can be manipulated in real-time.  As with many
functions, if the mutes are done in real-time (i.e., if you are not
recording when you make the mutes), the mute changes will be lost when you
change patterns.

Real-time (non-step-entry) mode turns out to be very important for
programming rhythms on the MC-303.  First, during step-time programming,
you are unable to change mutes, effects levels, volume levels or filter
settings.  These can all be set (and recorded) when running in real-time
record mode.  In this way, a jungle-y filter sweep can be pre-programmed in
a pattern, giving you one less knob to turn at performance time.  During
the performance of a pattern, all of the stored settings can be overridden
by simply adjusting the appropriate function's controller.  Once you've
modified a function, the MC-303 turns over control to you, in essence
eliminating the internal stored function changes.  You maintain control of
that function until you change patterns.

So, how did I fare with the MC-303 as a rhythm programmer?  The load-time
issue really ticked me off initially.  It still does.  I was hoping that
the MC-303 could be a real-time creativity device in the same way that the
TR-909 was.  No such luck.  However, the good MIDI control (basically, grid
control of 108 MIDI notes), the four velocity levels and the real-time
adjustment are enjoyable, and I find myself writing pretty good percussion
tracks with the MC-303 as the controller.

Score:  5 1/2-out-of-10 Richie Hawtins  (minus 2 for the real-time
problems, minus two for lack of programmability, minus 1/2 for some static
digital sounds)


MC-303 AS A BASS SYNTHESIZER (the 303 factor)

Given the numbering scheme chosen for this box, the obvious question is
whether this can be used as a replacement for the ubiquitous Bassline.  The
short answer -- no.  And I'm not going to do the purest thing, OK?

As stated above, the MC-303 is strictly a digital sample-playback box.  In
order to make the 303 "acid-y", a real-time control of filter cutoff and
filter resonance was added.  Although these are welcome on any synth, it's
a bit too little in this case.  You are given a number of  TB samples to
manipulate, and pretty much have to do with those.  Your mileage may vary,
but I found the majority of them to simply be too tame.  The resonance does
not have a high degree of "squelch", there is only a single lowpass filter
option and the cutoff cannot be forced to key-follow.  Hence, a filter
setting appropriate for one set of notes may not be applicable for the
entire range of a pattern.  A quick scan of the MIDI implementation
verifies that there is neither a key-follow, nor any filter option other
than lowpass.  Again, there is little opportunity to modify the sound
chosen, although there are more options than with drum instruments.

The sequencer/programmer is excellent.  It is quite similar to the
TB-303/MC-202 style of programming, with entry of individual steps, rests
and ties, octave select buttons and the works.  As with the rhythm parts,
you can choose between four velocity settings for each note;  in addition,
there are four gate times available for each note (a la MC-202).  Very
flexible, and opens the door for some interesting programming.  Sadly, and
again like the rhythm programmer, you cannot enter real-time function
changes while in step time.  This really becomes crucial with TB-like acid
line containing slides and filter changes.

If you wish to enter slides, you can try it in real-time mode.  The slide
function is really a portamento (again, like the MC-202).  If you want to
program slides/portamento/filter-sweeps into your pattern, you simply
record the changes using the real-time recorder function.  While the
pattern plays, you can hit the portamento button or change the filter
setting, and the control movements will be recorded.  The only caveat --
there seems to be an operating system glitch that will mute notes that
appear too close to a portamento button it.  I believe that this is related
to the Portamento button's dual use -- when portamento is on for a channel,
that channel becomes a monophonic channel.  When it is switched off, the
channel is polyphonic.  This mode change may explain the glitches that
occurred when severely exercising the portamento button.  The solution is
to record the portamento changes at a _very_ slow tempo, giving plenty of
room around surrounding notes (if possible).  Filter changes, and other
real-time controls, do not seem to affect the sounding of notes.

The other problem I have with the pattern sequencer:  it's too difficult to
change information in a pattern.  Frankly, it has proven to be easier to
either live with a less-than-perfect pattern/track, or to completely
re-record it.  As a dedicated computer-sequencer user, you can bet I'm not
too happy about that.  Especially given the joyous big-chicklet keyboard on
the MC-303!

Pattern editing functions include:  Pattern and part copy (smallest unit -
one measure), pattern and part erase (again, smallest unit is one measure),
blank measure insert, key transpose (either the whole 'part' -- all notes
in one channel -- or a range of notes within a single 'part'), velocity
change (entire part - no changes for individual notes!) , gate time (again,
only the entire part), time shifting (entire part, again), data thinning
(no control over which functions get thinned -- all controllers for a part
are thinned!) and part quantize.  Grrrr.  This grew tiresome, and proved to
limit the complexity of part that I built into a pattern.

The other sequencing problem occurs with the MIDI implementation.  Simply
put, the MC-303 will not transmit anything beyond the MIDI note and
velocity information.  Why is this so important, you ask?  Well, here's my
situation.  I don't like the MC-303's internal TB-303 emulation.  I want to
use the Will System's MAB-303 I have.  The MAB uses the Portamento
controller to signal slides, and velocity changes to signal accents.  The
MC-303 will transmit the notes, and the velocity of each note.  That's
great.  However, the all-important slides (even when programmed into the
MC-303 as portamento controller changes) will not be transmitted!
Therefore, no slides on the MAB-303!  Since a number of 'boxes' are
appearing that will support MIDI controller messages (BassStation, MAB,
Pulse, etc.), the total lack of controller transmission means that the
MC-303 often cannot be used as a bass sequencer for live techno.
Troubling, since it would appear that is exactly what the MC-303 was
created for...

Finally, the output configuration comes into play here.  Two outputs for a
machine with drums, bass lines and pads is simply too few.  Even for live
performance.  Without the ability to manipulate the individual instruments
externally (with delays, filters or whatever), a lot of the flexibility
seems to be gone.

Score:  4 out of 10 Woody McBrides  (minus 2 for the sounds, minus four for
the sequencer limitations)


MC-303 AS A SEQUENCE PLAYBACK TOOL (the MMT-8 factor)

Given the above griping about the sequencer limitations, the lack of full
MIDI record and transmit, and the dichotomy between step-time and real-time
recording methods, you can bet I'm not expecting you to sell your MMT-8.
However, there are a few real positive things to say, here.

First, the mute functionality really excels.  Have the ability to mute
individual percussion sections (as stated in the DRUM PROGRAMMER section)
really puts the MC-303 a step above the MMT-8 for this type of programming.
Also, the inclusion of a serious quantize function really makes this thing
shine.  The quantize function allows you to 'dial in' the amount of
quantize to apply, and provides three types of quantize -- grid, shuffle or
'groove'.  As you might expect, used in moderation these quantize function
can spice up an otherwise sleepy track, and the templates available for the
groove quantize exceed those that are available in any of the software
sequencers I've been using.  Of course, there is no way to quantize one
track to another's contents, but that is a function that only recently has
been available in software tools.  In addition to 'dialing in' the amount
of timing effect, you can also 'dial in' the amount of velocity adjustment
that a groove quantize function will provide.

My only concern with the quantize functions has to do with the internal
timing of the MC-303.  The 303 is based on 96ppq timing, and it sometime
feels as though the quantize function 'steps' a bit too much.  My
assumption is that the granularity of the internal timing is adversely
affecting the smoothness of the quantize functionality.  I may be wrong,
and I've done no timing studies to verify this, but I can 'feel' the
quantize function jerk around the timing in an uncomfortable way.

The MC-303 includes an arpeggiator, and some of these functions are just
great.  The output of the arpeggiator can be recorded to the sequencer, and
can follow a number of internal templates.  Some of these templates are
excellent.  There are a number of arpeggiator templates that simulate
guitar picking and such.  However, I found that the "Sequence" options are
the best, especially if you make appropriate adjustments to the 'Accent
Rate' control.  If nothing else, these arpeggiators are incredible fun, and
could (perhaps) be used to spur some creative moments.

One final note on the sequencer functions.  There has been a lot of
discussion about the limited number of  user patterns (50), and the large
number of preset rhythms.  All true, but I've not run into many problems in
this area.  First, in addition to the 50 user patterns, you can enter 300
'Variation' patterns.  This is basically a pattern (either preset or user)
with alternate mute settings.  This may not seem that impressive, but it
provide incredible functionality when creating songs.  A song, on the
MC-303, is a string of patterns, each of which has one rhythm and seven
synth parts.  The way you end up programming a song is by creating patterns
that are 'chuck full' of tracks, then creating variations that mutes
combinations of tracks.  Using this paradigm, you can create 5 very full
patterns, then use mute variations to 'thin' the patterns into a song with
an appropriate structure.  All-in-all, this actually works fine for me...

In addition to the sequencer and arpeggiator, there is an additional
playback function -- the RPS, or Real-time Phrase Sequence.  The RPS system
allows you to assign parts (single tracks from a pattern) to a key, and
trigger that part at any time using the MC-303 keyboard.  Big fun!  The RPS
can use parts from either preset or user patterns, and this really broadens
what can happen during a live gig.  For example, last week I played a fun
little mini-gig.  I played MC-303, a friend played tape deck and noise
boxes, and some Goth Gal screaming somewhere along with us.  Like I said --
fun.  No rehearsals, no pressure.  I set up a real simple user pattern with
a bass part and a rhythm part.  I also set up a comprehensive set of RPS
keys to provide guitar wacka-wacka, breakbeats, synth turnarounds and other
fun stuff.  I had a blast, my friend thought it was a hoot, and (since I
was playing the works through someone's bass amp) no one got hurt.  This
really work similar to Studio Vision's MIDI Keys, and really can be used to
spice up a live set.  Well recommended!

One bug was found here -- if you do some odd combination of keystrokes (I
think that you have to select a new RPS set while the sequencer is running,
and is about to load another pattern, or something) the whole works
crashes.  It will either play some arbitrary pile of notes, or will simply
freeze.  When this happens (and, in the heat of the gig, it will),  keep
nodding your head, smile at your S.O., and reboot!  I expect this to be
fixed in the next rev...

Score:  7 out of 10 Orbitals  (minus four, again, for the poor MIDI record
and transmit, minus 1/2 for the perceived timebase problem, plus an
additional 1/2 for the variety of arpeggiations and grooves,  plus an
additional 1 for the way-cool RPS function.)


MC-303 AS TECHNO SYNTH (the legendary General Techno [tm] factor)

Well, it's a bunch of samples.  A pile of them are old-hat orchestral hits
that nobody outside of Ibiza would use.  Some of them are funky and nice.
A few of them transcend into the "gotta-use-'em" set.  The drums are
excellent sample sets.  However, tone modification is a bit of a bitch.
The following is a list of the modifications that you can make to the
sounds:

LEVEL
PAN (including RANDOM PAN)
PORTAMENTO ON/OFF and PORTAMENTO TIME
LFO RATE, SHAPE, AMOUNT and DESTINATION(PITCH, FILTER and AMP)
FILTER CUTOFF and RESONANCE
AMPLITUDE ENVELOPE ATTACK, DECAY and RELEASE
BEND RANGE

Does something seem to be missing?  Does A LOT seem to be missing?  Damn
right!  How about a high-pass filter?  How about an envelope for the
filter?  LFO delay?  Man, this is just depressing...  Perhaps I've not
gotten comfortable with SoundCanvas style synthesizer, but I doubt I will
ever get comfortable with exceedingly limited functionality.

Frankly, one thing that Roland, and other manufacturers making dance music
modules, must remember is the transient nature of the sound.  A sweeping
pad that is hot today will be anathema in three weeks.  No one significant
has user _that_ orchestra hit in five years.  My feeling is this -- over
the course of a few years, the MC-303 will be used as a driver for external
synthesizers, and the internal sounds (save for the drum kits) will seldom
be heard.

Given that, are there enough sounds to play with?  I guess.  The MC-303 has
become the box that I play with while I'm vegging in front of the
television.  Given that, I can find enough sounds to write with.  They get
replaced once I'm in the studio, but I can at least use them to get
started.

There is a special mode (called Sound Module Mode) in which the MC-303
becomes a 16-channel multitimbral sound module.  In this mode, the MC-303
responds to a number of MIDI controllers, and can generally be used to good
effect (given the limitations of the sample set and the single pair of
outputs).  Frankly, I tried this out, but will probably never use it in
this way...

Score:  4 out of 10 2Unlimiteds  (minus 3 for the dated sounds, minus 3 for
the limited programming options)


MC-303 AS ITSELF (the how-I-use-it factor)

So, you want to know how I've been using the beast, huh?  As I've said,
I've installed it as the watching-TV-productively tools of choice.  It
works fine for that.  I use it extensively as a drum programmer, and
occasionally for a step-time programmer that gets dumped to Logic Audio.
Some of the sounds are good enough that they get used in recorded tracks.
I took it to a live gig, and had fun with it (minus the crash...).  It
makes 14-year-olds I know very jealous.

Most of the net-news I've seen (including most of this one) is attempting
to compare the MC-303 to old Roland boxes, or even as the Great Hope (or
Satan) of  techno.  I've got a totally different read on this.  The MC-303
has replaced one synth in my life -- the Yamaha QY-20.  I've not had the
QY-20 for long, but I no longer use it, choosing to use the 303 instead.
It is reasonably portable (although not battery powered, yet), easy to
program in a variety of ways and pretty good sounding.  I generally use it
as a seed-bed, creating ideas which will eventually get moved to a more
serious sequencing or performance rig.

It's unfortunate that the MC-303 cannot be the be-all techno-box.  Perhaps
an MC-303 Pro should be made -- with more user patterns (i.e., no preset
patterns), complete MIDI handling by the sequencer, more editing and
synthesis functions, non-volatile sample memory and a higher timebase.  It
would probably cost $400 more to produce such a thing, but it would solve a
good number of my complaints with the MC-303 as it currently stands.

Worth the money?  I don't know.  Read the reviews, and read this little ol'
article.  If you think you can live with the limitation, you should
probably take one home.  Work with it for a few weeks, then decide.  If you
no longer want it, I'm sure there are a number of kiddies out there in
net-land just waiting to buy your used techno-box...

My own, personal score:  4 1/2 out of 10 Darwins.  Good enough to keep
around for a while, fun and occasionally useful, just not the majick I had
been hpoing for.

{And, in case you are wondering, I am in no way implicating that I exist in
the same stratosphere as Richie, Woody or even 2Unlimited...}

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==    Niels Mayer ..... mayer@netcom.com ..... http://www.eit.com/~mayer   ==

Well, after several days of vast adventuring (walked almost the entire
distance from cupertino stevens creek area to where it's not even called
stevens creek anymore... then walked el camino from sunnyvale to stanford
mall and back) I have finally procured a vehicle.

It is a 1985 Chrystler Fifth Avenue (read: boat).

PROS                     CONS
----                     ----
air conditioning         this thing is MASSIVE
plush phatty seats       pimpmobile - warez the fuzzy dice?
impact/death resistent   you wanna park?  bwhahaha
smooth ride              float feeling, like "sh*t i have no control"
didn't borrow money      $1300.23 w/tax+license

I would rather have an electric car, or cycle... or that darn second fiero
I kept trying to meet the owner to hook up (owner never there) (first fiero
was sold)

Hope it lasts for awhile until I can sell/trade/etc it!  Hope the police
find _my_ car!  (reminder: buy a club or similar anti-theft system, or plan
ahead for what you'll have to do if you lose your car)

peace,
Max

I think I may check out the XLR8R party tonight; on Friday, I would check
out Xanadu if I were in Sacramento ;).  The Ninja Tune show should be good
too, it's a different lineup than the one earlier this year.  Lotsa free
stuff and outdoor parties on this first official weekend of summer too.  
Check out Making Waves all around SF on Saturday, then there are several 
freebies on Sunday, including Sunset maybe.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

UG Friends...
I didn't write this post...but i was astounded as to how much i
shared his view so i hope u will read this w/an OPEN mind... peace :)

    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -    -

You know, I love this scene.  I love it.  When I see a flyer for an upcoming
party, I just cant wait for it to arrive..  The music; an unending vibe
unifying us all for a night, the people; a multi cultural rainbow of
children of the era of plur dancing and joining together in a great
celebration of music, and finally, The Drugs...  It never seems to fail.
Druged out, coked out, acid eating idiots not giving a damn about anything,
not even their own lives..  I've come accross too many people in my time
that have a severe problem, yet just dont give a shit about their lives.
They treat me good, and we bond, as friends do.  But what about the non stop
worrying that accompanies this "great friendship"??  I hate it..  The one
thing about the scene that really fucks with my head and my heart..  I cant
just turn my back on my friends, yet showing them that someone actually
cares about them doesnt seem to shed any light on their darkness.....  I
accept the fact I cannot change someone, but I will always show them that I
do give a damn..  I recently quit drugs and alcohol myself..  I was never a
real bad user, but I have had my bouts with problems that accompany their
presence.  Am I the only one that feels this way??  I mean, what has come
over me?  I actually have no urge to do the things that I once did, and the
thing that caused this was watching what it did to people.  Its all shit, no
matter how you look at it.  P.L.U.R.???  What does peace love unity and
respect mean if we cant co-exist witout the sedatives that we use??  Why?
Why the need?I finally looked at it for what it was:  In order for you to be
totally happy, and to be totally at peace with yourself and your suroundings
(the life goal), you must finally accept things and look at things for what
they are.  Be at peace with them.  Help people.  Love one another.  But, you
cannot do this when you are strung up, for you are not actually looking at
the world in its actual light.  You are using a sedative..  Take it in the
face, fight against the dying of the light.  Give a damn about one another.
I mean shit, things arent getting any better people if we all continue to
destroy ourselves and one another.  Look around you.  This is reality.
Accept it.  I give a damn.  I do.

                              This has been brought to your attention by,
                              Infants (Infantile, Infanz) a.k.a.
                                Brandon Dee on UNDERNET #RAVE
                              -PEACE-LOVE-UNITY-RESPECT-

--------------95E520F5070FB96B956F3B8C
Content-Type: text/html; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">do give a damn..&nbsp;
I recently quit drugs and alcohol myself..&nbsp; I was never a</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">real bad user,
but I have had my bouts with problems that accompany their</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">presence.&nbsp;
Am I the only one that feels this way??&nbsp; I mean, what has come</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">over me?&nbsp;
I actually have no urge to do the things that I once did, and the</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">thing that caused
this was watching what it did to people.&nbsp; Its all shit, no</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">matter how you
look at it.&nbsp; P.L.U.R.???&nbsp; What does peace love unity and</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">respect mean if
we cant co-exist witout the sedatives that we use??&nbsp; Why?</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">Why the need?I
finally looked at it for what it was:&nbsp; In order for you to be</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">totally happy,
and to be totally at peace with yourself and your suroundings</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">(the life goal),
you must finally accept things and look at things for what</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">they are.&nbsp;
Be at peace with them.&nbsp; Help people.&nbsp; Love one another.&nbsp;
But, you</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">cannot do this
when you are strung up, for you are not actually looking at</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">the world in its
actual light.&nbsp; You are using a sedative..&nbsp; Take it in the</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">face, fight against
the dying of the light.&nbsp; Give a damn about one another.</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">I mean shit, things
arent getting any better people if we all continue to</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">destroy ourselves
and one another.&nbsp; Look around you.&nbsp; This is reality.</FONT></FONT></B>
<BR><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">Accept it.&nbsp;
I give a damn.&nbsp; I do.</FONT></FONT></B><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600"></FONT></FONT></B>

<P><B><FONT FACE="Comic Sans MS"><FONT COLOR="#006600">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
This has been brought to your attention by,</FONT></FONT></B>

Infants (Infantile, Infanz) a.k.a.</FONT></FONT></B>

The original DJ-70 does have the scratch dial!!!  What the MKII added was 
: a new OS, a tap tempo feature, a global BPM matching feature and a SCSI 
interface.  The Roland techs told me that you can't wire the SCSI 
interface into the old DJ-70 (rat bastards!)
:)
I love my DJ-70!!!

Subject: RE: why i'm a raver not a clubber
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Lemme say this first:  I don't like clubs.  They tend to be a little 
meat-markety for my taste, and remind me too much of my school dances . . . 
but maybe I just haven't been to the right ones.  I'm underage, so my 
selection is a lil limited.  Maybe  I'm just bitter coz I can't get into most 
of them, eh?

But as far as club people being rude, well, some are, some aren't.  I've met 
some hella friendly and cool people at clubs, and I've met my share of people 
that I felt were a lil rude and shallow at raves (but maybe they were having a 
bad day, who knows).  And I'm talking about UG raves too, not massives.

Well, I guess people treat you a lil different when you're a black chick 
wearing a beanie. Hmmmm . . .

But anyway, I've been fortunate enough to meet enough beautiful people at 
parties and other places, so I always feel loved.  And I think most of you are 
probably just as fortunate . . .

So I guess I'm saying that no matter where you are, rave, club, or whateva, if 
you bring in good vibes, you'll get back good vibes, and you can block out the 
bad.  Oh, and I'll be wearing ponytails at Wonderland (saving the beanie for 
another fiesta, baby).

xoxo--Miccaela

"I dont think 'This is my party' is applicable anymore. The party's kind of
over. Now it's more like, 'This is my life,' 'This is my tribe.'"
                                                               - Nan Goldin

"That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the cheif danger of the time."
                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

I hafta admit all diva vocals ain't bad.  Like that song that goes
"A little bit of ecstacy . . . a little bit of you and me . . . a little bit 
will set ya free . . . a little bit of ecstacy . . ."

Hey!  I'm one of those girls in the club that you can tell don't go to clubs 
regularly cuz no one knows them and they just don't seem to fit in.  And we 
come w/ our friends and take up the dance floor because we make little circles 
that we take turns dancing in.  We act kinda goofy and sometimes form soul 
train lines and do the running man or the cabbage patch.  And we request "I'm 
Too Sexy" so we can do our lil diva/model walk, and "Vogue" so we can do our 
sloppy ass voguing.  I personally like to request "Hoochie Mama" or some other 
2 Live Crew song so I can bust out with my perfected infamous _ghetto ass 
booty dance_  . . . you know the one that the girls do in those low budget 
miami rap videos . . . pump pump pump get it get it shake shake shake a lil 
sumthin.  Can't do that kind of stuff at a rave, wouldn't want to anyway.

I prefer raves to clubs, but when I do go I get my money's worth.  Cuz I have 
too much fun.  Plus I know all the _real_ club kids have just as much fun 
talkin about me.  It works out for everyone.

xoxo--Miccaela

Subject: Quartz Lock on Gemini vs. Technics
In-Reply-To: <199706192038.NAA26590@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970620073806.4195E-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I wanted to recommend a correction or end up starting a really annoying 
thread, not sure which yet...

The XLR8R article and now this post both indicate that the new Gemini's
have a fault, that the quartz lock only works at zero and goes on to
indicate that this is not the case with the SL1200mkII.

The quartz lock only activates when the green light turns on on a 1200,
namely at 0.  So a Technics SL-1200mkII has the same "problem".

If the AC line level changes at any point while the turntable is playing
up or down at all from 0, there may be a slight (not audible, but
noticeable if you're dealing with two beatmatched records) difference in
speed.  This might be (I'm speculating here) why generator powered sound
systems tend to require more "babysitting" of beatmatched records (because
of the variations in power amp draw while working from load that reacts to
varying loads).

When you get your 1200's "calibrated" or "tuned" what they are doing is
adjusting the fader to have it's zero point right in the middle so it
matches with the switch for the quartz lock.

A Technics 1200 is only quartz locked when at +/-0 and the green light is
ON.

Source for the quartz lock thing (and a really helpful and informative
thingy anyway):
http://hyperreal.com:2000/0/music/djs/sl1200.html

thread, not sure which yet...

The XLR8R article and now this post both indicate that the new Gemini's
have a fault, that the quartz lock only works at zero and goes on to
indicate that this is not the case with the SL1200mkII.

The quartz lock only activates when the green light turns on on a 1200,

noticeable if you're dealing with two beatmatched records) difference in

systems tend to require more "babysitting" of beatmatched records (because
of the variations in power amp draw while working from load that reacts to
varying loads).

When you get your 1200's "calibrated" or "tuned" what they are doing is

I don't know..

 When I first started raving. I had a GREAT vibe inside. Enough good vibes
to make anyone that looked at me SMILE! Yep. Anybody remember?
 But then people started tripping out. Thinking I was STUCK UP?!?!? because
I was "quiet" They started talking shit. Calling me names..
 Well. This made me somehow forget how to smile. Then people would say I
was faking my smile. No. I just forgot how to.
 So then I just started looked upset. And so on, and so on..
 Thanx peoplez!!!  

But. Now. I just have that I don't give a HOOT vibe. Yep. I need to defend
myself sorry..

Weird huh?
Jeff

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead <knucklehead@club.net>
Subject: Poetry: Abort, Retry, Ignore....nrr
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Came across this and thought I'd share. Hope it hasn't been posted before....


To the meter of "The Raven" by Edgar Allen Poe...

      Abort, Retry, Ignore?

      Once upon a midnight dreary, fingers cramped and vision bleary,
      System manuals piled high and wasted paper on the floor, Longing
      for the warmth of bed sheets, still I sat there doing spreadsheets:
      Having reached the bottom line, I took a floppy from the drawer.
      Typing with a steady hand, I then invoked the SAVE command and
      waited for the disk to store, Only this and nothing more.


      Deep into the monitor peering, long I sat there wond'ring, fearing,
      Doubting, while the disk kept churning, turning yet to churn some more.
      But the silence was unbroken, and the stillness gave not token.
      "Save!" I said, "You cursed mother!  Save my data from before!"
      One thing did the phosphors answer, only this and nothing more,
      Just, "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"

      Was this some occult illusion, some maniacal intrusion?
      These were choices undesired, ones I'd never faced before.
      Carefully I weighed the choices as the disk made impish noises.
      The cursor flashed, insistent, waiting, baiting me to type some more.
      Clearly I must press a key, choosing one and nothing more,
      From "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"


      With fingers pale and trembling, slowly toward the keyboard bending,
      Longing for a happy ending, hoping all would be restored,
      Praying for some guarantee, timidly, I pressed a key.
      But on the screen there still persisted words appearing as before.
      Ghastly grim they blinked and taunted, haunted, as my patience wore,
      Saying "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"

      I tried to catch the chips off guard, and pressed again, but twice as
       hard.
      I pleaded with the cursed machine: I begged and cried and then I
      swore.  Now in mighty desperation, trying random combinations,
      Still there came the incantation, just as senseless as before.
      Cursor blinking, angrily winking, blinking nonsense as before.
      Reading,  "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"

      There I sat, distraught, exhausted, by my own machine accosted.
      Getting up I turned away and paced across the office floor.  And
      there I saw a dreadful sight: a lightning bolt cut through the
       night.
      A gasp of horror overtook me, shook me to my very core.
      The lightning zapped my previous data, lost and gone forevermore.
      Not even,  "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"

      To this day I do not know the place to which lost data go.
      What demonic nether world is wrought where lost data will be stored,
      Beyond the reach of mortal souls, beyond the ether, into black holes?
      But sure as there's C, Pascal, Lotus, Ashton-Tate and more,
      You will be one day be left to wander, lost on some Plutonian shore,
      Pleading,  "Abort, Retry, Ignore?"

                                                      - Author Unnown





*****************************************************************
                         Tim (knucklehead)

  Knuckleheads Home Page:   http://www.club.net/~knucklehead
  BBQ & BEATS Home Page:  http://www.club.net/~knucklehead/BnB
*****************************************************************

             <Pine.GSO.3.95.970620073806.4195E-100000@atari> 
Date: Fri, 20 Jun 97 09:46:06 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


wow, i guess Technics SL1200's are as silly as I've always said they
are (yet another hyped piece of "must have" equipment -- if you're not
graced by the presence of this overpriced boat-anchor, then your just
not cool enough to be a real raver).  My audio turntable (a 15 year old
Dual 714Q) has quartz locked direct drive with phase-locked pitch
control. all you need is a phase-locked-loop circuit and you can
quartz-lock at variable speeds. such a circuit could be designed by a
junior-year electrical engineering student, or pick up a 40 year old
book on servo control theory and figure it out for yourself.

to have a supposedly quartz locked turntable that is dependent on line
voltage/frequency, well, that takes the cake. How lame can you get?

Y'all should check out the Vestax turntables (the ones with the +-50%
speed control and the ability to play backwards).  They seem pretty
cool, but then again, I couldn't give a hoot about turntables -- I mix
w/ CD's and I think vinyl sucks. Digital rules.

PS: i guess it'll take the whizzes at Technics another 10 years to
figure out that you don't need a overweight, resonant, hard to
manufacture curved tube for a tonearm. do the geometry -- a straight
tube with an  angled headshell will do the same thing, but will track
better (less rotational inertia), and won't resonate as much. but then
again, i guess it just doesn't matter much.... vinyl is a fundamentally
flawed medium, a living anachronism... improving a turntable like the
1200 is probably about as useful as fitting a dinosaur with
rollerblades. :-)

PPS: anybody want to buy a Technics SL-1100A (the granddaddy of the
1200??) it works fine, just needs a little tonearm adjustment and a new
cart/needle. Seems to be no different from the 1200 other than being
heavier and more clunky looking; it has a rotary pitch control rather
than the linear one. Make an offer for this dinosaur. Rollerblades not
included.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

hello all-

this monday, the 23'rd of june, will be a monday night dinner organized by
yours truly, matthew d. p. k. lanier.  the monday night dinner was a
tradition started about a year ago, and has served as a way for many
sfravers to meet each other in person in a relaxed setting.  it's also
served as a way for several newbies to get ushered into the scene...

so, here's the skinny...

when - monday, june 23'rd at 8:30
where - kan zaman, a wonderful little restaurant at haight and parker
(more detailed addresses to come)
who - you!

why - because it's fun.

rsvp - please, to matt@lanier.org (a different address from this one)

so, come on down and eat with me and other mysterious raver types!


matt =)

matthew d. p. k. lanier / professional hugger and empath / matt@lanier.org - i web, therefore i am / matt@saturn5.com - i read too many mailing lists / mlanier@designmedia.com - i work too much / +1-415-753-2978 - duh /

Well I like 1200's and the cureved tone arm Im no Tech Eng. wizard so
I don't know the schematics of it but a bent tone arm works better for
me. And Analog in MOST not all but most cases is better to me than
digital. Why should we let some doctor dictate what our ears can hear
and what decibals that a Human can hear at. That is pure bull shit!!

Sorry my $0.02

Love,
Macadio

>Administrative Notes

>   possibly hope to get all the info every week.

>   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
>   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
>   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
>  
>   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
>   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar

>   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
>   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
>   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
>  
>   subscribe sfraves

Oh yeah, I know what you mean.  I remember about 15 yrs ago (ouch) putting a
rekkid on my parents old Grundig cab stereo thingy and playing a boom box for
background beats.  Using the the volume controls for desired effects and just
start scratchin the H_ll out the rekkid.  That old Grundig was so spongy nad
hard to control, but eventually I got it sound pretty good. :)  Whew... major
flashback.  Yeah, yeah what a difference a pair of 1200's can make. ;)

and keep it in sync :)

On Fri, 20 Jun 1997, macadio wrote: 


> 
> Well I like 1200's and the cureved tone arm Im no Tech Eng. wizard so
> I don't know the schematics of it but a bent tone arm works better for
> me. And Analog in MOST not all but most cases is better to me than
> digital. Why should we let some doctor dictate what our ears can hear
> and what decibals that a Human can hear at. That is pure bull shit!!
> 
> Sorry my $0.02
> 
> Love,
> Macadio 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
> ---"Niels P. Mayer"  wrote:
> >
> > 
> > wow, i guess Technics SL1200's are as silly as I've always said they
> > are (yet another hyped piece of "must have" equipment -- if you're
> not
> > graced by the presence of this overpriced boat-anchor, then your just
> > not cool enough to be a real raver).  My audio turntable (a 15 year
> old
> > Dual 714Q) has quartz locked direct drive with phase-locked pitch
> > control. all you need is a phase-locked-loop circuit and you can
> > quartz-lock at variable speeds. such a circuit could be designed by a
> > junior-year electrical engineering student, or pick up a 40 year old
> > book on servo control theory and figure it out for yourself.
> > 
> > to have a supposedly quartz locked turntable that is dependent on
> line
> > voltage/frequency, well, that takes the cake. How lame can you get?
> > 
> > Y'all should check out the Vestax turntables (the ones with the +-50%
> > speed control and the ability to play backwards).  They seem pretty
> > cool, but then again, I couldn't give a hoot about turntables -- I
> mix
> > w/ CD's and I think vinyl sucks. Digital rules.
> > 
> > PS: i guess it'll take the whizzes at Technics another 10 years to
> > figure out that you don't need a overweight, resonant, hard to
> > manufacture curved tube for a tonearm. do the geometry -- a straight
> > tube with an  angled headshell will do the same thing, but will track
> > better (less rotational inertia), and won't resonate as much. but
> then
> > again, i guess it just doesn't matter much.... vinyl is a
> fundamentally
> > flawed medium, a living anachronism... improving a turntable like the
> > 1200 is probably about as useful as fitting a dinosaur with
> > rollerblades. :-)
> > 
> > PPS: anybody want to buy a Technics SL-1100A (the granddaddy of the
> > 1200??) it works fine, just needs a little tonearm adjustment and a
> new
> > cart/needle. Seems to be no different from the 1200 other than being
> > heavier and more clunky looking; it has a rotary pitch control rather
> > than the linear one. Make an offer for this dinosaur. Rollerblades
> not
> > included.
> > 
> >
> =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

stickers, toys, paint, stuffed animals etc. please do! 

DIRECTIONS:

>From 280-get on 880 north (Oakland) and follow the directions below.

>From 880-get on 101 north (San Fran) and follow the directions below.

>From 101:
Take the San Tomas exit and go west (?) 
[If you have been driving south it is a right, for north it is a left]
After a couple of miles turn LEFT on BENTON.
IMMEDIATELY turn RIGHT on MARYANN.
Turn RIGHT on PATRICIA (great names, don't you think?)
After one block the road will come to a T, I am right in front of you.

2468 Karen Drive.
 
Walk around the right side of the building to get to our front door, #3.

These simple directions will minimize confusion and the risk of getting lost,
even if it is a bit longer.

If you have questions or get lost, call (408)241-1046.

Feel free to show up about 6 or 7-ish.  Later is fine too, but don't miss the
love boat to Wonderland.  "I'm late, I'm late, for a very important date!"

Everyone and anything is welcome to the party, as long as it has a good vibe!

If anyone knows Alaska, please invite him.  Alik aka Earthlen will be there
for those of you who know him or would like to!  (Wouldn't we all?)

Thanks everyone, I can't wait!

Why does this "debate" matter? What difference does it really make if you
listen to House music, trance, techno, Jungle, in a barn, a car,  a jail
cell, a fucking out house, or in a warehouse or a club? Any of you "ravers"
that want to distinguish themselves from "clubbers" so much ever go to MAD?
Then you're a "clubber" too. 

I cant believe people are actually trying to make themselves feel superior on
the basis of where they go to hear music.

It's no wonder why anytime issues of race, ethnicity, gender and sexuality
get brought up on this list, they turn into flame wars of attrition. A lot of
people here can't even be accepting of differing music styles and VENUES,
much less of the diferring types of people who attend these events. 
--Monty

Subject: Disillusionment and Rave Ideals
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
References: <Pine.GSO.3.95q.970620091526.24719B-100000@uhunix5>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> On Wed, 18 Jun 1997, Robert Pointer wrote:
>
> > Alright guys, its been awhile since I've posted (coupla weeks), but
> I'm
> > sittin' in my kitchen right now making a tape of old skool stuff and
> its
> > making me feel nostalgic.
>
> i LOVE 808 state, et al... are ya calling me old??? j/k (!!!)


Heck no. Being old is a state of mind not a matter of years.

Anyway, I almost became jaded and disillusioned w/ things (rave
"electronica", etc.) for awhile.
I guess it's because I was going through hard core studies of political
science (concentration: political philosohpy - Graduated CSUS - took me
freakin' years tho) and I saw a lot of hypocrisy in the scene based upon
what I was learning and what I believed.
There was a lot of junk propaganda during those times.
There was a period of time when promoters really tried to attach
themselves to these ideals of utopia and peace and happiness as
something that raves would accomplish - y'know, change the world.
Anyway, this stuff was pure marketing and it soured my experience w/
individuals. Being a DJ probably didn't help either (whenever money
enters into the picture, intents and ideals quickly change and/or get
prostituted).
I just started buying records that I wanted to hear only (my girlfriend
hated it at the time 'cuz I started buying real mellow house -
emotionally based techno) and stopped going out. But seeing how raves
have evolved as off late (backing off of the whole "raves will change
the world" , "just pay your $25 to find out how!") and letting them
just be what they are - really great enviroments for like-minded people
to enjoy others as well as the music.
I'm sure that there are people that still try to espouse these ideals
(and I don't want to take away from how they feel necessarily), but the
"rave ideals that will change the world" is too unrealistic.
Nowadays I feel more comfortable approaching the scene again w/o
worrying about people's intentions.
I guess my problem was that I held these potential ideals really high
and to compromise them through a medium that wasn't prepared to
translate them into the real world (you know - preach to the
non-converted) was not right.

Well ... that was my deep thought for the day. (time to go to sleep.)

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

gee i didn't intend my post to start a flaming club vs. rave thread.
i was just bored at work and was thinking about how much i preferred
raves over clubs. 

if you want to flame, flame me for bringing out my point of view. for
telling you how *i* feel about the situations, music people at
clubs/raves. for sharing my experiences with the scene. 

i know i was condescending towards the club scene but i in no way was
trying to be superior. i made some of my points a bit grandious but it
was all in good humor. (or was the post not clear enough?) 

sorry if i'm not as opened minded as you. sorry if i'm not well
rounded enough to enjoy high energy music. is it me? i didn't read any
flames. i didn't read any "you suck you stupid #$%*, clubs are way
better than raves." i just read a bunch of messages from people who
shared their views on the topic. it's almost as ludicrous as expecting
everyone to keep their mouths shut about party reviews because they
might offend someone by saying "the dj spun shiity music, the people
were tweekers yadda yadda." eesh! sorry for not conforming to
everyone's ideals. my ideas and how i feel are from my past
experiences.
so if my parents were devoted nazi's, then hell! i'd probably hate you
all and hang you up a tree!
hehe but they're not so i'm just a raver kid from the bay area.
:) veann

p.s. if anyone wants to flame me, please do so privately =)

through NetScape :(

MIRC for windows :) then, install it, and go on IRC! :)

MIRC or IRCle files on hyperreal so that other can download 'em

From: darrele@netcom.com (Darrel Etter)
Message-Id: <199706202129.OAA15457@netcom22.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: The TB303
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Fri, 20 Jun 1997 14:29:33 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> From: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
> Subject: Re: The TB303
> 
> At 04:20 PM 6/18/97 -0700, you wrote:
> >Well.. If the 303 is a Fender Strat.
> >Then the JP-8000 must be an Ibanez S470 or something.
> >
>         I must defenitely say that the TB-303 is not the Strat of techno.
> TB-303 might be a really good bass, since it's main purpose is creating
> basslines. I'd say that the Strat of techno is the SH-101. Because without
> it, there would have never been acid. Which means no trance. And so forth.

I'm not a guitar player, but I've played music with many of that
species. They all tell me they play the strat because it is
flexible. It has three pick-ups so you can get mellow to harsh; a wide
variety of timbres from the guitar. It us used in jazz, heavy metal,
every kind of music. None of those cheap plastic Rolands (tb-303,
sh-101, mc-202, etc.) has this quality. I'd say the tb-303 is the
Montgomery Wards Dan Electro imitation of the 90's.  (I havn't got my
facts completely straight, so correct me if I'm wrong) The Dan Electro
was a very cheap guitar made using surplus lipstick containers for
pickups. BUT, by accident, it had a individual, gritty, stand out
different sound that many people liked and used. That's what the
tb-303 is also. AN ACCIDENT used in a creative fashion that everyone
is copying. It does not have the classic instrument status of the
strat. No one who could afford a MiniMoog, a Jupiter-8, or an Arp 2600
would even bother looking at the tb-303. I doubt it was even marketed
towards musicians. Just like people couldn't afford a stratocaster
might end up with a Dan Electro. That said, comparing the tb-303 to a
strat is kindof an insult to a tb-303.

=Darrel (cut my teeth on Buchla synths, and played a Roland SH-5
through a DynaKit tube pre-amp for distortion and a Sano
"Computa-Rythm I" through DeltaLab DL-4 and Moog filter in Ice Cream
parlors back when Kraftwerk was cheezy pop music, so don't fuck with
me! :) )

PS: I have a 1957 Fender Duo-sonic that sounds better than a strat,
but is not as flexible :P

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I think someone has mentioned this before, but can people use private
email instead of posting things like the following (I made this up as an
example)--

HI ALL you leetle sfwavers! :) :) :)  *smoochy star love kissies*
I'm going to a rave tonight with all my bestest friends and we're all
bringing toys and lotion and candy!!!! *SQUEAL*
Hi John, Mary, and Bob!  I wuv you!


I think you guys get the picture ;)  I'm all for lovey-dovey stuff some
of the time, but wading through a mailbox filled with messages like this
can get tedious, if not mildly nauseating...

not a flame, just a comment,
Timothy

Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom13.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id PAA07186; Fri, 20 Jun 1997 15:59:47 -0700
Message-Id: <199706202259.PAA07186@netcom13.netcom.com>
To: darrele@netcom.com (Darrel Etter)
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: The TB303 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 20 Jun 97 14:29:33 PDT."
             <199706202129.OAA15457@netcom22.netcom.com> 
Date: Fri, 20 Jun 97 15:59:47 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


>facts completely straight, so correct me if I'm wrong) The Dan Electro
>was a very cheap guitar made using surplus lipstick containers for
>pickups. BUT, by accident, it had a individual, gritty, stand out
>different sound that many people liked and used. That's what the
>tb-303 is also. AN ACCIDENT used in a creative fashion that everyone
>is copying. It does not have the classic instrument status of the
>strat. No one who could afford a MiniMoog, a Jupiter-8, or an Arp 2600
>would even bother looking at the tb-303. I doubt it was even marketed
>towards musicians. Just like people couldn't afford a stratocaster

Full agreement with you on this one. The Tb-303, 808, 909 were regarded
as CHEAP, CHEEZY TOYS by electronic musicians everywhere back when they
were released in 1981 (for tb303). This is why i find the unthinking
trendoids reverence towards these boxes so comical and worth-poking-fun
at nowadays. They're still just as cheezy now as they were then... Do
you all start howling at how the theremin is the cornerstone of cheezy
sci-fi movie soundtracks and observe 5 minutes of silence every time
somebody mentions its hallowed name? I think not. Maybe I'm just not
into idolatry as much as you all. I find it kind of sickening to hear
ravers talk about how everybody is a star and they don't worship people
like they did back in the old rock and roll days. And instead, they
start worshipping a machine, which, in my opinion, is even more
sickening.

That and the elitism -- because these boxes are hard to find and really
seriously overpriced for what you're getting (unless you buy it from
somebody's grandma who is cleaning out their attic) -- because you're
not considered "cool" unless you have one (e.g. Fatboy SLim's
"Everybody Needs a 303"). Perhaps y'all can form some kind of
priesthood and bless and annoint your flock with a filter sweep and a
well-placed slide? 

Well, whatever. It's just a tool. That's my point. I find it funny to
see how pissy people get when one calls their gods out into the light
and sees them for what they are.

Last  word on this, pleeze? 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

Subject: Vague warnings about...stuff
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Vague is my middle name....

Getting... uh...stuff from strangers is dangerous, getting to know what
good stuff tastes like is one way avoid taking too much stuff that may not
be...good stuff.

That said, beware this...stuff that has a super-strong soapy aftertaste,
some people had this stuff last weekend and some of them are just now
recovering... Besides the soap (not bleach) like aftertaste, goose bumps,
tingly scalp, feeling cold, initial dizziness, and not being able to sit
down were reported as side effects.  The scary thing is, these people
didn't know anything was wrong until the next evening, when they compared
stories of the morning after.  One person spent the morning picking lint
out of his carpet, another person spent the whole day cleaning the back of
every CD in his collection.  All of them noticed obsessive behavior and
suspension of reality.  The latter effect lasted 3-4 days...  

This stuff could be really bad if some one takes it, then thinks they are
going to sober up by morning to drive home...  Or work...

Hope this saves somebodies week. Hope this pisses nobody off!  (Notice the
lack of names, places, and substances...)

ChrisP -Who knows better

at speeds other than zero is not specificaly mentioned. On the other hand,

quartzlocked control." Do you mean to sugest that Matshusita are lying?

hey everyone,
     i haven't posted to the list in a long time. but, now i feel the need to
speak. i consider myself both a raver and a clubber. nikita, come-unity,
space (in san jose), the velvet shop (in SJ as well), spundae, and many
others don't deserve to be lumped in the same category as city nights and the
soundfactory. i could have commented on many things, but i just chose a few.

>  *you make soooo many new friends rather than just some guy who wants
>  your number and turns out to be some gad awful player who thinks he's
>  "the bomb"

some of the coolest ppl i have met have been on nights when i've gone out to
nikita, come-unity, roots, and the list goes on. if you have a bad attitude
(thinking that you are better or more enlightened because you are a "raver"
and all others are just "vibeless clubbers" for example) with ppl, then you
won't meet any new ppl at all. also, you can meet shady ass guys anywhere,
including parties, not just at clubs.
 
>  *better music (okay so i'm biased. i don't like high energy music with
>  high pitched whiny voices... my bad)

this statement is way too biased. some of the best damn djs i have ever heard
in my life have been at clubs. i seriously doubt that i will ever see carl
cox (the number one dj in the world and with good reason) spinning at some
party. face it, clubs will pull in the best djs in the world (not just house
djs, techno and trance djs as well) and they will go off!!!!! 
 
>  *i hate that circle (i'll say it once again:) when two people are in
>  the center dancing and everyone else seems to crowd around them and
>  just watch.  ooo big pet peeve :P

i've never had the unfortunate experience of seeing a cirlcle in any club.
but, i have seen them at many a rave that i've gone to.   
      i might add, that at clubs, you can laugh, dance, hang out against the
wall, smile, chain smoke, drink tons of water and whatever else you want with
no problem. i've also noticed another thing. many ppl on this list have the
same negative kind of attitude that they think the "clubbers" have. go out
and experience some of what a club has to offer instead of judging everything
by one bad experience. it won't damage your UG values if you open up your
mind a little.

much love to all and see you at origin on saturday.

dorena

1967

Acid Rock is the Sound of the Underground- All night psychedelic dance parties. The sound is driven by insane and warped sounds created on a Fender Stratocaster by Jimi Hendrix (a God to be worshipped).

1987-1997

Acid House is the Sound of the Underground- All night psychedelic dance parties. The sound is driven by insane and warped sounds created on a Roland TB303 by the many, many faceless producers (not Gods, merely people) of Our Generation.

The TB303 absolutely IS the Fender Stratocaster of our generation!

andrew

> tingly scalp, feeling cold, initial dizziness, and not being able to sit
> down were reported as side effects.  The scary thing is, these people
> didn't know anything was wrong until the next evening, when they compared
> stories of the morning after.  One person spent the morning picking lint
> out of his carpet, another person spent the whole day cleaning the back of
> every CD in his collection.  All of them noticed obsessive behavior and
> suspension of reality.  The latter effect lasted 3-4 days...

Alik Earthlen sez:
>I totally know what you mean, wish gets like that sometimes, I guess 
>it's because it's not UG and lots of *homies* which don't have anything 
>do to on wednesday night show up... 

I don't wanna whine and start a big race debate, but I don't like the tendency 
of a lotta folx to classify certain types of folx as "homies" or "ganstas" or 
"hoochie mamas," etc., and assume that these people are ghetto, negative, 
rude, or mean.

So if you see somebody at a party/club/whatever, who may be a minority, 
wearing baggy clothes (or maybe tight & revealing clothes if they're female), 
maybe speaking a little of dat "ebonics," please don't assume that they're not 
cool, accepting, and sweet.  Cuz they might be.

How many times have I told of my beanie experience?  Well, like I've said, I 
think it kinda sux that people treat me different when they see I'm a black 
chick sportin a beanie and some big jeans, no matter how big my smile is . . . 
Golly, what happened to all that PLUR, hmmm?

I'm _NOT_ accusing Alik (cuz you seem like a big sweetie :-) ) or anyone else 
of stereotyping, or being a racist--I'm sure if you look at your behavior and 
thought processes, you can surmise for yourself whether you are or you aren't. 
 So NOBODY GET MAD!  I'M NOT UPSET, just concerned, and I'm not accusing 
anyone of anything!  Who the hell am I to judge?  It's jus the use of the word 
"homies" just kinda freaked me out, cuz I know that can entail some negative 
perceptions of certain groups of people, dat's all.  I _DON'T_ know who 
exactly Alik was talking about when he used that word, all I know what I 
_THOUGHT_  he might mean.  So I repeat that I'm not trying to flame him, cuz 
I'd do that off the list anyway, like everyone should :-).

I'm not saying that if you see some brotha looking like Snoop Dogg or Dru Down 
at the next party, you should give him a big hug and slap some stickers and 
glitter on his cheeks.  Matter of fact, I don't think you should do that w/o 
asking to anyone, cuz you never know if they'll be comfortable w/ it or 
appreciate it.  I would :-), but everyone's not like me.

Just be careful not to prejudge folx, yes?

xoxo--Miccaela
