At 8:38 PM -0400 6/20/97, DorenaB@aol.com wrote:
>some of the coolest ppl i have met have been on nights when i've gone out to
>nikita, come-unity, roots, and the list goes on. if you have a bad attitude
>(thinking that you are better or more enlightened because you are a "raver"
>and all others are just "vibeless clubbers" for example) with ppl, then you
>won't meet any new ppl at all. also, you can meet shady ass guys anywhere,
>including parties, not just at clubs.
>

I must give a strong second to sister Dorena's post.  But I guess I am one
of those old-skoolers so my view is from a person who remebered when this
all started, was very very fresh and very very new.

I know that many of you are new to all of this and many of you are
old-ass-timers like myself (yay!).  More power to you all.  I must say that
what all of this has become is one massive club.  As one person in XLR8R
put it, "Rave is dead."  Rave, beleive it or not, at one time was UG.  They
were the same thing.  It was exclusive only to the extent that you had to
work to find out where things were going to be at, as well as the
possibility of:
-The party moving last minute
-The cops busting the place at ANY minute.

To me, w/o these two elements at a minimum all you have is a club.  I have
lost hundreds of dollars going to clubs that have been busted or moved.  I
have been to raoming parties that were NEVER in the same place, and threw
parties with that in mind.  There is nothing like the tension of being in a
break-in, or a muni-yard, or a hill, or someplace that is DESTINED to be
busted.  All you hope for is that the next beat that will be dropped is not
your last.  Unless you've experienced this you wouldn't understand.  The
collective of people was not around a slogan of plur, we didn't need that.
All anyone needed was some good beats and the family was formed.  Nothing
is greater than dance to bring people together.  The DJ's and the people
who threw these "raves" knew this and it showed in the intensity of thier
music (nobody can or ever will come close to Jeno, Ernie, Josh, Markie,
and countless others during the hieght of this period).  Like I said, w/o
the tension all you have is a very well organized, bustproof party.

IMO, people are very, very spoiled.  Pre-sale tickets, with all the good
intentions make our scene even more overground.  These days it seems more
like a bill graham production than anything else.  DJ's are now superstars
with all the glamor and paparrazi and hookers that would make even some
rap/rock(long dead,IMO) stars would envy.  There was a time when you didn;t
know the DJ's name, but he put you in a place that you would not soon
forget.  Why?  The tension.  What tension do we have these days?  Let me
count the gripes and moans.  The tension these days amounts to "people" not
dancing (huh?), people throwing bad vibes (huh?), & the ubiquitous people
with attitude (huh?).  No wonder people have been taking GHB and other dumb
drugs.  If that's was all the tension that surrounds parties these days I
would probalby be a GHB junkie too ;).

Nope I am quite afraid that all of what was is no longer and many are left
grabbing at straws for the real deal.  No, it's not a matter of being
jaded, it's a matter of people and what brings them together, and what
binds them in the dance.  It is tension, it is struggle done together.  The
music is the glue, and the DJ cures it for us, whoever that may be.

There was a time that everyone danced.

So to me I am not a raver, but am a former raver.  I am not a clubber
either.  I am just me, a person who really enjoys house/techno/jungle in a
good setting, and seeing/partying with the friends I have made through the
years.  We've all grown up together, gotten really high together, and
shared something that came once and is often imitated, but has YET to be
duplicated.

The fact that people have created two camps of people and can distinguish
themselves is further proof of the de-evloution.  At one time, beleive it
or not, there was ONLY rave.  And rave was the only thing that mattered.
We never had time to talk about clubbing or clubs, but we sure did know
(through the phone) when the next rave came along.

I sure do hope some of the youngbloods get off their butts and do it like
we used to, UG.  No flyers, just word of mouth (this should work unless the
community is so communication weak that it cannot muster some 600 people
via word of mouth).  No club, how about a warehouse?  How about an
unpermitted outdoor spot?  How about right here in the city where your
chances are slim, but if you pull it off it could be the one you were
waiting for...but I think that people think about their pocketbooks, and
are far too worried about being locked up to have true heart.

Props to the old-skool, and props the the new skool who know that the fuck
I'm talking about, and moreso are doing it.  You know who you are.

Much peace & dance,
Have fun,
John

P.S.  If I hear a slam about old-skool one more time I'm gonna get riled
up. W/o Old-skool there wouldn't be no rave in this city, no four color
flyers, no good DJ's, no record stores/stores, no mags, no good sound
systems, no nuthin'.  So unless you know some history, please watch who you
disrespect.  Better yet why not just try to do better, everyone will
benefit.

P.P.S.  Did you know that "back in the day" we didn't have ANY fights, no
OD's, no emergency rooms, and no guns, no 'tudes.  Just guys in bright
colors, and bra-booty-betty's (you missed it!) shakin' it and breakin' it.
Huggin and cryin' dancin and never lying.  No slogans, just the beat...and
the ass would ALWAYS follow.

P.P.P.S  Nope I don't NEED to go to no rave and see all the bright new
faces UNLESS there is some tension of a real UG event.  You know the type,
could get busted, could have only 1/2 a sound system (anyone remember
equinox in Hunter's Point!  Ivan & Leise?  No?), might have to move any
minute?  Ever seen a caravan in the full moon light...600 cars heading into
the moon like 600 pure bred sons of bitches on horseback?  All these
memories will be like tears in the rain...time to die.

P.P.P.P.S  Remember when Ameba was the central spot (along w/ the Be-At
line) to find out the haps?  Now all you gotta do is log on...

P.P.P.P.P.S  Who started Full Moon's?  Who is Rave Called Sharon named
after (first & last name please)?  Where was the FIRST Toon Town?  The
First Basics?  The First Gathering?  The first Eklypz?  Where were you when
you first heard "Feel it!" by coco-steel& lovebomb?  Who played "Atom Bomb"
by Dj Pierre first in this city?  How many map points have you been to
since moving to the city, or at all?

"What is house music?  A unique form, a unique form of music." - DJ Pierre

"Without a foundation, all you got is dirt." - JSL

Props to all that care, and much respect to those who are still doing it,
and much luck to those who have yet to do it.

a few weeks ago I was at 1015 on a friday night and it was packed with the
usual scam-a-wham peoples and was a real energy sucker as far as crowd
goes.  Nonetheless I remembered who I was and got into some groove and for
about thirty seconds I found myself in an alternate club dimension...
Whoever was spinning hit some rare funk and threw out some serious vibe.
I caught it and it picked me up like king kong with a baseball glove.  In
the middle of all the wandering hungry eyes, big hair, ck-1 and all that I
found thirty seconds of the Good stuff and was loving it. Someone handed
me a flyer just like that and I knew I was doing something right.  People
looked at me funny like I was doin something wrong but I didn't care I was
ridin the train. 

too bad it was only half a minute.

Precedence: bulk

mini review
I was _vastly_ disappointed by the Ninja Tunes that I heard tonight.
After paying my 20$ to get in with assurances that the music was really
jungle but that it just varied a lot, I went into a mass of shoulder to
shoulder club people (a few ravers in sight, most standing still actually)
and this blaring RAP music the DJ was happily (and possibly skillfully but
I couldn't tell) spinning.  It didn't take long for me to realize, this
wasn't a rave, wasn't a club that was like a rave, wasn't jungle, wasn't
dub, wasn't anything but rap rap rap.  A little bit of slow r*b and rap
beat to accompany, but that's it.  I looked around thinking "I double
checked, yep this is xmission theatre, and those are images of ninja masks
flashing amongst the graphics..."

Earlier this afternoon I was at a coffee place next to the Juice Club in
Cupertino.  De Anza college kids hang out there.  A live band was playing
a sort of upbeat jazz/modernish bit that I swear moved me and felt a lot
more fun.  I was the only person who spent some time dancing to it
... but I should have hung out longer there and save myself the trp to
SF!

Sorry if I offended any rap fans out there, becuase I'm sure that kind of
music has it's merits, and perhpas the ninja tunes were great for their
genre, but I was one unsatisfied raver for certain!

Love,
Max

much space)

-east coast vs west coast (yep, we did that too)
-and the ubiquitous "I love you all!" posts (It's like when someone says I
love all humanity...does that mean the mass murderers too?), smiles, and
hugz dreck.
-How come nobody hugz me at parties
-GHB is a good thing
-All drugs are good

Now don't get me wrong, even my pompous ass has participated in a few of
these (if not all ;)).

The next few years ought to prove interesting as I expect more and more
ridiculous posts.

Oh yeah, as I expected, the NRR posts are back in full force.  To coin a
phrase from the Right Reverend Martin O'Brian "The circle is now complete".
Back to deleting everything.  Oh how I wish for moderation, how I wish for
massive filtering, how I long for clear conversation, and how I hate that
slogannering PLUR.

PLUR sux.

HUGZ and sweet saccharin kisses and aspartame dreams, I wish glitter and
lollipops and teddy bears and good things to you all.  Personally I wish
someone would wish me Martha Stewart in full leather, can we make a slogan
out of that.  Good things for Bad People?

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id KAA23789
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 21 Jun 1997 10:04:23 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom23.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id KAA13225; Sat, 21 Jun 1997 10:04:20 -0700
Message-Id: <199706211704.KAA13225@netcom23.netcom.com>
To: "Mr nStuff" <stuff@hooked.net>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Musical Question 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 20 Jun 97 20:36:28 PDT."
             <199706210339.UAA28540@mom.hooked.net> 
Date: Sat, 21 Jun 97 10:04:19 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> You have a Roland JP-8000 right?

Yep. It rules.

> I have a major question about this keyboard. And I have not found the
> answer anywhere online. Which is scarey. Please have the answer I am
> looking for.

Check out the June Keyboard magazine for a review.

> Is the JP-8000 capable of pitch bending?

Yes. It has a pitch bend wheel that'll work in two dimensions. one controls
bend, the other direction controls LFO2 which can modulate the filter,
the amp, or the pitch with a triangle wave. I have a feeling this isn't what
you're asking for...

>  I mean does it hold the note for
> desired lengths?

Depends on the "desired length". I have a feeling you're talking about
portamento-- the jp-8K will glide between notes in an amount of time
you can "dial in", and the glide will take the same amount of time no
matter what the interval. It'll do this in "monophonic" mode (legato),
as well as "polyphonic" mode.

>  And layer with the following notes? Ect?

In polyphonic mode, yes. It has 8 voice polyphony.

>  It does this like
> the 303 right?

The 303 is monophonic. It's probably closer to hitting the
"monophonic"/legato button on the JP-8K... (note, this refers to the #
of simultanous notes, not non-binaural sound). There's a few "303"
presets on the JP8K which put you in monophic mode to emulate the the
TB-303.

>Totally step programble too...Right nStuff?

The JP8K has "realtime phrase sequence" (RPS) that lets you record
notes and assign a 4 measure pattern to  47 of the 48 keys on the the
keyboard. You can then hit one key and play back a sequence you
recorded, with options to switch patterns immediately, on the beat, or
on the measure when you switch keys.  you can also assign real-time
motions (e.g. a filter sweep) to two different buttons on the front-panel.

As far as I can tell, it just does real-time "loop" recording with the
ability to edit/erase mistakes, override sections, etc. No step
recording. I haven't played with this much, so there's probably more
here that I don't know about.

Note that the JP8K is meant mostly as a performance and MIDI synth so
it's not a workstation with a complete sequencer and step-record
capabilities, etc. If you want to step record, it has a complete midi
implementation so all you have to do is hook it to your sequencer. all
the knobs and sliders output  midi controller changes so if you're set
to record these on your sequencer, you end up recording all your knob
tweaks along with your midi notes.

-- Niels Mayer
   Deus SysEx Machina

I think the problem was that people I'd asked about their music style had
given me the impression it was jungleist or dub or of that genre.  My
expectations were set wrong... Other factors: the SFRaves group doesn't
seem to be the "hiphop type" _as much_ as other styles (although my
personal experiences with hiphop are that it's way cooler than the rap
that nija tunes served) and the background music from their message was an
often sampled bit I hear at jungle parties.  I think I just put things
together wrong, set an expectation, and when it was broken I was like
"this sucks" and left.  I suppose if I'd been keen on that type of
rappishhiphopflavour then I would have had a lot more fun -
thanks for the perspective,
Max

> >wasn't a rave, wasn't a club that was like a rave, wasn't jungle, wasn't
> >dub, wasn't anything but rap rap rap.  A little bit of slow r*b and rap
> >beat to accompany, but that's it.  I looked around thinking "I double
> >checked, yep this is xmission theatre, and those are images of ninja masks
> >flashing amongst the graphics..."
> >
> >Earlier this afternoon I was at a coffee place next to the Juice Club in
> >Cupertino.  De Anza college kids hang out there.  A live band was playing
> >a sort of upbeat jazz/modernish bit that I swear moved me and felt a lot
> >more fun.  I was the only person who spent some time dancing to it
> >... but I should have hung out longer there and save myself the trp to
> >SF!
> >
> >Sorry if I offended any rap fans out there, becuase I'm sure that kind of
> >music has it's merits, and perhpas the ninja tunes were great for their
> >genre, but I was one unsatisfied raver for certain!
> >
> >Love,
> >Max
> >
> >On Sat, 21 Jun 1997, Paul Ramos Geronca wrote:
> >> hello
> >> 
> >> did anyone go to see the Ninja Tune kids perform?
> >> i hope i wasn't sleeping on anything

choices. you know, if i choose to do one thing, respect my choice to do so!
it's my life, not yours to judge. and i'll do the same for you. isn't that
what this so-called 'plur' is all about?

This is not a flame, so I'm posting to the entire list because people need to
see this...

In a message dated 6/21/97 12:58:17 PM, you wrote:

<<gee i didn't intend my post to start a flaming club vs. rave thread.
i was just bored at work and was thinking about how much i preferred
raves over clubs.<<

Fine, then you should have taken a little more time to think about what you
were going to write, before you went ahead and made sweeping generalizations
about people who go to clubs.  If you're going to post something on a public
list, use your head before you hit "send." If not, then people are going to
take you to task on it. 

>>if you want to flame, flame me for bringing out my point of view. for
telling you how *i* feel about the situations, music people at
clubs/raves. for sharing my experiences with the scene.<<

You have every right on this green earth to say whatever you want to say,
just as I have every right to criticize it if I have a problem with it. Are
you really complaning because people find fault with your post? Is everyone
supposed to think alike? 

>>i know i was condescending towards the club scene but i in no way was
trying to be superior. i made some of my points a bit grandious but it
was all in good humor. (or was the post not clear enough?)<<

Maybe including that last paragraph in your original post would have helped
avoid any negative response you may be recieving now. See, now that you've
had time to THINK about what you wrote, you're now acknowledging that you
could have presented your ideas in a different way. In any event, as far as
I'm concerned, it was people's subsequent posts that troubled me more than
yours. 

>>sorry if i'm not as opened minded as you.<<
In all honesty, you should be sorry. If we as a movement arent as accepting
as we claim to be, and in turn have a negative bias against people for
reasons so friggin' trivial as where they go to listen to music, we're
doomed. Maybe this is your wake up call.


>>is it me? i didn't read any flames. i didn't read any "you suck you stupid
#$%*, clubs are way better than raves." i just read a bunch of messages from
people who
shared their views on the topic. it's almost as ludicrous as expecting
everyone to keep their mouths shut about party reviews because they
might offend someone by saying "the dj spun shiity music, the people
were tweekers yadda yadda." eesh! sorry for not conforming to
everyone's ideals. my ideas and how i feel are from my past
experiences.<<

Constructive criticism(which sorely lacks in this scene) and what I
characterize as useless discussion are two different things. There is no
difference between people who go to warehouse parties and people who go to
clubs. Period. Name ONE DJ in the scene who has refused to play in club. Name
ONE of the major crews in this scene who would refuse to throw a jam in a
club if given the opportunity. F-8?  They do a club. Gateway does sound in a
club every Monday night. My man Macadio just spun in a club. Pacific doesnt
have a club, but I know they'd love to start one. FTT is all about clubs now.
And of course we all know that Wicked does a club every Wednesday night.
Anyone else?

--Monty

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jun 21 13:25:34 1997

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id NAA22699;
	Sat, 21 Jun 1997 13:25:34 -0700 (PDT)

          by precipice.v-site.net (8.8.4/8.8.4) with ESMTP

        sfraves@hyperreal.com

At 9:27 PM -0700 6/20/97, Alik Earthlen wrote:
>you wrote:
>
>>I must give a strong second to sister Dorena's post.  But I guess I am
>one
>>of those old-skoolers so my view is from a person who remebered when
>this
>>all started, was very very fresh and very very new.
>>
>
>I don't wanna start a flame... But the only thing I got to say about
>this post is: WOW, DID SOMETHING BAD HAPPEN TO YOU TODAY JOHN? OR ARE
>YOU USSUALLY THAT STRESSED OUT?
>
>that's it.. thank you drive through
>
>PLUR (which John thinks we don't need) and HUGS (which John I think
>needs) and SMOOCHIES (which John won't get, cause he has been a bad bad
>boy!  ;)   )
>
>Alik aka EarthlEn

Hello, all.  This is John S. Lee's girlfriend, writing this note in support
and defense of my man. Not that he needs my defense to handle all of you
glitter-huggers, but I thought you might like a testimony about him from
someone other than himself.  Some of you have a difficult time
understanding John or believing he has anything positive to say.  I'd like
to correct each and everyone of you that this applies to, as well as
express some of my own views on this subject.

I've know John for almost 3 years and never have I know a more giving,
loving, supportive individual.  You all must be thinking, "God, what a
deprived life she must have."  Quite the contrary.  I come from a loving
home, in which my parents are not only still married (30 years!) but still
deeply love each other.  I have many close, long-time friends.  I have been
far from love starved.  And I was doing the "PLUR" thing before it was
called that.  Back then, we called it love and friendship.  Hugs for
everyone!  Our love can change the world!  How many changes did we make?
How many of those rave "friends" was I able to count on in times of need?
ZERO!  Surprised?  I was at one time but the less naive I become, the less
surprised I am by anything.  Love can conquer all but there has got to be
great commitment to that love.  Spreading my love thinly through a crowd of
people I barely know proved to be nothing but draining.  And when it came
time to give to the people in my life who really care for me, I came up
short.  John has played an integral part in helping me understand that
concentrated love is much more powerful than the "free love for everyone"
approach.  He loves me deeply and we exchange many hugs and "smoochies???"
a day.  One true, real hug from a loved one provides me with more energy
and positivity than a thousand hugs at a rave ever has or will.

PLUR is not the root of all evil but I think too much reliance on it and
not enough focus on personal and societal improvements can be detrimental
to us all.  Its easy to give a perfect stranger a hug.  Its not easy to
deal with friends on bad trips, friends with drug addictions or "ravers"
who choose to deface the party facility with their self-important tagging.
These are very real problems within the rave community.  I read many of the
posts on this list and not enough of them address these issues.  PLUR is
nothing without commitment to organization and change within the group.
This list is a power source which I see as being greatly underutilized.
And what's with all the judgement I hear from the PLUR team, criticizing
clubbers with attitude just because they don't have a welcoming committee
at the door?  I prefer clubs to raves because I don't have to deal with all
the bullshit of being expected to love people I don't even know.  I respect
everyone, I save my love for people who appreciate it.

I don't buy the PLUR claim of acceptance of everyone, either.  How would I
be received if I showed up at a rave in a business suit?  Would I be
welcomed into the ever-accepting community?  Maybe eventually, but not
without a few stares & laughs first.  And would I first have prove I was
"one of you" by giving everyone a hug?  This is ridiculous.  Are people
required to be comfortable with touching the community at large in order to
be accepted?  What if I am really shy?  What if I am uncomfortable talking
to people I don't know?  What if I like myself this way and just want to
catch a groove?  Or, God forbid, I want to stand quietly on the sides and
observe?  According to PLUR, I would be bringing the party vibe down by
just being myself.  Not everyone at a rave fits into the PLUR model and
IMO, this is what I remember creating the beautiful experience.  Everyone
is different.  Embrace those differences.  We should be able to party
together as ourselves, not try to work everyone into a model we've chosen
for them.

This silly comparison of raves and clubs is taxing.  The way I see it, the
major difference between the two, is ravers are less honest about their
judgements.  Most everyone is judgmental in one way or another.  It's human
nature.  Clubbers might just be a little more honest about it.  They are
not trying to be rude, they are just being themselves.  If their attitude
does not fit the PLUR mold, then don't go to clubs.  If you are a PLUR
believer, check yourself on your criticisms of others.  Are they really bad
people or are they just different than you?  How perfect are you that you
have the right to label people as bad just because they don't act as you
wish they would?

Back in my raving days, a friend used to ask everyone she met, "Why are you
a raver?  What in your life has led you to the rave?"  Most every one's
response had something to do with negative experiences they have had in
their lives.  Unacceptance.  Disapproval.  Abandonment.  Pain.  Whether you
call it a rave or a club or a party or UG, it is the place everyone goes to
get away from reality.  It creates a pleasant environment for everyone to
forget about all the not-so-nice things that may be going on in their
lives.  We're all just trying to escape ourselves for a little while.

PLUR would make more sense to me if it were just, PLU.  Peace, love & unity
are global issues.  PLU would be much more inviting to and accepting of the
community a large, which is, by the way, where true change is possible and
happening.  Does President Clinton subscribe to this list?  Does he or any
other political leader know of PLUR?  And would they care?  Change isn't
seeded at the rave, people.  It is in individual lives.  It is within
communities which focus on helping others, not circle-dancing, blow pops
(which we all know are usually eaten to occupy a grinding jaw, not to take
us back to the innocence of childhood) or PLUR.  But if you only want
ravers in your little make-believe utopia, then what is all this yapping
about anyway?  Just keep on with the rave.

So, I encourage everyone, ravers & clubbers, to ask themselves, "Why am I a
raver/clubber?"  Ask your friends, then discuss your answers.  As far as I
am concerned, keep on PLURing, as long as everyone understands that rave
ideology is not going to change the world unless you get yourselves out of
the dark, smokey, warehouse and begin to act within the larger community.
I sympathize with your frustration within the rave scene but see that many
resources for change are not being implemented.  And if you do petition and
work for communal change, keep in mind individuals' differences.  Don't try
to turn everyone into a raver.  Do you really want the whole world at your
rave? I don't think you do.  Could we really deal with a whole world full
of baggy pants, whistles, blow pops & elmos?  This is PLUR by your
standards, right?  Everyone having fun in the way the ravers prescribe.  Be
sure to include a warning for all new PLUR recruits: "Party as we tell you
to or you'll have to leave.  We don't want anyone destroying our vibe."

Good luck to all, and could we please, please not forget the listen to the
music and dance our asses off?  That's what its really all about anyway,
regardless of  your answer to the question of why you, personally, are
there, right?  At least that's what I always thought.

Peace, Love and Unity (not necessarily at the rave),
Megan Haggerty
(John S. Lee's girlfriend)

to me is veiled fascism with a happy face.  One reason why I will continue
to plur bash at every opportune time.

And no, I do not need to be tolerant of everything, just those things that
don't infringe upon my right to be me.  Plur sux.

Peace,
John

i enjoyed about half of the stealth tour last night. it wasn't bad at all. they
 spun some good stuff. after 330 it turned kinda bad for me; my body as not
responding to the vibe. besides my friend left me at 2 and i was there in the
front dancing. i spot several ravers, but i think there were ravers in disguise
and ravers in heart. i mean, no one would think i was a raver, but i rave. and
label doesn't matter. i was the young (*my* id worked. *shh*) chinese boi in
black frame glasses, and a green virtual chicken pet hanging around my neck. i
understand that there were quite a few of asian guys with black frame glasses
though. so.  anyway, i just love it when they spun squarepusher's vic acid, or
rustic raver, actually maybe! i keep hoping they would put the torque 12" on
the turntable, but they opt for panacea instead, and it was OKAY with me! i am
going to wonderland tonight! (first rave in calif!) and might be bringing a
friend who's never been to a rave, so i hope ppl will be gentle to us.  i might
be alone, but let's just hope i will be safe. when does the ticket place close
today anyway? and when does wonderland start? end? tak much! i need to soothe
and shower with pizzicato five now....weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee................

circling-boi/kero/jo-ey/everything else

okay, i went, even though i was more than exhausted from my 2 days in 
san diego registerng for classes (at least they're good!) and 4 hours 
of sleep in between 2 days of running around and flying to and from 
sd... but my friends paged me at around 8:45, told me they could get me 
in free, so we went.. i was a little more than dissapointed to hear 
that it was at minna, just from past experiences with being stuck in a 
sweatfest... we got in at like 11:30-12:00, or something like that, and 
the heat already washed over me... i had no idea who we were grooving 
to.... anyways, dan came on... i've definitely seen him spin better, 
but it was hot, he looked exhausted... on the car ride back, we decided 
he'd just responded to the vibe of the party, which wasn't real high 
last night... simon was tearing it up downstairs... and then dj paucus 
(sorry if i messed up the spelling, he's really good friends with one 
of my friends, so i feel bad if that's misspelled!) was incredibly 
dope.. i was definitely impressed... then we went upstairs to watch 
hipp-e fucking things up... he's just such a solid dj.. every time i 
see him, the more i like him.. we left at about 5:45-6:00.. beautiful 
day in the city! everyone who may be partying tonight, stay safe and be 
happy! =)


                               much love,
                           anissa, princess of the universe!

Subject: Re:why I'm a raver not a clubber redux (long)

Precedence: bulk

Megan Haggerty wrote:
>Hello, all.
<snip>
>How many of those rave "friends" was I able to count on in times of need?
>ZERO!  Surprised?

not at all. i've been burned by more 'pluralists' than i care to
acknowledge. that's the thing.... eventually the drugs catch up and ppl
stop caring about anything else. it's all a facade. okay, not all of it,
that may be an exageration. but i can totally relate to what you're writing
here. maybe i'm old and jaded.... :P

<snip>
>I don't buy the PLUR claim of acceptance of everyone, either.  How would I
>be received if I showed up at a rave in a business suit?  Would I be
>welcomed into the ever-accepting community?  Maybe eventually, but not
>without a few stares & laughs first.

we actually have this big music fest in austin (sxsw) and at the last one
they actually had josh wink spinning at one of the bars (austin is
primarily a live-music town)... i thought it was *great* to see ppl there
who you'd never find at a rave - men and women in suits, or just jeans and
t-shirts - all really enjoying the music and getting into it. even ppl my
parents' age (i'm 30...). it was fabulous!

And would I first have prove I was
>"one of you" by giving everyone a hug?

good lord, i hope not. i *am* shy, don't tend to talk freely with
strangers, but that in no way doesn't mean i don't respect them as humans
and welcome them into what ever place i'm in.

> Everyone
>is different.  Embrace those differences.  We should be able to party
>together as ourselves, not try to work everyone into a model we've chosen
>for them.

bravo. anyway, imo, all of this bullshit is propagated either by high
school students who think they know it all (as i did when i was that age -
don't mean to sound snotty here), or by those who never grew out of that
mentality. one can only hope that they will. you know, i used to be a
clubkid (tho it wasn't called that then) and i dressed to the tee in my
little tight dresses and went out with this attitude that i was the shit.
it was *my* club, and how dare you think that you can belong here. well,
i've outgrown that and come to love (i use that term loosely) all sorts of
ppl for the characters that they are. fuck it anyway, who gives a shit. and
if some kid with a lolly pop wants to judge me now 'coz i'm not 'kewl'
enough for them, who gives a damn? i go out, to clubs, to raves, to hear
the music, to get taken on a trip, and to dance my _ass_ off. to have fun.
that's all. not to see or be seen. not to judge. people who find it amusing
to judge and laugh at others, and this is only my philosophy, usually have
some need to elevate themselves. what they don't realize is that it
usual;ly causes a backlash. i mean, would you trust someone who gets a kick
out of putting down ppl? i wouldn't. anyway, if there's someway to benefit
others through raving (say, by the proceeds of a party going to a worthy
cause), then i'm all for it. more parties should be held in this manner.
other than that, i don't see where raving can save the world. i've seen it
mess up too many ppls lives. too many ppl.

>This silly comparison of raves and clubs is taxing.  The way I see it, the
>major difference between the two, is ravers are less honest about their
>judgements.  Most everyone is judgmental in one way or another.  It's human
>nature.  Clubbers might just be a little more honest about it.  They are
>not trying to be rude, they are just being themselves.  If their attitude
>does not fit the PLUR mold, then don't go to clubs.  If you are a PLUR
>believer, check yourself on your criticisms of others.  Are they really bad
>people or are they just different than you?  How perfect are you that you
>have the right to label people as bad just because they don't act as you
>wish they would?

you know, one of the things that drew me the most to this community was
that there are so many _different_ kinds of ppl, brought together by their
love of a certain kind of music. let's try not to let that change. again,
just be yourself. if someone doesn't like you for who you are, ask yourself
why you need such a persons' approval. do you?

>Back in my raving days, a friend used to ask everyone she met, "Why are you
>a raver?  What in your life has led you to the rave?"  Most every one's
>response had something to do with negative experiences they have had in
>their lives.  Unacceptance.  Disapproval.  Abandonment.  Pain.  Whether you
>call it a rave or a club or a party or UG, it is the place everyone goes to
>get away from reality.  It creates a pleasant environment for everyone to
>forget about all the not-so-nice things that may be going on in their
>lives.  We're all just trying to escape ourselves for a little while.

>Change isn't
>seeded at the rave, people.  It is in individual lives.  It is within
>communities which focus on helping others, not circle-dancing, blow pops
>(which we all know are usually eaten to occupy a grinding jaw, not to take
>us back to the innocence of childhood) or PLUR.

never mind the glucose that our bodies are craving after hours of dancing!
i digress.

>So, I encourage everyone, ravers & clubbers, to ask themselves, "Why am I a
>raver/clubber?"  Ask your friends, then discuss your answers.  As far as I
>am concerned, keep on PLURing, as long as everyone understands that rave
>ideology is not going to change the world unless you get yourselves out of
>the dark, smokey, warehouse and begin to act within the larger community.

and how many ppl really do that? just curious.... it's like those ppl who
bitch and whine about who's in office, but they never go out and vote. get
real.

>I sympathize with your frustration within the rave scene but see that many
>resources for change are not being implemented.  And if you do petition and
>work for communal change, keep in mind individuals' differences.  Don't try
>to turn everyone into a raver.  Do you really want the whole world at your
>rave? I don't think you do.  Could we really deal with a whole world full
>of baggy pants, whistles, blow pops & elmos?  This is PLUR by your
>standards, right?  Everyone having fun in the way the ravers prescribe.  Be
>sure to include a warning for all new PLUR recruits: "Party as we tell you
>to or you'll have to leave.  We don't want anyone destroying our vibe."

i always thought that plur was 'peace, love, unity, and _respect_'. i don't
think you can have the plu without first having the respect. for ppl and
their individual choices. as long as they're not interfering with your
life, what difference does it make?

>Good luck to all, and could we please, please not forget the listen to the
>music and dance our asses off?  That's what its really all about anyway,
>regardless of  your answer to the question of why you, personally, are
>there, right?  At least that's what I always thought.

me too! "my" club in rochester (where i grew up) had this neon sign on the
dance floor that screamed 'dance your ass off'! and that _is_ what it's all
about. dance your ass off, have a blast! it's a hedonistic movement before
anything else. props to those who try to do some communal good with the
proceeds.

peace, e. :)

.............................................................................

over. Now it's more like, 'This is my life,' 'This is my tribe.'"
                                                               - Nan Goldin

"That so few now dare to be eccentric marks the cheif danger of the time."
                                              - John Stuart Mill (1806-1873)

Happenstance.  Parents fucking.  Lucky health.  Countless un/conscious
decisions, paths followed, trails blazed.

I have reached a point:  I am my own man.  I am not a raver or a clubber
or a honkey, or an MC, poet, student, asshole, lover, fighter, none of
this.  I will have none of it.

And who are we to classify others, much less waste the force to CATEGORIZE
OURSELVES?  I said this in my last oration: there is simply no need for
any of you, or any of me to squeeze ourselves into tangible objects, that
a personality librarian could figure out where to stack.

This string, although John Lee is really funny, is bollocks.  GET GRIPS,
yall.  There is no such thing as this or that.  Positive or negative.  I
have quite honestly been amazed to find this obsession with typology, with
identification within a particular grouping, with this bullshit sense of
'I am funkier than thou.'  Not that I don't enjoy it.

Did any of you ever go to a Dead show?  I noticed a similar weirdness.  WE
ARE SO PEACEFUL, DIG US.  No, not them, just us.  they come here and do
x/y/z and fuck everything up.  Bollocks.

I suppose if I could give any advice to you all: read Confucius.  I am
being very, very serious.  While your at it, read Ayn Rand.  Confucius is
the kingpin of interpersonal life as far as I'm concerned.  Ayn Rand had
some good ideas...

My friends, life is short, afterlife uncertain.
For this simple reason, take no shorts in making YOURSELF happy.  There is
a huge amount to be said for self-centeredness.  I am not saying that
losing yourself to loving a man/woman is wrong.  I am not saying that
hugging people at random is wrong.  But above all, and I'll end with this:

I liked it.

Got there about 11:00 - 11:30ish.
 It reminded me of a PLURy Oak50 ravE from last year. Not many people there
yet but. Everyone had there possitive helmets on. I guess around 2AM, the
place was packed!
 It was pretty much a Break-Beat show down. Lots of my favorite Break-Beats
though. And fortunetly, played alittle faster than normal. Later on,
nothing but phat, dope-azz house tunes. Including one I never heard at the
ravEs before, just got the album last week. It goes alittle something -lie
-lie -like this: "SO LET IT BE WRITTEN. SO LET IT BE HOUSE" Great sample!
 Ofcourse, I already have like five of the BEST samples you will hear in
the up -n- coming years...All in my head here. Oh, and on some VCR tapes &
WAV formats. But....Can't be telling you all. Most of you probably have a
sampler already, I don't. So....You will have to wait tell I use them 1st! 
=]:..

 Oh, where was I? The place was really clean. Nice carpet-ting on the
ground level room. And a nice clean pavement down in the bassment. Warm
water =[.. Lots of candy to purchase. Clean bathrooms.
 LOW VOLUME!?!? =[

 Had to watch my back a few times for the occasional violation. I really do
need a rear-view mirror on my forehead when I am dancing.  My door don't
swing both ways. Hi Deepfog! Oh.
 Some people seemed to have thought, that five hours of my dance was
alittle to much. But I still felt good dancing so. Don't matter what they
think huh? Just because you like to watch me dance, don't mean that I am
dancing for your sake. I will stop when I wanna.
 Can you believe it...I heard someone say "Ok, that dance is getting
alittle boring now" Well. He must have been watching me dance along time to
grow such a tolorance to it.   =] I laughed at the comment ofcourse. I find
the original ones to be funny. It's thoughs played out remarks I get tired
of hearing.
 Lets face it though. The music just gets boring after awhile. My dance is
simply a reflection of that.
 Just playing.

 Man. Some DJ was playing really sloppy though. I didn't see his face but..
Pulling the needle off the record, and starting a new song? What.. Did he -
NOT want the song to fade out? So he pulled the needle off first, before
the record ended? He made everyone fear, the party was over.
 I saw the name DAN on the flyer. Is DAN the same as DJ Dan? Hmmm. I didn't
see DJ Dan though. I wasn't up at the booth train spotting I guess.

My question of the day:
Why should I have to proove myself?

Anyways. I had alot of fun. And had a great work out. Although I don't
believe my body is thanking me for it.
Oh and. Alot of my inhabilities, are becoming abilities agian.

Did that make sence? Hmm.
Great Mini-massive. Good vibe. Excellent music, tell the wee hours of the
morning, when they started sounding like "Go away songs".

Jeff
I get really disappointed in my self sometimes. But I am working on it.

go to WONDERLAND because my car died and i'm having alot of personal 
problems and she wants to see me.. i met her through raving and she has 
been there for me more than ANYONE. 
when i'm sad she'd do ANYTHING to make me smile, and i am the same. drugs 
don't even get into our friendship because we don't let drugs control 
ANYTHING of what we do. but then that's just us.

we area  group of friends, about 20 people strong (more or less) that are 
there for each other regardless of time/place/money/anything, and we call 
ourselves EBF -- east bay family. some of us (me) are in south bay, some 
aren't even IN the bay but we take care of each other and we don't 
abandon each other in times of need -- in fact, just when you think no 
one's there for you -- EBF makes you realize you are loved.
that's what our family is about, we all met each other through raving, we 
are friends that stick together, and everyone has proved this to be true 
to me since the day we all met. not ONCE have i been burned by my "rave 
friends". in fact sometimes i think they're the only ones that have never 
let me down in my life.

so..
i guess i disagree strongly with what you said about raver friends 
abandoning you when you're in need.
coz i've gotten more love and support from friends like amanda than i've 
ever even expected from ANYONE in my life.
much love,
lara

and you KNOW that i will NOT let you down.

Let me explain alittle bit further.

What I meant to ask was. I guess...

Can it pitch bend like the 303 where.. Well. I suck at talking. Anyways, I
will explain it like this.
=]:...

 With the 303. When you select a note to be played on a step. You have the
option to "slide" that note to (or through) the next step. So if you make
the following note higher or lower, it will slide to your next note
sounding like a pitch bender. You can also select "slide" on a [step]
before a [step with a note]. Making it slide into the [step with the note],
giving it a reverse sound affect.
 Plus adding alittle "Accent" here and there makes for some acid-E sounding
rythms too. You know?
 That pitch wheel is all fine and dandy but. It takes alittle programming I
think, to get the exact result I am looking for. The wheel is like bending
a guitar string. It is a "live" action. I want to slide the notes up and
down in a sequenced pattern / monotonious fassion if you will.
 I amagine you can use the pitch wheel to slide the notes while recording.
But it seems impractical & time consuming to have to figure out how far you
need to move the wheel, to get the desired "flawless / industrial" pitch
bends. Where as, with the 303 you just program how far you want the pitch
to go, by selecting the desired [following notes], after the [starting
"slide" note]. And you can even make a long "precise" wavy pitch bend by
adding the "slide" option to more steps in the chain. Compound that with
alittle accent on desired notes...
 Lets just say. I can honestly get, one tb-303 to actually sound like 3
seperate rythms within a 16step pattern with these abilities. Bassline,
rythm, and lead all in one!

 Plus. With that pitch wheel. Lets say you slide it up. Unfortunetly with a
pitch wheel..What goes up, must come down. Or vice-aversa. But with the 303
you can slide it up, back down a bit, then up really high, keep it there
for awhile, drop it to a D flat, and back up to an A sharp with alittle
Accent in the middle of the bend, and so on.  Without having to figure out
how far to move some wheel to get the right note every time. Oh.

Is the JP-8000 limited in this way? 
Perhaps the LFO2 option is what I am looking for?
I am making little sence, I know. Like usual nStuff.


Jeff
Any more info?

Oh, we (me and my crew) were sooooooo juiced about Wonderland . . .

Then:
1.  7:30 p.m. we left Sacramento over 1 hour late cuz a friend was running 
very late
2.  9:30 p.m. we got lost (ended up in Oakland)
3.  10:00 p.m. we got lost again (this time in SF, had to ask for directions 
to map point)
4.  10:20 p.m. Faster Bamboo, where I was told I could pick up my reserved 
presales and directions to the party, was CLOSED!!!
5.  10:30 p.m. The voice mail, which was supposed to be updated at 9pm, wasn't 
updated!
6.  11:30 p.m. We looked for another party (supposedly taking place on 540 
Howard), no sign of a party there.
7.  11:45 p.m.Updated Wonderland voice mail gave directions to a new map 
point, but we were already lost and decided to go to a party in Oakland
8.  11:55 p.m. We were split up into 2 cars . . . we lost the other car 
(directions inside)
9.  12:30 a.m.  No money, no phone cards, couldn't call the other car, 
couldn't check voice mail . . . we were stuck in downtown Oakland again
10.  1:00 a. m. Remainder of us went home (Sacramento) and tried to go to a 
party in Sacramento
11. 3:30 a. m. Sac party was in the boonies . . . ran out of gas (thankfully 
near a gas station)
12.  5 a.m.--Forget it!  We just went home so we could get some sleep and go 
to High Noon tomorrow.

Moral of the Story:  Something about leaving early, which we should know by 
now

DRAMA!!!

But the good thing is I gotta whole lotta Pixie Stix and Tootsie Pops leftover 
(since I never got to a party) to hand out at _Alternate_ (Sac rave, w/ jungle 
and house . . . what more could you ask for).

Hope you all had fun . . . all in all, I did (what an adventure) . . . how was 
the party?  I know it had to be good . . . :'-(

xoxo--Miccaela

From: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: wonderland review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Well, it started off great. Good music, and a good vibe building.
Well, unfortunately when we came to the door, we were late enough to have
missed the map point, but as we began to ask if we could buy tickets there,
they suddenly let us in for free. We went upstairs and saw some decent
music, and a good vibe thick in the air for about 3 minutes when the lights
came on and the music stopped. We were herded into the back rooms and told
to be quiet(I guess to calm the cops). Then they handed out candy. I was
trying to figure out the logic, giving sugar to people told to be quiet. Oh
well. They then told us about 20 minutes later(a whole lot of sitting, but
meeting new people all the same)that the party would start again shortly. 5
Minutes after that, nope, but there would be an alternate party at a certain
location which they gave us. We went there to find a dead end. We hung
around for 2 hours as others showed up, quite a bit really, dancing around a
car stereo. It's interesting to see about 40 people grooving at a dead end
in freezing cold SF winds which were sweeping off the bay to a quiet car
stereo. But they danced on the nearby flatbed trailers and it was all silly.
Me and my friends played tag and goofed off. We then decided to leave, but
in good time as we saw the cops roll past us to this other gathering.

        While we sat around the room and were told to be quiet, I got the
image of Jews in Nazi Germany. It was that crazy. They then said, "You can
go into the other room, but have to sit down because the cops might see your
shadows. Whoa, they sure are buckling down on those 'tenderloin' district
raves. I mean c'mon, don't they have better things to do? While we walked
back to the car(thanks again Rebel)we were offered weed twice and heroin
once. Now that seems like much more to worry about to me. Sheesh.

        -chris

At 1:06 AM -0400 6/22/97, lara at vibe.org wrote:
>i would have to disagree about raver friends..
>i'm not sure what kind of crowd you are talking about, but my friends in
>the scene have done more for me than anyone in my life.
>amanda, is on her way from SF right now (11 fucking pm) to pick me up to
>go to WONDERLAND because my car died and i'm having alot of personal
>problems and she wants to see me.. i met her through raving and she has
>been there for me more than ANYONE.
>when i'm sad she'd do ANYTHING to make me smile, and i am the same. drugs
>don't even get into our friendship because we don't let drugs control
>ANYTHING of what we do. but then that's just us.
>
BEWARE...  It is very easy to fool yourself that you have control over
drugs.  I hope that some day you do not find that control slip out from
under you before you know it.  It has happened to some of my least
suspecting acquaintances.  Control with drugs is a facade.  People take
drugs to lose control.  That's the trill.  And if any of you should ever
fall at the mercy of those drugs, I do hope that you'll be there for each
other.  I cannot say that this has been my experience, nor the experience
of anyone I know.  Have you ever dealt with a drug addicted individual?  A
person you thought you knew can become a complete stranger and very
difficult to deal with.  Good luck to anyone who is even remotely involved
with drugs.  Don't overestimate yourself; don't underestimate drugs.

>we area  group of friends, about 20 people strong (more or less) that are
>there for each other regardless of time/place/money/anything, and we call
>ourselves EBF -- east bay family. some of us (me) are in south bay, some
>aren't even IN the bay but we take care of each other and we don't
>abandon each other in times of need -- in fact, just when you think no
>one's there for you -- EBF makes you realize you are loved.
>that's what our family is about, we all met each other through raving, we
>are friends that stick together, and everyone has proved this to be true
>to me since the day we all met. not ONCE have i been burned by my "rave
>friends". in fact sometimes i think they're the only ones that have never
>let me down in my life.

Well, I hope that this remains true after the party is over.  I, too, had a
close knit group of rave friends.  The group fell apart for me when I
stopped raving so much and found that without that central focus of the
party, I had less in common with them than I thought.  If you feel your
group is different, then more power to you.  I have had several private
responses from people who strongly agreed with me & found it comforting to
know that they are not alone in their sad realization of who they can and
cannot count on.  I would never wish abandonment on anyone, but I would
have liked to have been more aware of the possibility of it.  I am not
telling anyone that all your friends are going to leave you.  Just be
prepared for it.  Examine your friendships.  If you find little to talk
about other than the rave, get ready for possible disappointment.  This is
not to say that you or your friends are bad people if this happens.  It is
a fact of every one's life, whether they are raving or not.
Disappointments occur.  I, simply, am a person who likes to hope for the
best and prepare for the worst.  My story is being told in hopes of
providing just a bit of insight to possible outcomes.
>
>so..
>i guess i disagree strongly with what you said about raver friends
>abandoning you when you're in need.

How can you disagree with my experiences?  They are very personal to me and
I am quite sure that they happened.  If you have had different experiences,
then state them as your own.  Please do not try to override my statements
with yours.  I have not spoken as the representative of a larger group.  I
only stated what I know I have experienced.  I suggest you do the same.
You have projected a certainty about the future of your friendships and
this is dangerous.  Not that they will necessarily turn out as mine did,
but I do not advise banking on the future.  It can turn on you when you
least expect it.

>coz i've gotten more love and support from friends like amanda than i've
>ever even expected from ANYONE in my life.
>much love,
>lara
>
Love and support from friends should be expected.  I hope your friends have
raised your expectations of people and you should keep those expectations
high, even with people outside of the rave community.  I think that is a
major problem in our society; we do not hold one another to very high
standards.  If change & evolution is in order, we must take greater
responsibility for ourselves and our community.  We cannot control other's
actions, but we can speak out on them.  If you have been hurt, do not allow
the person who hurt you to get away without expressing yourself about it.
This is something I actively work on in myself and have found that open
communication is the key to personal, relational & societal advancement.
But everyone must have their say.  Please don't exclude non-ravers from
this, because you might just be surprised who ends up really being there
for you.

>and you KNOW that i will NOT let you down.

And how do I KNOW that?

O.k. Gang:

Here is the info that I recieved in a fax from the promotions agency for
Citi:Zen:

The Big Top Tour

Moby, LTJ Bukem, Banco de Gaia, 808 State, Eat Static, Ed Rush,
Empirion, Fabio, Grooverider, Headrillaz, Jason Bently, Joey Beltram,
Juan Atkins, Kevin Saunderson, Logical Progression (LTJ Bukem, DJ Blame,
MC Conrad, Dr. S. Gachet and others), Loop Guru, Liquid Todd, Michael
Dog, Nico, Scott Hardkiss, System 7, DJ Trace, etc.

plus date will feature some of the best local DJs from the region.
It is will feature 3 main stages:

1) The logical Progression stage featuring the best drum and bass talent
from the UK Based label (good lookin' and lookin' good I'm sure)
2) the MegaDog Stage providing a diverse eclectic forum for electronica
3) The Big Top Stage which will feature premier names from the UK club
Culture (808 state etc...)

It will have a 10 date run in 8,000+ capacity venues.

September 12th in San Francisco!
Sept. 13 in L.A.

I'll post more info as I get it.

Rob.
rwpointer@citiscape.com

A fwd post from my friend Ebi, of the Friday night shin-dig at the

----------
> Date: Sunday, June 22, 1997 11:05:20 
> From: dj ebi
> To: 96fa295@dvc.edu	
> Subject: my review.....
> 
> well I dont know what all these people were talking about. If they don't
know 
> who ninja tunes are and what they do then, tell them to send me their
twenty 
> bucks and I'll make them a tape of all the different styles they
encompass.
> JUST KIDDING! :-P
>
> I thought the party went off. Yes shoulder to shoulder, but if you can't
dance 
> to music- any kind of music, get off the floor.
> I was a bit let down with Funky Porcini. although his set consisted of
some 
> of his classic tracks, he's definitley better in the studio than on the 
> tables.His music varies in tempo so much anyhow that it has much more
meaning 
> if you can just follow the rhythms, and enjoy it for its musical sense.
> The highlights of the night had to be Amon Tobin, and the guys from Up 
> Bustle&... With all three of them going off at the same time. It was like 
> clock work. Amon aka Cujo has to be the most inovative junglist there is
right 
> now. Although many of his tracks get labeled experimental, they always
have a 
> dark twist. Much props to the people who stayed through the dark stuff.
some 
> of it was so hard I expected to see a mosh pit form. 
> 	All the meanwhile scrathing was a main theme through the night. Enhancing
> all the music from, hip hop to jungle and even funk. To all the turntable 
> technisions out there this was a real treat. The music played was so good
that 
> if you weren't into all the tricks you could just enjoy the treats and
get 
> your groove on.
> In the small room a constant dancable beats. I believe these were the
local 
> DJs. I didn't spend to much time in there, but each time I ventured it
was 
> always full of people lovin it.
> 	Another highlight of the night was the toilet upstairs filled to the rim
> with brim, because of people using the Lucky Strikes napkins that don't
flush. 
> Always a party pleaser! 
> anyway....................... 
>                              ebi

To: mayer@netcom.com, stuff@hooked.net
Subject: Re: Musical Question
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Is the JP-8000 limited in this way?

	It sounds like what you're looking for would be the monophonic
legato mode on the JP-8000. Make your sound monophonic with the "mono"
button, then turn on legato mode with the shift key & the "mono" button
simultaneously. Turn on portamento & set your glide rate with the portamento
wheel.

 	Now play a note, then play a second note without letting go
of the first note until the second one is down. The sound will slide
up to the pitch of the second note without retriggering any envelopes,
sounds like a pitch bend.

Hi everyone, here's my little review of the moST FabuLous TIME
I've ever had!!!! it was aMAazzzinggg!!,

ok, so Eric and I get there around 7pm to help setup, we do some 
stuff, blah blah blah..then someone comes up to me and tells me
that I have to pay $5 bucks or else I have to go to the map point
and get a ticket or something like that...am all "AS-IF!!", so I paid
(or rather someone paid for me, thanks Duston! ;) I owe you $$$)
and went on my merry way...  the decorations where BEAUTIFUL!!!
I specially loved the signs that had different directions on them,
pretty confusing, but cute :) everything was nicenicenice :) the
peps where all cute and beautiful and nice :)

THE MUSIC WAS RAD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
VLAD has a really really really nice Set! I really enjoyed dancing to
the stuff he was playing :) the highlight of my night was INDIGO! (Hi
Philip!) his set was soooo RAD that I fainted for a sec or two ;) 
thank you so much for having such a good set :) 

THen the music stopped, the lights went on, but I was still smilin'
and having a lot of fun! :) after a few hours we all left :( tried
to find out where I was goin' and who my ride was going to be!, we
all went to the supposedly meeting place called 3COM park in SF.
got there,it was Freezzzing, not many peps. I jumped on someone else's
car and went to 7-11 for a few mins to get something to eat, when I 
came back..all the cars where gone... I guess my RIDE decided to leave
without me. Thanks Guys! I really enjoyed being stranded in the city!
[*hugs*]...got back in the car went to the other location on 24th and
Illinoi, no music yet... no sign of my ride :( [*sigh*] Anyhow, to make
a story short...

* brought Peanut Butter and Jelly sandwiches for everyone!
* it was Freeezzzing!
* The Music was ROcking (LI's and MICRON'S SET WHERE DA BOMB!!!!!!)
* the music went out cause the thingy ran out of gas.. :o/
* we decide to make a bon fire.. :) (me, jer and betsy's idea!) ;)
* the thingy brakes after pputting gas in it. :(
* McGyver managed to fix it, the music was pumping again! :)
* the SFPD showed up :( a few hours after
* decided we should all go to TallPaul's house (all the peps that hadnt
left cause they were stranded basically)
* waited 3 hours for someone to come rescue us.
* on the way to Paul's we ran out of gas.

:O) and I've had a BLAST!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Hellos to: FairyPrincess, Russ, Betzy, Paul#1, Paul#2, CuddleMeZoey,
April, Philip1,Philip2, Rod, Eric, Rema, Rubilicious!, Boomerang(Peter),
DeepFog(Tony), Dan, Alex, Jupiter, Macadio, Jeremy1, Jeremy2,Derik,
Aaron, Jess, Fernando (THANKS so much for the ride!),
frost, etc etc etc etc....

[*HUGS*]
PabloPop in state of exhaustion.

From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net>
Subject: R.I.P. Ameba, you were the BOMB!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I gotta give some props to the Ameba crew in all it's variations;

Shouts to Mark Ameba, Alan, and all past and future Amebites, including
Andrew & Mattie B. (the only two that come to mind, there are
others)(Anybody remember Acme Acres?).

This store was RAVE CENTRAL before all the me-too's moved into town (This
includes Behind the Post Office, Housewares, BulletProof, etc.)  Ameba at
one time was THE place to go and not only get good mix tapes (the only
other store was BPM at the time) and stay in touch with the scene (the only
place was Ameba, BPM was all about DJ's and DJ' culture...).  You could
find out about anything and everything going on in all of this.

They will be missed as Haight street goes through  what the rest of this
city is going through; a massive white out.   Gentrification at all costs.
As this city slowly loses it's color and it's flavor, Ameba is just another
sign of things to come, on all levels.  Rave hasn't changed, it's just been
replaced by rampant commercialism and dollars.

Enough of my soapbox.  See y'all later Ameba, you will be missed.  Haight
street has lost one of it's most orignal and most flavorful tennants.  This
city is slowly starting to suck.

Farewell and much luck to all the Amebites, great and small!

Much love,
John

P.S.  Watch as Hunter's point turns pale.  As the mission begins it's
massive transormation from the center of latin culture to yuppie south
where the only other language spoken is that of money; spanish will nary be
heard except for the multitude of bad tapas joints open up so that yuppies
and other bay area crawlers gobble for flavor; too bad, you chased it out
since it was all "undesireable".  As this wonderful multi-cultural city
begins it's transformation into one dull and boring place.  Where even my
gay brothers will be monotone.  I certainly expect over the next decade
that SF will elect it's first Republicans into the supervisors seats, and
as the Great Sellout Willie Brown sells this city to the highest bidder
(and yes, I voted for the asshole).  Hold on tight, this will be one long
slow ride into boredom.

ABC-YA!

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL18.199706230219090489@msn.com>
To: "funkateers" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: High Noon (sacramento event)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey folx, just went to my first _High Noon_, a semi-regular Sacramento daytime 
outdoors party . . . it was bomb.  Anybody looking to kick back, dance, and 
listen to good music (DJ Flash, I think his name is, was pretty good today) on 
a Sunday afternoon should come out.  I saw a fellow sfraver out there (Hi 
Scott), and all the people were beautiful and friendly.  This time (there was 
a new location today) it was out by Mather, by this little lake/pond, in the 
middle of a field . . . lots of thorny stuff, but a really nice breeze coming 
off the lake.

It looks like the event is kinda small, cuz I think there was about 50 people 
there.  I don't know why that is, because it's FREE and they have FREE WATER 
AND PUNCH.  The next one is July 6th, the info # is 916.603.0772, so come out 
and support your local rave crew (SRC) and djs.

Just some tips if you go:  1.  Bring your own water and drinks, cuz there's a 
limited supply  2.  Bring stuff to keep you cool (visors, spray bottles, ice, 
shorts)  3.  Put on insect repellant  4.  Bring blankets and chairs to sit on. 
 5.  Go the bathroom before you come (there are _no_ bathrooms).  This is what 
me and my friends did and we had a blast (even the nonravers loved it).

Come on out!  I'm planning on attending the next one.  Oh, and see you at 
_Alternate_ here in Sac Saturday night (it's on the calendar if you want to 
check it out).

xoxo--Miccaela
battling for the most frequent poster award . . . but hey, I keep it pretty 
much rave related or list related, so I ain't planning on slowing up . . .

add this thread to the sfraves "dumbest conversations/threads"
---------------------
Forwarded message:
From:	jsl@nexsys.net (John S. Lee)
Sender:	sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
To:	sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: 97-06-22 01:32:35 EDT

After this "I'm a raver not clubber thread"  I started to think of some of
the other dumb threads we've participated in.  The raver/clubber thread
will top the list for now but I remember:

-Battle of the BPM boneheads
-Why can't people dance freely thread (i.e. why do some people take up so
much space)
-PLUR
-Dancing styles (cricle dancing vs "real" dancing)
-gansgtah threads ad nauseum
-Promoters you love to hate, but won't tell 'em to thier face
-east coast vs west coast (yep, we did that too)
-and the ubiquitous "I love you all!" posts (It's like when someone says I
love all humanity...does that mean the mass murderers too?), smiles, and
hugz dreck.
-How come nobody hugz me at parties
-GHB is a good thing
-All drugs are good

Now don't get me wrong, even my pompous ass has participated in a few of
these (if not all ;)).

The next few years ought to prove interesting as I expect more and more
ridiculous posts.

Oh yeah, as I expected, the NRR posts are back in full force.  To coin a
phrase from the Right Reverend Martin O'Brian "The circle is now complete".
Back to deleting everything.  Oh how I wish for moderation, how I wish for
massive filtering, how I long for clear conversation, and how I hate that
slogannering PLUR.

PLUR sux.

HUGZ and sweet saccharin kisses and aspartame dreams, I wish glitter and
lollipops and teddy bears and good things to you all.  Personally I wish
someone would wish me Martha Stewart in full leather, can we make a slogan
out of that.  Good things for Bad People?

PLURBLES, HUGZ, FUZZY THINGS, BUBBLES and BLISSFULLBLISS...god I want to
throw up,
John

P.S.  Anything else you want to add to the list.  I would like to add this
post as one before someone else does so there. ;)

Cc: pengo@ten.net, jer@best.com

Precedence: bulk

...And only one person drank my soy milk.  [sniff]

Don't you all know about that mad cow disease?

Well from my vantage point the WonderCrew did a wonderful job and then they
had the courage to move the party to the secret alternate spot.  That is
where Jeremy brought...doughnuts?!  Wow.

Never fear folx.  One day we will conquer the law enforcement threat to our
movement.  Just hang tight, and please try to avoid being one of those
people 5 years from now that just say "oh, i did that rave thing for a
while." i've been busy talking to a lot of people that are out partying
nowadays, and i am delighted to hear the aspirations for the future some of
the current rave crews have.  You know when I was sitting there observing
some of these police officers trying to gather information from each of us
at the dance studio that were out in the lobby, there was one taller police
officer that almost looked like...he didn't want to break up the party.
Had sort of a sadness in his eyes.

Oh, but that can't be true.

[blake]  remember how tony robbins always says that humans seek pleasure?
well, i observed the cops leaving the secret alternate spot, which was
outdoors on the bay side, and one of the cops did a donut.  with the car
that WE paid for.  so you see, the cops are really no different from us.
they seek pleasure.  they probably get a sense of accomplishment from
knowing that they cleared out a bunch of whacky looking kids with nose
rings and blue hair so that they can sit and write a report somewhere under
a freeway overpass.  but then we indulged in the pleasure of engulfing
Jeremy's donuts (did you make those yourself, Jeremy?) and giving each
other lots of hugz and other related stuff.

you see, i almost had as much fun just hanging out in the parking lot after
the party was over with (prematurely, i might add) as hanging out at the
party.

so, all i would have to say to tony robbins, is...yOU'RE rIGHT!

chakra

but he just plays his dat tapes and dances around like a psycho
at the "climax" of his warfield show he stripped down
yelling at the top of his lungs and made the christ pose
it would be one thing if he made his tunes live

than the tracks on cd
but anyway it was always really disapointing
i was embarassed for him at the warfield

hi all.  We had two gas cans that we borrowed for the renegate 
wonderland afterparty, but both of them are missing!  I don't know who 
either of them belong to, but somebody walked off with one of them 
without permission, and I (duh) put one down next to my car and was so 
tired that I drove off without it.  I'm dumb, sue me.

can anyone who knows who these gas cans belong to or who knows who has 
them now please contact me so I can get them back to the rightful 
owners?  Thank you!

gas, transported equiptment, set up, and ***especially*** to Dan and the 
Magyver-esque guy who fixed the generator when it broke.  You guys are 
wonderful and we love you!

Off to sleep I go...

Hey man...

First of all, being anal isn't to cool when you're cutting down the 
promoters who worked hella hard and put thier ass's on the line to put on 
all these cool parties for us...

Second of all...and I don't really know the answer to this question but 
maybe someone does...is there really any legal party permit for raves...I 
kinda doubt it...

I kinda have to agree with Star here...like I said when I left the party 
"isn't there like someone murdered in the US every ten seconds?..." I'm 
not blaming the SFPD...it's thier job...I just think the whole thing is 
kinda rediculas. Drugs and all aside...we're having a party...not 
bothering or hurting anoyone...just celebrating life I guess...I don't 
know...but should that be against the law...I don't think so.


Anyway...I'll stop now.

Stay cool everyone!

Matt

Wow!...once again another crazy evening in the SFraves scene. Well, I 
thought the wonder crew did a great job in setting up, the place looked 
wonderful, and the vibe was awsome as usual. AndyW was dropping some phat 
beats in the main room and then as we all know of course...the bomb 
dropped. Yet, the party must go on! So we waited out in the freezing 
cold and kept the vibe just as high as it was back in the dance studio. I 
must say It felt soooo awsome to be a part of that vibe, (even thought I 
had to sit in the car have the time to dethaw :P.) Anyway...studio or no 
studio...SFPD or no....well, I guess not...anyway I had an AWSOME time. 
Except for the fact that ONCE AGAIN, I didn't get to see macadio 
spin...this is starting to get on my nerves *8^)

Gotta give mad-phat-love to everyone there, and especially all the great 
new friends I made, you guys are SUPERAWSOME, and I can't wait to see you 
all at the next event!

To keep it short...

Staaaaayyy Cooool!

Matt - the other one

Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.95.970623005133.8195A-100000@nodserv.mpath.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Mon, 23 Jun 1997, Matthew Alan Schwartz wrote:
> On Sun, 22 Jun 1997, Mr nStuff wrote:
> > Cops are out to up-hold the law. It's not there fault if the promoters
> > don't follow big brothers rules.
> > 
> Second of all...and I don't really know the answer to this question but 
> maybe someone does...is there really any legal party permit for raves...I 
> kinda doubt it...
...
> bothering or hurting anoyone...just celebrating life I guess...I don't 
> know...but should that be against the law...I don't think so.
> 

It's extremely unlikely that the bust was for "raving".  The constitution
has been limited in other ways - "peaceful assembly" has _numbers_
attached to it nowadays, and especially for commercial events, there are
county, city, and state laws regarding venue capacity, insurance, and fire
codes.  Some parties we have even had to hire Seattle police to work the
door or they would have busted the party (even though we did buy
insurance, and did pass fire code - and yes the inspector managed to make
it to almost every rave venue and he always collected his little fee)...
Also, I wasn't at wonderland so I don't know what when down exactly, but
sometimes things like noise reports, drive by seeing 30 kids on a sidewalk
most of whom are 12, anonymous phone calls from the vast array of narcs
that for some reason call police about everything for whatever their
whacked in the head motives are, etc etc etc.

  Things happen, but I really can't agree that someone is cracking down on
"raving" just to stop fun.  If a cop or group of cops are looking to bust
something, odds are they aren't looking at the party, but they are there
for the conditions (fire permits and sh*t) following up from a report of
noise level, drugs, underage kids, permits, etc.  I think it's a
perspective thing.  I'd like to say I'd rather police never came to raves
or paid attention, but you know what, I'd be awefully *glad* they were
around if I saw a fellow raver overdose or get seriously hurt or (forbid)
there actually ever was a fire at a show (anyone ever see a fire at a
rave?) you know what I mean?  Same thing with door security at big
parties, they seem to suck, but overall it makes sense that they pat for
weapons, and take markers...

hope i didn't just open myself for mass flame damage,
love,
Max

I'm from the Seattle scene... sorry if that sounded totally weird when I
wrote that, I was refering back to parties we through where we had to cut
a check to the PD for services rendered - we wrote "extortion money" on
the comment line at the bottom of the check.  Our attitude then was that
we didn't see why we had to pay _them_ instead of our own people just to
keep from being busted.  Their reasoning was the size of the parties
warrented the presence .. like seeing parades or other large gatherings,
there are always police

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>

I'm going to make a comment about how I enjoy some of the stupid threads on 
sfraves, and if something pops up that I don't want to read (like all that 
techy 303 stuff that wasn't stupid, but just over my head and generally 
uninteresting to me), then I just delete it and don't whine about it . . . I 
figure I'll have to deal with a bunch of folx telling me about how they 
shouldn't have to do that and blah blah blah, and perhaps you're right, but I 
can honestly say I don't care.  Sorry.  Not trying to be bitchy, just letting 
you know how it is w/ me, my way or the highway and all that (ain't I PLURy?). 
 

And I'd have to say that the dumbest thread I ever saw was the one that was 
real popular when I first subbed, the thread that went something like:
"I like to kiss other girls at parties in front of my boyfriend"
"I hate it when guys come up to me when I'm kissing other girls at parties and 
try to 'get in on the action'"
"just because I like to make out w/ members of the same sex at parties doesn't 
mean I'm homosexual"
"everybody (is/isn't) gay to some degree"
It was dumb, but entertaining.  I laughed my ass off at some of the, shall we 
say, creative logic behind a lot of the posts.

This "dumb conversation" thread is pretty stupid, and pointless too (cuz we're 
still going to have plenty of nrr and other stuff no matter what anyone says). 
 But I participated in the whole astrology thread too, so of course I had to 
participate in this one too.

Part of life is having to deal w/ stuff you don't like.  Why should I (or you) 
expect the list be any different?  I'd sometimes consider complaining about 
all the drug and tech threads, but just because I can't really relate to them 
and I'm not interested in them really doesn't give me the right to censor 
them.  So I kept my mouth shut (until now, sorry) and just made use of my 
delete button.  Because who the hell am I to judge?  You know what they say 
about glass houses . . .

To sum it up:  You may not like what someone else posts.  Chances are they 
could say the same about your posts.  You both could be perfectly justified in 
your disapproval.  So what's easier:  to just delete the uninteresting, 
irrevelant (make that uninteresting and irrelevent to _you_), or to waste a 
lot of bandwidth and time (yours and everyone else's) by complaining about it 
(because nothings going to change).  Well, I think the answer is pretty 
obvious, although it doesn't seem like that to everyone.

Like right now, I'm wasting plenty of bandwidth and time.  But I do that 
regularly, so it's no biggie for me (well, I think most of the stuff I post is 
RR or SFRR, but I'm sure someone can tell me different).  So most of the time 
I keep my mouth shut when others do it, but I just couldn't resist a little 
venting this time.  Had to show you all that you're living in a glass house 
just like mine, cuz I get a big ego boost out of telling people off and being 
patronizing and all that.  What can I say, I gots issues and stuff.

You know me.  Always gotta put my 2 cents in.  I'd apologize but I'm not 
really sorry about doing it and I don't plan on stopping it.  And like I 
always say, I could be wrong.  But I'm pretty sure I'm not this time and it'd 
be hard to convince me otherwise.

xoxo--Miccaela
writing her first bitter and inflammatory post in a while and feeling damn 
satisfied
