From: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>
Subject: Beatmatching Digitally, also RR
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Niels vomits:
>PS: don't let the vinyl wankers start telling you that you can't
>possibly beat match w/ CD's. They're all full of shit. However, you
>can't beat-match well unless you have a decent CD-players. Even though
>CD DJ mixers have been out for a few years, the pioneers where the
>first product that didn't suck.


What he isn't telling you here (because he obviously doesn't know any
better) is that they mostly SUCK under rave conditions. I've been mixing on
Pioneer CDJ-500's since 1995, and many of the experiences I've had/heard
playing at events has been one form of trouble or another. They're fine for
your studio, bedroom, or playing *small* renegades or clubnights... But
when you have to play on a larger/louder soundsystem, you're in for a ride
that doesn't always end happily.

I was actually unable to mix at a peak slot this very weekend, at an event
that I have been looking forward to for months, because the sound was loud
enough and bassy enough so that the CDJ's COULDN'T TRACK THE DISCS... I'm
standing there, with the CDJ's on perfectly levelled cinderblock stacks,
I'm ready to go on, and they won't even give me a fucking reading. I missed
my set because of them. I couldn't play. The conditions were pretty close
to optimal as far as the physical setup of the decks goes, the person who
rigged them has consulted with pioneer on the proper way to go about
this... It still didn't work. In order for me to have played, I would have
had to QUARTER the volume to get the CDJ's to track. Needless to say, I was
pissed...

I'm NOT a vinyl "wanker", as Neils says in his tiring childish arrogance.
The *point* is this: The 1200's stand up like mack trucks. It comes down to
craftsmanship. The CDJ's, and believe me I love them, are made rather
unsturdily. They are totally fragile, and they have a TON of things that
can all too easily go wrong on you. The loading doors on them wear out, the
lasing unit needs to be kept really clean, the buttons that control vital
functions wear out easily and lose contact... Essentially they are not
built to survive raves yet. I'd like to see the cd-dj's petition Technics
to make one as sturdy as the 1200's...

I've also seen them fuck up on other dj's as well, in a variety of
rave/club conditions. Once again, Neils doesn't seem to have any experience
other than his bedroom... And he passes off his knowledge with this
arrogance and rudeness that is somewhat sickening...

The other issue about them is this: (not mentioned probably due to a
further lack of experience)... You can hold a mix for longer (without
touching it) on the 1200's if you are good enough. The reason is because
the pitch adjustment on CDJ's is digital, and it counts only to one-tenth
decimal place. In other words, you can get either +6.5 or +6.6. If you
nudge it just right you can get it to waver between the two, but when
you're dealing with the milleseconds between what is "on" and "off" beat,
it isn't enough. You have to constantly keep one hand on them to compensate
for this. If Pioneer added one more decimal place (a hundredths point) it
might help a little. On a 1200, because it is not digital, you can get as
close as your patience, time and skill allows.

Wait a while on the CDJ's if you're planning to play events with larger
soundsystems, Pioneer just doesn't have the design worked out all that well
yet. I'm hopeful, because otherwise they are kickass machines, and a LOT of
fun to use. If you're hacking out your own tracks, the primary benefit is
that you can buy a CDR and mix your own "dubplates". Being digital, they
also sound fucking awesome, but when they skip, it's far worse than when a
record skips. For now, I'm going to start buying vinyl again. Ya just can't
trust 'em.

-Joshua

 "Tue, 24 Jun 97 00:35:58 PDT."             <33AF78DE.392@sirius.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:42:48 -0700
To: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lola*mar <lola@cloudfactory.org>
Subject: a few words about constructive posts and being nice by laura
 lamar and matt cantu
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

matt cantu and i are pals and co.workers who have noticed a mess o
dissention on this list lately and have the following advice to offer,
should you choose to accept it.....

o  please do not read every response to your posts as if it is a personal
attack on you.  just because someone's opinion is different than yours does
not mean that they are attacking you.  imagine if you will, laura and matt
hard at work at salinas.net.  laura gasps in exasperation as her mac
crashes for the umpteenth time in an hour, and she utters, "i hate macs."
matt hears this from his desk across the room and says, "oh yeah, well i
hate pcs!"  laura looks at matt in her fit of annoyance and snaps, "oh yeah
well i hate you!"  this sounds pretty ridiculous, does it not?  i mean the
fact matt likes macs and laura doesn't is no reason for laura not to like
matt.  she may not understand why he prefers macs over pcs, but his
preferences have not a whole lot to do with the matt laura knows as a
person, and simply because he may disagree with her on that particular
point does not mean he has something against her as human being.  not
everyone is going to agree.  please take the time to exercise some of the
_understanding_ and _respect_ so heavily dashed into the plur closing of
many of our emails....

o  think before you speak.  give yourself some time to cool off over
something that initially might have upset you.  "i have so many posts i
have never sent after cooling down [and re.reading them]."   we often will
respond to one little word that tacks itself onto our psyche and overlook
the entire meaning in a message as we are too fixated on that one word or
phrase which set us off.  please take the time to recognize that this is
something we all do and try to combat it.  it impacts the list and everyone
on it and it oftens leads threads completely astray and debases them into a
public flame war.

o  avoid name calling, even in jest.  a lot is lost in translation in
communication via email i.e. body language and voice inflection.  therefore
it is easy to misinterpret what may have been meant as a tongue in cheek
comment.  please "say what you mean and mean what you say"....also things
like this sucks and that sucks rarely do anyone any good.  rather than
blatently condemn something, maybe give another alternative to that
something.  for example, let's say matt and i are having a conversation
about mixers, and he suggests a numark.  if i didn't want us to reach some
sort of consensus on what our group wanted to buy, i might simply say,
"numarks suck for this reason and that reason and blah blah blah," but
since we both want to learn from the discussion so as to actually
accomplish something, i should say, "i don't like numarks because of the
cross fader but this pioneer looks kinda neat because i hear it's
crossfader is pretty solid and look at all of the channels on this thing!"

which brings me to another point:  are we trying to help eachother and
learn from eachother or are we trying to feed our own hungry egos by
one.upping and downsizing others?

just some stuff to think about.

love,
lola

"divide add multiply and understand."

       ^ V ^ i r t u a l   D e s i g n e r
_______./_\.______lola@cloudfactory.org_____________ 



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 24 13:45:34 1997

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id NAA09407;
	Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:45:34 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from eat.organic.com (h10.n145.organic.com [204.152.145.10])
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id NAA09370
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:45:24 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from brianb.organic.com (brianb.organic.com [207.76.136.136]) by eat.organic.com (8.8.3/8.6.12) with SMTP id NAA25461 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:48:38 -0700 (PDT)

Date: Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:45:03 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net> (by way of Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>)
Subject: Internet drug references receive media backlash
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
X-MIME-Autoconverted: from quoted-printable to 8bit by hyperreal.com id NAA09370
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From Monday's edition of Salon:

The New York Times' reefer madness

 In a shocking article, the newspaper of record reveals that many Net users
     are deviating from officially mandated Just Say No drug rhetoric!

                              BY DANIEL RADOSH
                          -------------------------

Readers of the New York Times might assume that front page stories are
selected on the basis of newsworthiness. Occasionally, however, the paper
gives an article prominent play in order to advance a cultural agenda (or,
more cynically, to prove that it still has the clout to do so). Last month
the Times-manufactured fuss over heroin chic led all the way to a lip-biting
announcement from President Clinton.

Last Friday, the Times was at it again with an article headlined, "A
Seductive Drug Culture Flourishes on the Internet." To the paper's credit,
this topic is at least not hopelessly pass. It is even worthy of serious
coverage. But as with the heroin chic story, objective reporting here takes
a back seat to middlebrow fear-mongering. Given the confluence of two of
America's favorite boogeymen (drugs and the Internet -- together at last!),
there is no doubt that this too is a story with legs.

The article, by Christopher S. Wren, begins like this: "Even as parents,
teachers and government officials urge adolescents to say no to drugs ..."

Parents! Teachers! Government officials! Wren expeditiously establishes
societal order, then proceeds to shatter it, thus creating a sense of threat
that pervades the entire article.

"... the Internet is burgeoning as an alluring bazaar ..."

A bazaar! People are buying drugs over the Internet! Well, not quite. It
eventually becomes apparent that this bazaar mostly "sells" ideas. And the
occasional hemp baseball cap.

"... where anyone with a computer ..."

And a modem, of course, but Wren's on a roll here.

"... can find out how to get high on LSD, eavesdrop on what it is like to
take heroin or cocaine, check the going price for marijuana, or copy the
chemical formula for methamphetamine, the stimulant better known as speed."

Scary, huh? But it's hard to see how any of the above rates as "alluring."
Chemical formulas are no more seductive on the Web than they are in library
books (which, for the record, also contain such information). Checking the
price of marijuana is more likely to scare off the curious than anything
else ($400 an ounce? Are you fucking kidding me?). And as for "find[ing] out
how to get high on LSD": Um, take it, right?

The mood established, Wren goes on:

"Teen-agers need only retreat to their rooms, boot up the computer and click
on a cartoon bumblebee named Buzzy to be whisked on line ..."

People familiar with the Internet, of course, will know that one must
already be online before Buzzy appears. Indeed in order to find Buzzy, one
first must first do a search for something along the lines of "hemp, pot,
bong, wasted, dude," and then travel, of one's own volition, to the site
where Buzzy lives. The many millions of Times readers who are not Net savvy,
however, can be forgiven for picturing a scene like this: Little Tommy turns
on his computer for a relaxing game of Duke Nuke 'Em when he suddenly sees a
seductively alluring little bee. Out of curiosity, he clicks on it and is
whisked (whisked? on the Web?!) to ...

"... a mail-order house ..."

That's right, mail-order. Wren describes two sites that advertise books,
paraphernalia and, in one exceptional case, actual pot seeds, but he does
not make clear that you can't actually purchase this stuff online. Teenagers
who want their own hydroponics set-up can get an address off the Web, but
then they must unretreat from their rooms, find stamps, write a check and so
on, just as if they'd gotten the info from the back of Rolling Stone. Wren
acknowledges that drug chat on the Web "would be nothing new to a high
school or college bull session, but face-to-face contact can help
adolescents evaluate a speaker's credibility. The anonymity of on-line
discussion, in contrast, tends to make even outlandish statements seem
credible to impressionable young eavesdroppers." I won't deny that folks can
be way too gullible about what they read online, but my own experience is
that plugged-in youngsters are far less impressionable than novice adults
(hello, Pierre Salinger).

But that's a hallmark of this type of article: the claim that the Internet
is inherently more persuasive than it should be. Sort of how people once
feared that flashing "drink Coca-Cola" between frames at the Saturday
matinee would drive audiences trancelike to the refreshment stand. "We
really are witnessing the development of the most powerful medium that has
ever existed, in terms of its ability to attract and interest young people,"
asserts Jeff Chester of the Center for Media Education. "It's more powerful
than television ... because it is interactive," confirms anti-drug activist
David Rosenbloom.

The Web is more engrossing than TV? What are you, high? For balance, Wren
quotes HotWired's Jon Katz, who makes a similar point but without the
ominous spin.

To prove that online drug pushers are targeting young people, Wren points to
a combination of "glitzy" graphics and "a sassiness that leaves sober
arguments against drug use looking pallid." Something sober looks pallid?
Get outta here!

"One clue to adolescence on the Internet," continues Wren, "is the
prevalence of cartoons in praise of marijuana." Or maybe that's just a clue
to the psychological adolescence of potheads of all ages. Check out the two
examples that accompany Wren's article. In one, three Freak Brothers
rip-offs cavort beside bubble letters that read, Jerry Brownishly, "Why
ain't we the people free to grow our own?" In the other, a Popeye look-alike
named "Pot-Peye" smokes his spinach, while Bluto says, "Ya'know Pot-Peye, I
can, like, dig your beautiful headspace, man!" Tell me these gems are aimed
at anyone under 45.

The article's final section is titled, "A Vast Warehouse of Misinformation."
Wren is horrified to find a chat room in which "When a man asked whether it
was safe to mix methamphetamine with alcohol ... a seasoned user named Durto
assured him, 'Yeah, you can drink on speed, and drink and drink.'" Maybe I'm
sharper than the average would-be speed freak, but those extra two drinks
suggest to me that Durto is being sarcastic. Did Wren intentionally misplace
a ;-) somewhere?

I wouldn't put it past him. Consider the part where he writes that "the
Internet also abounds in casual advice like the 'suggestions for first-time
users' of 'ecstasy,' a hallucinogenic stimulant that has been found to
damage the brains of monkeys ... Nicholas Saunders, the author of these
suggestions, cautioned ecstasy neophytes only to 'avoid alcohol and other
drugs, and if you are dancing, realize that you may be dangerously
overheated even without feeling uncomfortable.'"

Hey, that's pretty good advice, and far more likely to make an impression on
a determined raver than a lecture about simian research. But Wren wants us
to gasp: The stuff causes brain damage and Saunders' only warning is about
dancing?

But that's not his only warning. Saunders goes into extensive detail about
the brain-damage research, as well as the possibilities of kidney and liver
damage, heart trouble, strain on the immune system and much more. None of
this, by the way, is presented with any graphics, sass or "interactivity,"
although there are hundreds of footnotes. In fact, Saunders' pro-ecstasy
treatise is quite scholarly -- pallid, even. It may be 90 percent bullshit,
but it's disingenuous of Wren to call it "casual" and imply that it's
designed to entice kids. Hell, I could barely slog through one chapter.

In and of itself, I'm not too concerned that one New York Times article is
trumped up. The buzz-kill is that once the rest of the media-political
culture jumps on this story, it's going to make the original piece seem
downright reasonable. Look for a concerned, clueless proclamation from the
president any day now.
June 24, 1997

Daniel Radosh is a New York City freelancer. His last piece for Media Circus
was on Michael Moore.





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 24 13:50:07 1997

	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id NAA09952;
	Tue, 24 Jun 1997 13:50:07 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mercury.Sun.COM (mercury.Sun.COM [192.9.25.1])

it is certainly a personality thing. . . any time you are giving off
happy, comfortable vibes, you're more likely to receive them in return.
my problem is when I go to a party in a *great* mood and my grins are
reciprocated by scowls from packs of overdressed kids who look more like
a tommy hilfiger advertisment than a group of people having fun.

you're right-on-target about working to be accepted, though: if I felt
more comfortable in my situation I would probably be capable of approaching
a group and saying hello, etc, but that has resulted in my feelings being
hurt in Florida and the midwest on several occasions, so lacking
a real solid foundation in this area I'm reluctant to risk having my only
social encounters be negative ones.  [I'm out here on a 2 month internship,
and I don't know anyone out here.]

that said, I will make it out to an event shortly and will be trying my
hardest to be an extrovert!

-jon

------------   ORIGINAL ATTACHMENT   --------
SENT 06-24-97 FROM SMTPGATE @MAILMN (mayer@netcom.com)


>I want to thank everyone who posted on how to beat match. You have
>turned me on to one of my current favorite ways to get high.
>
>But I have a problem. All I have at home is a dual CD player(cheapo).
>Is there a formula for beat matching, on CD's?
>Am I just a beginner?
>Is that why Trains Wreck at Casa Hernan?

I mix on Pioneer CDJ-500mkII's w/ an Pioneer M-500 mixer. These are the
best DJ mixing decks that were available back when I purchased them in
April '96. There may be other good ones out now, such as the new high
end Vestax. Don't get anything by Denon, Gemini, Numark, GLI, etc. They
suck, IMHO.

Assuming you have (1) pitch control, (2) some way of quickly phase
aligning your tracks (e.g. a jog-dial like on the 500mkII's), (3) a
precise way of  setting cue points, and the ability to instantly start
playing back as soon as you hit and hold the cue-button or the play
button... if you have all these capabilities, you're good to go. if
not, you probably will be struggling w/ cd mixing forever.

Although you can try to beat match by "getting lucky" w/ two tracks
that are speed-matchined, you still need to "phase match", that is, get
the 1-beat's aligned. this is best done with a precision cue-up, like
they teach you in college radio broadcasting. 'cept you're doing it on
cd's (well, back when i did college radio, it was done w/ LP's only).

Best thing to do is carefully cue up by running the cd through a few
measures (i do this w/ the jog-wheel, much like you'd do by manually
rotating vinyl). Find the one. Then Set the cue point at that point
(usually, a drum hit).

when you hear the "one" on the playing track, hit and hold the cue
button, listening on the monitor headphones. as soon as the tracks
start trainwrecking, figure out which one is faster, and adjust the
non-playing track's speed. then hit and hold the cue button again on
the next "one" from the playing track. repeat speed adjustment as
needed.

when you can play both tracks in synch for about as long as you want to
do your crossfade, hit-and-hold the cue button for a few measures to
get your timing just right (rehearse), then with the same tempo, hit
the play button, which will start your track at the cue point. then hit
the cross-fader and off you go.

Later, if you want to start getting fancy, you can start listening for
clashing bass-lines, and, for example, kill the bass (via EQ) on the
non-playing track and bump it up as you pull out the playing track.

PS: don't let the vinyl wankers start telling you that you can't
possibly beat match w/ CD's. They're all full of shit. However, you
can't beat-match well unless you have a decent CD-players. Even though
CD DJ mixers have been out for a few years, the pioneers where the
first product that didn't suck.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

things have been getting worse lately.

so......with that said.....

my suggestion......instead of posting the address, try posting a/the
phone number.  if this is not an option...then send each other
personal e-mails with all of the info in it, but just don't make it
"public" knowledge.

think that those are obviously ok.....just use your common sense.

this is not directed at u julie......i like u and everyone else on
here....these are just my suggestions about something that i believe
to be very important.

bottom line: do everything possible to keep addresses and other
"sensitive" information from going to the WHOLE list.

thanks....
dan

I just thought I'd you know, try to keep up with the general
level of intelligent, interesting, pertinent posts lately by saying:

I really like Oakland quite a lot.  I think it's a very cool place mostly.
there are parts that aren't so good, but in general, I thought you all
would like to know that I like Oakland.  Or maybe I just want to get
emails sent to me that I wrote and say, damn, he's smooth, I bet everyone
is fascinated by what he's saying.

I think perhaps hyperreal would get an award from me if they could house
the sfraves calender, the sfraves message/info list, and the sfraves,
really painfully repetetive and boring list.

This rubbish reminds me of like Model United Nations, or Junior Statesmen
of America conferences from HS.  If you let them speak, they will repeat.
If you let them repeat, everyone will.  And nothing new will be said.  But
at least everyone gets a chance.


Paz,
SAGA/MAX

> What he isn't telling you here (because he obviously doesn't know any
> better) is that they mostly SUCK under rave conditions. I've been mixing on
> Pioneer CDJ-500's since 1995, and many of the experiences I've had/heard

But I was talking about the CDJ-500mkII, which wasn't released until
early 1996. I bought the first batch i could get retail in April '96,
so either you're full of shit, confused, lying, or both. The CDJ-500 
was a glorified karaoke box, which was never intended for DJ use, so it
certainly can't stand up to loud volume.

> that I have been looking forward to for months, because the sound was loud
> enough and bassy enough so that the CDJ's COULDN'T TRACK THE DISCS... I'm
> standing there, with the CDJ's on perfectly levelled cinderblock stacks,

perfectly levelled doesn't mean anything for CD players. cinderblock
doesn't mean anything. it's compliance PLUS mass. if you're short on
either one, your sound will suck. on turntables, it'll just give you
that muddy distorted bass (caused by feedback) that drives the kids
wild. i'd rather use an equalizer or compression or both if i want that
effect.

it's no big magic to get your sound isolated. except if you're a
fawning 1200-worhipping wanker that thinks the fabled glorified
boat-anchor was built by aliens that had deep mystical knowledge of the
intricacies of low-fi sound reproduction. sorry -- it's 20-40 year old
technology, no big shit. the 1200's are heavy and on big springy/damped
feet in order to be compliant. if you feel like hauling around  bricks
and sponge, you can make isolation that's just as good for any CD
mixer.  But I personally enjoy the increased portability of the
CDJ500mkII+mixer in a single roadcase that can be carried by a single
person. the bricks and sponge can be carried in a separate load.

>I'm ready to go on, and they won't even give me a fucking reading. I missed
>my set because of them. I couldn't play. The conditions were pretty close
>to optimal as far as the physical setup of the decks goes, the person who
>rigged them has consulted with pioneer on the proper way to go about
>this... It still didn't work. In order for me to have played, I would have
>had to QUARTER the volume to get the CDJ's to track. Needless to say, I was
>pissed...

Sounds like you still are. Well don't take it out on me and my opinion,
especially because you weren't prepared. and you can pull that corncob
out now, it's now  ripe n' saucy and ready to eat.

>I'm NOT a vinyl "wanker", as Neils says in his tiring childish arrogance.
>The *point* is this: The 1200's stand up like mack trucks. It comes down to

Yeah, 1200's do great out in the desert at burning man. they do great
when the wind is blowing the cart around, do great when tweaked out
ravers bump the tables lightly... and the vinyl does great to with all
the sand and grit and cigarette smoke.

> The loading doors on them wear out, the

no problems so far.

> lasing unit needs to be kept really clean

never cleaned it. it has protective covers that cover the lenses as
soon as you open the unit. i guess you're talking about a different
unit, like the original CDJ500, which was a karaeoke unit.

> the buttons that control vitalfunctions wear out easily and lose
>contact... Essentially they are not

No problems here either.

> And he passes off his knowledge with this
>arrogance and rudeness that is somewhat sickening...

Um. who's being rude here? I think you're being a perfect ass, and not
even giving the oringal poster any information or answers, just a bunch
of puffery about how pathetically experienced  you are because you
can't understand the  elementary high-school physics behind sound
isolation (hey, if he gets to be a snotty wank, i do too).

>The other issue about them is this: (not mentioned probably due to a
>further lack of experience)... You can hold a mix for longer (without
>touching it) on the 1200's if you are good enough. The reason is because
>the pitch adjustment on CDJ's is digital, and it counts only to one-tenth
>decimal place. In other words, you can get either +6.5 or +6.6. If you

i guess you need the knobs to go up to 11 on your mixer to make it
louder too?

just because the display doesn't have umpteen digits of precision doesn't
mean the linear potentiometer that controls the speed doesn't have higher
resolution. i know i can get between the "digits" on the readout. 

 ....

Whatever.  I'm sure something better will come out in the future, it
always does. I posted an opinion based on my observations. Take it or 
leave it. I didn't notice you saying anything other than what a
lame-ass sucker you are for not being able to spin in your timeslot
because you weren't prepared, that and a bunch of factually incorrect
and stupid non-information. 

-- Niels.

Chris,

First, I was born in San Francisco.  While I've never lived in Oakland, I
have been there many times over the years and am familiar with the area.

Second, the URL i sent you (which i see you didn't bother checking) 
connects you to a PDF document that contains statistics for crimes
reported for selected California jurisdictions.  Oakland and San Francisco
are two of those jurisdictions. 

For 1995 and 1996, Oakland actually has fewer reported homicides and lower
FBI & California Crime indices then San Francisco.  Oakland also
experienced about a 30% reduction in homicide ('95 vs '96) vs. a 15%
homicide reduction in SF. 

Do these numbers not make Oakland a violent place?  Of course not.  But
they do serve to put Oakland's violence in some perspective, which I felt
your one sentence was sorely lacking.

Third, I think "unfortunate use of the word darkest..." is a gross
understatement of the way you chose to describe Oakland.  You're obviously
well aware of the historical significance of "deepest, darkest...", and it
has nothing to do with robert frost.

If you meant to allude to frost's poem, say so; it's your job as writer to
take responsibility for your own words and how people are going to
interpret them.  It'd be clear to me that my audience would be making
racial associations with that phrase, not poetic ones.

Finally, you've obviously had a genuinely bad experience with Oakland, and
I'm truly sorry about your paper boy.  That's not anything that anyone
should have to go though, and i mean that.  It is not, however, an excuse
to make vast generalizations about an entire metropolis or parties that
happen there.  


--goolz

First and foremost we would like to say hello and thank you to everyone
who came to ORIGIN. Also a big thanks to the entire ORIGIN family and
you know who you are, for all the hard work and dedication that was put
into the Summer Solstice celebration. The party was beautiful and the
music was incredible. Alot of good people just enjoying each other and
sharing positive feelings.

Rumors get started and then escalate through misinformation,
miscommunication and wild imagination. Find the TRUTH, the real TRUTH,
people who care take it upon themselves to search for the real facts
through logic, common sense, a clear mind and
communication. Jumping to conclusions without knowing the truth is
unnecessary and harmful. Don't get involved in idle gossip and rumours.

The truth about what happened at ORIGIN is as follows. According to eye
witnesses and the official report made by the officer on site, the two
men involved in the incident were not patrons of the event but rather
outsiders who snuck into the party. They were displaying aggressive
behaviour and fighting amongst themselves. They eventually hurt each
other and they were immediately taken to first aid and then transported
to the hospital where they were treated and sent home in a matter of
hours.

THERE WERE NO DEATHS !!!!! There were no other incidences at the party.
We live in a real world and there are people out there who through their
own life experience have learned to communicate in a certain way. It is
sad to see that these two people settled their differences in this
manner.

Thanks to everyone for their concern. Peace to you all!

Nomad Interactive


"The Truth Shall set you Free"
                     Farley Jackmaster Funk

On Tue, 24 Jun 1997, Adam Gould wrote:

> If you meant to allude to frost's poem, say so; it's your job as writer to
> take responsibility for your own words and how people are going to
> interpret them. 

	This is kind of personal thing of mine, but why does everyone have
to go pointing fingers all over the place under the guise of "taking
responsiblity for one's words". There is this thing called communication,
and maybe if people backed off for a second and took the time to check on
the meaning they are inferring from the words we use, we might get to some
common ground at some point in our lives... Point being there is no way in
hell that one is going to know how everyone if going to interpret their
words, and over the form of email, the number of inferences people
can/will make grows exponetially...
	I didn't know some of the references that seem to have come out of
the line in question, but I think people are a bit high strung when they
demand an apology without even verifying that they got the correct
meaning. Such an assumption shows some level of disrespect in my book as
there was no room for the possiblity that the original poster did not have
malicious intentions.
	On the other hand, there has been discussions which people know
that the language they are using is going to be taken a concern way and
they continued to use trying to imply that there was nothing wrong with
it. After being flamed heavy, they still maintained that there was nothing
wrong with the language they were using and they would continue to use,
which I think shows a level of complete disrespect...
	I don't know, people seem to be so argumentative over who is going
to make an effort these days (myself included as gem might point out)...
Maybe we need something to happen that MAKES us all do real work for a
little while...

dave

    I was lookin through the Magaziene section at Barnes and Noble Today when

more of those cute little CandyRavers in the LA pics than the SF pics. The

standin there watchin. I'm wondering why this is. It had me puzzled. It
always makes me smile at partys when i see someone all dressed up in their
funky-ist of gear, coated in glitter and stickers, with a smile bigger than

Date: Tue, 24 Jun 1997 19:15:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: Dave Bayer <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Reply-To: Dave Bayer <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
To: "\\SFRaves\\" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: The winds blew thru the trees
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.96.970624153727.9111C-100000@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So thrusday night we packed up the car, made food, remembered to put water
in the freezer to be transformed into block ice and eventually got on the
road in the usual late routine. Stopped to pick up a couple friends and
drove out to one site in the Sierra Foothills. Had to take a sleep break
before getting there because no one was awake enough to drive...

Two to three hours of odd sleep in the drivers seat and I am just about ok
to drive... So we continue on as the sun rises over the mountains. Finally
we pull in early Friday morning to two stands of scaffolding already setup
and people waking up (to the sounds of one small dog barking of course).
We could hear people wandering around (sticks breaking under feet in the
woods, laughter from another front of trees) and the breeze ffffffing thru
the tall pines. Set up the tent and get some sleep (only to be awakened by
intense heat reminscent of black rock, and slowly coming to and deciding
we needed to put up a shade for the mid afternoon sun). Lounge the day
away after a little work. Tried to make it to the waterfall but the
directions were not quite right, and we ended up heading down to a little
stream where I sat throwing sticks for the small barking dog listening to
three people bathing in the distance while the trees went
ffffffooooooooooooooo and gem leaned against my back. On the way out we
noticed the tailpipe of the van got squashed a bit when we went over the
logs and up the steep hill so I played with a rachet and wrench for a few
minutes to open it up. We got back just as evening falls... Some friends
start playing tablas and sitar and digis but it didn't go quite as was
hoped I believe. Then some ambient on the little system....  Some djs are
still missing and the live acts are either experiencing gear problems or
not up yet either, no bother....

Then the big generator gets fired up as darkness descends thru the pines. 
The fffffffff soound gives way to a lllloooooowwww rumble as the two
blocks of EV MT sound refernece decide to join us for the night. The fire
gets lit so a few people can cook food wrapped in foil. We sit listening
to ambient crystal clear at ~100 feet (thru pines as well). People come
back from the cliffs which are separated by another stand of trees with
reports that they could hear the music crystal clear out there as well... 
We cut up some more wood for the fire as more people arrive. Then thru the
trees a glow rises and the lights have been turned on and are scanning the
trees with radiant colors (dichromic I believe was the word someone used
to describe the colors which means something in chemistry to me, but I
don't know if that means the use chromium compounds to get those colors
though it looked like it)... And then the music gets harder and more
people show up and the music gets harder and the fog machine fills the
meadow with mist and the music gets harder. Then the gabber comes on just
as a few more friends show up (hurray) and goes on and people dance and
the lights go and I wish there were a few more people dancing (maybe 10),
and then some trance and head to the fire to talk for a little as the
music doesn't keep me going... Then a while latter, the music changes and
oh joy, it gabber girl, Warrior princess playing hard and most silly music
so I get to dance with about about 20 other people while the other dave
comes bouncing out in only a way that that dave could without bringing to
mind all the flak I hear about gabber in san fransisco... Somewhere in
here UV-99 shows up and they are talking about their plans for the next
day...

The gabber ends and I talk a little bit and then head to bed and sleep til
the afternoon (the tarp over the tent worked wonders). So gem and I were
out and about with a little barking dog for most of saturday. Walked all
over talking to people, listening to music, out to the cliffs with the
little barking dog and gem. Got the correct directions to the waterfall,
but driving wasn't really an option. So I sat around listening to thee
trees, watching people try to level the big truck and hang scrims. And
then go about making foods...

And then night fell, and the big speakers turned on, and then the
projectors turned on, and then the cyberlights came on, and then the
strobes came on, and then the lazer was turned on and out in the trees
there was clear loud music, about 50 people dancing (maybe more I am bad
with numbers), and a bunch by the fire (why do people like to sit around
the fire at night instead of dancing? But to each their own)... I missed
greg's set and I missed Dan efex's set, bt the rest of the music was
really good - in fact it was the best party musically I have been to in a
long long... All pretty hard and driving though it went with most of the
crowd that was up there with yells galour.

So sunday things started to get broken down. We made some coffee for those
that were around, had some soup and sandwiches. helped to clean up the
horrid mess that was the communal kitchen area, retrieved my contributions
to it (oops, I just realized that the plywood we brought up to use as a
food prep table got left up there), started packing up the car, talked
with people, yelled for shango, talked with people, wished the barking dog
would let other people come close to me without barking at them, listened
to the wind in the trees, broke down the speakers, woke shango up for the
keys which ended up being in the igition to the big truck, knocked the
grounding rods out of the ground (3 feet of copper likes to stick in the
ground), then got to tag with gabber girl which is the first time I have
had someone to tag with it was a lot of fun...

So Trust's first big party went off pretty well though they lost a LOT of
money as it seems that the tickets that went out didn't really get paid
for, which is kind of frustating as the ticket pocily was very laid back,
with everyone involved (whether working, spinning, or coming up to dance
and lend a hand when they saw it could be lended) contributing to the
finacial side of the party...

Anyway, I enjoyed myself, the party was very well put together (except
for the problems with the Pioneer CDJ units ;) ) and I would like to make
more of these happen in the future...

dave

I'm going to try to speak to you with a little respect, even though its tough.
First of all, there is no such model as CDJ-500mkII, you're confusing a
technics 1200mkII with a CDJ-500II or CDJ-500-2. Those are off of the boxes
and the manuals. Check your facts. When I started using them in 1995, I was
actually mixing on a pair of 500-G's. So I am not lying, not full of shit,
and apparently you are confused.



>Sounds like you still are. Well don't take it out on me and my opinion,
>especially because you weren't prepared. and you can pull that corncob
>out now, it's now  ripe n' saucy and ready to eat.

Yeah.



>Yeah, 1200's do great out in the desert at burning man. they do great
>when the wind is blowing the cart around, do great when tweaked out
>ravers bump the tables lightly... and the vinyl does great to with all
>the sand and grit and cigarette smoke.

My point was that CDJ's are much easier to do damage to. The signal gets
more fucked up and is more noticeable when it skips, and sometimes will
*stop* if the source of the vibration is strong enough. You might not have
that much experience playing on yours in adverse conditions. I don't know.



>> The loading doors on them wear out, the
>no problems so far.
>> lasing unit needs to be kept really clean
>never cleaned it. it has protective covers that cover the lenses as
>soon as you open the unit. i guess you're talking about a different
>unit, like the original CDJ500, which was a karaeoke unit.

As I said, I've moved my decks around a lot, they've seen use in a lot of
different environments. I've played on other people's cdj's, both in the
studio and at at shows. Mine have been subjected to normal wear and tear on
the road, and on airplanes, and whatnot. Maybe yours haven't left the
house. I don't know. I am speaking of both the 500-g's and the 500-II's
because I've had problems with both. I have friends that have had problems
on both, with both the hardware and skipping issues that spoke of. I've
conversed with Dj's in other cities that use them and gotten their
feedback, and it appears that some of the unit's faults are universal.



>Um. who's being rude here? I think you're being a perfect ass, and not
>even giving the oringal poster any information or answers, just a bunch
>of puffery about how pathetically experienced  you are because you
>can't understand the  elementary high-school physics behind sound
>isolation (hey, if he gets to be a snotty wank, i do too).

I tried to give the original poster some good information, unfortuneatly I
chose to slam you on a public list along with that info. That was a
mistake, which I have addressed. I hope that original poster can glean some
pertinent information from my current responses, which are not intended to
fan the flames of burning shit. I have no need to "defend" my range of
experience. I don't claim to know everything.



>just because the display doesn't have umpteen digits of precision doesn't
>mean the linear potentiometer that controls the speed doesn't have higher
>resolution. i know i can get between the "digits" on the readout.

You say that you "know" that you can get between them, you say that it
doesn't mean that the resolution isn't there, where is your proof for these
statements? I started mixing on 1200's for about 2.5 years prior to using
the CDJ's, and am comparing the differences based on my experience, as well
as concurrence with other individuals who have had the same conditions that
I have.



>leave it. I didn't notice you saying anything other than what a
>lame-ass sucker you are for not being able to spin in your timeslot
>because you weren't prepared, that and a bunch of factually incorrect
>and stupid non-information.

pissed you off. Read more carefully, and I'll speak more carefully. Deal?
We did a soundcheck the day before, and it didn't really work too well, so
I had to hope for the best. The only manner in which I was unprepared was
not having any records on me, due to the fact that I sold my record
collection to start a CD collection, over 2 years ago. My information is
factually correct, and hopefully this time you will read a little slower
and find that since I'm not trying to insult you any further, you can also
glean a little information from my experience.

-Joshua

My opinion:

If I believe something should change, I should use every means at my
disposal to help this happen.  Voting takes very little time relative to
anything else, and if I can vote in someone that (for instance) supports
environmental protection, maybe I won't have to waste a bunch of time in
activism (for instance) to fight logging in national forests.  Even if
you're a violent revolutionary anarchist, you can always vote for whoever
you think will weaken the police and military most.

The one thing you should *never* do is to vote for a major-party candidate
because you "know" the minor party can't win.  This is a self-fulfilling
prophecy.  Think about it -- "You should vote for me because the person you
like will never win."  Bad logic, and a bad decision.

However, one thing is certain: the fact that less than half of the
population votes will never cause those voted in to voluntarily give up.
"Oh, I guess that was a vote of no confidence, so we'll dismantle the House
of Representatives."  Yeah, right.

// grigs

sorrow with your girlfriend, who I might add did a great job protecting 
her man =), you do expect her to show her (L)ove to you, you do want to 
be conected with her so she would understand what you are going through, 
and in another words you want (U)nity. And I'm sure you  want (P)eace 
for yourself, so stop saying PLUR sux... because most of us do belive in 
PLUR. And most of us do want Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect from others 
and the world that we live in. 

So as again I will say....
P..........L.............U.............R
H..........U.............G.............S

Alik aka EarthlEn

Hi everyone...
It's so hard for me to sit here and see all of you flame each other and
get pissed off at each other about what so and so said and that so and so
meant to say this or that.
To tell you all the truth, I didn't even know what  "flaming" was until I
subscribed to this list a year ago.
People will say what they want.  It's all about living in America.
I'm not going to add to the current thread that's been going on; but I
will say this.

I have never felt such a closeness to people I have never met before. 
It's like, all you guys (and gals!) are like family; and when I see one
of my brothers accusing one of my other brothers of saying something
demeaning, I lose that sense of family.  We're all in this together,
folks.  Name-calling and accusations are not necessary.  True, there has
been a lot of violence in our scene lately, but you've got to remember
that we are not the only ones that go to these parties.  We all know that
none of us on this list could be the cause of such heinous acts, so why
are we all yelling at each other?

I still have yet to meet a majority of you, and when I do, please
remember, you're all a part of my family.

much love,
jay
(doughboy!)

P.S.  Geez, Macadio!!!!!  Am I ever gonna hear a live set from you ever
again????  =)

<poke my belly and i go "hee-hee">
<feeling low?  Try some BASS-- it's the cure for whatever ails ya!>

Subject: watching or dancing
To: CheerioHN@aol.com

---CheerioHN@aol.com wrote:

> It seems that there are a lot
> more of those cute little CandyRavers in the LA pics than the SF
pics. The
> kids at the LA parties were dancin around the DJ stand, the SF kids
were
> standin there watchin. I'm wondering why this is. It had me puzzled. 

...and then goes on to talk about candy ravers.


what i want to know, however,  is why aren't people dancing?

excuse my ignorance but i'm still trying to figure this sf rave thing
out because it's so different from what i know from england.

i noticed this at Basics where the dancefloor was packed but about 70
percent of all the people were just standing there watching the dj or
talking. it was a bit off-putting. no wonder you guys here don't like
massives. they are weird.

in england where most raves are massives the whole dancefloor is one
bouncing mass and if you're not dancing you leave the dancefloor. i'm
not complaining, don't get me wrong. i'm just curious. i can
understand the appeal of watching the dj spin but it's not quite what
i go to raves for. i love the feeling of being one of thousands of
people bouncing to the same beat. as much as i loved the trance + acid
experience of last sat at f8 i did miss this feeling of unity and
security and happiness and closeness. it felt lonelier and more
introvert than my british rave experiences. maybe that has to do w/
the choice of drugs. don't know. gotta try it again some time. haven't
really been to enough raves/parties here yet to compare or form an
opinion. i'm just a bit puzzled.

ben's theory about the massives here is that there are a lot of
non-ravers due to the fact that here the beer drinkers can't go to
bars until they're 21, so they come to raves. in england you only find
real hardcore ravers at raves because the beer drinkers can go to
pubs. here the scene seems a bit diluted.

i'd love some input on this topic. it's so easy to mis-interpret
cultural differences and i don't want to do that.

iris


===

standard."
Al in Quantum Leap.

One more time for the record:

I never said ANYTHING bad about Oakland... I used to live there and think
it's a great place... It's had its string of fucking awesome parties... Trust
me... I used to attend commercial parties EVERY weekend.

My post was IN NO WAY saying that UG ravers are better, more enlightened, or
safer than anyone else... It's just an observation I have made over the past
few years that violence has a tendency to occur at a higher rate at the
parties with more ppl attending.  If you think about this it DOES make
sense... More ppl... more possibilities for violence to occur...

And don't think that just because ppl in the underground have their candy and
stickers that they are safe  from violence... that was something that I NEVER
said... it was an assumption that someone else decided to make. My comment
was just an opinion from personal experience... So flame me for it... :) It
makes me smile.

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Jun 1997 02:03:54 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <3.0.2.32.19970625003756.00b387d8@scruznet.com>
X-Sender: island@scruznet.com
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0.2 (32)
Date: Wed, 25 Jun 1997 00:37:56 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Bruce Eisner <bruce@mindmedia.com>
Subject: Island Web and Psychedelic Island Views
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Island Web at http://www.island.org has updated it's look. We also have one 
the most extensive new link databases -- which will be updated as well soon with
separate page for each topic area. It's a fascinating place to begin exploring 
the ideas catalyzed by the psychedelic experience.

On Island Web, you can find back issues of our first four Island Views 
newsletters, resources about Huxley's vision. You can join the Island community 
and have your e-mail address and web site published in Island Village. 
Or you can join our mailing list and receive updates and news flashes.

We also have a marketplace with videotapes, audiotapes, books, and other items 
of interest to ELFers.

Soon, we will be announcing the publication of Psychedelic Island Views Vol 3, No.1.
Contents include:

* Interview with Terence McKenna by Bruce Eisner
* The History of the Digital Be-In
* The Electronic Koolaide Test by Douglas Rushkoff
* Interview with Owsley Stanley by Bruce Eisner Part One
* Changes <column> by Elizabeth Gips
* Smoke and Mirrors <Book review> by John Beresford 
* Poem by Nick Herbert, AKA Dr. Jabir
* Shadow Dancer (excerpt part 1) (Fiction) by Dr. James Fadiman
* Last Word by Peter Stafford

Island Web and Psychedelic Island Views are sponsored by Island Foundation. Island 
Foundation is a non-profit California Corporation dedicated to a culture inspired by 
the visionary experience -- an idea first put forth by Aldous Huxley in his last novel, 
Island.

We are looking for volunteers to help with portions of the web site and the magazine. 
If you would like to help, please e-mail me -- Bruce Eisner at bruce@mindemdia.com. 
Island Foundation is supported by memberships, donations, sales from our marketplace 
and commercial sponsors. We ask that you help and be sure to explore the resources 
we are bringing to the enthegenic community.

Welp, since everyone else has posted their happenings for the night, I
just had to post mine. Well, we decided to go to wonderland at around
7:45 and drove quite fast to get tickets at Solid Grooves before it
closed at 8. We made it and then called the map point, called a few more
times and decided we had a wrong number. Thanks Orson for telling me the
new number! Anyways, my friend and I lagged as always, and got to the
party around 1:30 to find cops outside and lots of upset ravers outside!
Anywho, we hung around at our car with the hopes the cops would leave
but we got back and to see the entire party being cleared out.  We heard
about two makeup parties, but my map from the 60's had no Illnois
street. So we went to 3-COM to find a lot of VERY cold ravers, we were
very cold, and waited around until once again SF's finest came and we
once again dispersed.  I found my way to my good buddy's after party in
San Jose, and saw a lot of tired ravers listening to people spin on
belt-drive turntables. But my buddy Matt threw a good party, and I'm
glad he did, such a nice boy! I feel so proud, I took him to his first
rave, anywh0, I'm rambling, several people wanted me to ask this, is
there going to be a make up party by Wonderland?  We all doubt refunds,
but throw a make-up party! Welp, I love you all!
PLUR
Matt the SmUrFy

At 12:13 AM 6/25/97, Iris + Ben wrote:
>what i want to know, however,  is why aren't people dancing?

no shit! i've never been to a party anywhere else where there were so many
ppl just standing around. and all over the dance floor! flame me if you
will, but i find it sort of disconcerting to be dancing around with all
these ppl just standing there... it really makes so much of a difference
when everyone is dancing. i thought that this was a large part of what
raves were about....
>
>excuse my ignorance but i'm still trying to figure this sf rave thing
>out because it's so different from what i know from england.

yup - i've been to parties in tx, toronto, all over ny, and a few in
england. everyone dances there, even when they're just walking around! how
can you not? i don't know, i find it hard not to be moving to the beat,
even if i'm tired and sitting against a wall somewhere. my head still bobs!

>i noticed this at Basics where the dancefloor was packed but about 70
>percent of all the people were just standing there watching the dj or
>talking. it was a bit off-putting. no wonder you guys here don't like
>massives. they are weird.

very odd, indeed.

>in england where most raves are massives the whole dancefloor is one
>bouncing mass and if you're not dancing you leave the dancefloor. i'm
>not complaining, don't get me wrong. i'm just curious. i can
>understand the appeal of watching the dj spin but it's not quite what
>i go to raves for. i love the feeling of being one of thousands of
>people bouncing to the same beat. as much as i loved the trance + acid

(snip)
yeah, it really makes a huge difference in the ambience of the party.
saturday i kept dancing around and wondering why all these ppl were just
standing there.... i felt sad for them in a way.

anyway, i've devoted far too much of my time already this morning to email,
so i'm outta here.

cheers - e. :)

'Throw away holiness and wisdom
 and people will be a hundred times happier.
 Throw away morality and justice,
 and people will do the right thing.
 Through away industry and profit,
 and there won't be any thieves.

 If these three aren't enough,
 just stay at the center of the circle
 and let all things take their course.'

				--Lao-Tzu

am trying to learn (for the 80th time) that I must shave the impatient,
elitist, and caustic elements of my nature from my outward character.

At least until you people know who I am, tee hee.

Keep it surreal, sistren, bredren,
pax,

From: Iris + Ben <jarmin@rocketmail.com> (by way of Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>)
Subject: good fun so far
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hi all you sfravers

aaah, it's so good to be back on sfraves. i was suffering from serious
withdrawal symptoms. i see you're still bickering about the same old
stuff and the rumours are still as sensationalistc as ever. i love you
guys :)

i had to unsvbscribe when we came over here from england and we
haven't had regular access to a computer until now. and this is only
temporary until we move on again.

we've had great fun since we arrived 3 weeks ago. i call this my email
vacation and it's the weirdest thing i've ever done. we've been
staying w/ people we've met on this list, hanging out w/ them, going
to parties w/ them and we have now completely abandoned our plans of
renting a car and driving out to the southwest because we won't have
time. there's so much to do around here, so many people to meet, so
many PARTIES TO GO TO!!! this is such good fun. and we still got 6
weeks to go.

so far we've been to:
warmth, beats, basics, several house parties, freaky people, and F8.
next weekend: happy kids and area 51.

thanks to all of you for taking in 2 complete strangers
thanks to ruby for making me understand the candy raver phenomenon,
thanks to adam for introducing me to trance,
thanks to julie (say hi to amy), eric (i can't believe we lost that
baseball glove), ora (sorry we didn't make it to wonder), nancy (who's
probably in europe right now. see you in england in august), byroni
(who we only experienced in a semi-conscious state so far but were
told he's always like that), chris + carol (lovely place), ibukun (for
the riceroni. best after-rave food ever! gooey, no need to chew.),
ivan (for trying to get us onto the right BART)....

now, let me just clear some stuff up:

1. yes, the music is generally harder and faster in england

2. clubs are NOT raves. sometimes rave tunes get into the club scene
but they are usually completely corrupted. clubs play mainstream music
and are usually pretty dreadful meat markets. raves in englang are
generally huge legal licenzed warehouse parties of up to 8000 people.
the atmosphere at these raves is the same as the atmosphere was at
warmth, i.e. good vibes and family atmosphere, and you will only find
dedicated hardcore ravers there, no clubbers, no beer drinkers. 
the underground raves are smaller but usually equally good with a
slightly greater possibilities of non-ravers sneaking in. they are
more new age traveller parties and the music and crowd are more
diverse but not mainstream. you'll get anything from happy hardcore to
techno to jungle. the trance i've heard here so far would be far to
slow for these do's.

3.yes, these big raves are commercial. the only way to get around the
stupid laws on assemblies/parties/repetetive beats (Criminal Justice
Act) was to apply for licences, pay horrendous fees, let the police on
site. so the organizers became commercial. these raves are expensive
but bloody good fun sometimes w/ funfairs outside or movie marquees.
it's a big thing and not only a dance party.

4. the candy raver scene is completely new to me. never seen anything
like it in england. can't comment on that yet because i haven't quite
figured it out yet. i've been told there's a glittery trance scene in
london but it's supposedly gay, i.e. fairly exclusive and shunned be
hardcore ravers.

5. MCs are cool and an important part of the english rave scene. DJs
usually work w/ the same MC all the time and the MC is there to hype
up the crowd. they rap or sing and make people aware of which dj is
spinning.

all of this is my completely subjective opinion of what i've seen and
experienced in england and here, which is not necessarily
representative. the milton keynes scene might be completely different
from the manchester scene and SF is, from what i gather from the list,
different from the LA.

but who cares. it's all great fun. it's all a matter of taste. it's
all a party.

o.k. that's it for now.
love you all 
and to all those sfravers that we haven't met yet: hope to meet you
all soon 

iris + ben


===
"You can't trust women. They just don't understand the double
standard."
Al in Quantum Leap.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 25 10:57:59 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id KAA02697;
	Wed, 25 Jun 1997 10:57:59 -0700 (PDT)

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Jun 1997 10:57:50 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from brianb.organic.com (brianb.organic.com [207.76.136.136]) by eat.organic.com (8.8.3/8.6.12) with SMTP id LAA12766 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 25 Jun 1997 11:01:05 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <3.0.1.32.19970625105308.0084e9b0@hyperreal.com>
X-Sender: brian@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0.1 (32)
Date: Wed, 25 Jun 1997 10:53:08 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: the leaping trout <cathode@idiom.com> (by way of Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>)
Subject: 6 days on top of the world ( very long )
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it all started last wednesday when inSECT and I packed up the truck and
headed east towards Sacramento in search of a 16'x16' army tent and a 25Kw
generator... For some unknown reason our navigational skills failed us and
we got lost on the way to both places...however it all worked out fine and
after a few u turns we managed to get on our way up into the Sierras at the
wopping speed of 35 mph... After much driving and a little fretting about
the possibilities of further wrong turns we found our destination ( a
clearing off of a dirt road in the middle of nowhere ) slightly before
sunset... Much to our dismay we set to the task of seting up our newly
purchased tent without the assistance of our friends who had yet to arrive
from their journey to Fresno to retrieve the sound system...About an hour
later; shortly after we finished struggling with 135lbs of tent we heard
the rumble of a large truck on the dirt road and our excitment grew as our
friends neared... Wednseday night was a time for relaxation after a day of
driving all over the world... Thanks to Mari for the stunning Vegan Cuisine
that she amazingly pulled off on a campstove ( this is true talent folks
)... Finally sleep....

      Thursday morning we worked hard setting up Sound, Light, Camp,
Scaffolding and the Dj booth... Our group of 12 pulled together and we got
everything done before the sun reached is highest ( and hottest ) point in
the sky... We chilled for most of the afternoon as more of our friends and
even my little brother ( a definite non-raver ) arrived,  I spun a few
records on the newly erected system, watched an amazing sunset ( i can't
even begin to describe it ), ate some more of Mari's amazing fare and slept
comfortably in the back of the sound truck ( my tent was too full at this
point )


    Friday morning we dug the Latrine, a shitty job which brought out a
strange side of everyone ( the conversation went way off into left field ),
completed the set up of the rig,  went to find a waterfal ( thanks for the
ride and the company Dave, Gem and Soda )...ended up bathing in a steam of
35 degree water ( boy is that a little chilly ) and heading back to camp in
time to prepare for the opening ceremonies...

The party started at about 8 pm with a live band playing on tablas,
digeridoos and a sitar. the music was good and was soon overtaken by the
deep drone of inSECT's ambient. the music moved through ambient to slow
dubby acid until Julio took over and brought in the beat with a blend of
Trancy house and Techno. At this time two Djs and a live act had yet to
show up and the other slotted live act is having gear problems. 2 hours
later LMNT takes the decks ( a 1/4 volume unfortunately- due to some lame
ass CD players ) and gives us some brutally hard Acid Trance ( this boy
rocks )... Gabber Dave was up next pounding the small crowd into submission
with a fine selection of hardcore... Dan Efex spun an unexpected set of
minimal Goa trance which kept the crowd grooving until..... GABBER GIRL
arrived... Now I was in the truck trying to sleep when this happened but i
heard it anyways so let me tell it this way.... Barney and Hardcore, Mr.
Rogers and Hardcore, John Wayne and Hardcore, Enya and Hardcore, the
Macerana ( sp? ) and Hardcore... it was insane with a capital INSANE... I
finally fell asleep as Johnsin took the decks and played some Tech step
Jungle ( mellow by comparison ).


Saturday the rest of the crowd arrived, UV99 had arrived the night before
and set to the task of constructing a laser show. Re ach spun some Hip Hop
and other breakbeat wierdness, ate more vegan food, watched another
beautiful sunset, hung out with my brother and his girlfriend (?) who were
kind of in awe and on some heavy psychedelics...

Saturday night began with a circle, moved into Seth Sutekh, Greg Sandler
and Then Dan Efex again... All were good but my nerves were too shot to
enjoy them as i was informed earlier in the day that not only would I be
spinning in the peak slot due to scheduling conflict with Dan Efex but I
would most likely be doing it alone thanke to those infernal CDJs ( inSECT
and I were all set to tag team )....The lights and the laser made the party
look so incredible ( true eye candy- the beast i've seen in years ). Deaks
was on next with some pounding stompy techno and some crazy mixing. His set
went well but it did little to calm my nerves...As his set ended I stood
there looking out wondering what was about to happen. I turned off the
power to the deck on which his last track was playing, brought in some
noise, faded to my favorite A&E department track and let the ACID begin. At
about this time I notice inSECT struggling with the CD players and as i
finally bring in Punk Floyd he tells me that i'm on my own... OH SHIT is
the only thought passing through my mind... my fingers were numb from he
cold, my flash light burned out, i accidently turned of the power on one
deck during a mix.... it was hectic, i was a mess... I'm not sure how it
really went...i'm too lost in a cloud of subjective self loathing to give
an accurate review... Thanks to Ernie and Maya for being there at the end
of my set to shower me with positivity... I will be doing this again ( and
getting it right )... I then cuddled up with my girlfriend in the truck and
went to sleep soon afterwards. The highlights of the night for me were
watching my brother and his friend on E for the first time...especially
introducing her to the bassbins =] ( there is a convert in the crowd ),
listening to Gabber Girl rant about relieving herself in the woods ( while
candy flipping)


Sunday we relaxed... music continued until about 6 pm as we tore down the
main sound system...Gabber Dave vs Gabber Girl ( what more can you ask for
)... Loaded up the main truck ( and mine too ), watched the last of the
beautiful sunsets, ate more food, said goodbye to all but the original core
group, watched the stars from the roof of the sound truck


Monday we packed up all that remained, hitched up the Generator and drove
home for a shower and some SUSHI =]



Thanks to: Everyone who was there... all old friends and new... Goolie you
rock ( thanks for staying to help us pack ).


-Virus-

VIRUS
Upcoming Dates:
 July- Eternity: Mirasol ( with InSect, Djs in residence )
----------------------------------------->>>
 FARMACY RECORDS... HARD ASS ID MOOZIK...
----------------------------------------->>>>
Special thanks to InSECT for his part in a great 2x4 @ Mirasol on June 12
Look out for more Acid Assaults in the future....

Thanks to the TRUST crew for a beautiful party, June 18- 24 will be in my
memory banks forever....y'all kick ass...

Much love to Ernie and Maya for being two of the coolest kids i've met in
years
----------------------------------------------->>>>

Date: Wed, 25 Jun 97 10:07:45 UT
From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL18.199706251756340119@msn.com>
To: "funkateers" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Give it a rest--More Origin/Violence Rant
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Just wondering if I was the only one who doesn't know what the big deal is.  
Especially after reading the post Max forwarded about what really went down.

I personally have no problem admitting that I don't give a damn about the 
whole thing, and I suspect I'm not alone.  I've been at house parties (w/ zero 
security) and had fights break out right in front of me, guns fired right next 
to me.  I go home in one piece and I have a good story to tell people.  I'm 
not trying to say I'm hardcore and I've seen a lot of shit go down, but I'm no 
stranger to violence.  It happens.  Life goes on (for the survivors).  Big 
deal.

You can tell when stuff isn't right at a party and other places.  If you 
don't, you should be more aware of your surroundings, because you might get 
hurt.  People just act funny when they're about to start trouble.  When you 
see the signs, you'd better steer clear.  Sometimes you might not react 
quickly enough, or even have a chance to react.  That's too bad.  But you take 
a chance w/ your life when you get in a car or walk down the street.  Parties 
are no different.

You can't really expect people to become nonviolent when man has been violent 
since he first came into existence.  A couple angry, idealistic posts aren't 
going to eliminate man's innate violent nature.  Take care of yourself and 
your friends.  Everyone else is going to do whatever they want anyway.

I might be wrong.  You may be able to stop the violence.  If you believe this, 
quit wasting your time posting and go do something about it if you care so 
much.  Actions speak louder than words.

xoxo--Miccaela

someone slightly misinterpreted my post and thought i didn't have a
good time at f8. let me just put that right for all of you who thought
the same:

nonono. you got me wrong there. it was different, yes, but i had a
wonderful time. you must have missed my brief post on mondays about
f8. i absolutly loved it. it was the best experience since my first
rave. just different.

and i'm not saying either one is better or worse. i would be such an
arrogant asshole if i was running around saying everything is much
better in england. and what would be the point in coming to another
country to check out the rave scene and then find it to be exactly how
it is at home. boooooring!

i'm just curious why people aren't dancing because i don't quite
understand that and want to know why. but maybe i haven't been to
enough parties.

sf and surroundings seems to have a very interesting culture w/ a
strange mix of manic industrious hyper-ness and almost catatonic
mellowness. would be interesting to know if that is caused by the
computer industry or if it's always been like that.

when you travel you should look for differences not similarities. so
if i ask 'why' don't think i don't agree, i just don't understand.

to say it again: i loved f8! and i even liked basics although that was
a bit strange. it was a bit off-putting that nobody was dancing. i'm a
bit shy and need the crowd around me. but i love massives and i don't
expect large crowds like that to be in absolutly complete harmony. a
certain percentage of bad vibes or even crime is normal in human
society and the rave scene is not an exception although i think this
percentage is much much lower there. 


iris


(brian. are you still forwarding my posts? i thought i was subscribed
again.)

===

standard."
Al in Quantum Leap.

minute songs turn into 40 minute
teeth-gritting-eyes-closed-sweat-drenched-drool--on-the-snare-drum-whisper-q
uiet-thunder-loud-expressions of RAVE!  The weird thing is that I can take
my fairly sober band mates along on this trip...

> in a cliche. Sorry people. Do you guys sit around and wait for
> something
> offensive or something that you could just possible disagree with in
> any
> small manner so you can jump on the author's throat for writing it?
> But I am
> sorry if I offended anyone. I guess I feel like I should leave the
> list now.
> I've just recieved too many threats than I can handle. I thought I
> joined
> the list for fun, and that raving was all about fun. That's all I ever
>
> looked at it as, an escape from my regular boring, miserable, lonely
> life.
> Sorry again.
>
>  -chris


You know what Chris? I would not leave the list. Your explanation is
completely honest and, I think, should put all of the alarmists at rest.
Mistakes can be made, but in this instance I really don't think that you
made a mistake. What we are witnessing (in this instance) are people
conditioned to respond to race related things in an alarmist manner w/o
hearing all sides of an issue.
Race and racism are important (concerning both political and social
ramifications), but this thing has just gone a little crazy and outta
control.
O.k., take a breather if you must, but if you decide to come back, I'll
be the first to say "welcome back."

rob.
rwpointer@citiscape.com

I

>The Dr. Seuss Purity Test


>Have you done it on a boat?

>Have you done it with a goat?

>

>Have you done it in a bed?

>Have you done it with the dead?

>

>Have you done it in the ass?

>Have you done it, high on grass?

>

>Have you done it in the car?

>Have you simply gone too far?

>

>Have you done it on the beach?

>Have you done it with the teach?

>

>Have you done it on your back?

>Have you done it strapped to a rack?

>

>Have you done it in a box?

>Have you done it with a fox?

>

>Have you done it in a tree?

>Have you done it with more than three?

>

>Have you done it in the rain?

>Have you done it for the pain?

>

>Have you done it wearing mitts?

>Have you done it 'tween the tits?

>

>Have you done it packed in rubber?

>Have you done it undercover?

>

>Have you done it on a perch?

>Have you done it in a church?

>

>Have you done it with a virgin?

>Have you done it with a sturgeon?

>

>Have you done it with ropes and chains?

>Have you done it while insane?

>

>Have you done it on the stage?

>Have you done it underage?

>

>Have you done it with all your friends?

>Have you done it in both ends?

>

>Have you done it with your dog?

>Have you done it on a log?

>

>Have you done it under clamps?

>Have you done it with the lamps?

>

>Have you done it for all to see?

>Have you ever had VD?

>

>Have you done it on Mother's couch?

>Have you done it in your mouth?

>

>Have you done it while on tape?

>Have you done it out of shape?

>

>Have you done it on live TV?

>Have you done it whilst you pee?

>

>Have you done it in the gym?

>Have you done it on a whim?

>

>Have you done it on a dare?

>Do you really think we care?


>Answer these and count your "no"s,

>pray this number never grows;

>Fifty questions we asked thee,

>score times two is your Purity.


--goolz

	...DJ Wildchild's "London Update of Drum and Bass"...

Iris + Ben (by way of Brian Behlendorf ) wrote:

> 5. MCs are cool and an important part of the english rave scene. DJs
> usually work w/ the same MC all the time and the MC is there to hype
> up the crowd. they rap or sing and make people aware of which dj is
> spinning.

First off, I'm really glad I got to meet the both of you at Beats.:)

Now the MCs - my friend Daryll from London has sent Melanie and me tapes
of the music over there that has MCs rapping or singing.  Now as
open-minded as I have tried to be, I just don't like it. I like to
interpret the music in my own way, not by someone else telling me how I
should. And if the MC is needed to hype up the crowd - well, I think
maybe better music should be played, cause it's the music itsself that
should hype up a crowd! :)

I certainly have not written off MCs as sucking - it may be something I
have to acquire a taste for - like JUNGLE!  I didn't used to like it,
but it grew on me! :)

love,
Amy

Oh my gosh...A couple great 12"s out this week.

G-Money- I understand- Integral UK

If you slept on 'Falling', G's last track, you shouldn't miss this
one. Straight up TRIPPY roller!! Weird grinding analogue bass line and
strange melodic but techy sounds througout. This track is amazing.
Liten and you'll understand.

Renegade Hardware- 2x12"- UK

Can't rememebr what this one is called, but it's vicious. 3 RH remixes
by the original artists and one track by DJ Kane. 3 dark steppers and
one amen workout. If you like it deep, this is for you!

E-sassin-??- Soundsphere US

New domestic d+b from LA. Check it out: Hard, dark techtep. A-side
uses what I think is a Boymerang break. It takes a while to get going,
but when it drops...you'll know it. Flip side is a minimal dark tech
piece.
Good stuff!

-SCiEnCe

> From: joshua nodeOne <joshua@nodeOne.com>
> Subject: Re: Beatmatching Digitally, not a flame
> 
> First of all, there is no such model as CDJ-500mkII, you're confusing a
> technics 1200mkII with a CDJ-500II or CDJ-500-2. Those are off of the boxes
> and the manuals. Check your facts. When I started using them in 1995, I was
> actually mixing on a pair of 500-G's. So I am not lying, not full of shit,
> and apparently you are confused.

Sorry, but you might be confused.  Brian and I just recevied, boxes, manuals,
and all, two CDJ-500mkIIs from J&R Music World in New York.  They are 
top-loading "professional" (whatever that means) CD players with tempo
control, looping, and god knows what else.  Going from turntables to these
is like learning to drive a car all over again.  And they are GORGEOUS!  I feel
like I'm piloting a starship when I use them!  So many buttons and dials and
lights and wheels!  Ok, so I'm a blinky-light nerd.  I'm just totally in love.

Laura

P.S.  Not rave related (not that this was either, but...) I'm changing jobs
in about two weeks and will be working in San Francisco full time.  I'm
so happy to have my home and my job in the same place.  So hopefully I'll
start being at MAD more than once every six months (there, I made it barely
rave-related)

as i said, it's a matter of taste (and what you *grow up* with)

MCs make sense in 5000 people raves in england, here i would find them
distracting too.
(i guess the idea is NOT to interpret the music in your own way but to
have the whole crowd moving as one. the MCs facilitate that. but if
you want to go it individually you can easily filter them out. they
are not as loud live as they are on mixtapes)

iris
