a lot of these friends of mines, *certain people* call them 
childish, stupid glittered up, silly frog back pack hanging off 
their shoulders, pacifier sucking people who need to "grow up." 
and that they go to parties acting fake.
i think this is a lack of respect. i think sometimes, because 
certain people are older and tend to know more about certain 
things and are jaded by certain scenes, they tend to become more 
static. rather than saying "hey! these new ravers are dressed
differently but it's cool! i can still hang out with them or try to 
get to know them," they isolate themselves from these *candy ravers*, 
stereotyping them before they really get to know them. i know, 
i've done this too, so i think it's just a reflex everyone has 
once in a while.

but my point is, how do *you* know we're acting fake? how do you 
know we're not genuinely happy to see our old friends or make 
new ones? because some of us may do a bit too much stuff and act 
like tweekers? because we like to dress up differently? because 
we haven't been in the scene 4, 5 or 6 years like you? because we 
like sucking on lollipops and pacifiers so we don't grind our teeth? 
because we're not perfect and make mistakes sometimes or are
misunderstood,
we don't know what PLUR means?

i can't speak for all ravers. i know some are in the scene as an 
escape from the real world, some for music, some for drugs, and 
there will be tons of other reasons. but i hate when certain people
criticize a whole group of people "ie. the new schoolers" for 
lacking PLURity. i know my friends and i practice plur. we may 
not always be perfect and sometimes forget. (i know i did. i'm 
sorry about the clubber post.) 

but ultimately there are a lot of us who still believe in hope.
PLUR does not suck. sometimes it may be cheesy and overused but 
it is a philosophy that we can try to live by.
to live in peace.
love and care for one another.
work together in unity.
and respect one another.

when i meet someone, 
or when i see someone i've met at a party before,
and i hug them,
i genuinely smile because i'm genuinely happy to see them :)

i'm still learning as i grow older. my views and morals grow as 
i do. 
when i'm 30 and still raving, and there's a new breed of 
ravers, with psychedelic tattoos on their foreheads, and bright 
colors rings attached to their eyeballs, i hope i won't be too 
jaded by then to keep an open mind. 
i hope i won't criticize and judge and condescend.
i hope i'll be like uncle noah and still party like a mad man :)

see you all at *IN THE BEGINNING* 
i'll be with my old school camera and 7 rolls of b/w film. so i 
better catch a picture of you! ;)

<genuine hugs>

(:>veann<:)

ps. it's okay if you don't agree with anything i say. flame me all you
want, hate me because i believe in PLUR, treat me like a child because
i can't refute your views well enough. either way i'll still keep my
head up.

you can't change me but you can broaden my views.

In a message dated 6/26/97 8:43:16 AM, you wrote:

<<I'm assuming you're joking, right? I can't tell exactly. So I can't
really reply. If you are not joking, then I would be quite upset at this.
However, I'm in a good mood, so I'll just assume you are joking. Ha ha! That
was funny! It reminds of me of that movie "Higher Learning". 'Unlearn',
everybody!
        -chris>>

I'm deadly serious. I've never seen "Higher Learning," nor would I ever cop
social theory from a film.  This country was founded upon racism(remember
slavery?), and it continues to be a functional aspect of our society. We are
socially stratifed much more in terms of race in this country as opposed to
class, gender, etc. Those of us who were brought up here are taught from day
one how to differentiate each other in many ways, most significantly by that
nonsensical concept of race. Our parents, our friends, our schooling, our
media, even our religions constantly bombard us with notions of race, both
positive and negative. Unfortunately, those positive and negative notions
tend to fall strictly along very specific sides. I think John S. Lee's direct
quotes from the Webster's Dictionary prove this point. We are taught that
Black=bad and White=good.  When notions like this permeate a society to this
extent, to the extent to where it becomes an acceptable part of our very
language, it easy to understand how UNCONSCIOUS RACISM can exist. To deny
 any of this is to deny what it means to live in America in my opinion. And
in light of your comment, ..."deepest, darkest..." I think you understand
what I mean.

Chris, the bottom line is this: there are people on this list who have been
deeply offended by your comments. The question as to whether or not you
consider it valid that you have in fact offended anyone is moot. You should
apologize because people ARE offended by what you said.

If you're down with PLUR, I truly believe you would understand that.

I mentioned it before,  but you should'nt fight this. You 're on a path now
that will lead to a deeper understanding of this issue. If you want to ignore
it now, fine. But the seed has been planted and will grow in you whether you
like it or not.

See you on the dancefloor.
--Monty

Tip:  When changing records, don't touch the pitch....

-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-snipped-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've seen good and bad things happen to peeps when first starting out.
I was taught when first starting to try to always put the pitch back to
zero.  I'm not sure why this happens, perhaps from the shear enjoyment and
adrenaline rush, I found myself creeping the pitch control, continually
speeding up every song just a bit until I had none left.  Searching for
speeding up every song just a bit until I had no advancement left.

   Anybody else ever had that problem?

                                                                Eric

I don't really post a whole lot but I just read "The Long Boom" in the 
July issue of Wired and I would just like to recommend it to everyone. 
 It describes how the next 25 or so years could turn out and why they 
might turn out that way.  While it doesn't focus on them, two of the 
important factors it mentions for global prosperity are openness and 
diversity which I think we  strive for in the rave community.  The 
article also mentions the fact that leaders are necessary to promote 
this openness and diversity so that nations don't turn inward and 
allow the world to fragment into isolated blocks.  Maybe the world is 
ready to listen to what the rave community has to say, now we just 
need to tell them.

j

You know,

 I don't even have all my chit yet. And I am already lecturing my friend on
this bad "touching the record" habbit. I find that if you have to doctor
the record by touching it, or pinching the spindle thingie all the time.
You did NOT match the beats yet, and more tempo adjusting is in order.
 I only touch the record or spindle when, I did not come in exactly on my
cue. To either slow it down or speed it up, to get it where it was suppost
to be without having to wait for another cue nStuff.
 If you have to nurse the mix by touching the records like this all the
time, it is most likely that your mix will change the atmosphere alot
before it's over, sounding pretty...Sloppy..


 Am I right nStuff?
 Jeff

From: Chris <lsavage@uclink4.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: Ok, really cool new thread to try and replace other bad
  ones!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        It's cool that you have a similar approach to me when you approached
the tables. I played trombone for 4 years, but also played guitar for 8, and
I studied music rather intensively(you have to if you wanna play be-bop.) I
didn't have a problem beatmatching, however, it came quite quickly to me,
although I am by no means a master at it.

        A technique my friend DJ Flite(go Brett!)taught me was to learn to
keep the vinyl you are trying to match up in sync with your finger(s). You
keep twirling it with you finger, making minute adjustments, then with your
other hand you can adjust the slider until you feel you are no longer
applying force with you twirlin' hand. Then let go. It takes a while to get
used to this, but before I knew this I would set the speed, cue it up, then
let it go. If it wasn't matcher I would cue it back up and adjust the
slider. That took a while. This new method can get me beatmatched in 5 to 10
seconds. Which is great because with hardstep you really gotta mix it up to
keep it interesting. Hope this gives you some ideas.

        -chris

isn't changing and neither is mine. So I'm dropping this and I hope you do too.

        -chris


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 26 14:02:50 1997

At 9:15 PM 6/25/97, John S. Lee wrote:
>I, like many others, have been on this list for some time.  And for the
>life of me, with all the various topics, various arguments, various
>disagreements, I cannot recall as much insensitivity, and callousness as
>the last few days of posts have demonstrated.
>
although i am a 'newbie' to _this_ list, i too am tiring of all the
bickering, misunderstanding, jumping to conclusions.... i haven't seen the
likes of this on any other list. constructive debate is one thing, but htis
is a bit much. it's really funny, or sad, how we can call ppl names when
typing to a screen... i wonder if these ppl are as insensitive when talking
in person? i consider myself hyper-sensitive, and i'm sure there are others
out there like me. i've already gotten my feelings slightly hurt through
flaming... i feel really sad for chris, regardless of his intentions when
writing his original post.

>This list has been filled with new people, who for the life of me, just
>don't seem to get it.  They don't think before they speak, they utter
>racist and vile things against people they know little or nothing about,
>and they do this at the same time while uttering that nonsencial word, PLUR.
>
well, i'll have to admit that i too can type off some things in the heat of
the moment and send w/o thinking... in the same way, i sometimes speak
without thinking. but i'm well aware of this flaw in my character, and
usually try to be a bit more aware of myself.

>You know, for all the pontificating of that acronym many of you aspouse,
>how little of it seems real when it comes to your expression of thoughts to
>the masses.  G-d, if this is new skool I am very, very happy to be old and
>jaded.  The one thing the old timers still have is openess, maybe not for
>new fangled parties where people stuck in adolesence can call themselves
>"tickle me glitter baby", but we are certainly open to each other.
>Something many of you PLURists (definitely a new school thang) aspire to
>but will probably never have.

and what the fuck is plur anyway? i've seen so many different words
applied.... i don't even know anymore. then again, don't know if i ever
did? from what i remember, in the early '90s, we all felt some sort of
unity with others' who liked to do the same sort of thing - there was no
name to it - we just smiled knowingly at each other. it was a nice feeling;
a feeling that i don't sense much anymore. part of it may be my fault - i
do tend to find it hard to relate to someone who's 15+ years younger than
me! but there wasn't a conscious push for 'peace, love, unity...' we were
there having fun, and brought together by our love of a certain music and
lifestyle. that's it. no explanations needed. my belief in respect w/in the
'scene' (and i even hate this word) i think stems from this - we did have
respect for one another. if someone was sick, you helped them. if someone
needed something and you had it, you shared. we were friendly and open to
one another, but not in this sickeningly-sweet way of 'ooooh i love you let
me hug you and yadda yadda ya.' the only thing i can think to call that is
respect. this, it seems, has been lost along the way. there is no longer
one group of ppl; instead there are factions. some violent, which really
troubles me. guess i had a bit of an eye-opener this past weekend - a big
fat welcome to the big city. i was naive, now i know. i was hoping that
things would be like what i knew, but they aren't. the reason i support the
idea of a metal detector is precisely for this reason. things have changed,
whether we like it or not.

>I can only wonder how you will take this scene to the next level with such
>juvenile and neandethal thoughts.  Like I said in the past, parties were
>better when there were more gays, varieties in sexual orientation, and
>definitely more color.  I doubt many of you PLURists could even hang with
>many of the parties in the old days since they were held in the "deepest
>and darkest" of Hunter's Point.

just a side comment, but how many of these new-skool pluralists are of
color? don't flame me, now, i've just seen over the years that this has
gotten to be a very white thing. which, as john writes, is sad. the
multi-cultural/ multi-personality aspect of this was one of the things i
loved the most - so many different kinds of ppl all brought together by the
love of one thing. hedonists, that's all, really. let's go have a blast and
fuck what society has taught us.

>-First, use your real name.
>There is nothing more phoney than someone hiding behind a psuedonym and
>spouting out some slogan.  If you want that acronym to have any credibility
>COME OUT, and revela thyself.  Using your real name is a good start.

name: elizabeth (e.'s short for that.) call me liz.

>-Secondly, If you can't use your real name use an adult one.
>What do I mean? Let's take "tickle me glitterboy", he would be MUCH more
>convincing if he called himself "tickle my dildo", or "sparky
>spunkshooter", or, if you really wanna get adult, "beat me bobby".  Now
>that is what I call real names for real people.  Besides, I know I would be
>more embarassed using a copyrighted name than using something original and
>adult.

i can see why other ppl would use a pseudonym... here you have 450
strangers reading your mail.... privacy is an issue. why does it bother you
what ppl choose to call themselves?

>-Lastly, Girls, grow up and take those pacifiers out of your mouths. And
>get that fucking frog off your back!
>Ladies, there are growm men around.  Despite all efforts at removing the
>sexual energy of some males, we are intrinsically turned on by grown women
>dressed upo as little girls.  Stop it now!  You've brought the women's
>movement back 60 years dressing like twiggy with a kermit backpack, a bunch
>of blowpops in your mouth, and girlie ponytails.  Grow up!  You need
>schooling from your elder sisters...you need to go back, way back, I'm
>talking booty-back and dress down some.  Don't get it?  What I'm talking
>about is taking that shirt off and stop wearing those goawdawful baggy
>pants and put your booty in some shorts.  A long time ago, this was the
>look, and beleive it or not, women were harassed less then looking like
>this, than now.  Why?  Don't ask me, but I sure liked it! So simplify, take
>off some garb and shake it a little.  You may find your need for that elmo
>less than the need for  hearing some good music while you bust a sweat.

don't know about being harrassed less when wearing form-fitting clothing.
again, why does it bother you what other ppl wear? stating that "there are
growm men around.  Despite all efforts at removing the sexual energy of
some males, we are intrinsically turned on by grown women dressed upo [sic]
as little girls" to me comes off as being very sexist. (correct me if you
disagree... if i have misinterpreted you here) first, women, from what i
understand (i being one of them), are more likely to dress for themselves
or for other women. despite what men think. second, men, control
yourselves. here you are admitting that you are nothing more than an animal
with uncontrollable desires. saying that we have to be responsible for
controlling your desires is rubbish. this is like saying that a woman
'asked' to be raped because of what she was wearing. para nara. welcome to
the 90s. we will wear what we want. i used to wear from-fitting clothes
(long time ago), and actually got a kick out of teasing men. this is no
longer the case. now i prefer to wear what's comfortable, especially when
it comes to dancing all night. no, i don't go around looking like i'm 3,
but i will wear what i want and not what you or anybody else wants. hello,
this is all a part of casting aside society's norms, which is what i
thought was a part of the rave culture.

>Ok, so now we have accomplished a few things that will make you a very
>valid spokesperson for PLUR; you have an adult name, and you are dressing
>like and adult partyer. But look at the advantages, people will take you
>more seriously now that you have a truly adult demeanor than when you were
>in ponytails yapping about some party you went to.  And fellas, you ain't
>immune, don't encourage the ladies by buying them dolls, and stop with the
>candy already, that's what overpriced "peachy-puff" girls are being
>exploited for.  Do something adult, and support your local exploited person.

this to me seems a bit much - you have dictated to the masses only how
_you_ think things should be. but we live in a democracy, so to each
his/her own.

>Now that we've gotten all of that out of the way let me tell you about my
>true fgeelings about this word, PLUR:
>it sux, period.
<snip>
>You have to keep the sensitivites of
>others in mind when posting.  It's called respect, but as I said there is
>little of that on the list of late.  For a real sense of PLUR and what many
>fo you yap about ad nauseam please reference the old-skool.  We may be
>jaded (not! ;( ), but look at the level of conversation that goes on.
>Sheeit, if motherfuckers are talking to Neils you know there's some serious
>respect going on (Neils is the man after all!).

i see you can talk the talk, but can you walk the walk? no disrespect
intended; just a question. really.

>Now I know some of you new-skool will be offended.  Oh well.  There will be
>others, and we've "talked", who know wassup.  They are the ones who live
>the ideal, are new-skool, and never use the term but show it by throwing
>parties, helping out thier pals in time of need, forsaking a party to make
>their friend feel good.  There are plenty of young good soldiers out there
>who work, live, breathe and eat the ideal since it is a natural part of
>their essence.  For those whom it is not natural?  They are the most vocal
>adherents.  Reminds me of Southern Baptists who love the ideals of Jesus,
>then don't want to integrate schools, don't want an end to slavery, want to
>limit women's choices and run thier wombs, snf sre not tolerant of anyone
>who isn't a staunch heterosexual.  For these folx PLUR is a slogan that has
>rules rigid and terse, unbendable, and only certain people are eligible,
>and there are litmus tests for adherence.

ahem... haven't you just told us how we are to behave, dress, act? what's
the difference? as the saying goes (or something like this) sometimes you
have to support what's wrong in order to support what's right. this means,
in the case of freedom of speech, you have to tolerate what others say (do,
wear...), even if you strongly disagree, in order to maintain the freedoms
we have.

>Well I've said quite enough.  Some of you will want to flame me, save it.

this is not a flame. i agree with some of your points, disagree with
others. (freedom of speech, again.) a lot of it i found funny, if read in a
sarcxastic way. but i have no way of knowing if this was what you intended.


>Some of you will utter on the list how I'm a know it all, save that too.
>Some of you will accuse me of being holier than thou, and most times I am,
>so save it.  Some of you will curse me out or try, save that too.  Why?  It
>has been done by better.

well, sue me for responding (note sarcasm here! ;)
>
>So think about what I've said, and you may kindly junk it.  I'm tired of
>the fake ass posuers and would like the posturing for who's most plur and
>wishing plur on everyone, and using phoney ass names, and using a phoney
>ass slogan that never leaves the rave.

now this, at least to me, is a very _pre-old-skool_ attitude. when i was a
little new-waver (and in high school, i might add) we often snubbed our
noses to 'posers'. i don't know what a 'poser' in this community would be.
a lot of us dress the way we want, regardless of the current trend, listen
to what we want (techno and not), and do what we want. we come to raves to
dance our asses off. (or is that primarily an 'old-skool' thing? innocent
question) there are no 'posers' - we come because we want to, not because
it will make us 'kewl' (god, i hate that word the most!)

>I will now leave the lot of you, and you know who you are, to your
>PLUR-reality.  Have fun, and when the party is over, count how many friends
>you have, then let me know how that PLUR thing worked out.

this is true to an extent - and i agreed with you before on it. some of us
do, tho, make good friends! ;) just beware of others, i suppose. there are
an awful lot of ppl who are so fucked up that they can't care for anyone
any longer. which is sad. here you can show how much you care by _helping_
those who really need it the most.

>P.S.  XLR8R - you made me do this.  I saw that letter and saw that PLUR
>crap and almost puked.  I did puke as a matter of fact and I was really mad
>'cuz I don't like to waste food.  So I did a "fly" n'stuff.  Now that's
>sticky-stink n'stuff.
>
uh... thanks for sharing? ;)

>Now will someone please close the door.

no.

cheers - e. :)
oops, sorry - liz.

At 02:17 PM 6/26/97 -0700, >-jspace wrote:
>Oh I've met you, chrisP and I think you definitely need to get someone

Haha fother mucker, when did they let you outa jail?  Welcome back anyhow...

RR-ish: A few weeks back, I was at Analog, when I noticed something neat.
There were a lot of people of color there.  Specifically there where a LOT
of African-Americans in attendance.  For some reason it surprised me, in a
good way. Why should that have surprised me?  Why should I find it odd that
we can all rave together?  I found myself wanting to go up to every black
person I saw having a good time and say something stupid like: "It's so
cool that you're here, tell all your friends to come next time, we need
more melanin in this house."  But, I couldn't find a good way to say it.
Still can't think of an inoffensive, non-patronizing way to phrase it.  

So, how do we encourage diversity?  How can we get more peoples of color to
experience the unity we call rave?

If we build it, they will come....

ChrisP- No more dead horses for me.

Subject: Supreme Court Applies Free-Speech to Internet
X-Mailer: ScoMail 3.0.Bd
MIME-Version: 1.0
Date: Thu, 26 Jun 1997 14:51:57 -0700 (PDT)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: Quoted-Printable
Message-ID:  <9706261452.aa09387@andrewk.pdev.sco.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	[Looks like the CDA is finally behind us...]

Thursday June 26 4:59 PM EDT =

Supreme Court Applies Free-Speech to Internet
By James Vicini =


WASHINGTON (Reuter) - The Supreme Court extended free-speech
rights to cyberspace in a historic ruling Thursday, striking down a feder=
al
law that restricted indecent pictures and words on the Internet computer
network. =


The nation's highest court dealt the Clinton administration a major defea=
t
by declaring unconstitutional the law that made it a crime to transmit
sexually explicit material to anyone younger than 18. =


The high-profile case marked the first time the Supreme Court granted ful=
l
constitutional free-speech protections under the First Amendment to the
giant worldwide network of linked computers used by tens of millions of
people. =


The justices by a 7-2 vote ruled that all key parts of the Communications=

Decency Act violate free-speech rights, amounting to illegal government
censorship. =


"Notwithstanding the legitimacy and importance of the congressional goal
of protecting children from harmful materials, we agree ... that the stat=
ute
abridges 'freedom of speech' protected by the First Amendment," Justice
John Paul Stevens said for the court majority in the 40-page opinion. =


The law, signed by President Clinton in 1996 as part of a
telecommunications overhaul, barred distribution to minors of indecent or=

"patently offensive" materials on the Internet. It provided for fines and=
 a
maximum two years in prison. =


The law defined indecent as anything that "depicts or describes in terms
patently offensive, as measured by contemporary community standards,
sexual or excretory activities or organs." =


The law did not target obscenity or child pornography, which already were=

illegal. The Internet indecency law has never taken effect because of the=

court battle. =


The ruling represented a major victory for the American Civil Liberties
Union (ACLU) and groups representing libraries, publishers and the
computer on-line industry, which brought the lawsuit challenging the law.=
 =


ACLU attorney Stefan Presser said, "Essentially the Supreme Court of the
United States took an idea from the 18th century, that is free speech, an=
d
said it has enduring quality, and will extend into the 21st century, beca=
use
government will not be allowed to censor what's on the Internet." =


Clinton said he would study the decision, gather people representing
industry, parents, teachers and librarians to review it, and continue to =
look
for a way to keep children from viewing pornography on the Internet. =


"With the right technology and rating systems we can help ensure that our=

children don't end up in the red light districts of cyberspace," he said =
in a
statement. =


The Supreme Court said the rapidly growing Internet deserved full First
Amendment protection, citing its unique characteristics as a public forum=

for the exchange of ideas and information. =


The high court rejected arguments that the Internet was similar to the
television and radio industries, where there has been a history of extens=
ive
government regulation and where indecent speech may be restricted. =


"The (Communications Decency Act) is a content-based regulation of
speech," Stevens said. "The vagueness of such a regulation raises special=

First Amendment concerns because of its obvious chilling effect on free
speech." =


"As a matter of constitutional tradition ... we presume that governmental=

regulation of the content of speech is more likely to interfere with the =
free
exchange of ideas than to encourage it," Stevens said. =


Chief Justice William Rehnquist and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor agreed
that the law was unconstitutional in that it would restrict adults' acces=
s to
material they otherwise would be entitled to see. =


Writing for the two, O'Connor said they would invalidate the law only in
those circumstances. That part of the court's ruling was unanimous. =


But O'Connor said for the two dissenters that she would uphold other
restrictions that prohibited the use of indecent speech in communications=

between an adult and one or more minors. =


In his statement, Clinton said, "The Internet is an incredibly powerful
medium for freedom of speech and freedom of expression that should be
protected. But there is material on the Internet that is clearly inapprop=
riate
for children ... We must give parents and teachers the tools they need to=

make the Internet safe for children." =

---------------
Copyright =A9 1997 Reuters Limited. All rights reserved. Republication or=

redistribution of Reuters content is expressly prohibited without the pri=
or
written consent of Reuters. Reuters shall not be liable for any errors or=
 delays
in the content, or for any actions taken in reliance thereon =

-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

Ethan,

Got a question for you. At the F8 2nd anniversery you played a very
enjoyable set that was more or less straight trance. Trance fit the F8
theme, and seems to fit the outdoors thang really well for me.

At the 2 previous gigs where I saw you spin (Harmony massive and that
benifit where I could hardly recognize you in drag), you spun what I
thought was another style. I don't remember too well, but that other
style seemed harder, more crunchy, and more minnimalistic. What do you
call that style of music? Are you moving away from trance, back to
something more pure or onto something more fresh? Or were my ears
deceived?

Curiously,

I have to agree with Christine (cricket) on this one...
I went to a party in Oregon a while ago (dec or jan) and it was the same 
way.  Picture this: 3 in the morning, lots of sporty adidas stuff, 
amazing lighting & lazers, good music, and me with a bag full of 
blo-pops and an arm full of bracelets, and an empty address book due to 
the lack of a vibe.  I walked around the whole night trying to talk to 
people with no luck.  The whole party wsa like, 50% "I'm dancing don't 
talk to me" people and 50% "I'm e-ing with my boyfriend/girlfriend don't 
talk to me" people.  LAME!  

Happy me, I found 3 sweet girls and 1 boy about 5 in the morning sitting 
outside smoking (near where the line was) saying hi and bye to every 
person that passed.  I gave them bracelets and smiles and promised them 
that if they ever came to SF that I'd take 'em to a party full of people 
just like them.  

They didn't think that suck parties existed.

Be happy that we have as much love in our scene as we do!!!  It's a rare 
thing!  You can't just say "oh well.  when the vibe dies here, I'll just 
move" because there's nowhere to move to!  We have the best vibe on 
earth (I think)!  So celebrate it and love it, okay?  Thank you.

Mad Luvin,
christine the candygirl (not christine the cricket girl!)

him

that's
>where he learned it 
>*grin*

>what i learned on my trip-
>our scene is truly the best! no matter how many people you have at a 
party,
>how good the music is, how good the visuals, drugs, location, blah, 
blah,
>blah are, a party is really nothing without a good vibe. and i really 
think
>the sf scene has got one of the best around :) i don't mean to offend 
anyone
>who may be from seattle (or anywhere else for that matter...) i just 
want to
>remind you guys how truly lucky we are. maybe if we concentrated less 
on
>*flaming* and more on our *scene* and how wonderful it is, we'd all 
feel a

>appreciation for it and everyone in it.

I have to agree with Christine (cricket) on this one...

I went to a party in Oregon a while ago (december = cold!) and it was 
the same way.  Picture this: 3 in the morning, lots of sporty 
adidas-wearing ravers dancing their asses off, amazing lighting & 
lazers, good music, and me with a bag full of blo-pops and an arm full 
of bracelets, and an empty address book due to the lack of a vibe.  I 
walked around the whole night trying to talk to people with no luck.  
The whole party was like, 50% "I'm dancing don't talk to me" people and 
50% "I'm e-ing with my boyfriend/girlfriend don't talk to me" people.  
LAME!  

Happy me, I found 3 sweet girls and 1 boy about 5 in the morning sitting 
outside smoking saying hi and bye to every person that passed. I gave 
them bracelets and smiles and promised them that if they ever came to SF 
that I'd take 'em to a party full of happy people just like them.  

They didn't think that such parties existed.  So I'm making them visit 
me this July. =)

Be happy that we have as much love in our scene as we do!!!  It's a rare 
thing!  You can't just say "oh well.  when the vibe dies here, I'll just 
move" because there's nowhere to move to!  We have the best vibe on 
earth (I think)!  So celebrate it and love it, okay?  Thank you.

Mad Luvin,
christine the candygirl (not christine the cricket girl!)

>i went to seattle last weekend to visit a friend and we went to a party 
and
>let me tell you guys, it made me miss and appreciate the sf scene so 
much!
>there were plenty of jnco's, adidas, drugs, glow sticks, and even some
>pretty decent music (with an amazing set from our very own drc)...but 
no
>vibe at all!
>there were no smiles, no hugs, no meeting of new people. the only 
person i
>met was some army guy who was trying to pick up on me.....
>there was however one, yes only one, person who came up to me with a 
smile
>and a lollipop (oops, is that a taboo word now?)....anyway, i thanked 
him
>and told him a little about the sf scene. and guess what? he said 
that's
>where he learned it 
>*grin*
>
>what i learned on my trip-
>our scene is truly the best! no matter how many people you have at a 
party,
>how good the music is, how good the visuals, drugs, location, blah, 
blah,
>blah are, a party is really nothing without a good vibe. and i really 
think
>the sf scene has got one of the best around :) i don't mean to offend 
anyone
>who may be from seattle (or anywhere else for that matter...) i just 
want to
>remind you guys how truly lucky we are. maybe if we concentrated less 
on
>*flaming* and more on our *scene* and how wonderful it is, we'd all 
feel a
>little more fortunate for what we've got and we'd have more respect and
>appreciation for it and everyone in it. 
>
>just a thought. i love you all. and i miss sf like crazy.....
>cricket :)

Message-ID: <Pine.PTX.3.95.970626162405.10262B-100000@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Last night, I went with my dingdong friends to VSF because it was Dudes'
birthdays, and they're sort of cheese, but it was fun, blah blah,
ANYWAYS...

I was up on the roof, and I was moving past a baldheaded black dude, and I
said 'Excuse me, cuz,' like cuz as in cousin.

He sort of took this strangely.  He told me that I should think twice
before saying that to black dudes, because some (not him, but some) would
take it. personally, and take it the wrong way, and that it might not be
good for my health in general to call black guys 'cuz.'

So, in any case, I invited him to sit down with my friend and have a
smoke.  My friend is a light-skinned black dude with dreads, really
spectacular looking guy, model-type, etc.

So, my friend and this other guy started talking about me calling him
'cuz' and all that stuff, and I wasn't really paying attention because
Alexa was sitting on my lap, but all the sudden, my friend says to the guy
I had brushed past (in reference to me):  'That kid is my nigga.'

Several times in my life, black friends of mine have referred to me as
their 'nigga' when trying to explain/justify/introduce/whatever me to
other black people.

I don't particularly dress or talk in an 'urban' (for lack of a better
word) way.  I definitely don't look country western, but I have sort of
longish curly hair, and I wear a lot of silly clothes.  When I get drunk,
I speak in a more relaxed jargon that reflects on the sort of mixed
environment I've grown up on, a sort of honkebonics, as we say.

But it always astounds me when all the sudden I'm someone's 'nigga.'
Of course, it feels good that a friend would use, such a hmmm... personal
word in reference to me.  Personal doesn't sound right.  What I'm
trying to say is that there is a lot of weight attached to the word
'nigga,' and as a wee honkey lad, it always makes me feel like I'm doing
the right thing when I get called that.

I would love to hear people's reactions to this, and I suppose I should
mention that the high school I went to was 30% Latin 30% White 20% Black
10% Polynesian and 10% Asian of some variety.  Word to M-A!

ANYWAYS..............

There is a GRIP of shit that could be done tonight, there are 3 new-to-me
deejays at Phunkateck, there's the WuTangstep party at the Casanova, etc
etc, what are yall fittin to do?

Paz,
SAGA/MAX

> First and foremost we would like to say hello and thank you to everyone

> you know who you are, for all the hard work and dedication that was put
> into the Summer Solstice celebration. The party was beautiful and the
> music was incredible. Alot of good people just enjoying each other and
> sharing positive feelings.
> 
> Rumors get started and then escalate through misinformation,
> miscommunication and wild imagination. Find the TRUTH, the real TRUTH,
> people who care take it upon themselves to search for the real facts
> through logic, common sense, a clear mind and
> communication. Jumping to conclusions without knowing the truth is
> unnecessary and harmful. Don't get involved in idle gossip and rumours.
> 
> The truth about what happened at ORIGIN is as follows. According to eye
> witnesses and the official report made by the officer on site, the two
> men involved in the incident were not patrons of the event but rather
> outsiders who snuck into the party. They were displaying aggressive
> behaviour and fighting amongst themselves. They eventually hurt each
> other and they were immediately taken to first aid and then transported
> to the hospital where they were treated and sent home in a matter of
> hours.
> 
> THERE WERE NO DEATHS !!!!! There were no other incidences at the party.

      A helicopter was flying around the northwest region yesterday when

 navigation and communications equipment. Due to the clouds and haze,
 the pilot could not determine the helicopter's position and course to
 steer to the airport. 

      The pilot saw a tall building, flew toward it, circled, drew a
 handwritten sign, and held it in the helicopter's window. The pilot's
 sign said, "WHERE AM I?" in large letters. People in the tall building
 quickly responded to the aircraft, drew a large sign, and held it in a
 building window. Their sign said, "YOU ARE IN A HELICOPTER."
 
      The pilot smiled, waved, looked at his map, determined the
 course to SEATAC airport, and landed safely. After they were on the ground,
 the co-pilot asked the pilot how the "YOU ARE IN A HELICOPTER" sign helped
 to determine their position. The pilot responded, "I knew we were in
 Seattle, and that had to be the MICROSOFT building because they gave me a
 technically correct, but completely USELESS answer."

bye for now...

From: Chris Porter <cporter@exploretech.com>
Subject: what I meant was...
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This should have been sent this morning, but it wasn't, this should be my
last post on the subject, it's my last post of the day for sure.

First, never again will I respond to any thread that is started by another
Chris, people cant seem to tell us Chris' apart.  The Chris who
accidentally started all this, is from Berkeley.  I, ChrisP, who knows
better than to use color in any post to Sfraves somehow became a target for
Trigger Happy John.  (sounds like a jungle band, eh?)  I can't wait for
people to come up to me this weekend and say: "You don't look half
Vietnamese".  I'm not, that's the other Chris.  Strange coincidence: I have
Cherokee grandparents too.

Second, I'd like to apologize for the useless negative flame I posted from
my house last night.  As of 5:00 yesterday I was quite proud of SFRaves for
not letting a touchy topic degenerate into stupid name calling.  Then along
comes John...  

What I wanted to say, (I should have ignored John's personal attacks) was
this: It is human nature for us to instinctively fear anything we consider
different. It is a survival instinct to mistrust those we don't identify
with.  Racism, classicism, sexism, and lots of other *.isism's stem from
this basic truth.  This is how humans evolved, and you can't expect to undo
1000 years of evolution with some silly presidential commission (read the
paper), or by calling each other names (read last nights messages.)  The
root cause of all this is very basic, humans beings will favor those they
feel they have something in with.  This effects everyone, we all behave
this way, it's inate.  It's not possible to treat everyone in the same way,
someone has to loose.  I believe this problem can only get worse until we
begin to identify ourselves as humans first, race, class, etc., second.
That's one of the great successes of the rave community, we all get
together on the dance floor, and for a while, we achieve unity through
dance.  For a while we forget what color, sex, age, we are and we JUST ARE.
 
When I first started lurking here, what impressed me most wasn't the
descriptions of parties or the fuzzy star hugs, but the intelligent, witty
discussion that went on about touchy subjects.  Religion, race and
politics, were discussed in a civilized manner, and that's what got me
hooked on the SFRaves scene.  The idea that ravers were intelligent
individuals, who could discuss their views eloquently was not something I
considered until I found this list. Needless to say the 6 months have been
disappointing.

ChrisP <-- just one of many chirs'

hi.

um, not to discount or discredit anyone's conviction or passion for the
topic, but can this racial thread please stop?  at least in being cc'ed to
the entire mailing list?  i weed through enough email in one day and the

 I too try to keep it at it's normal tempo. Or what sounds normal to me.
 But that volume knob! Sheeesh! It gets louder and louder!  Ah!!  Soon, you
find yourself having to keep the incoming song volume at normal, while
turning down the playing record, and turning up the master volume at the
same time. which makes it sound like the volume you are not touching is the
one actually getting louder. Then I have to turn the master volume down
while I am turning the sterio volume up! That way my master volume don't
get maxed out, and I can go another 20db on my next mix. But, I mean, you
can never have it to loud. Right guys? Come on......Guys?   Oh...

KATO_Eric nStuff --
-------------------------------
Tip:  When changing records, don't touch the pitch....

-=-=--=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-snipped-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've seen good and bad things happen to peeps when first starting out.
I was taught when first starting to try to always put the pitch back to
zero.  I'm not sure why this happens, perhaps from the shear enjoyment and
adrenaline rush, I found myself creeping the pitch control, continually
speeding up every song just a bit until I had none left.  Searching for
speeding up every song just a bit until I had no advancement left.

   Anybody else ever had that problem?

                                                                Eric

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Leslie Ayres <leslie@netcommunications.net>
Subject: Leslie Speaks?!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear folks,

Recently i met a few people on the list who didn't recognize my name (ah,
horror!) .. so clearly I haven't been spouting off and preaching my motherly
advice lately... and thus, i now give you some observations from the fairy
rave mother.

take it or leave it ... it's up to you.  These are *my* observations, from
*my* perspective ... but some of it may be helpful to some of you.

-----

NEVER assume that this list is filled with people like you.  There are young
people, old people, new-schoolers, old-schoolers, straight, gay, men, women,
people of every color and combination of colors, people who live on your
block and people on other continents. Some of us are fuzzy-plurry-folk, and
some are jaded and cynical. We're all different, and we see the world
differently.  The ONLY commonality is an interest in the rave scene.

------

There are people on this list who use it to satisfy their own agendas.  Some
of whom (apparently from the multiple postings, one after the other, beating
the dead horses to death) seem to have no life outside making their "points"
on sfraves.  Some of these people will take their obnoxious personalities
out on you, and they will twist your words.  If you don't want them to do
that, then don't reply to them.  It's that easy.

-----

When you post something that addresses anything that could be construed as
racist or sexist or whatever .... you will be flamed.  Think carefully about
how you word your messages, because you *will* be called on to defend what
you say.  So read and re-read what you're about to post as your opinion to
450+ people. 

-----

Vulgar language is offensive.  Use it and I, among others, will assume that
you are a vulgar, offensive person.  And I, among others, will conclude that
what you say is not of value -- because, frankly, to me, if you can't make
your point without name-calling, personal attacks and profanity, then your
intellectual capacity to construct a thoughtful argument is clearly
sub-standard, and as a result, your opinions are questionable.

_____

Just because it's email doesn't mean you're talking to a computer or a
faceless row of words.  You're talking to a real person with a history, a
viewpoint, and until you've met that person face to face, and had a real
live conversation with them, then you really don't know who you're talking
to.  Never assume.  Some of the ones who sound the nastiest on here are not
that way in person .... and some of them are.  Until you meet them, you
don't know which is which.  

-----

Starting rumors on sfraves is an irresponsible and damaging thing to do.  It
can damage the unwary subjects of the rumors in many ways.  This "death"
thread is case in point ... it was WRONG information, and yet we've had
hundreds of posts that have continued to promote this misinformation.  Use
your head, don't be sucked into assumptions just because you read it
somewhere.  And pay attention to the subject line of the posts you're
responding to... don't just keep copying something over and over after
you've learned that it was in fact not true.  

_____

Personal attacks should be *personal*.  Copying 450+ people with your
lame-brained nasty attacks and battles is rude and it is wrong.  If you get
your rocks off slinging your insults, go for it.... but not in front of
everyone.  Take it private, and keep it private. This goes beyond
netiquette, it is about behaving like an adult and keeping private
disagreements private. 

____

If you feel a need to post to SFRaves more than a couple of times a day,
please get a life.  This list is a way to share information, not someone's
personal forum to rant and rave, and not just a way to keep busy by sharing
your happy-day wishes with your friends.  

_____

Some people on this list like to be disruptive.  They disappear for long
periods of time, then return and stir up shit just to see what happens.
Why? I'm not a shrink, so my conjecture about their mental state is not
important. But DO NOT let them pull you into their manic crap.  Ignore it,
rise above it, don't get sucked in.  They only thrive on your resistance.
Don't give them the pleasure of your participation in their battles.

_____

It is clearly an ongoing challenge to keep SFRaves a forum for intelligent
and positive discussions about what we have in common -- we love music and
dancing.  Each person can do their part by raising their own standards of
behavior on the list ... sometimes that means refusing to be baited by a
shit-stirrer, and sometimes it means spending some extra time to make your
posts thoughtful and informative.  Sometimes it means apologizing for
something you said that you regret.  Be conscious that this is *our* list,
and every one of us can help keep the standards high.  

This doesn't mean you can't disagree with other people .... just do it with
respect and thought, and disagree on ideas and concepts ... listening to and
learning other people's viewpoints can only make you a better person.

I've left the list a couple of times due to job changes and lack of a
computer...  and when i come back, i often find that the rude and cynical
have taken to running roughshod over the unsuspecting newbies, which really
raises my hackles.

That's why, if i can possibly avoid it, I'm not going anywhere ... because
if the people who care about SFRaves leave (as they often do in desperation
during these exhausting and ridiculous flame wars), then the ones left
behind will suck the life right out of the true possibilities for what this
list is. 

Don't let that happen, folks, because when SFRaves is good, it's very very
good .... 

Leslie

FRANCISCO!!!!!!!!!

Our ideal roomate would be a female, or a male with a female spirit, who
can play with us, create with us, question the world, marvel at the
everyday and respect others.  They would know that it is as important to
respect uniqueness and individuality as it is to recognize
interconnectedness and universality.  We are looking for someone who is
true to themselves, intelligent, creative, & an explorer.

We are three raving, jubilant Goddesses, of varying sexuality.  We are all
self sufficient and together we form a warm and caring community.  The
house is often filled with singing, drumming & philosophizing- but it all
quiets down around 10PM Mon-Thur (hey! we've got day jobs, ya' know!).  Oh,
and there are 2 cats and a turtle on patrol at all times!  If you think
that you have a unique element to contribute to our home- give us a call!

YAAAAAH HEEEYYYY !!!!  :)  :)  :)

finally someone said something that is really down to what's really
going on here.

i didn't want to say anything because i do NOT want to get flamed or
make enemies, esp. w/ being a guest here and all, but...

the great big difference between the rave scene in england and here is
that you guys know each other too well. there's cliques and 'families'
and groups and tribes and every group is bitching about the others.
and don't deny it. i've heard you!

i know it's just human...but wasn't the idea of raving (at least in
the beginning) this wonderful feeling of tolerance, unity, belonging,
a huge family wherever you go? knowing that you can go to a rave
anywhere and you're at home?

is it really inevitable that all movement finally split up and become
tribal and eventually self-destruct in petty wars?

personally i will not get sucked into a clique or tribe and i would
love to continue tribe-hopping here in sf if you let me. (please?!)

see you all at area 51 

iris 



===

standard."
Al in Quantum Leap.

> I don't really post a whole lot but I just read "The Long Boom" in
the 
> July issue of Wired and I would just like to recommend it to
everyone. 
>  It describes how the next 25 or so years could turn out and why
they 
> might turn out that way.  While it doesn't focus on them, two of the 
> important factors it mentions for global prosperity are openness and 
> diversity which I think we  strive for in the rave community.  The 
> article also mentions the fact that leaders are necessary to promote 
> this openness and diversity so that nations don't turn inward and 
> allow the world to fragment into isolated blocks.  Maybe the world
is 
> ready to listen to what the rave community has to say, now we just 
> need to tell them.

In a message dated 97-06-26 04:53:17 EDT, John S. Lee:

<< I am sick of people like yourself bringing the species down with
 this garbage.  Here we are, 3 yearrs from the 21st centuryt and I still
 have to deal with rubbish my great-grandfather had to deal with.  What a
 crock. >>


I don't mean this to sound rude in any way... But if you are so enlightened
and would like people to be more accepting of each other, maybe you should
try to HELP the situation. When you throw harsh words back at someone who you
consider to be a racist or whatever, this only sets us back farther. If you
do recall,   Martin Luther King Jr. stood up to oppression PEACEFULLY. If
things are ever to become accepting among people of different cultures,
people first have to learn to teach people to realize the evil of prejudice
thru enlightenment, no harsh comments that will only put someone on the
defensive.

Someone once asked me why people in general are so mean and so angry... My
response was that people hate the feeling of fear. People fear what they do
not understand... People fear change. And when people feel fear, it makes
them get defensive... It makes them angry. Let's all choose not to be one of
those people... For the sake of mankind... Anger NEVER solves anything....
Ever.

Keep the peace... 
Love 'n' Lucky Charms,
~^v^~ Stefi ~^v^~

At 3:07 PM -0700 6/26/97, Chris Porter wrote:

>So, how do we encourage diversity?  How can we get more peoples of color to
>experience the unity we call rave?

by just being the nurturing and open family that we have the potential to
be.  by fostering tolerance and compassion and allowing it to brim over
into every facet of our lives.  by looking beyond the traps of color,
gender, religion, sexual orientation and anything else which stands to
divide us....

as a child, i used to really like m&ms.  i liked to dump them all out of
the bag and look at all of the different pretty colors.  i would often sit
down at the kitchen table and begin dividing my ration of m&ms up by color,
each different color in a separate pile.  after a while, i grew quite tired
of this method and was very uninspired to even eat the sick things.  but
then one day, i dumped out the bag and saw a different way that i could
split them up: instead of each pile consisting of the same color, i put one
m of each color in each pile. it sure looked pretty.  i was amazed by how
nicely all of the different hues complimented one another.  try it some
time and you'll see what i mean :>

extrapolate whatever meaning you like from this little anecdote.

thanks as always for your captivation....

love,
lola

        /M\          a         r
       ^ V ^ i r t u a l   D e s i g n e r
_______./_\.______lola@cloudfactory.org_____________

Hi all!  

This is just to reiterate what Leslie said.  Please think about what you
say and write!  Remember that these words are representing YOU to
hundreds of people.  Words are a funny thing; they can mean many, many
things depending on each individual's background and beliefs.

Language is a wonderful tool of communication.  It is also,
unfortunately, the basis for much misunderstanding.  But the beauty of
it, I think, lies in the possibilities...

"Every English sentence is a lesson in logic."    (Mark Twain?)
(and probably other langages, too, but i didn't coin the phrase...)

So, it follows that every post should be a lesson in logic as well. 
Think before you speak.

Peace, 
Heather  :o) -- a student of English, soon to be a teacher of the same

>       A helicopter was flying around the northwest region yesterday when
>  an electrical malfunction disabled all of the aircraft's electronic
>  navigation and communications equipment. Due to the clouds and haze,
>  the pilot could not determine the helicopter's position and course to
>  steer to the airport.
> 
>       The pilot saw a tall building, flew toward it, circled, drew a
>  handwritten sign, and held it in the helicopter's window. The pilot's
>  sign said, "WHERE AM I?" in large letters. People in the tall building
>  quickly responded to the aircraft, drew a large sign, and held it in a
>  building window. Their sign said, "YOU ARE IN A HELICOPTER."
> 
>       The pilot smiled, waved, looked at his map, determined the
>  course to SEATAC airport, and landed safely. After they were on the ground,
>  the co-pilot asked the pilot how the "YOU ARE IN A HELICOPTER" sign helped
>  to determine their position. The pilot responded, "I knew we were in
>  Seattle, and that had to be the MICROSOFT building because they gave me a
>  technically correct, but completely USELESS answer."
> 
> bye for now...

Date: Fri, 27 Jun 1997 04:05:37 -0700
In-Reply-To: Dan Capriles <micron1@rocketmail.com>
        "a BIG thank u to JSL" (Jun 26, 12:50pm)
References: <19970626195036.1450.rocketmail@send2.rocketmail.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.1 10oct95)
To: Dan Capriles <micron1@rocketmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: a BIG thank u to JSL
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been away from the list about a week.  On catching up, I'm
more than disappointed by what's been going on here, I'm appalled.
We are experiencing a continual stream of newcomers on this list who
use racially insensitive language.  I don't think this is a
particularity of this list -- if anything, we've been shielded from
this somewhat due to the multi-whatever nature of the Bay Area.
But it's gotten more and more noticeable.  

My very capable, wise and eloquent African-American friends on this
list have been grouching to me about this -- for good reason -- for
over a year.  

Now comes the latest thrash -- as an offshoot of what I think is a
growing concern and disaffection for this scene based on the 
increasing amounts of sketchiness, shiftlessness and self-absorption
that characterize the current period, and show up as an increasing
tendency toward violence.  We are all aware of the increasing risk
of this, which is why I think everyone over-reacted so strongly to
the supposed news to begin with.

But one relatively offhand if unthinking comment nearly blew this
list off its hinges.  This is the worst I've seen it, and I must
say, asking for advance slack 'cause I'm gonna name a name or two
this time, that John Lee over-reacted and let himself succumb to
the feedback loops that always blow up when the race issue comes
around.  I don't think any of the Chris 3 were listening and posting
very carefully either.  There was a lot of heat, friends, and not
much light.  That is not historically the outcome we expect from
sfraves.  

Now let me tell you where I was this past weekend: Detroit.  A city
where race is on the front-and-center of everyone's mind ALL THE TIME.
A city divided, bitterly torn, and yet with a strong sense of itself
and a devotion to what they have been historically and will be in the
future.  A city that will find that future if and only if it finds a
way to stitch back together the different threads of that community.
And it's not just black and white, there's a huge Arab-American
community, many Filipinos, and so on.  

One of the reasons Detroit techno is what it is, is that it bridges
all those gaps.  I went to a club called the Shelter on Friday night,
saw a DJ named Paris mix up a nice offering of house, techno, and a 
bit of jungle, and then Mike Huckaby wind it up with a classic SF-style
house set, for a club full of people of every race, gender and more
than the usual young ages.  All the while we were watching an
immense thunderstorm outside with the lighting crackling across the
clouds above the Renaissance Center (the inert fortress monument to
the wrong way to rebuild a city).  

Music offers a common area to leave behind our prejudices -- we all
have them, the first thing to dealing with your own personal racism
is giving up the idea you don't have any -- and understand that we
are all part of one unified and yet fractious human race.  

The dream of techno goes beyond prejudice and even words and to the
inspiration of the human soul -- when it's at its best.  Nothing's
perfect, the techno music scene in Detroit is just as factionalized
and divided as anywhere else, but that seems to be left aside when
the music plays.  Just like in SF.  

Words are what we use to communicate when we can't use music, and
words are imperfect.  If you were to say "deepest darkest" anywhere
in Metroplex Detroit, you can be damn well sure nobody misunderstands
that as the color of the Detroit River.  Words that inadvertently or
not bring our societal tensions over race to the surface -- especially
phrases like "deepest darkest" that are coded as separating "us" and
"them" -- are the ones most likely to raise a reaction from people
like John.  I hope you will *listen* to what John is really saying,
because it represents a reality for people who must confront this
society's fucked up racial attitudes every single waking moment,
unlike many of us who happen to be in the lighter-skin category.
Admittedly, John's tendency toward rhetorical dramatics might divert
attention from his message -- but the message is always there.  That's

why I find Black Adder's dismissive handwave so distasteful.  When
we stop listening, we stop learning.  That doesn't look good on any
of us -- and I've generally found Black Adder's views well constructed
and explained, and he's not afraid to state it even when it's not
popular.  

I'm NOT for an avoidance of conflict.  This isn't any goody two shoes
sitcom superficial view of life where we all agree we are Good People
and go to scenes from next week's episode.  This is a part of real life
where we make mistakes and misunderstand context and jump to conclusions
and blow up at each other . . . and generally, if we're smart, start
realizing it looks a little foolish to have your fingers typing ahead
of your brain after all.

We are in a cynical down-cycle of the music scene in my opinion.
I don't think succumbing to cynicism or avoiding the issue in a cotton
candy cloud of PLURity is the way to go.  My view of it is -- if you
got far enough to get to sfraves, you're doing good so far, now learn
from that and teach it well by how you think and act.

I'm climbing down from the soapbox once more.  Hope y'all don't mind
my bit of reality, I'm still learning this stuff too.

peace out 
phred

From: "John S. Lee" <jsl@nexsys.net>
Subject: Apologies part II
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't know what happened to my original apology post but I did do one.
Let me reitereate for those who may not have gotten it.

I was out of line with all the f-you's, and a-holes, and other vitriol.  I
should not have lost my temper in such an immature fashion.  I am sorry for
the disruption my words may have caused since it has had a negative effect
on the list.  For those people who I offended I offer my sincere apologies,
there was no need for you to get caught up in my madness.

Next time I see something devicive on the list I will be a bit more
careful.  Since that time I have made apologies to both Chris in the hopes
that we might reach and understanding and I think we all, in some way have.
We are taking steps toward greater understanding and appreciation, in both
directions.

So I wanted to put this out to you all in the hopes of increasing the peace.

With that said I also want to make one thing very clear.  This apology in
no way deflects from the fact that there was a poor choice of words and
insensitivtiy in the original post.  I am not apologizing for what I said,
just how I said it, it could have been done in a far more elegant fashion
w/o the cursing, name calling, baiting, etc.

I would hope that we, as a group, will stop and think about our audience.
Just as I can see how people could be offended by my words, people should
also see how thier words hurt others as well.  My understanding of this is
very clear, I can only hope that yours becomes as clear.  If we stop
considering each other then we will fight, rest assured.  And as we
approach the millenium do we really wanna go out like this, or like humans
w/ a sense of understanding about one another?  The choice will always be
ours.

Have a good one & peace,
John

P.S.  To the others who piped up against me that is your choice.  Hopefully
I am in your killfile as you are most certainly in mine.  Another chance at
understanding lost, but you can't win 'em all, and now we will both miss
out.  The strangest thing about the vitriolic responses was not that they
came, but who they came from.  As I expected the most vile came from the
people who use an acronym but when it came to brass tacks it was an ideal
they could not uphold.  Then there were the others who probalby live the
ideal, from them I heard nary a word.  It proved to me that yes there is
certainly hope for us all, but there will always be hypocrisy as we try to
strive for that ideal.

Now if you would kindly do so, spare the list from any more personal
flames.  I could care less with all the personal jsl this and that, I find
it rather  amusing (Megan and I got a few good laughs - although she was
going to fire something off that was not going to be nice so...).  Funny my
calling someone a-hole, and f-u was far worse than somone perception of
petential racism.  It speaks volumes about what people see as important and
why.  It is also a testament as to how far we really have to go before we
can all get along. There is no progress w/o struggle.

Only two more posts today...these had better be good. ;)

Over & out...ohh I forgot.  Thank you to all of those who understood where
I was coming from and why.  Much love to you all, you know who you are.
True warriors  all, and very real indeed.  I do promise to make an effort,
seriously, to meet with the lot of you, maybe at one of, er "your" events (
;) ), maybe over beers on a friday or saturday afternoon.  I have a car and
will travel.  It has been too long and it's time to hook up.  JC @ Sun;
you're the bomb and Florida is definitely in the house!  Much love to all
you crackerjacks!  Now please, do me a favor and dance.  I gotta find a
party or something this weekend so I'ze can listen to some good old
fashioned house music...better yet I'll make a tape and spare myslef
potential record touching DJ's ;).  Pax!

"What is house music, a unique form, a unique form, of music." - DJ Pierre
"Peace, live in it, or rest in it.  Come toghether, peace..." - DJ Pierre

X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.01 (Macintosh; I; PPC)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RealAudio Archive of House/Rave Tracks 
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; x-mac-type="54455854"; x-mac-creator="4D4F5353"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hiya All!

I've got an idea that I would like to implement on my spare time.
I am an owner of a digital communications company (sorry, sales &
marketing rhetoric - we make CD-ROMs, web sites, quicktime video stuff)
and am thinking of setting up a RealAudio archive of the best of
Techno/House/Rave for all of us to use when we want to revisit the
classics or research a track.
I stopped being a public DJ several years ago and have been buying
tracks on CD now instead of Vinyl (my 1200's were stolen  accelerating
my retirement). I have many classic house tracks that would be cool to
put online for people to listen to.
We have servers and all that cool stuff here and a little creative side
time would be great.
The problem is this:
There are many DJs that are on this list who probably don't have a whole
lot of spare time, but I am hoping there are those out there who have
some sort of way to capture audio to their computer (by way of a .wav or
.aiff file) and encode the audio to realAudio (via the free downloadable
RealAudio Encoder 3.0 or 4.0) and send it off to me.
I'll put online my stuff as well as whoever sends me what they think is
classic.
I'd like to include artist, personal notes from the submitter (why they
think it is classic), label, date created or something.
We could collect memories from people the first time they heard the
track.
(like the first time I heard bombscare - 2badmice - that is a story). To
have a place that gives context to our experiences would be awesome.

Anyway, I'd like some feedback on this one.

I think it would rock.

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com
http://www.citiscape.com

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Just curious, how much did those bad girls cost?

J&R Music World (look up # in http://garbanzo.ssesco.com/nau/mailorder.htm)
sells the CDJ-500mkII's for $599 ea, and the M-500 (mixer, you can use any
old mixer however, but this one is real nice) for $799. There's a complete
package they sell for $2300 which includes a custom Anvil case that fits
both CD players and the mixer (which is smaller than 19" rackmount standard
sized mixers)...

>Yea, I want to know too. And also, do they have digital outputs (S/PDIF). 

Unfortunately, not.

The reason for this, IMHO, is that you'd have to get into some relatively
expensive rate-resampling hardware in order to keep the SPDIF standard
44.1Khz sample rate on the output while the "input" sample rate changed
with the pitch slider (since that changes the bit-rate coming off the CD).
I don't have the schematic, but that's my OPINION based on my knowledge of
digital audio (go ahead and flame me, cathode and nodeOne, ya wankers).

==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

because neither of us is going to change viewpoints. You have some
preconceived notion of me as some useless drugged out lolly pop sucking
trendoid raver who doesn't know his ass from a hole in the ground... I
could turn blue in the face trying to convince you that this is not the
case but what would be the point??? Where would it get me??? What would it
teach you??? Nowhere and nothing.... I have seen your credentials, I know
what you do... I know that others may be impressed but alas I am not... I
believe that you know what you are talking about most of the time but I
also believe that you have neglected to educate yourself on many facets of
electronic music production and presentation ( i.e Instruments and records

is Owen ) say on the basis that we could not possibly know as much about it
as you do but in reality you have no clue as to the depth or breadth of our
combined knowledge... You take to insulting us as people for no reason
other than your obvious inability to carry on a didactic conversation...You
have insulted Josh about his profession and I'm sure you would insult me
about mine if you had any clue as to what I do... You may know about
electronics but you have revealed your lack of understanding in the fields
of art and design...oh well, nobody is perfect... Have a nice day and keep
the flames a' comin'

Root sez:
>I have a CD-G but I never use it. Is the "G" for graphics? Is this a
>Karaoke box?
>Does the "1" count always start at the beginning of the song?

I think that's what it might stand for... I think it'll play little vid
discs, although I've never tried it.   I use the "g" as one half of my
mixing rig - it works great except for the wear and tear... great for
home/studio dj use.

You can set the 1 count wherever you like:

Make sure you are on AUTO CUE mode by holding that little Auto Cue button
down until its on. Then hit pause, and adjust the pitchwheel to where you
want "beat 1". (I do it to exactly one frame before the kick or whatever
beat 1 is hits) Then hit cue, and it'll remember that as the "punch in"
point... Hit play or mess with the cue button like a sampler... its really
short though. (on the II's or mkII's you can hold cue indefinitely)


>I have a lame dual cd player because the pitch change is'nt constant or
>linear.
>But...is most of the problem with me because I havent done this for long?
>Can I learn on a cheap box?

I guess it depends on your abilities? I dunno. I can only really tell you
my experience, I've tried the rack mount denon's once, and I was able to
sorta do it on the first try, but I had been mixing for awhile already...
The cdj's seem far easier to make mental sense with...

Hope that helps!

-j.

Just something to consider....Its not the actual article just a 
synopsis from http://sciencenow.sciencemag.org/html/970626a.htm


Don't Put That in Your Pipe and Smoke It!

Compared to heroin and cocaine, many people--scientists and teenagers 
alike--consider marijuana a relatively benign substance. Two new 
studies in tomorrow's Science demonstrate, however,that marijuana's 
effects on the brain are disturbingly similar to those produced by 
highly addictive drugs. The findings may help scientists devise better 
strategies for treating marijuana dependence, for which some 100,000 
people in the United States alone seek therapy each year.

After previously linking a brain peptide called corticotropin 
releasing factor (CRF) to anxiety and stress in people withdrawing 
from alcohol, cocaine, and opiates, a team of researchers from The 
Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, California, along with two 
visiting scientists from Complutense University of Madrid in Spain, 
set out to investigate whether CRF might mediate the stressful malaise 
that some long-term marijuana users experience after quitting.

The active ingredient in marijuana is a cannabinoid known as THC. The 
researchers injected a synthetic version of the compound into more 
than 50 rats once a day for 2 weeks to mimic the effects of heavy, 
long-term marijuana use in people. The researchers produced a dramatic 
withdrawal syndrome by injecting the rats with a newly developed drug 
that counteracts THC. The group found the rats' anxiety levels, as 
measured in a standard behavioral test, shot up, and they displayed 
exaggerated signs of stress such as compulsive grooming and teeth 
chattering during withdrawal. What's more, when the scientists 
measured CRF levels in the rats' brains, they found that rats in 
withdrawal had two to three times more CRF than controls not given the 
antagonist.

The results, experts say, provide the first neurochemical basis for a 
marijuana withdrawal syndrome, and one with a strong emotional 
component that is shared by other abused drugs. ``The work suggests 
that the CRF system may be a part of a common experience in 
withdrawal--that is, anxiety,'' says Alan Leshner, Director of the 
National Institute on Drug Abuse.

But withdrawal is just one component of addiction. Addictive drugs 
also have immediate rewarding, or reinforcing, effects that keep 
people and animals coming back for more. The drugs produce these 
effects, scientists believe, by stimulating the brain's so-called 
reward system. A key event in the reward pathway is the release of 
dopamine by a small cluster of neurons in a brain region called the 
nucleus accumbens. When Gaetano Di Chiara and colleagues at the 
University of Cagliari in Italy infused THC into a small group of 
rats, they found that dopamine levels in the nucleus accumbens jumped 
to double those in control rats infused with an inactive 
cannabinoid--a surge similar to that seen with heroin.

The studies ``send a powerful message that should raise everyone's 
awareness about the dangers of marijuana use,'' says David Friedman, a 
neurobiologist at Bowman Gray School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, 
North Carolina. But they also suggest avenues for treating marijuana 
dependence: For instance, chemicals that block the effects of CRF or 
even relaxation exercises might soothe the miserable moods experienced 
by people in THC withdrawal.

(c) 1997 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science

>>>>> "Chris" == Chris Porter <cporter@exploretech.com> writes:

    Chris> In best DEVO voice "Mongoloid man/He was a Mongoloid
    Chris> man/Same as you and meeee..."  Those Wacky Devo guys sure
    Chris> were racist eh?  How many of us are old enough to remember
    Chris> that song?  Three?  Four?  <sigh>
	Um, first of all I am more than old enough to remember them,
and had all their first-ed LP's. Second, Devo was not refering to
people of asian descent, and the lyrics of the song were pretty clear
on that. They were referring to someone with Down's Syndrome, which
used to be called mongolism (perhaps because of the epicanthic folds
around the eyes). Especially true in the verse right after the one you
quoted "...one chromosome too many..."

	What I have been trying and trying to find are copies of Gary
Numan's albums (or CDs, if they were ever rereleased). I had all of
those as well and I would _kill_ to find a copy of "Are friends
electric" or "Telekon" again. Why is it that a bands/signers most
successful public album is usually the one that is LEAST their style?
(In G. Newman's case, "The Pleasure Principle"...)

	If you were just being sarcastic, then apologies. ;-)

	Marisa

Subject: This Week's SFR Calendar!

Precedence: bulk


Pride weekend should be massive here in SF, starting Friday night with
Organic, Little Louie Vega at the Sound Factory, and Happy Kids and 
Society.  Saturday features the massive Area 51, as well as some outdoors -
Grumpy Kids and Hijack, plus the weeklies (solid is supposed to be good, 
and dubtribe is back in town for vanilla fudge).  On Sunday, get some
sun at the Pride Parade along Market and dance on the Embarcadero.  Finally,
if you're still up on Tuesday, Stacey Pullen and DJ Disciple are coming
to 1015 Folsom...


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi
