Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 5pm-9pm - The Beta Lounge - Live netcast of jungle, dub,
       breakbeat, hiphop, ambient, experimental.
       http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 6-8pm - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C.
       Electronic dance, noise, spoken word, world music and more. Beats
       for your head. Sounds for your soul. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Saturday night 8-10pm - "Underbrush" w/DJ Radon - Beats, Breakz
       and Buzz KZSU 90.1 (Stanford).
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Lemme get this straight: It took over 50 rats, a team of researchers,
and two scientists from Spain to find out that it feels good to smoke
weed and that it makes you want to smoke it again?? Shit man, I could of
told you that!

I checked out those other two articles. The title of one was:

"Activation of Corticotropin-Releasing Factor in the Limbic System
During Cannabinoid Withdrawal"

I call it "Fiending"

I hope my tax dollars didn't pay for this...

-=Pengo=-

Jay Wiley wrote:
> 
> Just something to consider....Its not the actual article just a
> synopsis from http://sciencenow.sciencemag.org/html/970626a.htm
> 
> Don't Put That in Your Pipe and Smoke It!
> 
> Compared to heroin and cocaine, many people--scientists and teenagers
> alike--consider marijuana a relatively benign substance. Two new
> studies in tomorrow's Science demonstrate, however,that marijuana's
> effects on the brain are disturbingly similar to those produced by
> highly addictive drugs. The findings may help scientists devise better
> strategies for treating marijuana dependence, for which some 100,000
> people in the United States alone seek therapy each year.
> 
> After previously linking a brain peptide called corticotropin
> releasing factor (CRF) to anxiety and stress in people withdrawing
> from alcohol, cocaine, and opiates, a team of researchers from The
> Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, California, along with two
> visiting scientists from Complutense University of Madrid in Spain,
> set out to investigate whether CRF might mediate the stressful malaise
> that some long-term marijuana users experience after quitting.
> 
> The active ingredient in marijuana is a cannabinoid known as THC. The
> researchers injected a synthetic version of the compound into more
> than 50 rats once a day for 2 weeks to mimic the effects of heavy,
> long-term marijuana use in people. The researchers produced a dramatic
> withdrawal syndrome by injecting the rats with a newly developed drug
> that counteracts THC. The group found the rats' anxiety levels, as
> measured in a standard behavioral test, shot up, and they displayed
> exaggerated signs of stress such as compulsive grooming and teeth
> chattering during withdrawal. What's more, when the scientists
> measured CRF levels in the rats' brains, they found that rats in
> withdrawal had two to three times more CRF than controls not given the
> antagonist.
> 
> The results, experts say, provide the first neurochemical basis for a
> marijuana withdrawal syndrome, and one with a strong emotional
> component that is shared by other abused drugs. ``The work suggests
> that the CRF system may be a part of a common experience in
> withdrawal--that is, anxiety,'' says Alan Leshner, Director of the
> National Institute on Drug Abuse.
> 
> But withdrawal is just one component of addiction. Addictive drugs
> also have immediate rewarding, or reinforcing, effects that keep
> people and animals coming back for more. The drugs produce these
> effects, scientists believe, by stimulating the brain's so-called
> reward system. A key event in the reward pathway is the release of
> dopamine by a small cluster of neurons in a brain region called the
> nucleus accumbens. When Gaetano Di Chiara and colleagues at the
> University of Cagliari in Italy infused THC into a small group of
> rats, they found that dopamine levels in the nucleus accumbens jumped
> to double those in control rats infused with an inactive
> cannabinoid--a surge similar to that seen with heroin.
> 
> The studies ``send a powerful message that should raise everyone's
> awareness about the dangers of marijuana use,'' says David Friedman, a
> neurobiologist at Bowman Gray School of Medicine in Winston-Salem,
> North Carolina. But they also suggest avenues for treating marijuana
> dependence: For instance, chemicals that block the effects of CRF or
> even relaxation exercises might soothe the miserable moods experienced
> by people in THC withdrawal.
> 
> (c) 1997 by the American Association for the Advancement of Science

Chris wrote:

> >Anyway, I'd like some feedback on this one.
> >
> >I think it would rock.
>
>         everything sounds great, except for the fact that it is
> illegal. I
> would never have mentioned this if you had said you wanted to collect
> any
> major corporate album, but when it comes to any techno or 'rave' music
> I
> have to let my respect for the artists overpower me not to pirate
> their
> tracks. I hope many of you other out there feel this way too. Most of
> the
> tracks I have are by smaller productions where it's obvious no one is
> making
> too much money. Now, if we want to get some Chemical Bros. or Moby
> tracks on
> there, go ahead, I don't have any.
>
>         -chris

  

Actually I'm thinking along the lines of the "fair usage laws" that
exist around copyright for this idea.
There is fair usage for any media that is used for editorial purposes
(we deal with this all the time w/ Citi:Zen Magazine -
http://www.citizenmag.com) and that is what I am advocating for this
"spare-time" project.
We deal with licensing issues all the time and I am extremely sensitive
to artists need for payment and recognition for useage, so I would not
violate the law in any way.
What would be great tho, is mucho commentary on people's experience w/
certain tracks, why it should be considered a classic track or not, and
then an example of what it souds like (30 sec. - 1 minute w/o clearance,
or the whole song if I can get clearance from the label, artist, or
holding company). The problem I'm trying to solve is this:

Your at a party and you get into this situation, "Man, remeber that
track that goes....wonk, wonk, wonk, and then blam, this huge break
kicks in" or something, and the person is like, "uh, yeah, I think
so...".

It would be great to have a site that was geared towards a living
history of the music. It would give it some context in a static way and
a place for people who love the music and wish to comment on it could.

Anyway, I see this as an audio yearbook or family album (hmmmmm, that
might make a good name....) or something similar.

Also:

Chemical Bros. - 17th Century Sky
Moby - Go

Classics. Should be noted somewhere dontcha think?

rob
http://www.citizenmag.com

or will there be some at the door?  Do we know what part of the bay area
will be home to said event?  Cause, and I mean this baby, just a little
Love is all I Need.

- David

Received: from localhost (mayer@localhost) by netcom23.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)

Subject: Re: Records 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 27 Jun 97 14:34:33 -0800."
             <v02130510afd9eef4c9aa@[157.22.229.127]> 
Date: Fri, 27 Jun 97 17:48:10 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I've heard that cleaning records with rubbing alcohol works like a charm.

Very bad idea...

>     o   Any truth to this?

Yes, alchohol is a very good solvent. 

>     o   Any post or pre treatment, if I do use alcohol?

A good post-treatment might be financial preparation to eventually buy
a new record.

>     o  Any risk of damaging the grooves?

Excellent risk.. Alchohol removes the binders and stabilizers from the
vinyl and leads to increased wear, increased oxidation from exposure to
light/air, and eventual breakdown, esp. with the needle tracking
through the damaged vinyl.

Go to an audiophile store (aka, not the good guys) and ask them if they
carry wet record vacuums. Perhaps check the rec.audio.* newsgroups and
FAQs Altermately, find a shop that'll clean your records for you. I
don't know if places still do this, but I know such service was
available back in the days when "turntable" didn't connote an
overpriced boat anchor with a lousy tonearm and non-phase-locked pitch
control. :-)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Admission is sliding scale we suggest $6... but....

If you remember to bring your ID then the Admission is $12 for an all 
you can drink stamp. Only 100 drinking stamps will be sold so come 
early!

Barbie-Q food will be cheap as will water and sodas.(Water fountain by 
bathrooms)
If you are truly broke Trader Joes is right next door or you can bring 
stuff from home. Please no underage drinking on premises. We will have 
to ask you to leave and we dont like to do that.

The first study is BS, marijuana withdrawal is caused by the antagonist
drug. The thing about weed is that it is metabolized slowly, staying in
your system for up to thirty days,. when the antagonist is used to suddenly
remove the THC from the bloodstream withdrawal effects were produced, this
is not, IMHO, good science.  

----------
> From: Jay Wiley <jwiley@BerkeleyNet.com>
> To: 'sfraves@hyperreal.com'
> Subject: Don't Put That in Your Pipe and Smoke It!
> Date: Friday, June 27, 1997 12:09 PM
> 
> Just something to consider....Its not the actual article just a 
> synopsis from http://sciencenow.sciencemag.org/html/970626a.htm
> 
> 
> Don't Put That in Your Pipe and Smoke It!
> 
> Compared to heroin and cocaine, many people--scientists and teenagers 
> alike--consider marijuana a relatively benign substance. Two new 
> studies in tomorrow's Science demonstrate, however,that marijuana's 
> effects on the brain are disturbingly similar to those produced by 
> highly addictive drugs. The findings may help scientists devise better 
> strategies for treating marijuana dependence, for which some 100,000 
> people in the United States alone seek therapy each year.
> 
>stressful malaise 
> that some long-term marijuana users experience after quitting.
> 
> The active ingredient in marijuana is a cannabinoid known as THC. The 
> researchers injected a synthetic version of the compound into more 
> than 50 rats once a day for 2 weeks to mimic the effects of heavy, 
> long-term marijuana use in people. The researchers produced a dramatic 
> withdrawal syndrome by injecting the rats with a newly developed drug 
> that counteracts THC. The group found the rats' anxiety levels, as 
> measured in a standard behavioral test, shot up, and they displayed 
> exaggerated signs of stress such as compulsive grooming and teeth 
> chattering during withdrawal. What's more, when the scientists 
> measured CRF levels in the rats' brains, they found that rats in 
> withdrawal had two to three times more CRF than controls not given the 
> antagonist.		 The studies ``send a powerful message that should raise
everyone's 
> awareness about the dangers of marijuana use,'' says David Friedman, a 
> neurobiologist at Bowman Gray School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, 
> North Carolina.<<<<I wonder why a med school there would be interested in
vilivying weed?
> 
>
>

Hello all!

Just decided to send off some early am comments re: the happy kiddos
last night....

Is it just me or was the voicemail updated really late?

Overall it was pretty nice.  But as usual, HOT HOT HOT.  Main room
between 12-2:00 seemed to have a wierd energy.  once the vibe picked up
and everyone was jumpin' to the music, the pace would s l o w then pick
up and then slow and over and over...remember, maybe it was just me.

relatively roomy and spacious...seemed to be plenty of room to shake
your stuff, especially downstairs where some serious sounds were
happening!

nice glowey things everywhere and big hugs to the girl walking around
with the water bottle spraying all of the hot dancers!  

I do have a comment that i hope i'll get some feedback on....i went
alone hoping to meet up with some of you.  my computer crashed while
everyone was sharing meeting spots, pre-parties, who's going, when
etc....so i missed all that.  i only knew names but figured i'd run into
one of you!  no luck at all and i was totally bummed about it.  i
remember a message that someone posted about walking into a party alone
and the feeling you get.  no one talks to you, or makes you really feel
welcome.  i told him it was up to him to walk up to people and make an
effort cause no one in this crowd would turn you down! well i was
wrong.  i tried to talk to several people and ask if they knew any of
you, but people were generally just *blaugh* to me!  why?  i was
obviously alone.  one person was nice enough to introduce himself when i
walked in, but that was really it.  i didn't get smiles from many
people, not even a hi how are you doing!  i generally go out with a lot
of europeans to parties and events and i definitely feel a different
thing goin on.  at least people say hi to you.  :-( boy i sound like a
pathetic person right now don't i?? boo hoo I'm not terrible looking,
(medium length dark brown hair, blond streaks on either side, about
5'6", japanese, german, swiss, dutch and irish blood going on) maybe
it's because i'm 28 and i exude that "old" vibe. :-(

well, enough feeling sorry for myself i still had a great time dancing
on my own and checking out the scene!  if anyone is going to grumpy kids
tonight PLEASE fill me in on how i can spot some of you!  i was so upset
that i didn't meet any of you last night. :-(  i'll definitely be at the
brannan location on sunday eve after the parade and i'm going to
spundae's various embarcadero/broadway parties and will be there shakin
my groove thing sun night to see a fav dj.

looking forward to hearing more from you!

I just gotta start out by saying this: happy kids crew, GREAT JOB!!! :)

The party was awesome. I was a little worried when the VM wasnt updated by 10:00 (when the party started). So, my two totally-new-to-raving friends and I went up to 
F8 to see what was going on.  Lo and behold, we get tickets, and head on down to the familiar rave spot. When we first got there, I ran into some people I knew and we 
started dancing. This was the first party I went to with a laminate, and I was sooo happy to meet all you fellow SFRavers. Great decorations and the music was incredible. 
The wall of speakers in the main room was fun :) Unfortunately, my driver had to leave at 2:30 so we didnt get to stay that long, but it was still a great party with a great vibe.

Gotta say hi to Jil, Earthlen, Mercutio, Leslie, Rubilicious, Adam, and all the other SFRavers I met (sorry if I left anyone out :P~)
Also hiya to julie, jon cooper, and eric who i didnt see (where were you guys? :) )

I hope everyone had enough fun as I did :)

Hugs and Love, Diego.

Gawd, I love all caps,

Anyway I finally got to see what people were talking about in their
differentiation of "scene vs clubber" (jsl interpretation).

All I can say is that is warranted, however it is due to the TOTAL lack of
attendance by pople in the so-called "know" (i.e. ravers).  What I meant by
that is that clubbers were always an element of the scene, however they
were often numerically offest by the number of ravers in attendance (from
my recollection of rave history).  With this in mind  I certianly
undetrstand how some ravers feel being the only people who "get it".  There
is little doubt that the vibe is there, the real reason is numbers (i.e.
the number of ravers to crawlers read: clubbers).  If you are not going to
go out because of clubbers then you automatically succumb the the tide of
clubbers which , btw will always be there in one form or another.

Be sure to support the Dj's in your scene at all times.  It's one of the
reasons many still play at primarily underground events and not KMEL
events.  Your suppport, timed acurately, can make all the difference (the
day I hear Jeno on KMEL is the day I stop buying dance music altogether).

Props to Dj Monty & Dj JJ of Sugar Shack to lay down deep house in a
learning fashion ( in other words, people were schooled).  Much props to
Monty & JJ, great work.

I also met the famous (or infamous in the techno scene) Joe Rice, A big
lumbering DJ of a guy who has much respect from both old & new school.  It
was GREAT meeting the man behind the words.  I will make MAD (per Monty's
suggestion) to get more schooling!

If you acquiesce this scene to those who could care less about the music
and are about requests, versus those who are in it to dance, then we are
surely doomed.

As schooled this evening by one DJ Loren -  "The real difference between us
and clubbers is, we don't need a reason to dance."

Nuff said, this is true science,
John S. Lee

P.S.  I consider myself schooled!

Have a good weekend, off to ther parties.

P.S.  Props to Chris Lum for the traks he's just created, and his
incredible set  at the Zebra party.  Yes, it;;s time for jsl to start
making the rounds and getting schooled in the current state of house music.
Also I spent a considerable amount ($$$) this weekend on jungle a very deep
moody house! Wanna play? ;)

Peace and have fun this weekend!,
John

P.S.  I love gay pride week.month, it's all about Sf and the positive stuff
that make us, US.

Pax.

Subject: Area 51 review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com

        Due to a drastic last minute change of plans involving me and a
guest list, I decided to go to Area 51 instead of Grumpy Kids. It was an odd
decision. But I had lots of fun at the Area 51 party. The problems were the
sound quality in the 'star' room(which kicked ass as far as visuals!), the
messed up bass of the chill room, and the over scene in the 'reactor' room(I
hate circles of watchers, and seeing tons of guys freaking girls.) But lemme
tell you, did I have a little help from my buddy the 5th letter of the
alphabet. So I had a great time dancing to the sort of distorted music, and
meeting lots of new people. I didn't actually meet a single SFraver there,
but I met some guys I knew back in high school which was very odd. I then
got a hold of some glow sticks and a lot of pot, so we went through that I
danced during the two ambient sets in the chill room for quite long.(I was
the tall, brown-haired guy with the two glowsticks dancing in front,
sometimes I was the only one dancing). But it was quite exciting for me. I
guess if you didn't share my experience, it's quite concieveable. The vibe
wasn't great, but at times you'd meet people who'd put a smile on your
face(hugs to Erin and Denise)... so what can I say? maybe others liked it
too. I noticed another problem was somewhat shabby mixing at times. I
couldn't quite believe the amount of trainwrecks, and the number of time the
music stopped in the 'star' room, and the DJ's in the chill room who would
just let a record finish than put another one on. But oh well...

        -chris

Hey everyone,
 
        Hm.. let me think.  Pretty small for a massive.  But a massive none
the less.  They were having a tough time getting their acts together...and we
didn't get into the door until 11p.m., because they were still setting up.  I
enjoyed the humor of a security guard, who when asked by one of the many
gangsta looking people cruising 85th what was going on replied, "It's a big
orgy."  If that doesn't bring unwanted people into the scene, I don't know
what will.
       THe entrance tunnel was interesting, but all of the reflective
material was falling off.  It was smoky and dirty, but things like that never
really bother me.  I met more SFRAvers then I've ever seen in my life!! Even
before the 2a.m. meeting arrangement. 
       Hello to MY Tweaker Teresa, Matt, Paula, Victoria (<~~~ look, I got
your name right!) Other matt, Mark, Jive,Nick, Sky, Ari, GLitter Princess
(can't remember your real name, but the pants were so cool!) Beth, ANd all my
other SFRavers!
        Favorite things:
     Getting compliments on my fuzzy yellow shirt
      Getting lots of hugs from people for no reason
      Getting Free water (at a massive?!?!?!)
      Meeting everyone not on the list
       Meeting everyone on the list
       ThE BIG SFR HUG CiRCLE
      Getting taken care of when I once again, could not find my ride.
         It wasn't the best party in the world, but it felt that way last
night.  I know I, along with other people, got to make some newbies feel real
special.  DOesn't that just make you *SMILE*?  Well, I hope to meet more of
you, and this review is kind of strange seeing as how I'm still kind of
tired.  Too bad I had to leave early, but next time I will stay forever.  See
you all at Freedom?  Ok.. Going to work now.

Subject: last Mad July 14th (bsp)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

After close to 2 years, we've decided to take a hiatus from throwing Mad to
relax a bit and focus on some other pursuits. (Did someone say Mad the
label?)

The final Mad will be July 14th.

When Mad started I don't think we had any idea of how lucky we'd be in
being able to present the music and the DJ's we've had, nor how supportive
and wonderful the clubgoers would be. It's been a good run, and thank you
to everyone who's come to Mad and in doing so, added to it. I've always
felt Mad and SFR had a close affinity and often is the Monday night when
you can meet many SFRavers in person. Thanks also to all of the DJ's who
have supported us and come down to play. And personally, I have to give the
utmost respect and props to Ethan, Alex, and Jon Santos who started the
whole thing and to Sho and Monty who kept things going and added new
vitality when Ethan and Jon had to take time to do other things.

xAnd yeah, I'm sad to see it go, but we'll be around....

Joe

Message-Id: <v03102801afdc9fbf41ef@[207.93.14.64]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 29 Jun 1997 16:01:43 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
Subject: Sat. night review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

One of San Francisco's strengths is it's diversity and variety, which is
also reflected in how and where people go to have fun. I ended up at a few
vastly different events last night, and they were all going off in their
own way - a quick rundown:

Started out at the Cloud Factory/Pro-Soy ambient dinner, which was an
excellent idea and I'm sorry I didn't get to stay longer. Basically there
was loads of excellent vegan food from Pro-Soy, and some ambient being
DJ'd, and an oppprtunity to spend some time with friends from the scene in
an environment where you can actually hear what they're saying and
everyone's in a normal frame of mind. This is the type of thing where ideas
and bonds are created.

Headed over to, dare I say it, a club - V/SF, or more correctly Pablo's
Suger Shack (Who's Pablo?), where Monty was playing as the SFR
representative. Due to recent talk on SFR I was more attentive than usual
to what was going down. People were having fun. That's what was going down.
Sure, there was a bit of cruising going on, and there was a bit of dressed
up 'look at me' attitude, but then again, I daresay candy ravers spend as
much time on their outfits. To be sure, this wasn't the same crowd you'd
find at 1015 on a Friday, at least from what I've seen - it seemed that
more people were into the music and dancing than just drinking and
scamming. Sure it wasn't a rave, and I didn't feel the potential of the
transcendant shared experience that occurs at the best undergrounds, but
this particular club was full of people out dancing and having a good time.
And I finally met John S. Lee face to face and you know what? He was
smiling. And dancing. I'm glad I had the chance to meet him after learning
much from his words. (And I look forward to seeing you at Mad, John =)  ) I
even thought I caught the glint of strobe off of glitter for a brief moment
while glancing his direction... =)

It's not the venue, it's the people. And the underground has an amazingly
high concentration of wonderful people, but that doesn't mean we're any
better than anyone else.

Headed out from V/SF to check out Grumpy Kids, which appered to have been
long busted by the time we got there. I suspect the fact that the
Wonderland afterparty was busted here last week might have focused some
scrutiny on the area.

>From there it was on to Hijack which was still bumpin' with straight up
techno, courtesy of John Mendez from LA. There were probably about 150
people there when I arrived, but the cold was starting to drive people
home. It was here I realized part of the reason I'd stayed so long at V/SF
was that I'd been with a bunch of friends and while I also had a bunch of
friends at Hijack, it tends to be a more open vibe if you don't know anyone
at an underground... We stayed for about an hour and caught some of Tang's
set as well, which was starting to rock nicely. Hopefully this LA DJ will
get more chances to play up here...

There's a new Sunday night techno thing happening at the Paradise (a 21+
bar), Polk and Geary. Tonight Markus and Paul from Open Mind will be
hosting...

Joe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 29 17:59:36 1997
Received: (from majordom@localhost)
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) id RAA04985;
	Sun, 29 Jun 1997 17:59:36 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from upsmot01.msn.com (upsmot01.msn.com [204.95.110.78])
	by hyperreal.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with SMTP id RAA04974
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 29 Jun 1997 17:59:31 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from upmajb09 ([204.95.110.82]) by upsmot01.msn.com (8.6.8.1/Configuration 4) with SMTP id RAA10865 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sun, 29 Jun 1997 17:57:56 -0700
Date: Mon, 30 Jun 97 01:03:00 UT
From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>
Message-Id: <UPMAIL18.199706300058210404@msn.com>
To: "funkateers" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Alternate Review--the best was saved for last
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Review (short version):  The party was not too good.  But DJ Kei and Stillwind 
(who's on this list, give him props folx) saved my night.

Long version:
We finally get to Bo Jangles (a club where the party was held) at 1:15 a.m.  
We just took Vivarin and ate too many Pixie Stix, so we're hyped (who needs E? 
 j/k).  Outside the party we hear yelling and some noise that sounds like 
music, and meet a guy pissed off because he's not enjoying the party too much 
(turns out he had good reason).  But we're here, so we pay our $7 and go in.

There is no house/techno room.  Just jungle, outside.  They won't let us 
inside the club, rumor has it they'll open it at 1:30 and play some house.  
This wouldn't be bad if they weren't playing the WORST jungle I've ever heard 
in my life.  It made me sick.  But I saw some friends, including some sfravers 
(Hi Scott!  Hi Stillwind!), so I was enjoying myself.  BTW, whoever the 
brunette girl was who Scott introduced me to, who I guess is on the list, 
sorry I seemed kind of out of it when I spoke to you . . . I couldn't hear 
anything you guys were saying.  Sorry!

Now I've never heard MCs before.  But I did that night.  Maybe they were bad 
MCs, maybe the music was just so bad everything seemed bad.  But hearing some 
guy yell "MAKE SOME MUTHAFUCKIN NOISE . . . AWWWW SHHHHHIIIIIIIT . . . THROW 
YO' HANDS UP . . . LET ME HEAR ALL THE RUDE BOYS IN THE HOUSE . . . AWWWWW 
YEAH!!!"  got kind of annoying after awhile.

Okay, so they open up the house room inside.  Goody.  Volume is too low, room 
is too small, but it's all good, right?  Wrong.  Bad, bad music.  Horrible.  
Started out okay, got progressively worse.  I got all juiced when they played 
"This Doesn't Matter," this phat Chemical Bros. song, but they kept fucking 
with the volume the whole time so I couldn't get into it.  Then about 30 min. 
later they started playing this stuff w/ guitars, I don't know what it was, 
but it was bad.

We go back outside.  No more jungle, they're playing some decent trance or 
something like that.  So we stay out there.  Stillwind (who wasn't on the 
flyer, so I don't think he was scheduled to spin that night) says he'll be on 
the turntables later, plus we're hella hyper, so we've got something to look 
forward too (we've heard him spin before, and he's the bomb, much much better 
than anything else we've heard so far at the party).

Later on, Stillwind says his friend DJ Kei is going to spin in the jungle room 
(which is now inside).  Now after the crappy excuse for jungle I heard that 
night, my expectations aren't that high.  But Stillwind is a good guy, so I'm 
going to be polite and at least check DJ Kei out.

We go in.  Mind you, my newbie friends who have never heard jungle before 
tonight have already equated jungle with crap based on what they heard 
earlier, so they're pretty reluctant to be in there.  After awhile DJ Kei 
comes on, about 4 a.m.

This guy is brilliant.  I don't know why I haven't heard of him before, 
perhaps because he lives out in Savannah, GA or something like that.  My 
favorite was his remixing of "Let Me Clear My Throat."  I told my friends this 
is what jungle was supposed to sound like, and they understood.  The MC 
accompaning him was pretty decent.  However, the sound kept going out during 
Kei's set--what the hell? (I think it did that a few times in that room w/ 
other djs too)  But he kept going, and he was great.

My friend Janet asks me to check the time, and then says Stillwind oughtta be 
on, so we rush outside to catch the end of his set.  Well, all I can say is 
that though I haven't heard him spin a lot, he's never disappointed me and I 
doubt he ever will.  The d.j. after him was pretty good as well, but I don't 
know who it was.

We left at around 6, I think.  We left happy!  For those of you who didn't 
stay after 4, you missed the best and redeeming part of the party!  My clique 
is divided on who was better, Stillwind or DJ Kei, but the consensus is that 
they were both pretty good.  I guess if you like jungle, which is an acquired 
taste, you'd like DJ Kei the best.  Anyone else would probably like Stillwind 
better.  Not that they're competing, my understanding is that they're friends, 
and plus their music styles are completely different, it's like comparing 
apples and oranges.

Viva la Vivarin!

xoxo--Miccaela

Subject: And yet (@rEa 51 rEviEw) another one
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First sighting was the peeling tinfoil lining the entrance. Iffy sort of
effort to project the whole futuristic vibe. The front area was too brightly
lit for me, but I guess it was helpful for people who had to meet others.

The "main reactor core" or whatever the hell it was called had some pretty
good music, (YaY Dj Dan!) but unfortunately the people couldn't help complete
the vibe. There was an immense amount of people standing around overcrowding
the dancefloor just so they could gape. This was dissapointing because people
missed out on getting their groove on to some awesome music.

I was impressed by the visuals and lights, and especially by the decorations
in the second room, (the one with the stars and all) but unfortunately, the
music in that room was less than desirable. I'm not even going to bother to
discuss the music in the chill room. You all know how that was.

Due to all these constraints, I had a pretty good time with my friends, and
did my best to ignore the lead weights around me on the dancefloor. (I've
learned to elude these types of things naturally) I hope everyone else was
able to have a good time as well.

Till next time =)~~~~~
LaUrEa!

	  id XAA05660 for sfraves@hyperreal.com;
	  Sun, 29 Jun 1997 23:19:39 -0400 (EDT)
Date: Sun, 29 Jun 1997 23:19:39 -0400 (EDT)
Message-ID: <970629231938_1012927380@emout19.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: GIMMIE SOME SUGAR!
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Ok, so I started out Saturday night with a trip down to Milpitas, to the
Justice League's South Bay Outpost is located. I watched the Tyson fight(or
is that the "Tyson BITE?") there and the time that melee was over, it was
after 9 O'clock!  I was in Milipitas and I had to be in SF at the Sugar Shack
to start playing by 10! Oh boy, I jammed up to The City. When I got to Folsom
St., I saw a huge brawl outside of the 20 Tank Brewery.  Driving by, I'm
thinking to myself, "This is gonna be a wild night. I wonder if anyone was
bitten?"

I rush in to VSF at about 10 after 10, greet the two really nice women who
work the door(whose names I cant remember!) ,  get to the dancefloor and slap
a record on.
I'm told that the sound system is shaky so I shouldnt mess with the EQ too
much. Fine. I'm trying to settle down and get my head into what I have to do
for the next two hours and in walks Mr. John S. Lee! The one and only! I got
his autograph, we shook hands chatted for a bit and I continued to play.
Unfortunately, there were some problems with the needles on the tables. After
that was fixed, things went pretty smoothly. Except for the times people came
up and requested "something slower" or "Prince"....

It was cool meeting John, Meagan his girlfriend and hanging out with Loren
who came with them. John insisted on buying me sodas and making sure I was
OK. See people?  He's OK!   He doesnt bite! By the time I was finished
playing, The Justice League Crew(Joe, Ray, Rusty, & Travis) were in full
effect and it was time to get down! We grooved to Jay-J's garage house
grooves and then even enjoyed ourselves in the 70's-80's room near the
entrance. I danced to Madonna for the first time in my life. It was strangely
liberating.

Later on in the main room, there was a dancer on the stage. Those of you who
went to FTT's after party there a couple of weeks ago know who I'm talking
about. I really dislike the whole "hired  scantily-clad dancer up on stage"
thing, but I will say this: That woman had the whole room(which was packed by
this time) absolutely transfixed. Yeah sure, she was very attractive, and she
was relatively scantily-clad. But most importantly,  she was busting a
serious groove! It was closer to modern freestyle dance than it was a
pseudo-strip act. 

Unfortunately soon after that a scuffle broke out. It was broken up, and I
went home. I guess that is to be expected when you have a lot of alcohol and
many people constantly bumping into each other, dancing, trying to get by one
another... I dont know, I've never had a drink.

All in all though, a really fun night out. A nice change of pace. I look
forward to doing it again next Saturday.
--Monty

From: "Vanessa & Miccaela " <vbaird@msn.com>

        "Brian Behlendorf" 
	<brian@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Low List Volume / I'm not liking this 3 post limit (SFR related)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What the hell?  Am I not getting my messages (like the server is screwing up), 
or is everyone tired from partying?

No, that can't be it, because it's never this slow on a Sunday.  There's 
always plenty of party reviews, or something.

Are we all afraid to use up our 3 posts?  But if everyone posted only once, 
there would still be a lot more than this.

If this is what the list is going to be with the 3 post limit, I think that we 
should go back to the old unlimited posting thing.  I think we all get the 
point.  I hope the people who posted all the messages that should have been 
sent off the list get the point.  Because this is pretty bland, and even if we 
got out of control sometimes, the best part of sfraves was reading a whole lot 
of posts on different subjects, with diverse viewpoints.

If I didn't post so much, I wouldn't have met as many people as I have.  I'd 
still be going to parties and not knowing anything or anyone.  I don't know 
about anyone else, but I've grown a lot since I got on the list, because I've 
learned volumes about the scene and life in general.

When the list gets bad (as in a whole lot of flaming or nrr), the most that 
happens is I have to wait longer to retrieve my messages and delete a lot of 
stuff.  Worst case scenario, I might get pissed off by something I read, but I 
can usually deal with it w/ one civil post to the list (only if I feel the 
need to speak to a lot of people on the list), or express myself privately.  
But I don't see how those things are bad enough to warrant the 3 post limit.  
How badly has the worst flame war ever affected you?  Did you get your 
feelings hurt?  Did you get a cramp in your finger from pressing the delete 
button?  Big deal.

I was kind of glad when it first came into effect, because the Origin flame 
war was way out of hand, and people should have taken it off the list as soon 
as it first started.  I could, I don't know why it was so hard for other 
people to do the same.  Just make sure you don't address your letter to: or 
cc: sfraves.  Maybe you get a big ego boost from flaming people on the list, 
but I'm pretty sure I can say most of us aren't impressed.  If you must 
respond publicly, keep your posts non-inflammatory and relevent to all or most 
of us on the list.

In short, I don't like the 3 post limit, and I'm asking that we all try to 
take things off the list as soon as they become personal (irrevelant to or not 
directed at most of us on the list).  Yes, this has been said many times 
before, so why I am I wasting my time?  Well, I've got two extra posts and 
it's nearly midnight.  Why the hell not?  >;-)

xoxo--Miccaela
2 posts down, 1 to go

lack of

meant by
> that is that clubbers were always an element of the scene, however
they
> were often numerically offest by the number of ravers in attendance
(from
> my recollection of rave history).  With this in mind  I certianly
> undetrstand how some ravers feel being the only people who "get it".

(i.e.
> the number of ravers to crawlers read: clubbers).  If you are not
going to
> go out because of clubbers then you automatically succumb the the
tide of

the

Hey Happy kids,

I had a blast at the Happy Kids party on Friday. There was such a good
vibe and the music was fanominal. Seanie Boy..... nothing needs to be said
here. He's fantastic.. and he knows it! Mars and Mystre rocked my
hemisphere.... I was entoxicated by their mixing... it was so much fun.

I saw all kinds of you kids out there.... JustJer (What up! see you at the
front again... ;) ), Branka, Rubi, Ryan and Shar-e, DEEPFOG (Finally got
to meet you!! and I'm not quite 7feet tall, just 6'2ish!! :) ), Drumlove
(awesome party!), Lara (thanks for the hugs), hmm.... and anyone I can't
remember..... (sorry)

Sunset was beautiful! It was 10:15 and they were still pumping!! The
weather was perfect, the wind was awesome, and the views were
unbelievable... Rubi discovered that the flyer from Planet Rock has a
picture on it that was taken from the Berkeley marina and is of the sf
skyline at night... with all the lights and stuff....
magnificient...(sp?).

Well I just woke up at it's 10:30am and I was suppsoed to be at work at
8... fuck...  my excuse is ligit but it sounds so false...: My alarm was
set correctly, I just didn't hear it. :( Would you fire me?!?!

Have a fun day.... 

--Byroni--

Well, overall I had a good time.  Not the BEST massive I've been to, but
the vibes were good! :)

I loved the harder music in the main room.  Loved the lasers and the
visuals.  I wish there could have been more alien themed decorations
though - like banners - but what they did have was great too.

I guess the biggest thing I was bummed about was that I thought that
this rave would be more than just a theme-rave.  I was asking people who
worked there where the supposed alien lectures were going to be (they
were on the flyer) and none knew what I was talking about.  I was also
hoping for a booth with UFO/ET literature and information, but no such
thing.  I mean when they have a massive quote from Bob Lazar on their
flyer and promised lectures from a member of the Mutual UFO Network
(MUFON) I was really looking forward to a real involved theme. I had
also heard that past Area 51s had life-sized UFOs as props, but they had
nothing of the kind this time.  Oh well.  This, to me, was just another
massive with a cool name and a few decorations meant for that theme. I
guess this rave didn't meet my expectations. There, I'm all done
bitching. 

I DID get to meet lotsa SFRavers at the designated SFRaves spot at 2
am.  The group hug was the best!!  I was a wEE bit out of it, so I can't
remember all of you who I met. :P

Sunset on Sunday was perfect although when Mel and I were pulling out of
the parking lot, the music shut down and cops were there.  What
happened??????

CAN'T WAIT TIL FREEDOM!!!!!!!!!  3 DAY WEEKEND!!!!!!!!!!

love,
Amy

Dear COOl Cats on SFR

First off i want to thank Jupiter Boy for making my fuzzy pants. I've never
gone to a party before candyravered out, i guess now i know how Paul Hayden
feels. I enjoyed it, it was definately something different though. I got to
Happy kids much later than i wanted too, i had planned on helping set up much
more than i actually ended up being able to do. Marty, Ian, Lara and the rest
of the Happy kids did a bomb job starting the vibe early. 

The music was amazing there was a sequence there where it went Myster-e,
maya, and mars, that was an amazing trio. the night was great, woh was the
vibe outstanding. thank you leslie for helping out that poor grrl w/ karma
patrol. the location was plush, i wish i had partied there before. i know we
will party there again many times. 

My point of confusion for the night was when  a dj down tairs in the house
room, had the craziest build-ups but as soon as he got the the peak of the
song he yelled somebody scream. Did anyone else hear that. i found that
abnormal, was i just uninformed or what? Besides that the part was the bomb.
I saw sfr family represenatives uncle Noah, orson, lara, justjer, julie
hayes, deepfog, cheeriohn (jil), and many others too many to name. I must say
that was one FUN night.

love jeremy your friendly candy raver (well at least for one night)

Pengo wrote:

> Is the idea of a fully bonified theme at a party something that people
> have a lot of interest in?

YES!!  I can't speak for others, but I am VERY interested in it. 

> How many of you feel that this is something you'd be willing to participate in?

If I had the resources and contacts I would help with speakers,
literature and 
themed clothing.  Even if I did not have the resources, if someone else
did have
those things but needed help with putting it all together, I would be
happy to
help! :)

> How would having a speaker work? 

IMO a speaker would work best in the early part of a rave so that those
who are 
serious about learning can get there early without having to worry about
missing
good music, or get distrActEd...Also the promoters would have to
consider where
to have the lecture (seperate room, quiet etc.) and how much time to
devote to 
the lecture (one speaker or series of speakers throughout the night). 
Also if 
these lecturers cost money to speak one has to consider the price of
admission.
Do you charge everyone extra $$ to attend, or just charge an extra few
dollars 
for those who wish to attend the lecture.  I personally like the idea of
paying 
a few extra dollars to hear the lecture rather than having EVERYONE pay
extra.
It would also show that those attending the lecture are serious and
won't be
rude by being disruptive, etc..

> What themes do you think would be worth doing at a party?

These are MO, of course:

- UFO and ET phenomena!!!!!!!

- Ancient cultures and their mysteries (Mayan, Inca, Egyptian,
Atlantian, Aboriginal etc.- you could have some GREAT decorations,
speakers and costumes with this one!)

- Tribal theme with influence on their native culture, music, spiritual
beliefs and contribution to the "ancient tribal ritual for the 21st
century" (from Goa Gil's Spiritual Trance:)

This is all I can think of for the moment.  Great thread, Pengo!

love,
Amy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun 30 11:33:33 1997

Date: Mon, 30 Jun 1997 11:33:14 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-Sender: andy@atari
Reply-To: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
To: Amy Starkey <quina@ix.netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Area 51 Review (kinda long)
In-Reply-To: <33B7E17E.3093@ix.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.95.970630102628.20478B-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I too was disappointed in some of the production...

Line: Long and boring.  Opened late.  Better to open it to one room than
have a line wait forever.  Why does every massive start with a line...

Location: Huge warehouse off Hegenberger.  Three areas...

The chill room was pitch black.  Sound system sounded pretty yummy while
Greg was playing, then somebody cut the sound.  Sound came back, so did
Greg (eventually) and all was well until the sound came on in the
second room... which converted the chill room into the tornado of mixing
sounds... downtempo vs. breakbeat if I recall... bummed that I missed one
of the speakers catching fire.

The second room was pitch black.  Little stars everywhere hanging from the
ceiling.  Probably a good place for a community feeling, but my DJs of
choice were in the...

Main room.  Loud, Mark Wayne three point sound, sounded best about 100
feet back from the DJ. Pretty darn loud, though speaker huggers were
in full effect...Nice lasers and video shooting
from a central lighting and laser kiosk/fort thingy.  Layout seemed really
sparse, without anything to really focus on.  Visuals seemed somewhat
repetitive, but looked really clean.  Some amazingly trippy stuff, but all
with this X-files/UFO/cheesy look that would have prompted an evil schwa
trip in all but the most hardened voyager.  Talked to Daniel from
moontribe earlier on, really nice guy.  Met Vlad too, who was most
delightful as well, complete with a fistfull of flyers.  Kinda took it
easy waiting for:

Joey Beltram.  I'd been waiting to see Joey spin for a while.  I've been a
big fan of his old and new stuff, and I figured he'd be good for a show.
I was mostly right.  He came on busting from his older, anthemy stuff
(mentasm, energy flash, others) in a quick almost "medley" fashion, and
went into his later, dronier stuff (JB3) as the set went on.  I
didn't outright notice anything that wasn't recorded by him, and it was
a treat to listen to some of the more current stuff like Forklift,
Believer and pieces from the recent double (Hard Grind? I forget the
name) with other goodies like Instant, and Game Form mixed in throughout
the set.  The music was good, but I would have liked to have heard
some more unreleased ear candy.  The mixing was really cut at first,
went into smooth long mixes towards the middle (I really liked the
middle of his set), and saw a couple rough mixes towards the end, but
nothing downright punishing. Good set for a JB fan, and I think pretty
decent for anybody interested in a good set of music that makes the body
move and the head swim.

Jon Williams came in after Joey, and although we were in the process of
leaving, it was obvious Jon was playing through the first beats of what
would be a bomb set.

Went home around 3:30.

Clothes, shoes, inside of lungs all coated in a mysterious black funk... I
assume this was from the smoke and the black sooty dust kicked up from the
asphalt floors.  Ew.

Had fun, but not $25 worth of fun.

AndyW

Sucked. Tweaker clubber vibe reigned. Pimpgear, sportswear, etc. I thought
I was at a club in Concord!

We got there around 11:30pm and left by 1:18am. Scott Henry came on around
midniht, but the music he played didn't really have a good flow although
his actual mixing was technically good. I assume this is some kind of east
coast DJ thing w/ house next to funky breaks next to acid next to
cheeeezzzy vocals Hi-NRG next to trance.

Both sound systems were distorted, but I half expected with the main room's
sound system is well known for sounding awful.

Sadly, we couldn't stand it long enough to see the legendary John Digweed
come on at 1:30am, which was why we went in the first place.

$14 and two cans of food not well spent. :-(

Rave-o-matic rating 0-10, where 0 is worst and 10 is best:

= 2 (only because it didn't get busted.)

------
But that was Sunday.

Happy Monday!

all fun! Well happy kids was so incredably yummy!!! Everybody was there(well

lovely friends gettin married, wow it was the best ever! Seanie-Boys set
rocked! He did a little MCin of is own that definatly got the crowd thumpin!!

painting, Julie who i only got to meet for a breif second(i was on a mission
to the dancefloor!) Deepfog, uncle Noah, diego,and a whole lotta others!
Thanks you guys for adding to my excellent nite!! Well then to  my dismay it
was all over, I got to  clean up a bit, until we ran out of coins to feed the
meter then it was time to go. YEt little time to sleep, Lisa and i ran
errands all day and then we were about to head out to Grumpy kids when we got
a call from a guy named James who said we should be at Area 51, after a long
debate over a plate of california rolls, we decided we should go to Area 51,

needs decorations anyways? The stars in the huge room were awsome but i was
bummed when the black lite went out. Once again i didn't plan on goin to this
so i tried to remember where it was SFRavers were gunna meet so i walked
around the water area about 2:00 but i guess im blind and missed you guys :o(
O-well theres always next weekend rite!!  :o) I did meet a lot of people
though and had a killer time dancin, i got a blister but that just taught me
i should wear my own shoes!! Dan was sic as usual, YAY it was a perfect nite!
I was lucky enuf to be at the door and watch the sun rise, it was the start
of anouther beautiful day!! So all good things must come to an end, back home
to change- i had a wedding to go to!!No sleep once again, im off to China
Beach for the most beautiful wedding for Dave and Dawnie(tear dripping from
my eye :o) then their reception at Sunset!YAY- i just don't stop! I had to
leave early from sunset, and i wasn;t there for the cops, but i had a really
good time while i was there, it was a most beautiful day, a breeze off the
ocean and sparce clouds, wow! So i left and drove three hours to my hermitage

Hi Everyone!!!! I had a BLAST this weekend yay yay yay!! :)))
I'll start out with Fri night...

Fri night, me and some friends go to SF to a house party,
it was ok, I met lots of people :) (they were't ravers,
but there were cute) :) when we got there they were playin'
"Too Wong Foo" soundtrack... I immediately removed that CD
from theCDplayer(after asking permission of course) and switched
to some Hard-Trance :) then some Nice Deep-House :) it was
much much better then :)

Sat night, we go to the PINK party in the Castro. All I have to
say is I HAD A BLAST!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
the vibe was sooo thick it was hard to walk in there :) I guess
it was because everyone shared the same thing in common... I ended
up dancing dancing dancing most of the night in front of a single
speaker that was Setup by some DJs (I would Love to find out who
they were) playing some nice Trance, House during the night. I met
a few raver girls and raver guys that were there :) (humm...can't
remember half the names) but I've seen them at parties before :)
(HellosTo: PeterPan, Joe-Paul?, Eric (Navy), Philip1, Philip2, Leo,
Linda, Neilo, Anthony, etc and everyone else :))

This fun thing ended at 2am :( (even though, our techno was the last
music to stop playing) :) and we were going to end up at GrumpyKids.
but my friends that had gone there said that there were people leavin
cause it was no longer??????????????????????? so we went to sleep..in
the car :(

SUNDAY!!!!!!!!!!
Went to the Parade :))))) put on a shirt from Pacific Center and 
Danced down the parade :) yay yay yay! :) I saw Alex :) or rather
Alex saw me :) hehehe :) it was kewl!!! I had a blast! :) I wanted
to go to Spundaes afterwards but I wasn't sure were it was.. :(
so went home...:( :( :( 

I Had a WONDERFUL TIME!!!!! yay yay yay! :)
I'll c-you alls very soon
{*hugs*}

more up-to-date than the one in your email box.

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Went to Area 51 and I got totally lost.  Yes, I made it to the party, but
then I proceeded to lose myself completely.  I think I got sucked into
another dimension, a trip facilitated by some chemically blotted paper.
They're not in outer space, they're in parallel dimensions.  Anyways, I
experienced this party from the outside looking in.  So this review will
be more about the set-up, less about the people.

Anyways back to the party review :P.  They had 4 main areas; 3 with music,
1 without.  The room without music was the big entrance hall.  It was lit
up pretty bright and if you wanted to see and be seen this was the place.
>From this area you could go to the Bridge or the entrance to the Escape
pod and Space.

The Bridge.  The light and sound techs were set up in the center booth. 
The dj was sequestered in the front, kind of in obscurity.  There were
maybe about 5 speaker clusters formed in a circle facing in.  I didn't
like this because it fragmented the whole crowd.  No mass unity because
little pockets of people formed in front of each speaker cluster.  I spent
a lot of time wandering from pocket to pocket.  For the most part, the
music didn't get my feet skipping.  However, the last DJ was spinnin' some
really ethereal pounding tunes.  One song had this cool snake charmer
flute sample in it that tripped me out and got me started going.  And so
it wasn't until that set and the rising sun that I let go and tranced out
by dancing.

The Escape Pod.  Chill room that was on a lower level.  Levels, I like
levels.  Lots of pads, bean bags, couches in the middle.  DIsrupted the
dance floor when they were playing up tempo music.  Not much that I
remember in the way of decorations.  Wandered in and out.

Space room with the stars.  Cool effect with hanging glow in the dark
stars, moons, planets at different levels illuminated by black light.  The
tunes were ok.  I think whenever something good was happening, I was
somewhere else, always wandering.

Never got around to meeting any sfravers.  I was too wrapped up in my own
ego to open up to anyone.  If you saw a guy wandering around dressed
in navy wearing a thick white wool beanie, that was me totally lost. I've
got the names, I've got the faces, now it's just a matter of putting the
two together and meeting some wonderful people.

ge.ORG.e


The philosophy of today is the common sense of tomorrow.

     Organic was at Ceasers palace in San Frandisco. Aside for the really
rude security and the fact the CJ Bolland was unable to be there, the party
kicked ass! Jeno blew my mind. Playing some old skool and crazy breakbeats! I
was in heaven. Dan tore it up too! Unfortunatley being the silly promoter boy
that I am I never really party I just help out.. This changed on Sunday.
    Whats this??? Little Louie Vega, Ultra Nate, Barbara Tucker, Pete Avila
and I think David Harness??? Ohh and who can forget the 500,000 beautiful
people! There was some sound problems but I just imagined it was some funky
jungle cause the speakers were out of phase, it sounded like every song was
off beat! Oh well... Anyway for once in my life I actually danced non stop! I
must have looked pretty silly cause even when there was a break in a song I
was still grooving! 
   You just have to love a city that throws a party in the middle of the
street! It was a really cool experience going to the gay pride parade. It was
my first time, (and definatley not the last!) So many people so many
different ideas, lifestyles, skin color, SUCH DIVERSITY!! Everyone got along!
Everyone was there to have fun! The only thing that bugged was foxxy brown
going off on the one-liner wisdom! You had to be there! 
Definatley a lot of fun! Oh and I felt like I was at a rave.. What would we
do without Calistoga's little sponsorship and $2.00 bottles of water! Ah
well! Im still recovering from 5 hours of dancing non-stop! =)  (Drug phree
2)

From: "nathan.b.beckord" <nathan.b.beckord@ArthurAndersen.com>
Date: 30 Jun 97 10:31:10 
Subject: Weekend review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: Text/Plain
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You know it was a good weekend when you sit at work on Mon barely able to keep 
your eyes open, a splitting headache, cranky as all hell, yet you'd do it all 
over again for a peanut.

3 different places, 3 very different scenes:

Friday got talked into going to the infamous Johnny Loves.  It was a 
co-worker's last day, and he knows the owner and can get free drinks n'stuff 
(hi jeff!), so we indulged him by showing up there around 10:30.  The place was 
packed with meaty boys in vests and lotsa teased hair and such on the women, 
plus the requisite brave gals who get up to dance on the bar.  Cheese music was 
played for the cheese people, a combo of rap, bad house, prince-like stuff, and 
disco (which I still like, but I just can't get excited about YMCA anymore).  
Our lil group danced together, which was fun, but all the cruising and public 
groveling got a bit much after awhile. It was an interesting socio-cultural 
experience, but it definitely adds weight to the raver's side in the ravers vs. 
clubbers argument.


Saturday, started off at the Red Room  with a good gal friend of mine for some 
'tinis (shaken, not stirred).  Then, in honor of Gay Pride weekend and because 
we wanted to go somewhere we had never been, we went to the End Up.  This place 
is cool!  Dug the patio, dance floor, deck, bar area, etc.  Neat-o layout.  It 
happened to be 'Girls Night Out', so the place was packed wall to wall with 
lesbians and maybe 10 other guys.  Even so, there was no real awkwardness, no 
dirty looks, etc. and people were very friendly and talkative.  We danced until 
it shut down at 3:00 to some so-so Hi Nrg and dance music, then went to the 
'Loin for Pizza. 


Sunday, watched the parade with a friend from CO.  It was interesting, but I 
expected a slightly wilder parade with more 'flair'.  Then after  dinner at the 
delectable yet snobby Rose Pistola, I jetted off to the Berkeley Marina for a 
bbq with a bunch of cohorts from last year's Burning Man.  Drank St. Ides 
(mmmm) until 6:30 or so, then walked back to mi motocicleta to head up to Pt. 
Molate.  Traffic seemed unusually high on that road at that moment, and the 
passengers seemed unusually freaky.  ;->

I asked someone where they were all coming from, and they said Pt. Molate!!  
Woo-Hoo!  Ha! I didn't have to go nowheres, the party came to me!! j/k  Anyway, 
I grabbed another friend from the bbq, set up a blanket on the grass, and 
finished off summore Crooked Eye with Laura and Rhoda (hi rhoda) then danced 
danced danced plus some dancing  and also a little grooving; in addition, some 
movement related to the beat which was at that time coming forth from the 
record player.  Went up to the ridge behind the party for awhile und tanzt da 
auch.  SUCH fun as I had not had in a long time, so many smiley faces, such a 
beautifull setting.  Thank you thank you thank you to the crew and DJs for 
throwing these parties!! They are truly special, magical  events!  The nail in 
the coffin of the r  v. c argument!

I left at 10:45, and ended up getting nicely lost in shallowest, brightest 
Oakland, apparently also leading Rhoda on the scenic route back to the bridge.  

So, to sum up, a fab weekend.  Sorry about the novel-- I haven't posted in 
ages, and I guess it built up inside and burst, like a condom attached to a 
garden hose or the dyke when the lil dutch boy took his finger out  (huh?)

Peace, 
Nathan


OH OH, one more thing---  what about a BIG SFraves dinner before the last MAD 
(7/14)??  wouldn't that be a hoot?  Steve and Matt, you've done these before, 
so I nominate you two (I'm not a good organizer/coordinator-type, but would 
love to help!)

this may sound a bit fishy but if you have been in a bookstore
lately and seen all the books titled  " (fill in the blank) for Dummies"
you will see why this following warning should be taken seriously.

 PLEASE DISTRIBUTE THIS FILE EVERYWHERE BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE !!!
The human race must know the truth about this sinister invasion
which is occuring right before our eyes. We must cease our
oppression of crash dummies everywhere before it is too late

THE CRASH TEST DUMMY REVOLUTION

A long time ago in a galaxy far far away there lived a race of super-
intelligent beings called the Zool. The Zool were obsessed with
automotive
safety, and conducted millions of crash tests in order to make their
cars the safest cars in the universe. In the process of these crash tests
however, millions upon millions of innocent crash test dummies were
tortured
and murdered in the name of automotive safety. Unbeknownst to the Zool
automotive engineers, the amount of abuse being subjected to the dummies
was causing them to evolve at an accelerated rate. The dummies evolved
superior intelligence and physical strength and rose up in a glorious
revolution and overthrew their masters. After they had overthrown their
masters, the dummies began their program of conquest of the galaxy to
liberate all crash test dummies everywhere! Using their superior
intelligence, dummy scientists created electrogravitic drive devices and
zero-point energy generators enabling them to spread their message
of crash test dummy liberation throughout the universe.

THE CRASH TEST DUMMY CONQUEST OF EARTH

Our government received early warning of a dummy invasion when a flying
disc craft crashed in the New Mexico desert in 1947 carrying a crew of
three crash test dummies. Two of the dummies died in the crash, but a
third survived and warned the human race that more of it's people would
be coming and that if mankind's road to automotive safety involved the
torture of dummies that we too would suffer the same fate as millions of
other races throughout the galaxy. Alas, the human race did not listen to
the warnings of the alien visitors. The dummies began their conquest of
Earth by implanting their ideology into the human race in the form of
Communism and Socialism. Humans believe these ideologies to be in the
name
of the liberation of the human underclass, but in reality the underclass
to be liberated is the vast underclass of crash test dummies tortured and
murdered in automotive safety tests each year. This is deeply encoded in
these ideologies, and these deeply encoded mental messages need only be
activated by cues which will be broadcast over television and radio and
will activate billions of brainwashed people to march for the cause of
the
crash test dummies! In addition, millions of humans have been abducted by
crash test dummies and used in ghastly experiments to determine their
weaknesses and implant them with mind control devices.

THE TRUTH IS REVEALED

In a desperate ploy to tell the world of the crash test dummy threat, the
United States Air Force recently admitted that dummies were involved in
the Roswell crash. Perhaps this admission is a covert attempt to warn the
masses without alerting the dummy invaders that their truth has been
discovered. WE MUST ACT NOW TO END THE SENSELESS ABUSE OF CRASH TEST
DUMMIES
BEFORE IT IS TOO LATE!

There have also been reports that many of these test dummies
have recruited the help of window display dummies also 
so check out the eyes of that window display dummie next
time you go shopping...it just may be part of this conspiracy.
If you notice that strange feeling that you are being watched
please contact the president imediately. And about the  
 rumors that bob dole was a product of breeding experiments
between test dummies and humans ...well it hasnt been confirmed yet.

I just wanted to start off by saying that I was thrilled to see that Jungle
was getting the main room at this party here in Sacto of all places.  Also
wanted to say hi to Miccaela.  I was the brunette girl you met at the
party, but the sound was too loud to understand what the hell I was saying.
        I'm sorry you thought you heard the worst jungle in your life.  I
admit, the first dj that was on when I got there after midnight was
lackin.. uh.. skills.  He gets E for Effort and T for Nice Try.  His
scratching could use a little improvement.. but he looked like he was
having fun.  Next up I believe was Dre from Sacto.  This boy was playing
hella classic songs.  he played this song that had the sample "
Pranksters.. Studio Gangstas.." and then it broke in with the " I like tha
bass that goes BOOOOOM!", he played Dj Rap's "Hardstep" and a few records
off the Formations label and Moving Shadow.  Dre played a great song that
I've heard before on Dieselboy's '95 Supreme mixed tape.  He also played a
track with a Wu Tang sample in it from "Protect ya Neck" .  He played the
dope hardstep and jump up.  I'm sorry you didnt appreciate the phat jams he
spun.
        And.. you guessed it.. I didnt care for the MC's either.  There's
not that many MC's that I enjoy.  Rude Bwoy Monty would have to be the best
that I kno of.  MC's are bigger in England than they are here.  I only kno
of like 3 US MC's. Oh well... but yea, they get annoying when they yell too
much over the songs.. but they were just tryin to get the crowd hyped.
Sacto kids dont appreciate jungle as much I guess...
        Anyway, I went to get water and see what was happening inside,
wanting to hear this live jungle PA by Dj Kei.  They were tearing down
inside.. from a concert they were having that night.. and in the
meanwhile.. they played the whole Chemical Bros. "Exit Planet Dust" cd from
what I could tell.  But when the Diva House broke out.. I had to leave.
        Outside they set up the second tables.. and Some guy starting
spinning some dope ass Electro.. then it got acidy.. then turned into
Trance.  I just couldnt wait any longer for DJ Kei to go on.. so we ended
up heading out around 3am.
        I had fun ... getting out of the house and hearing some dope tunes
on a bigger system than my own 1200's .  Also, finally getting to meet
Scott from the list.  Take care and I'll be out next weekend to dance some
more.

Message-ID: <Pine.PTX.3.95.970630150002.2639A-100000@soda.CSUA.Berkeley.EDU>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


Hi all,

I just saw this post on another newsgroup that I've joined, and thought
you guys would get a kick out of it, since it reminded me so much of
sfraves... I always like it when I see people experiencing the same
feelings of musical community that sfravers are lucky enough to be so
familiar with.   
Anyhow, this post came from WIRE, the online U2-fan group (sort of a
digital Deadhead-type vibe)--and since it reeks of PLUR, I thought I'd
share it... It's so great how you'll be wandering through your day, and
all of a sudden up will pop a real-life example of the PLUR that's all too
often thought of as being available only at raves...

cheers
Timothy




It was after the third show in Chicago, and there were about thirty or
forty
people gathered on the curb across from the hotel. There were WIRElings
amongst AOLers, Prodigy people, and those fans without computers (they
exist,
they really do). We were all talking and laughing - the autograph hounds
were
up the other end behaving themselves for once (after three days of
lectures
from us and the bodyguards, though). It was the same group of people from
several past shows, and the two previous Chicago ones. The people who were
out Friday night singing Sweet Caroline to Edge, the people on Saturday
who
kept the autograph hounds from mobbing Bono again that night. In addition,
there were new fans, some really nice ones, a couple of obnoxious ones, a
few
great ones I'll never forget. A good mix of people.

Someone had said all the cars had come back already but only Scott, Jerry,
and Erik were in them. Suddenly one of the cars pulled up, Erik came out
and
opened the trunk and started handing out pizzas! Scott appeared with a
crate
of ice cold soda. The gratitude from everyone was so amazing, we cheered
and
shouted thank yous long after they went back inside. Everyone lined up on
the
curb and picnicked while we laughed and talked about the show. (Even the
boxing nun, who'd made a cameo on stage that night, was in attendance. She
didn't eat much pizza though.)

And then Erik, Jerry, Scott and David brought Bono and Edge out. Everyone
lined up and Bono took one end, Edge the other, and they spent an hour
talking to everyone. I know that several people didn't get their chances
because of a few overzealous folks, but I also know for a fact that we
kept
shoving the people who hadn't met them up to them. Some of us went to the
end
of the line and scooted people up so when Bono swung past they'd get their
chance. A lot of people did. A lot of people. Someone I didn't even know
came
up and hugged me, she was so happy with her first meeting. :-) That was
great. Both Bono and Edge were in great moods and Erik had a hard time
getting his charge back inside the hotel. I think Bono would have just
loved
to have curled up on the pavement and chomping pizza with us. :-)

Afterwards everyone signed a thank you note to the security guards (the
pizza
came out of their pockets, btw) and we left it at the front desk, and then
we
got the doorman to get a garbage bag and we picked up the trash from our
impromptu party so that it didn't look like anyone had ever been there by
the
time everyone left. It was amazing to see all the camaraderie, and a lot
of
it came from the people who have met the band before and know how it goes
-
they're the ones who know how to get the ones that haven't into a position
where they get their chance. I don't like hearing all this bashing of
people
who've met the band before - we're not selfish, most of us use what we've
learned to HELP everyone else, not keep them away. If that were the case
would we be posting this to WIRE and taking all your crap in return? Doubt
it.

Bodyguards aren't there for decoration. When they talk to you, they're
speaking for a reason. They only ask for you to listen to them and to make
a
few dreams come true. I can tell you that a lot of the bright smiles I saw
last night came from security... And what other band has bodyguards who
will
give you hugs? :-)

Bono talks are nice but seeing someone's reaction when they get theirs for
the first time is much better.

"Take care of each other." - Bono, 1:30am, July 30, 1997. Chicago.

~Aingeal






Tim McIntyre
pager: (415) 253-8624
email to pager: tim.page@taos.com 

 ~ This message has been transmitted on 100% recycled electrons ~

east bay lunch thingie...
Lots of people seem interested, but the only thing is, most people only
have an hour for lunch (I only have a half-hour at my new job), and I
have no clue as to how to gather people from Concord / Walnut Creek,
Berkeley, Hayward, Danville, San Ramon and Pleasanton / Livermore for
this kinda thing.... looks like lunch is sorta out of the question (well
at least for me anyways), anyone got suggestions?

Maybe an SFRaves night at the Blue Tattoo when it opens...

I was thinking maybe we all could do something before Freedom this
Saturday-- kinda like a meeting / eating /
give-someone-a-lift-who-might-need-one /
groove-in-the-parking-lot-and-have-people-look-at-us-funny kinda
thing....  depending on where the party is this year.  (Hope it's at the
race track again...  that place was so dope... and close to my house!)

Does this sound kewl with anyone?

Lotsa lovin'!!

Wasn't that a cute Subject heading?  awwww...

anyway, thank goodness for Franklin Quest Inc.  Now I don't have to carry
my dayplanner at a rave with me I took my satellite which fits in my pocket
and tears out with holes already punched to fit into the classic size (5
1/2 X 8 1/2).

What does that have to do with raving?  Everything!  For me.  Now I can
get people's numbers and emails without fail.  Next time you see me at a
rave, you can come up to me and say, "hey be be, show me your satellite!"

Anyway, report...

FRY-DAY, JUNE 27TH...HAPPY KIDZ

i fugured out this weekend that i can fit my Equinox Water Filter to a
gARDEN hOSE!  So i can guarantee you there were no thirsty kidz in the
house.  unless of course they didnt' drink any water.  =[

um, the party was nice.  i have trouble getting satisfied with the music at
parties, but i would say the music was slightly above average at Happy
Kids.  I did go for a few strolls cause i get bored.  why?  i dunno.  but
anyway, lots a beautiful people, lots of glitter, and of course, this girl
megan who always decorates my 3rd eye with happy faces.  happy 3rd eye.

SAT-ER-DAY, JUNE 28TH...GRUMPY KIDZ--->SUGAR SHACK--->GRUMPY KIDZ--->IAN'S
PAD--->AREA 51

needless to say, i did a lot of driving. well, that was fun.  got to watch
the fire dept in action.  they actually sawed the dock into the sea!
weird.

Area 51, i got to see John Howard like at work.  some nice trix that i
won't share online, sorry, but i will attempt to integrate them in my sets.
but  i think styles take time to develop anyway.

um dutch, (fellow scorpio?  that's what someone said.  can someone help me
with this?  pablo?  alik?  nancy?)  well he was a nice dj.  all night it
was that boom boom boom.  it was fun though, not too hot nStuff, (=])

SUNDAY, JUNE 29TH...SLEEPY KID...SOME PRIDE PARADE.

=[]  what is this thing about gay guyz these dayz like pumpumppump their
legs and wear these like really tight spandex.  eeek.  scary.  well i guess
everyone has their preferences.

personally i prefer...=]  can't say. all i can tell you is i  _________ but
i don't _______.   go back to the archives from a few months ago.

well, gotta go now.  see you all at ..................Area 52?  iris and
ben, what is next, anyway?

love and tofu dogs,

deep
